content: i) \[f^{2}\left ( 4 \right )\]	\[ =f\left ( f\left ( 4 \right ) \right )\];\[=\left ( \frac{\left ( 3\left ( 4 \right ) \right )}{\left ( 4+2 \right )} \right )\];;\[= f\left ( 2 \right )\];\[=\left ( \frac{\left ( 3\left ( 2 \right ) \right )}{\left ( 2+2 \right )} \right )\];\[= \frac{3}{2}\] (ANS);ii) Let \[y= \frac{\left ( 3x \right )}{\left ( x+2 \right )}\];\[xy+2y= 3x\];\[x\left ( y-3 \right )=-2y\] ;\[x=\frac{\left (2y  \right )}{\left (3-y  \right )}\];\[f^{ -1 }:x \mapsto \frac{\left ( 2x \right )}{\left ( 3-x \right )},x\neq 3 \](ANS);

Coordinates of M = $$\frac{(-1+3)}{2},\frac{(10+2)}{2}= (1,6)$$; AM = $$\sqrt{(5-1)^2+(8-6)^2}$$;= $$\sqrt{20}$$ (ANS);Gradient of AM = $$\frac{(8-6)}{(5-1)}= \frac{2}{4}= \frac{1}{2}$$;		       Gradient of AC = $$\frac{(10-2)}{(-1-3)} = \frac{8}{-4}= -2$$;since the products of the gradients is - 1, the lines are perpendicular,(shown);Area of triangle ABC = $$\frac{1}{2} (AM)(BC)$$  = $$\frac{1}{2} (\sqrt {20})(\sqrt{(-1-3)^2+(10-2)^2)}$$;= $$\frac{1}{2} (\sqrt {20})(\sqrt{80})$$;= $$\frac{1}{2} (\sqrt {1600})$$;= $$\frac{1}{2} (40)$$;= 20 (ANS)

$$(\cot A-\tan A)\cos A$$= $$(\frac{\cos A}{\sin A} - \frac{\sin A}{\cos A})\cos A$$;= $$\frac{(\cos ^2A)}{\sin A} - \sin A$$;= $$\frac{(1-\sin ^2A)}{(\sin A)}-\sin A$$;= $$\csc A - \sin A - \sin A$$;= $$\csc A - 2\sin A$$ (Proved)

i)	   $$\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x} = 3 + \frac{4}{x^{2}}$$ (Ans);	ii)	$$\frac{\delta y}{\delta x} \approx  \frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x}$$; $$\delta y \approx  \frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x} \delta x = (3+\frac{4}{x^{2}})\delta x$$;When $$x = 2$$ and $$\delta x = p$$,;$$\delta y \approx (3+\frac{4}{4})p = 4p$$

i)Triangle AOP is a right-angled triangle.;  $$\frac{AP}{OA} = \tan  0.4$$;  = $$10 \tan  0.4$$; = 4.228m;Perimeter of shaded region = arc AB + 2(AP);  = 10(0.8) + 2(4.228)m; = 16.5m ;ii)	Area of Triangle AOP = $$\frac{1}{2}(\frac{OA}{AP})$$  = $$\frac{1}{2} (10)(4.228)m^2$$;=$$21.14m^2$$ ;Area of shaded region = 2(area of triangle AOP) - area of sector AOB; = $$2(21.14) - 0.5(10)^2(0.8)$$;  = $$2.28m^2$$;

i)$$\vec{OC} = \vec{OB} + \vec{BC}$$  = $$b+\frac{1}{2}a$$;= $$\vec{OD} = p\vec{OC}$$= $$pb + \frac{(3p)}{2}a$$ ;ii) $$\vec{AB}= b-a$$;$$\vec{DB} = q\vec{AB}$$;  = $$qb - qa$$;$$\vec{OD} = \vec{OB} - \vec{DB}$$; = $$b - qb + qa$$; = $$(1 - q)b + qa$$ (Ans);From i) and ii):;$$pb + \frac{(3p)}{2}a  = (1-q)b + qa$$;$$p = 1 - q$$ (1);$$ \frac{(3p)}{2}a = q$$ (2);Solving (1) and (2) gives ;$$p = \frac{2}{5} and q = \frac{3}{5} $$

a)$$y = \frac{16}{x^{2}}+ \frac{x^{3}}{3}$$;$$y = \frac{16}{x^{2}}+ \frac{x^{3}}{3}$$;At the stationary point,; $$\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x} = 0$$;$$\frac{-32}{x^{3}}+ x^2 = 0$$;$$x^5 = 32$$;	$$x = 2$$;Therefore stationary value of $$y = \frac{16}{4}+ \frac{8}{3}= \frac{20}{3}$$ (ANS);$$ \frac{\mathrm{d}^{2}y}{\mathrm{d} x^{2}}= \frac{96}{x^4}+ 2x$$;When x = 2,; $$\frac{\mathrm{d}^{2}y}{\mathrm{d} x^{2}}> 0$$;Therefore the stationary value is a minimum.(Ans);b)   length of wire = 100;   RS + ST + TPQ + QR = 100; $$2x + y + \pi x + y = 100$$;$$y = 50-x-\frac{\pi x}{2}$$;   area, A = RSTQ + TPQ; = $$(2x)(y)+ \frac{1}{2}\pi x^2$$; = $$2x(50-x-(\frac{\pi x}{2})+\frac{1}{2}\pi x^2$$;= $$100x-2x^2-(\frac{\pi x}{2})/2$$ (SHOWN);$$ \frac{\mathrm{d} A}{\mathrm{d} x}= 100-4x-\pi x$$;At the maximum value,;                                   $$\frac{\mathrm{d} A}{\mathrm{d} x} = 0$$;$$100 - (4 + \pi )x = 0$$;$$x = 100/(4+\pi )$$;$$max A = 100(\frac{100}{(4+\pi )})-2(\frac{100}{(4+\pi )})^2-\pi /2(\frac{100}{(4+\pi )})^2$$;= ?700.124 \approx 700$$ (shown)

i)$$v = 6+pt-t^2$$ At A v = 0 and t = 6;Therefore $$0 = 6 + 6p -36$$; $$6p = 30$$; $$p = 5$$ ;ii) Displacement from O,; $$s=\int_0^6vdx$$;= $$s=\int_0^6(6 +5t-t^2)dx$$ = $$[6t+ \frac{(5t^{2})}{2}- \frac{t^{3}}{3}]_0^6$$	= 54 m;therefore OA = 54m ;

$$\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x} = \frac{3}{4}-kx$$;when x = -1, ; $$\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x} = \frac{3}{4}+k$$;when x = 1, $$\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x} = \frac{3}{4}-k$$;since the tangents are perpendicular,;$$( \frac{3}{4}+k)( \frac{3}{4}-k)=-1$$	;$$ \frac{9}{16}-k^2=-1$$;$$k^2 = \frac{25}{16}$$;$$k = \frac{5}{4}$$ ;	$$y=\int \frac{3}{4}- \frac{5}{4}xdx$$;= $$ \frac{3}{4}x- \frac{5}{8}x^2+c$$  ;Given that y = 0 when x = 4, we have;$$0 = \frac{3}{4} (4)- \frac{5}{8} (16)+c$$;$$c = 7$$;therefore, ; $$y= \frac{3}{4}x- \frac{5}{8}x^2+7$$

i) $$\vec{AB} = \vec{OB} - \vec{OA}$$;= $$(-6i - j) - (j)$$  =$$-6i - 2j$$;Given that $$\pi  + 2j$$ is perpendicular to $$\vec{AB}$$, we have $$(\pi +2j).(-6i - 2j)=0$$  ; $$-6p - 4 = 0$$;	   $$p= \frac{2}{3}$$ (Ans);img;ii) Angle OBA is the angle between the vectors $$\vec{OB}$$ and $$\vec{AB}$$;Therefore; $$\cos  \angle OAB = (\vec{OB}.\vec{AB})/(|\vec{OA}||\vec{AB}|)$$;	        = $$\frac{((-6i-j).(-6i-2j))}{(\sqrt{6^2+1^2}\sqrt{6^2+2^2})}$$; = $$\frac{38}{(\sqrt{37}\sqrt{40})}$$;= $$\frac{19}{\sqrt{370}}$$;$$\angle OBA = 8.97 ^{\circ} $$ (Ans);$$\vec{AC}=k\vec{AB}$$;$$\vec{OC}-\vec{OA}=k\vec{AB}$$;$$\vec{OC}-j=-6ki-2kj$$;$$\vec{OC}-j=-6ki+(1-2k)j$$;since $$\vec{OC}$$ is a unit vector,$$|\vec{OC}| = 1$$;$$(6k)^2 + (1 - 2k)^2 = 1$$;$$36k^2+1-4k+4k^2=1$$;$$40k^2-4k=0$$;$$4k(10k - 1)=0$$;$$k=\frac{1}{10}$$ (ANS);Therefore$$\vec{OC}=-\frac{6}{10}i + (1-\frac{2}{10})j$$;	         = $$\vec{OC}=-\frac{3}{5}i+\frac{4}{5}j$$(ANS)

Equation of BC: $$y = 3x - 3$$ (1); $$5y = x + 13$$ (2);Sub (1) into (2): $$5(3x - 3) =x + 13$$;$$15x - 15 = x + 13$$;$$14x = 28$$;$$x = 2$$;Sub into (1) ; $$y = 6 - 3$$ = 3; Therefore C(2, 3) ;Let the coordinates of A be (x, y).since M is the midpoint of AC, we have ;$$(5,5)= (\frac{(2+x)}{2},\frac{(3+y)}{2})$$;(x, y) = (8, 7);A(8, 7) (ANS); Gradient of AB = gradient of CDE; = $$\frac{1}{5}$$;Equation of AB:  ; $$\frac{(y-7)}{(x-8)} =\frac{1}{5}$$;$$5y - 35 =x - 8$$;$$5y = x + 27$$ (3);Equation of BC : $$y = 3x - 3$$ (1);Sub. (1) into (3): $$5(3x - 3) = x + 27$$;$$15x - 15 =x + 27$$;$$14x = 42$$;$$x = 3$$;Sub. into (1) $$y = 9 - 3$$;	 = 6;Therefore B(3, 6) (Ans);Let the coordinates of D be (x, y).since M is the midpoint of BD, we have;$$(5,5)=(\frac{(3+x)}{2},\frac{(6+y)}{2})$$;Therefore (x, y) =(7, 4); D(7, 4)(Ans)$$"gradient of AE = -1gradient of BC = \frac{-1}{3}$$;Equation of AE:; $$\frac{(y-7)}{(x-8)} =\frac{-1}{3}$$;$$3y - 21 = -x + 8$$;$$3y = -x + 29$$ (4);Equation of CDE : $$5y = x + 13$$ (2); (4) + (2);$$8y = 42$$;$$y = 2\frac{1}{4}$$;Sub. into (2) $$5(2\frac{1}{4})=x+13$$;$$x=5\frac{3}{4}$$Therefore $$E(5\frac{3}{4},2\frac{1}{4})$$ (Ans)

img;i) Consider $$4 = |5 - 3x| + 2$$;$$|5 - 3x| = 2$$;$$5-3x=\pm 2$$;Therefore $$x=1 or \frac{7}{3}$$;From the graph, $$y \leq 4$$ if $$1 \leq x \leq \frac{7}{3}$$(ANS); ii) Consider $$3 = |5 - 3x| + 2$$;$$|5 - 3x| = 1$$;$$5-3x = +- 1$$;$$x = \frac{4}{3} or 2$$;From the graph, $$y \leq 3$$ if $$\frac{4}{3} \leq x \leq 2$$ (ANS)

a)a = T1 = 7 and T2 =6.8;a + d = 6.8;7 + d =6.8 ;Therefore d = - 0.2;Sum of the first 50 terms = S50; = $$\frac{50}{2}(2(7)+49(-0.2))$$	= 105 (Ans).;b) Let Tn be the amount of grant paid in the nth year where 1995 is the 1st year. Then ; $$T_n = 10000(0.9)^{n-1}$$;i) For ;Tn < 2000;$$10000(0.9)^{n-1} < 2000$$;$$(0.9)^{n-1} < 0.2$$	;$$(n-1)\log0.9 <\log0.2$$;$$(n-1)< \frac{\log0.2}{\log0.9}$$;$$n > 16.3$$;The smallest n that satisfies the inequality is 17.;Hence the first year in which the grant falls below £2000 is 2011.(Ans);ii) Between 1995 and 2004(inclusive), there are 2004 - 1995 + 1 = 10 years;The total amount paid is a geometric series with first term 10000, common ratio 0.9 and number of terms 10.;Therefore total amount paid = £ $$\frac{(10000(1-0.9^{10}))}{(1-0.9)}$$=  £ 65132(Ans);iii) Between 2005 and 2014(inclusive), there are 2014 - 2005 + 1 = 10 years.;      Amount paid in 2005;    = Amount paid in the 11th year;    = T11;    = $$10000(0.9)^{10}$$;The total amount paid between 2005 and 2014(inclusive) is geometric series with first term $$10000(0.9)^{10}$$, common ratio 0.9 and number of terms 10.;Therefore amount paid = £ $$\frac{(10000(0.9)^{10}(1-0.9^{10}))}{(1-0.9)}$$; $$= \it\unicode{xA3}  22710 $$(Ans);     iv) The total amount paid after n years is given by;$$S_n =\frac{((10000)(1-0.9^n))}{(1-0.9)}$$;When Sn > 90000;$$\frac{((10000)(1-0.9^n))}{(1-0.9)}>90000$$;$$100000(1-0.9^n)>90000$$;$$(1-0.9^n)>0.9$$;$$0.9^n < 0.1$$;$$n\log0.9 < \log0.1$$;	$$n =\frac{\log 0.1}{\log 0.9}= 21.85$$Therefore by the 22nd year, the total amount paid will exceed $$\it\unicode{xA3} 90000$$ for the first time.(Ans)

a) The straight line equation connecting $$y^2$$ and $$\sqrt x$$ is given by: ;$$\frac{(y^2-16)}{(\sqrt x-10)} = 1.5$$;$$y^2 - 16 = 1.5\sqrt x - 15$$;$$y^2 =1.5\sqrt x + 1$$ (ANS);When y = 5,;$$25 = 1.5\sqrt x +1$$;$$\sqrt x = 16$$;x = 256 (Ans);img;b)i)$$y = px^2 + q\sqrt x$$;$$\frac{y}{\sqrt{x}} = px\sqrt x + q$$;Therefore p is the gradient and q is the vertical intercept of the straight - line graph.;$$p = \frac{(23-3)}{(10-0)}$$;     = 2.0 (Ans); q = 3.0 (Ans);ii) When $$2y = 43\sqrt x$$;ie. $$\frac{y}{\sqrt{x}} = 21.5$$,;the value of $$x\sqrt x$$ obtained from the graph is 9.2.;Therefore $$x\sqrt x = 9.2$$;$$x^{\frac{3}{2}} = 9.2$$;$$x = (9.2)^{\frac{3}{2}}$$; = 4.39(Ans)

a) i) $$\frac{\mathrm{d} }{\mathrm{d} x} \tan ^2x = 2\tan x \frac{\mathrm{d} }{\mathrm{d} x}(\tan x)$$; = $$2\tan x sec^2x$$ (Ans);ii) $$\frac{\mathrm{d} }{\mathrm{d} x}( \frac{x}{(x^2-3)}) = \frac{((x^2-3)(1)-x(2x))}{(x^2-3)^2}$$;= $$\frac{x^2-3-2x^2}{(x^2-3)^2}$$;= $$-\frac{(x^2+3)}{(x^2-3)^2}$$ (Ans);b) Given $$x^2+5y^2+2xy = 4$$ ;Differentiate w.r.t x,; $$2x + 5\frac{\mathrm{d} }{\mathrm{d} x} (y^2) + 2\frac{\mathrm{d} }{\mathrm{d} x} (xy) = 0$$;$$2x+5\frac{\mathrm{d}y }{\mathrm{d} x}\frac{\mathrm{d} }{\mathrm{d} y} (y^2)+2(x\frac{\mathrm{d}y }{\mathrm{d} x}+y)=0$$;$$2x+10y\frac{\mathrm{d}y }{\mathrm{d} x}+2x\frac{\mathrm{d}y }{\mathrm{d} x}+2y = 0$$;$$(10y+2x)\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x} = -(2x+2y)$$; $$\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x} = - \frac{(x+y)}{(x+5y)}$$; At (1, -1),;$$\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x}= -\frac{(1-1)}{(1-5)} =0$$;Therefore the tangent to the curve at (1, -1) is a horizontal line through the given point. Hence the equation of the tangent is y = -1(Ans);c) $$y=e^{3x}\cos x$$;$$\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x} = e^{3x} \frac{\mathrm{d} }{\mathrm{d} x} \cos x + \cos x\frac{\mathrm{d} }{\mathrm{d} x}(e^{3x}) $$;  = $$e^{3x}(-\sin x)+\cos x(3e^{3x})$$; = $$e^{3x}(3\cos x-\sin x)$$;At the stationary point $$\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x} = 0$$;Therefore $$e^{3x}(3\cos x-\sin x) = 0$$;$$3\cos x = \sin x$$;$$\tan x=3$$; $$x = 1.25$$ (Ans)

a) $$\frac{\cos (A-B)}{\cos (A+B)} = \frac{7}{3}$$;    $$\frac{\cos A\cos B + \sin A\sin B}{\cos A\cos B-\sin A\sin B} = \frac{7}{3}$$;    Divide the numerator and denominator by $$\cos A\cos B$$;$$\frac{1+\tan A\tan B}{1-\tan A\tan B}=\frac{7}{3}$$;   $$3+3\tan A\tan B = 7-7\tan A\tan B$$;   $$10\tan A\tan B = 4$$;   $$\tan A\tan B=\frac{2}{5}$$ (ans);b)i)  AB = OB - OA; = $$12\sin \theta -5\cos \theta $$;If AB = $$R\sin (\theta -\alpha )$$; =$$R\sin \theta \cos \alpha  - R\cos \theta \sin \alpha $$;Then;	$$R\cos \alpha  = 12$$ (1); $$R\sin \alpha  = 2$$ (2);$$(1)^2+(2)^2$$:;$$R^2 = 12^2 + 5^2$$;R = 13 (Ans)$$\frac{(2)}{(1)}: \tan \alpha  = \frac{5}{12}$$$$\alpha  = 22.6^{\circ}$$ (Ans);ii)  When $$AB = (3)(13)\sin (\theta -22.6^{\circ})=3$$$$\sin (\theta -22.6^{\circ})=\frac{3}{13}$$;$$\theta -22.6^{\circ}=13.3^{\circ}$$;$$\theta =35.9^{\circ}$$ (Ans);iii) For $$0^{\circ}<\theta <90^{\circ}$$ and A between O and B, we must have ;$$OB>OA$$ ; Therefore$$12\sin \theta >5\cos \theta $$;$$\tan \theta >\frac{5}{12}$$; $$\theta >22.6^{\circ}$$;Therefore $$22.6^{\circ}<\theta <90^{\circ}$$ (Ans)

a)From $$2^x4^y = 128$$;we get $$2^x2^{(2y)} = 2^7$$;therefore$$x+2y=7$$ (1);from $$\ln (4x - y) = \ln 2 + \ln 5$$;we get $$\ln (4x - y) = \ln 10$$;therefore$$4x-y=10$$ (2);Solving (1) and (2) gives x = 3 and y = 2(Ans);b);i)$$\lg(1-2x)-2\lg(x)=1-\lg(2-5x)$$;$$\lg(1-2x)-\lg(x^2)=\lg10-\lg(2-5x)$$;$$ \lg(\frac{(1-2x)}{x^2})=\lg(\frac{10}{2-5x})$$;therefore;  $$\frac{(1-2x)}{x^2}=\frac{10}{2-5x}$$;$$(1-2x)(2-5x)=10x^2$$;$$2-9x+10x^2= 10x^2$$;$$9x=2$$;$$x=\frac{2}{9}$$ (Ans);ii)   $$3^{y+1}=4^y$$;$$\lg3^{y+1}= \lg4^y$$;$$(y+1)\lg3 = y\lg4$$;$$y(\lg4-\lg3) = \lg3$$;$$y = \frac{(\lg3)}{(\lg4-\lg3)}$$;   = 3.82(Ans);img;c) Graphs of $$y=\ln(x+1)  and  y=\frac{x}{2}$$;img; Given;	$$x-2\ln(x+1) = 0$$;	$$2\ln(x+1) = x$$;$$\ln(x+1) = \frac{x}{2}$$;therefore the answers of the above equation are the x- coordinates of the points of intersection of the graphs,;$$y=\ln(x+1)  and  y=\frac{x}{2}$$;From the graph, $$x \approx 2.5$$ (Ans).

i) Coordinates of X are $$(1+3t, t^2 + 7t)$$; Gradient of OX = $$\frac{(t^2+7t)}{(1+3t)}$$;$$1.5=\frac{(t^2+7t)}{(1+3t)}$$ ; $$1.5+4.5t = t^2+7t$$;$$t^2+2.5t-1.5 = 0$$;$$(t+3t)(t-0.5) = 0$$;Therefore ; $$t=-3  or 0.5$$ (ANS);ii)   $$x=1+3t => \frac{\mathrm{d} x}{\mathrm{d} t} = 3$$;$$y = t^2+7t => \frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} t}= 2t+7$$;therefore;$$\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x} = \frac{\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x}}{\frac{\mathrm{d} x}{\mathrm{d} t}}= \frac{(2t+7)}{3}$$;iii)when t= - 2, x = -5, y = -10;therefore P has coordinates (-5, -10);When t = -5, x = -14, y = -10;therefore Q has coordinates (-14, -10);When t = 2,; $$\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x} = \frac{2(-2)+7}{3} = 1$$;therefore equation of tangent at P :;$$ \frac{(y-(-10))}{(x-(-5)) } = 1$$;$$y+10=x+5$$;$$y=x-5$$ (1);when t = - 5 ,;		  $$\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x} =\frac{ (2(-5)+7)}{3} = -1$$;therefore equation of tangent at Q:;$$\frac{(y-(-10))}{(x-(-14))} = -1$$;$$y+10 = -x-14$$;$$y = -x-24$$ (2);Solving (1) and (2) gives ;$$x = -\frac{19}{2}  and  y = -\frac{29}{2}$$;Therefore coordinates of R are $$(-\frac{19}{2},-\frac{29}{2})$$ (ANS);On the graph, the positions of the points P, Q and R are as follows:;img; Therefore Area of triangle PQR;= $$\frac{1}{2}bh$$;= $$\frac{1}{2}((-5)-(-14))((-10)-(-\frac{29}{2}))$$;= $$\frac{1}{2}(9)(\frac{9}{2})$$;= $$\frac{81}{4} units^2$$ (ANS);iv)From $$x = 1+3t$$,;we have ; $$t = \frac{(x-1)}{3}$$;therefore; $$y = t^2 + 7t$$; $$y = (\frac{(x-1)}{3})^2 + 7(\frac{(x-1)}{3})$$;$$9y = x^2-2x+1+21x-21$$Multiply both sides by 9; = $$x^2-19x-20$$ (ANS)

a) Distance of P from A after t seconds, $$S_p=8t$$;   Distance of Q from A after t seconds, $$S_q=10(t-3)$$;   When Q overtakes P (i.e $$S_p=S_q$$ ), we have $$8t = 10(t-3)$$; = $$10t-30$$;$$2t = 30$$;$$t = 15$$ ;and $$s=S_p$$; = 8(15); = 120;b) i) Let sc and sm be the displacements from the depot of the car and motor-cyclist respectively.;$$s_c = 20t + \frac{1}{2}(-0.2)t^2$$;= $$20t-0.1t^2$$;and;$$s_m = 0t + \frac{1}{2}(0.6)t^2$$; = $$0.3t^2$$;when the motor-cyclist passes the car,;$$s_c=s_m$$;$$20t-0.1t^2 = 0.3t^2$$;$$20t-0.4t^2 = 0$$;$$t(20-0.4t)=0$$;therefore ;	  $$t=50  or  t=0$$;t = 50(Ans);and;$$S = s_m$$;= $$0.3(50)^2$$;= 750(Ans);ii) Let $$v_c$$ and $$v_m$$ be the velocities of the car and motor-cyclist respectively, measured in $$ms^{-1}$$;         $$v_c = 20+(-0.2)t$$;$$v_c = 20-0.2t$$;$$v_m=0+(0.6)t$$;= 0.6t;When t = T = 50,;$$v_c = 20-0.2(50)$$;$$20-10 = 10$$ ;$$v_m = 0.6(50)$$;= 30 (Ans);iv) At t0, the velocities (and hence the speeds) of the two vehicles are the same.; $$v_c=v_m$$;$$20-0.2t_0 = 0.6t_0$$;$$20 = 0.8t_0$$;$$t_0 = 25s$$ (ANS)

i)For P: $$s_p = \frac{1}{2}gt^2$$;therefore; $$20=\frac{1}{2}(10)t^2$$;	$$t^2=4$$;t = 2;For Q:;$$s_q = ut+\frac{1}{2}at^2$$;= $$15t+\frac{1}{2}(g\sin 30^{\circ})t^2$$;= $$15t+\frac{1}{2}(10)(\frac{1}{2})t^2$$;= $$15t+2.5t^2$$;$$DE =\frac{20}{(\sin 30^{\circ})}$$;     = $$\frac{20}{(\frac{1}{2})}$$;=  40;therefore ;   $$40 = 15t+2.5t^2$$;$$t^2+6t-16 = 0$$;	$$(t+8)(t-2)=0$$;therefore $$t = 2$$;therefore P and Q arrive at B and E respectively at the same time.(Shown);For P: $$v_p=gt=10(2)=20ms^{-1}$$ (ANS);For Q:;	 $$v_q=u+at$$;	= $$15+5t$$	=   $$15+5(2)$$ = $$25ms^{-1}$$ (ANS); ii)	After the rebound, ; $$v'_p=12-10t'$$;At C,; $$v'_p=0'$$;Therefore ;	     $$12-10t'=0$$;$$t'=1.2$$;Therefore P takes 1.2 seconds to go for B to C (Ans) ;	Also, ; $$s'_p=12t'-\frac{1}{2}(10)t'^2$$;$$s'_p=12(1.2)-(5)(1.2)^2$$        		         = 7.2;Therefore BC = 7.2 m (Ans);iii)since P takes 1.2 seconds to go form B to C, Q must have taken 1.2 seconds to go from E to F. Therefore Q takes 3.2 seconds to go form D to F.;For Q,; $$v_q=15+5t$$;$$15+5(3.2)=31$$;Therefore the speed of Q at F is $$31ms^-1$$ (ANS);	Using $$v^2=u^2+2as$$;from E to F,; $$31^2=25^2+2(5)(EF)$$; $$961=625+10(EF)$$;	$$EF = 33.6m$$ (ANS)

Let $$u_x and u_y$$ be the horizontal and vertical components of the initial velocity respectively.;$$u_x = 25\cos x$$;= 25(0.96) = $$24 ms^{-1}$$;$$u_y = 25\sin x$$; = 25(0.28 ; = $$7 ms^{-1}$$;$$x = u_xt = 24t$$ (1);and ;$$y = u_yt-\frac{1}{2}gt^2$$;= $$7t-5t^2$$ (2); When the arrow reaches the ground, y = 0;Therefore ; $$7t-5t^2 = 0$$;$$t = \frac{7}{5} =1.4s$$;the time of flight is 1.4 seconds;Horizontal distance travelled = 24(1.4); = 33.6 m;i)  Let  $$v_x and v_y$$ be the horizontal and vertical components of the velocity at time t.;Now,; $$v_x = u_x$$;              $$\tan \beta = \frac{v_x}{v_y}$$; $$4 = \frac{24}{v_y}$$; $$v_y = 6ms^{-1}$$;ii) Let v be the speed;$$v^2 = v_x^2 + v_y^2$$;= $$24^2 + 6^2$$;$$v = \sqrt{612} = 24.7ms^-1$$;iii)For the vertical component of the velocity ;$$v_y = u_y - 10t$$ = $$7 - 10t$$;	When;	$$v_y=-6$$;	$$7-10t = -6$$;	$$10t = 13$$;$$t = 1.3s$$;Therefore the time taken to reach B from A is 1.3 seconds;(iv) Using (1) and (2):;$$x = 24(1.3) = 31.2m$$;$$y = 7(1.3)-5(1.3)^2=0.65m$$

Since the gradient of the curve, at the point (x, y) on the curve, is given by $$\frac{(x^2-4)}{x^2}$$;It means that,;$$\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x} = \frac{(x^2-4)}{x^2}$$ $$= 1-\frac{4}{x^2}$$;Therefore $$y= \int 1-\frac{4}{x^2}dx = x+\frac{4}{x}+c$$, c is a constant.;since the curve passes through the point (2, 7), therefore ; $$7 = 2+\frac{4}{2}+c$$;$$c=3$$;$$y = x+\frac{4}{x}+3$$

When the particle returns to O, $$s=0$$;$$\frac{1}{3}t^3-2t^2+3t = 0$$;	$$t^3-6t^2+9t=0$$;$$t(t^2-6t+9)=0$$;$$t(t-3)^2=0$$;$$t=0  or  t=3$$;Therefore $$T=3$$;i) When the displacement is maximum, the velocity (v) is zero; $$v=0$$;$$\frac{\mathrm{d} s}{\mathrm{d} t} = 0$$;	$$t^2-4t+3=0$$;$$(t-3)(t-1)=0$$;$$t=1  or  t=3$$;When t = 1,;	 $$s = \frac{1}{3}t^3 - 2t^2 +3t$$;	         = $$\frac{1}{3}-2+3 = \frac{4}{3}$$ (ANS);Therefore the maximum displacement from O is $$\frac{4}{3}m$$.;ii) The acceleration (a) is given by $$\frac{\mathrm{d} v}{\mathrm{d} t} $$;$$a=\frac{\mathrm{d} v}{\mathrm{d} t} = 2t-4$$;When $$t=3$$;i.e. (t = T),;$$a=2(3)-4= 2\frac{m}{s^2}$$;Therefore, the acceleration of the particle at time T seconds is $$2\frac{m}{s^2}$$.

a) For equation $$x^2-4cx+c$$;to have real roots, the discriminant must be non-negative. i.e;$$D\geq 0$$ ;$$(-4c)^2-4(1)(c)\geq 0$$;$$16c^2-4c\geq 0$$;$$4c(4c-1)\geq 0$$;$$c\leq 0 or c\geq  \frac{1}{4}$$ (ANS);img;b) $$y=mx$$ (1);$$y=x^2+3x+4$$ (2);Equate (1) to (2):;$$mx = x^2+3x+4$$;$$x^2 + (3-m)x + 4 = 0$$;For the equation to be tangent to the curve, the above equation must have two equal roots, i.e D = 0;$$D=(3-m)^2-4(1)(4)= (3-m)^2 - 16$$;For D = 0, we have;$$(3-m)^2=16$$;$$3-m = \pm 4$$;$$m=7 or -1$$ (ANS)

img;a) $$y=Ae^{-kx}$$;$$\ln  y = \ln  A - kx$$;= $$-kx + \ln A$$;Therefore the gradient of the straight line when ln  y is plotted against x is -k and the vertical intercept is ln  A.;img;The vertical intercept is 4.5.;Therefore ln  A = 4.5; A = 90.0 (ANS);The gradient is $$\frac{-2.5}{28}$$;Therefore $$-k = -\frac{2.5}{28}$$;k = 0.0893 (ANS);b)     $$px + qy = xy$$;Dividing by xy,;$$ \frac{p}{y}+ \frac{q}{x} = 1$$;$$\frac{1}{y} = \frac{-q}{p}(\frac{1}{x})+\frac{1}{p}$$ ??(1);From the information given, we have;$$ \frac{1}{y} = (-1.5)(\frac{1}{x})+c$$;and when $$\frac{1}{y}= 0, \frac{1}{x} = 2$$;$$0 = -1.5(2)+c$$;$$c=3$$;therefore $$\frac{1}{y}= (-1.5)(\frac{1}{x})+3$$ ??(2);Comparing (1) and (2), we get;$$-1.5=-\frac{q}{p}$$;$$q=1.5p$$ ??(3);And $$\frac{1}{p} = 3$$;$$p=\frac{1}{3}$$ (ANS);$$\Rightarrow  q =0.5=\frac{1}{2}$$ (ANS);c)Let $$Y = x - y$$ and $$X = xy$$. ;Then the equation of the line is;$$ \frac{ (Y-2)}{(X-1)}= \frac{ (4-2)}{(5-1)}$$;$$2Y-4=X-1$$;$$2Y=X+3$$;Substituting $$Y = x -y$$ and $$X = xy$$, we get;$$2(x-y)=xy+3$$;$$2x-2y = xy+3$$;$$y(x+2)=2x+3$$;$$y = \frac{ (2x-3)}{(x+2)}$$ (ANS)

i) BD = BE + ED; = $$BC\cos  \theta  + AD \sin  \theta $$;  = $$12 \cos  \theta  +5\sin  \theta $$ (SHOWN);ii) $$BD = 12 \cos  \theta  +5\sin  \theta $$;$$R\sin (\theta  + \alpha ) = 12\cos  \theta  + 5\sin  \theta $$;$$R\sin  \theta  \cos  \alpha  + R\cos  \theta  \sin  \alpha  = 12 \cos  \theta  + 5 \sin  \theta $$;Therefore,;$$R\cos  \alpha  = 5$$ ??(1);$$R \sin  \alpha  = 12$$ ??(2);$$(1)^2 + (2)^2 : R^2 = 12^2 + 5^2 =13^2$$;$$R=13$$ (ANS);$$ \frac{ ((2))}{((1))} : \tan  \alpha  = \frac{12}{5}$$;$$\alpha =67.4^{\circ}$$ (ANS);When BD = 8,;$$13\sin (\theta +67.4^{\circ})=8$$;$$\sin (\theta +67.4^{\circ})=\frac{8}{13}$$;$$\theta  + 67.4^{\circ} = 38.0^{\circ} or 142.0^{\circ}$$;since $$\theta $$ is positive, ;$$\theta  = 74.6^{\circ}$$ (ANS);iii) $$AE = AD\cos \theta  = 5\cos \theta $$;$$EC = BC\sin \theta  = 12\sin \theta $$;Area of triangle ABD;=$$\frac{1}{2}(AE)(BD)$$;=$$\frac{1}{2}(5\cos \theta )(12\cos \theta +5\sin \theta )$$;=$$\frac{1}{2}(60\cos ^2\theta +25\sin \theta \cos \theta )$$;area of triangle BCD;=$$\frac{1}{2}(EC)(BD)$$;=$$\frac{1}{2}(12\sin \theta )(12\cos \theta +5\sin \theta )$$;=$$\frac{1}{2}(60\sin ^2\theta +144\sin \theta \cos \theta )$$;Therefore area of quadrilateral ABCD;= Area of triangle ABD + area of triangle BCD;=$$\frac{1}{2}(60\sin ^2\theta +144\sin \theta \cos \theta +60\cos ^2\theta +25\sin \theta \cos \theta )$$;=$$\frac{1}{2}(169\sin \theta \cos \theta +60)$$;=$$\frac{1}{2}(\frac{169}{2}\sin 2\theta +60)$$;=$$ \frac{ (169\sin 2\theta +120)}{4}$$ (SHOWN);iv) $$area=\frac{ (169\sin 2\theta +120)}{4}$$;since $$\sin  2\theta $$ is at most 1, therefore;maximum area = $$\frac{ (169+120)}{4}$$; = $$72.25cm^2$$ (ANS);and it occurs when,;$$\sin 2\theta  =1$$;$$2\theta  =90^{\circ}$$;$$\theta  = 45^{\circ}$$ (ANS)

i) $$\vec{OA} \ast \vec{OB}=|\vec{OA}||\vec{OB}|\cos  \angle AOB$$;$$(\binom{10}{5})(\binom{1}{3})=\sqrt{10^2+5^2}\ast \sqrt{1^2+3^2}\cos  \angle AOB$$;$$10+15 = \sqrt{125} \sqrt{10} \cos  \angle AOB$$;$$\cos  \angle AOB = \frac{ 25}{\sqrt{1250}} = \frac{ 25}{(25\sqrt2)} = \frac{ 1}{\sqrt2}$$;$$\angle AOB = 45^{\circ}$$ (ANS);ii)$$\vec{AB}=\vec{OB}-\vec{OA}$$;=$$(\binom{1}{3})-(\binom{10}{5})=(\binom{-9}{-2})$$;$$|\vec{AB}|=\sqrt{9^2+2^2}$$;=$$\sqrt{85}$$ (ANS);$$\vec{AC}=\vec{OC}-\vec{OA}$$;=$$(\binom{c}{3c})-(\binom{10}{5})=(\binom{c-10}{3c-5})$$;$$|\vec{AC}|=\sqrt{(c-10)^2+(3c-5)^2}$$;since $$|\vec{AC}|= |\vec{AB}|$$;we have;$$\sqrt{(c-10)^2+(3c-5)^2}=\sqrt{85}$$;$$(c-10)^2+(3c-5)^2=85$$;$$c^2-20c+100+9c^2-30c+25=85$$;$$10c^2-50c+40=0$$;$$c^2-5c+4=0$$;$$(c-4)(c-1)=0$$;Therefore c = 4 or 1;since c > 1, therefore c = 4 (ANS);since $$ \angle BAD=90^{\circ}$$, then $$\vec{AB} \ast \vec{AD}=0$$;	since is on OB produced,;$$\vec{OD}=\lambda  \vec{OB}, \lambda >1$$;=$$((\lambda ),(3\lambda ))$$;$$\vec{AD}=\vec{OD}-\vec{OA}$$;=$$(\binom{\lambda -10}{3\lambda -5})$$;$$\vec{AB} \ast \vec{AD}=0$$;$$(\binom{-9}{-2}) \ast (\binom{\lambda -10}{3\lambda -5})=0$$;$$-9\lambda +90-6\lambda +10=0$$;$$15\lambda =100$$;$$\lambda = \frac{ 20}{3}$$;Therefore $$\vec{OD}=(\binom{\frac{20}{3z}}{20})$$ (ANS)

i) $$\angle PQR=60^{\circ}$$	;Therefore;$$\angle DQF = 360^{\circ}-90^{\circ}-90^{\circ}-\angle PQR$$;=$$120^{\circ}$$;And $$\angle QPS = 120^{\circ}$$;Therefore;$$\angle CPA=360^{\circ}-90^{\circ}-90^{\circ}-\angle QPS$$;=$$60^{\circ}$$;area of QDEF = $$\frac{120}{360}\pi r^2=\frac{1}{3}\pi 30^2=300\pi cm^2$$;area of PABC = $$\frac{60}{360}\pi r^2=\frac{1}{6}\pi 30^2=150\pi cm^2$$;Total area = 4 x area of CDQP + 2 x area of QDEF +2 x area of PABC; = 4(30 x 80) + 2(300p) + 2(150 p); = 9600 + 900 p; = $$12400cm^2$$ (3sf) (ANS);ii) arc length DEF = $$\frac{120}{360}(2\pi r)$$; =$$\frac{2}{3}\pi (30)$$; =$$20\pi cm$$;arc length ABC = $$\frac{60}{360}(2\pi r)$$; =$$\frac{1}{3}\pi (30)$$; =$$10\pi cm$$;Length of external boundary;= (4 x CD) + (2 x arc length DEF) + (2 x arc length ABC);= 4 x 80 + 2 x 20p + 2 x 10p;= 320 + 60 p;$$\approx 508cm$$ (3sf) (ANS);img; $$\angle CPY = 90^{\circ}$$;$$\angle DQX = 90^{\circ}$$;$$\angle CPY + \angle APY = 90^{\circ}$$;and since DQ is perpendicular to QX; $$60^{\circ}+\angle APY=90^{\circ}$$;$$\angle APY = 30^{\circ}$$;area of triangle APY;=$$\frac{1}{2} \times AP \times AY$$;=$$\frac{1}{2}(30)(30\tan 30^{\circ})$$;=$$\frac{450}{\sqrt3}$$;=$$150\sqrt3cm^2$$;area of QDEX = $$\frac{1}{4}\pi r^2$$;=$$\frac{1}{4}\pi (30)^2$$;=$$225\pi cm^2$$;area of smaller part;= area of triangle APY + area of QDEX;= $$150\sqrt3+150\pi +2400+225\pi $$;=$$2400+375\pi +150\sqrt3$$;$$\approx 3840cm^2$$ (3sf) (ANS)

i)$$V = 2(x+4)^2-32$$;$$\frac{\mathrm{d} V}{\mathrm{d} t}=4(x+4)$$;Now,;$$ \frac{\mathrm{d} V}{\mathrm{d} t}=\frac{\mathrm{d} V}{\mathrm{d} x} \ast \frac{\mathrm{d} x}{\mathrm{d} t}$$;$$50=4(x+4)\frac{\mathrm{d} x}{\mathrm{d} t}$$;when x = 16 ,;$$50=4(16+4)\frac{\mathrm{d} x}{\mathrm{d} t}$$;$$\frac{\mathrm{d} x}{\mathrm{d} t}=0.625$$;therefore the rate of increase of the depth of the liquid is $$0.625cms^{-1}$$;ii)	$$50=4(x+4)\frac{\mathrm{d} x}{\mathrm{d} t}$$;When $$\frac{\mathrm{d} x}{\mathrm{d} t}=0.8$$,;$$50=4(x+4)(0.8)$$;x = 11.625 (ANS)

(a) Let $$f(x)=ax^3+x^2+bx$$ 	By remainder theorem,;$$f(-1)=3$$;$$-a+1-b=3$$;$$a+b=-2$$ ??(1);and;$$f(2)=6$$;$$8a+4+2b=6$$;$$4a+b=1 ??(2)$$;Solving (1) and (2) simultaneously, gives ;a = 1, b = - 3.;Therefore $$f(x)=x^3+x^2-3x$$,;The remainder when the expression id divided by x - 3 is,;$$f(x)=3^3+3^2-3(3)$$;  = 27 (ANS); b) Let $$g(x)=2x^3+7x^2-2x-1$$;By trial and error, we found that;$$g(\frac{1}{2})=\frac{1}{4}+\frac{7}{4}-1-1=0$$;By factor theorem, (2x - 1) is a factor of g(x).;$$g(x)=2x^3+7x^2-2x-1$$;=$$(2x-1)(x^2+4x+1)$$;For g(x) = 0;$$(2x-1)(x^2+4x+1)=0$$;$$x=\frac{1}{2}$$;or $$x=\frac{ (-4\pm \sqrt(16-4))}{2}$$;=$$-0.27 or -3.73$$;The answers are $$\frac{1}{2},-0.27 and -3.73$$;img;(ANS)

i)$$y=(x^2-4)(2x-1)$$;when x = 0, y = (- 4)(- 1) = 4;therefore the curve cuts the y - axis at (0, 4);when y = 0,;$$(x^2-4)(2x-1)=0$$;$$x=\pm 2 or \frac{1}{2}$$;Therefore the curve cuts the x- axis at (-2, 0), $$(\frac{1}{2},0)$$,(2,0) (ANS);ii) $$\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x} = 2(x^2-4)+2x(2x-1)$$;=$$2(x^2-4+2x^2-x)$$;=$$2(3x^2-x-4)$$;At the turning points,;$$3x^2-x-4=0$$;$$(3x-4)(x+1)=0$$;$$x=\frac{4}{3} or -1$$;when $$x=\frac{4}{3},y=(\frac{16}{9}-4)( \frac{8}{3}-1)=- \frac{100}{27}$$;when x = -1, y = (1 -4 )(-2 - 1) = 9;Therefore the turning points are $$(\frac{4}{3},-\frac{100}{27}) and (-1,9)$$.

a) i) $$\frac{\mathrm{d} }{\mathrm{d} x}(\frac{ (2x+5)}{(1+3x)})= \frac{ ((1+3x)(2)-(2x+5)(3))}{(1+3x)^2}$$;=$$\frac{ (2+6x-6x-15)}{(1+3x)^2}$$;= $$-\frac{13}{(1+3x)^2}$$ (ANS);b) $$2x^2+xy-3y^2=7$$;Differentiate both sides w.r.t x,;$$4x+x\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x}+y-6y\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x}=0$$;$$(6y-x)\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x}=4x+y$$;$$\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x}=\frac{ (4x+y)}{(6y-x)}$$;At the point(2, 1),;$$\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x}=\frac{ (4(2)+1)}{(6(1)-2)}$$; = $$\frac{9}{4}$$ (ANS);	i) Given that $$\frac{\mathrm{d} x}{\mathrm{d} t}=0.08$$;when x  = 2,;$$\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} t}= \frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x}  \ast  \frac{\mathrm{d} x}{\mathrm{d} t}$$;=$$\frac{ (4x+y)}{(6y-x)} \ast \frac{\mathrm{d} x}{\mathrm{d} t}$$;=$$\frac{ (4(2)+1)}{(6(1)-2)} \ast (0.08)$$;= 0.18 (ANS);ii) since $$\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} t}=0.18 >0$$,;y is increasing (ANS);c) $$y = \tan (x + 1)$$;$$\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x}=sec^2(x+1)$$;when x = 0, $$\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x}=sec^2(1)$$;Gradient of tangent = $$sec^2(1)$$;	Gradient of normal ;= $$\frac{-1}{gradient of tangent}$$;=$$\frac{-1}{(sec^2(1))}$$;=$$-\cos ^2(1)$$;=- 0.29 (ANS)

a)  i) $$AB = 8\sin \theta$$;   $$ BC = (7 + 8)\cos \theta$$ ; = $$15\cos \theta$$ ;Therefore perimeter of ABCD,;$$P = 2(AB + BC)$$;   $$= 2(8\sin \theta  + 15\cos \theta )$$;  $$ =16\sin \theta  + 30\cos \theta $$ (shown) ;ii) Let$$P=R\sin (\theta +\alpha )$$;$$16\sin \theta +30\cos \theta =R\sin \theta \cos \alpha  + R\cos \theta \sin \alpha $$;Therefore;$$R\cos  \alpha  = 16$$ ??(1);$$R\sin  \alpha  = 30$$??(2);$$(1)^2+(2)^2: R^2(\cos ^2\alpha  + \sin ^2\alpha )=16^2+30^2$$;$$R^2=1156$$;R = 34 (ANS);$$ \frac{ ((2))}{((1))}:\tan  \alpha  = \frac{ 30}{16}$$;$$\alpha  = 61.9^{\circ}$$(ANS);iii)  Therefore $$P=34\sin (\theta +61.9^{\circ})$$;since the maximum value of a sine function is 1, the maximum value of P is 34.(ANS);Furthermore,;$$\sin (\theta +61.9^{\circ})=1$$;$$\Rightarrow \sin  \theta  + 61.9^{\circ} =90^{\circ}$$;$$\theta  = 28.1^{\circ}$$ (ANS);iv) When P = 20,;$$20=34\sin (\theta +61.9^{\circ})$$;$$\sin (\theta +61.9^{\circ})=\frac{ 10}{17}$$;$$\theta +61.9^{\circ} = 144.0^{\circ} or 36.0^{\circ} (N.A)$$;$$\theta  = 82.1^{\circ}$$ (ANS);b)i) $$\tan ^2A =\frac{ (\sin ^2A)}{(\cos ^2A)}$$;=$$ \frac{ (1-\cos ^2A)}{(\cos ^2A)}$$;=$$ \frac{ (1-p^2)}{p^2}$$ (ANS);ii) $$\cos 2A=2\cos ^2A-1$$;=$$2p^2-1$$ (ANS);iii) $$\cos 3A = \cos (2A+A)$$;=$$\cos 2A\cos A-\sin 2A\sin A$$;=$$(2p^2-1)p-2\sin ^2A\cos A$$;=$$(2p^2-1)p-2(1-\cos ^2A)p$$;=$$(2p^2-1)p-2(1-p^2)p$$;=$$2p^3-p-2p+2p^3$$;= $$4p^3-3p$$ (ANS)

img;img;a) $$ay^2-bx^3=1$$;$$y^2=\frac{ b}{ax^3}+\frac{ 1}{a}$$;Therefore the gradient of the line is $$\frac{ b}{a}$$;and the vertical intercept is $$\frac{ 1}{a}$$;From the graph,$$ \frac{ 1}{a}= 4$$;a = 0.25 (ANS);$$ \frac{ b}{a}=\frac{ 10}{20}$$;$$\frac{ b}{0.25} = \frac{1}{2}$$;B = 0.125 (ANS);$$y^2-x^3=1$$;$$y^2=x^3+1$$;Therefore on the same axes as the previous graph, the line $$y^2=x^3+1$$ has a gradient of 1 and a vertical intercept at 1.;From the graph, $$(x^2,y^2)=(6,7)$$;Therefore x = 1.82, y = 2.65 (ANS);b)$$y^2=px^q$$;$$\lg  y^2 = \lg  px^q$$;$$2\lg y=\lg p +q\lg x$$;$$\lg y=\frac{ q}{2}\lg x+\frac{1}{2}\lg p$$;When lg  y is plotted against lg  x, the gradient is $$\frac{ q}{2}$$ and the vertical intercept is $$\frac{1}{2} \lg  p$$;Therefore $$\frac{ q}{2}=-2 \Rightarrow  q=-4$$;and ;$$\frac{1}{2}\lg p = 0.5 \Rightarrow  \lg  p =1$$;$$\Rightarrow  p=10$$;Therefore, p=10, q=-4 (ANS);c) Equation of the line:;$$ \frac{ (y^2-3)}{(xy-1)}= \frac{ (11-3)}{(5-1)}$$;$$ \frac{ (y^2-3)}{(xy-1)}=2$$;$$y^2-3=2xy-2$$;$$y^2=2xy+1$$;When y = 3, 9 = 6x +1;$$x=\frac{ 4}{3}$$ (ANS)

i) $$x=t^2-2t \Rightarrow  \frac{\mathrm{d} x}{\mathrm{d} t}=2t-2$$;$$y=t^2+2t \Rightarrow  \frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} t}=2t+2$$;Therefore;$$\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x} = \frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} t}  \ast  \frac{\mathrm{d} t}{\mathrm{d} x}$$;=$$\frac{ (2t+2)}{(2t-2)}$$;=$$ \frac{ (t+1)}{(t-1)}$$ (ANS); ii)Gradient,;$$\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x}=\frac{1}{2}$$;$$\frac{ (t+1)}{(t-1)}=\frac{1}{2}$$;$$2t+2=t-1$$;$$t=-3$$;$$x=(-3)^2-2(-3)=9+6=15$$;$$y=(-3)^2+2(-3)=9-6=3$$;Equation of tangent:;$$ \frac{ (y-3)}{(x-15)}=\frac{1}{2}$$;$$2y-6=x-15$$;$$2y-x+9=0$$ (ANS);iii)since the tangent to the curve at this point is parallel to the y- axis, then $$\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x}$$ is infinity.;Therefore $$\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x}=\frac{ (t+1)}{(t-1)}= \infty$$;Hence,; $$t-1=0 \Rightarrow  t=1$$;$$x^2=(1)^2-2(1)=-1$$;$$y=(1)^2+2(1)=3$$;Therefore the coordinates are (-1, 3) (ANS);iv)$$x=t^2-2t$$ ??(1);$$y=t^2+2t$$ ??(2);(1) + (2):;$$2t^2=x+y$$;$$t^2=\frac{ (x+y)}{2}$$;Sub. into (1):;$$x=\frac{ (x+y)}{2}-2t$$;$$2t=\frac{ (y-x)}{2}$$;$$t=\frac{ (y-x)}{4}$$;Squaring both sides,;$$t^2=(\frac{(y-x)}{4})^2$$;$$\frac{ (x+y)}{2}=(\frac{ (y-x)}{4})^2$$;$$8(x+y)=(y-x)^2$$ (ANS)

a) For line AB,;gradient of line AB = $$\frac{ (11-1)}{(3-(-2))}= \frac{10}{5}=2$$;	using $$y=mx+c \Rightarrow  y=2x+c$$;use point  A(-2, 1);$$1=2(-2)+c \Rightarrow  c=5$$;therefore, y = 2x + 5 is the equation of line AB (ANS);For line CN,;gradient of line CN = $$-\frac{1}{2}$$;use $$y=mx+c \Rightarrow  y=-\frac{1}{2}x+c$$;use point  c(-1, 8);$$8=-\frac{1}{2}(-1)+c \Rightarrow  c=\frac{15}{2}$$;therefore, $$y=-\frac{1}{2}x+\frac{15}{2}$$ is the equation of CN (ANS);b) To find coordinates of N, solve for x and y from;$$y=2x+5$$ ??(1);$$y=-\frac{1}{2}x+\frac{15}{2}$$ ??(2);$$\Rightarrow  2x+5 = -\frac{1}{2}x+\frac{15}{2}$$;$$\Rightarrow  4x+10 = -x + 15$$;$$\Rightarrow  5x=5$$;$$\Rightarrow  x=1$$;with x =1,(1) gives y = 2(1) + 5 = 7;therefore coordinates of N = (1, 7) (ANS)

L.H.S = $$\frac{ (1+\cos A)}{(1-\cos A)}- \frac{ (1-\cos A)}{(1+\cos A)}$$ ;= $$\frac{ ((1+\cos A)^2-(1-\cos A)^2)}{((1-\cos A)(1+\cos A))}$$;= $$\frac{ ((2\cos A)(2))}{(1-\cos ^2A)}$$;=$$ \frac{ (4\cos A)}{(\sin ^2A)}$$;= $$4\frac{\cos A}{\sin A} \frac{1}{\sin A}$$;= $$4\cot A\csc A$$;=R.H.S (Proven)

$$y=x^2+\frac{24}{x}$$;$$\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x}=2x-\frac{24}{x^2}$$;gradient of the curve at P = $$2(2)- \frac{24}{(2)^2}$$;= 4-6;=-2;Equation of the line tangent to the curve at point  P(2, 16) is $$\frac{ (y-16)}{(x-2)}=-2 \Rightarrow  y-16 = -2x+4$$;i.e. y = -2x + 20.... equation of tangent to curve at P;x-c\infty rdinate of A is given by 0 = -2x + 20;x = 10;i.e. A(10, 0);y-c\infty rdinate of B is given by y = 20;i.e. B(0, 20);Area of triangle AOB;= $$\frac{1}{2}(10)(20)$$;= $$100 sq units$$ (ANS)

Volume of the cylinder, V ;= (circular base area) x (height);= $$(\pi r^2) \times (4r)$$;= $$4\pi r^3cm^3$$;$$\frac{\mathrm{d} V}{\mathrm{d} r}=4\pi (3r^2)$$;=$$12\pi r^2cm^2$$;From $$\frac{(gradV)}{(gradr)} = \frac{\mathrm{d} V}{\mathrm{d} r}\Rightarrow gradV = \frac{\mathrm{d} V}{\mathrm{d} r}|_{(r=5)}(gradr)$$;where;$$ \frac{\mathrm{d} V}{\mathrm{d} r}|_{r=5}=12\pi (5)^2=300\pi cm^2$$;$$gradr=(5+p)-5=pcm$$;therefore $$gradV = 300\pi pcm^2$$;Percentage increase in V = $$\frac{ (gradV)}{V}  \times  100%$$;= $$\frac{ (300\pi p)}{(4\pi (5)^3)} \times 100%$$;= $$\frac{ (3p)}{5}  \times 100%$$;= $$60p%$$ (ANS)

a) Gradient of the curve at P = 5;$$\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x}=4x-7=5$$;$$x=\frac{ (5+7)}{4}=3$$;Use y = 2x y =2(3) = 6;Hence P(3, 6) (ANS);b) $$\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x} = 4x-7$$;$$\Rightarrow  \int dy = \int  4x-7dx$$;$$\Rightarrow  y = 2x^2-7x+c$$;Using P(3, 6) we have,;$$6=2(3)^2-7(3)+c \Rightarrow  c=6-18+21=9$$;therefore $$y=2x^2-7x+9$$

a) By Ratio theorem, since M is the mid-point  of AB, we have;$$\vec{OM}=\frac{1}{2}(\vec{OA}+\vec{OB})$$ ;  =$$\frac{1}{2}(a+b)$$ (ANS);b) By Ratio theorem again, we have,;img;$$\vec{OD}=\frac{1}{3}(2\vec{OM}+\vec{OC})$$;=$$\frac{1}{3}[(a+b)+c]$$;= $$\frac{1}{3}(a+b+c)$$ (ANS)

a) Height of the triangle;= $$\sqrt{(5x)^2+(12x)^2}$$;=$$13xcm$$;therefore area of the triangular face of the pyramid;= $$\frac{1}{2}(13x)(10x)$$;=$$65x^2cm^2$$ (ANS);b) Total surface area of the rectangular sides; = 4(10x)(h);= $$260xhcm^2$$;  Total surface area of the rectangular faces;= $$4  \times  (65x^2)$$;=$$260x^2cm^2$$;therefore total area of metal sheet needed;= $$40xh+260x^2cm^2$$;$$\Rightarrow  40xh +260x^2=1200$$;$$\Rightarrow  2xh + 13x^2=60$$;$$\Rightarrow 2xh=60-13x^2$$;i.e. $$h=\frac{ (60-13x^2)}{(2x)}$$ (SHOWN);c) Volume of the inverted regular pyramid;= $$\frac{1}{3}  \times  (100x^2)  \times  12x = 400x^3cm^3$$;  Volume of the rectangular top with rectangular sides;= $$100x^2hcm^3$$;$$\Rightarrow  volume of container=100x^2h+400x^3cm^3$$;  i.e. volume V = $$100x^2(\frac{ (60-13x^2)}{(2x)})+400x^3$$;=$$3000x-650x^3+400x^3$$;=$$3000x-250x^3cm^3$$ (SHOWN);iv) $$\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x} = 3000-750x^2$$;$$\frac{\mathrm{d} ^{2}y}{\mathrm{d} x^{2}}=-1500x$$;$$\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x} = 0 \Rightarrow  x^2 =\frac{ 3000}{750} = 4$$;i.e x = 2 cm (ANS);at x = 2 cm,;Volume V =$$3000x-250x^3cm^3$$;=3000(2) - 250(2)^3;=$$ 4000 cm^3$$ (ANS);$$ \frac{\mathrm{d} ^{2}y}{\mathrm{d} x^{2}}=-3000 = -ve$$;Hence the volume V has a maximum value at x = 2 cm. (ANS)

a) $$5\cos ^2x-8\sin x\cos x=0$$; $$\Rightarrow  \cos x(5\cos x-8\sin x)=0$$;$$\Rightarrow  \cos x=0 or 5\cos x-8\sin x=0$$;$$\Rightarrow  x=90^{\circ},270^{\circ}or \tan x=\frac{5}{8}$$;$$\Rightarrow  x=90^{\circ},270^{\circ} or x=32^{\circ},212^{\circ}$$;therefore $$x=32^{\circ}, 90^{\circ}, 212^{\circ} or 270^{\circ}$$ (ANS);b) $$5\tan ^2y+7=11secy$$;$$\Rightarrow  5(sec^2y-1)+7=11secy$$;$$\Rightarrow  5sec^2y-11secy+2=0$$;$$\Rightarrow  (5secy-1)(secy-2)=0$$;$$\Rightarrow  secy=\frac{1}{5} or sec y =2$$;$$\Rightarrow  \cos y=5 (rejected) or \cos y=\frac{1}{2} $$;i.e $$y=60^{\circ} or 300^{\circ}$$ (ANS);c) $$1+2\sin (\frac{ (3z)}{2 }+75^{\circ})=0^{\circ}$$	;Let  x = $$\frac{ (3z)}{2 }+75^{\circ}\Rightarrow  1+2\sin x=0$$;$$\Rightarrow  \sin x=-\frac{1}{2}$$;$$\Rightarrow  x = 210^{\circ},330^{\circ},570^{\circ}$$;$$\Rightarrow  \frac{ (3z)}{2}+75^{\circ} = 210^{\circ},330^{\circ},570^{\circ}$$;$$\Rightarrow \frac{ (3z)}{2} = 135^{\circ},255^{\circ},495^{\circ}$$;	i.e $$z=90^{\circ},170^{\circ},330^{\circ}$$ (ANS)

a) $$AB = \sqrt{(9-3)^2 + (6+2)^2}=\sqrt{36+64}=10$$;$$BC=\sqrt{(-8)^2+(h+2)^2}=\sqrt{h^2+4h+68}$$;$$AB=BC$$;$$\Rightarrow  h^2+4h+68=100$$;$$\Rightarrow  h^2+4h-32=0$$;$$\Rightarrow  (h-4)(h+8)=0$$;	  h = 4 or h = - 8(rejected) (ANS); b) Gradient of line AB = $$\frac{ (9-3)}{(6-(-2))}= \frac{6}{8}=\frac{3}{4}$$ Gradient of line BC = $$\frac{ (-5-3)}{(h+2)}=- \frac{8}{6}=-\frac{4}{3}$$;Now	$$(\frac{3}{4})(-\frac{4}{3})=-1$$;Therefore angle ABC is a right angle. (SHOWN);c)M is the mid-point  of line joining A(6, 9) and B(-2, 3), hence;M = $$((\frac{1}{2}(6-2)),(\frac{1}{2}(9+3)))=(2,6)$$ ;P = $$((\frac{1}{2}(6+h)),(\frac{1}{2}(9-5)))=(5,2)$$;Line MP : y = mx + c where ;M = gradient of MP = $$\frac{ (6-2)}{(2-5)}= \frac{4}{-3}$$;Use M = $$(2,6)$$;$$\Rightarrow  6=2(\frac{-4}{3})+c$$;$$\Rightarrow  c= 6+\frac{8}{3}=\frac{26}{3}$$ ;Therefore, ;$$y=-\frac{4}{3x}+\frac{26}{3}$$ ?equation of line MPQ;To find Q, substitute y = 0 into above equation, we have,;$$0=-\frac{4}{3x}+\frac{26}{3} or x=\frac{26}{4}=1\frac{3}{2}$$;hence, Q = $$(1\frac{3}{2},0)$$;Therefore, $$M= (2,6)$$, $$P=(5,2)$$, $$Q=(1\frac{3}{2},0)$$ (ANS);d)$$MP = \sqrt{(6-2)^2+(2-5)^2}=\sqrt{25}=5$$;$$BC = \sqrt{(5-1\frac{3}{2})^2+(2-0)^2}=\sqrt{(\frac{3}{2})^2+2^2}=\sqrt{\frac{25}{4}}=\frac{5}{2}$$;therefore; MP:PQ= $$5: \frac{5}{2}$$;= 2:1 (ANS)

(ANS);ii) Sales of television in December of 1996;= $$T_12$$;= a + 11d;= 2100 + 11(200);= 4300 (ANS);c) $$T_1$$ = first term of the sequence = 210 = 15 x 14	;$$T_N$$ =last term of the sequence = 990 = 15 x 66;To find the sum from $$T_1$$ to $$T_N$$, need to determine the number of terms in the sequence which is given by:;$$n=\frac{ (T_n-T_1)}{15} + 1$$;$$\Rightarrow  n=(66-14)+1$$;i.e n = 53;therefore sum of the numbers ;= $$\frac{n}{2}(T_1+T_n)=5\frac{3}{2}(210+990)$$;= 31800 (ANS)

$$(1-\frac{x}{3})^9=1+9(-\frac{x}{3})+36(-\frac{x}{3})^2+84(-\frac{x}{3})^3+...$$;=$$1-3x+4x^2-\frac{28}{9}x^3+...$$;since coefficient of $$x^3$$ is of interest to us, we only need to consider the terms $$4x^2$$ and $$-\frac{28}{9}x^3$$ in the expansion of $$(1-\frac{x}{3})^9$$;$$(9+8x)(1-\frac{x}{3})^9=(9+8x)(1-3x+4x^2-\frac{28}{9}x^3+...)$$;$$\Rightarrow  term involving  x^3  in the equation$$;= $$[9(-\frac{28}{9})+8(4)]x^3=4x^3$$;therefore coefficient of $$x^3$$ = 4 (ANS)

eq 0$$;Let ;$$y=f(x)$$;$$\Rightarrow  y=5- rac{6}{x}$$;$$\Rightarrow   rac{6}{x}=5-y$$;$$\Rightarrow  rac{ 1}{x}= rac{1}{6} (5-y)$$;$$\Rightarrow  x= rac{6}{(5-y)},y
eq 5$$;therefore $$f^{-1}(x)=  rac{6}{(5-x)},x
eq 5$$ (ANS);b) To find x such that ;$$f(x)=f^{-1}(x)$$we have ;$$5- rac{6}{x}= rac{6}{(5-x)}$$;$$\Rightarrow rac{ (5x-6)}{x}= rac{6}{(5-x)}$$;$$\Rightarrow (5x-6)(5-x)=6x$$;$$\Rightarrow 25x-5x^2-30+6x=6x$$;$$\Rightarrow 5x^2-25x+30=0$$;$$\Rightarrow x^2-5x+6=0$$;$$\Rightarrow (x-2)(x-3)=0$$;therefore x = 2 or x = 3 (ANS)

i)$$\vec{OA}=3i+j=\binom{3}{1}$$;$$\vec{OC}=4-2j=\binom{4}{-2}$$;by vector addition,;$$\vec{OB}=\vec{OC}+\vec{CB}$$;=$$\vec{OC}+\vec{OA}$$;=$$\binom{4}{-2}+\binom{3}{1}$$;=$$\binom{7}{1}$$ (ANS);ii) To find acute angle \theta between the diagonals of the parallelogram OABC, apply vector scalar dot-product of diagonals OB and AC.;$$\vec{AC}=\vec{OC}-\vec{OA}=\binom{4}{-2}-\binom{3}{1}=\binom{1}{-3}$$;Now;$$|\vec{OB}|=\sqrt{7^2+(-1)^2}=\sqrt{50}=5\sqrt2$$;$$|\vec{AC}|=\sqrt{1^2+(-3)^2}=\sqrt{10}$$;$$\vec{OB} \ast \vec{AC}=\binom{7}{-1} \ast \binom{1}{-3}=7+(-1)(-3)=10$$;$$\Rightarrow  \cos  \theta  = \frac{ (\vec{OB} \ast \vec{AC})}{(|\vec{OB}| \ast |\vec{AC}|)}= \frac{10}{((5\sqrt2)\sqrt{10})}=\sqrt{\frac{1}{5}}=\sqrt{0.2}=0.4472$$;therefore ;$$\theta  = \cos ^{-1}(0.4472)=63.43^{\circ}$$;=$$63.4^{\circ}$$ (ANS)

i) To find acceleration, we differentiate v with respect to t,;Acceleration,;$$a=\frac{\mathrm{d} v}{\mathrm{d}t} =5(2t)+(1-3p)$$;= (10t) + (1 - 3p) (ANS);ii) Acceleration, a = 3 when t = 2;$$\Rightarrow  3=10(2)+(1-3p)$$;$$\Rightarrow  3p=20+1-3=18$$;ie. p = 6 (ANS);iii) Now $$v=5t^2-17t+6ms^{-1}$$;since p = 6;To find values of t when the particle is at instantaneous rest, we solve for t when v = 0;$$\Rightarrow 5t^2-17t+6=0$$;$$\Rightarrow (5t-2)(t-3)=0$$;$$t=\frac{2}{3}s or 3s$$ (ANS)

i) Gradient of curve,;$$\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x}=y^1=x^2+1\frac{6}{x}^2, where  x>0$$;$$P -= (4, 18)$$;Gradient of tangent at P = $$4^2+\frac{16}{4^2}=16+1=17$$;Therefore gradient of the normal to the curve at P = $$-\frac{1}{17}$$Equation of the normal at P is given by;$$y-18=-\frac{1}{17}(x-4)$$;or;$$y+\frac{1}{17}x-\frac{18 4}{17}=0$$ (ANS);ii) To find the equation of the curve, integrate the gradient equation,;$$\Rightarrow y=\int \frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x}dx$$;=$$\int x^2+1\frac{6}{x}^2dx$$;=$$\frac{1}{3}x^3-1\frac{6}{x}+C$$ where C is the integration constant to be determined.;Now ;$$P -= (4,18)$$;$$18=\frac{64}{3}-\frac{16}{4}+C$$;$$C=22-\frac{64}{3}=\frac{2}{3}$$;Hence $$y=\frac{1}{3}x^3-1\frac{6}{x}+\frac{2}{3}$$ is the equation of the curve (ANS);Now;$$ \frac{\mathrm{d} ^{2}y}{\mathrm{d} x^{2}}=\frac{\mathrm{d} }{\mathrm{d} x}(\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x})=y^11=2x-\frac{32}{x^3} ;x>0$$;$$\Rightarrow 2x-\frac{32}{x^3}=0$$;$$\Rightarrow x^4=16$$;i.e x = 2;When x = 2,;$$y=\frac{8}{3}-8+\frac{2}{3}=-\frac{14}{3}$$;therefore coordinates of the point  is $$(2,- \frac{14}{3})$$ (ANS);Minimum value of the gradient = $$2^2+\frac{16}{2^2}=4+4$$= 8 (ANS)

i) Surface area of the circular cylinder;= $$\pi r^2+2\pi rh$$;$$\Rightarrow \pi r^2+2\pi rh=432\pi $$;$$\Rightarrow r^2+2rh=432$$;i.e $$h=\frac{1}{(2r)(432-r^2)}$$; Volume of cylinder ;= $$\pi r^2h$$; =$$\pi r^2[\frac{1}{(2r)}(432-r^2)]$$;$$V=\frac{\pi }{2}(432r-r^3)$$ (SHOWN);ii) To find r for which V is stationary, we solve for r such that;$$ \frac{\mathrm{d} V}{\mathrm{d} r}=0$$;$$\frac{\mathrm{d} V}{\mathrm{d} r}= \frac{\pi }{2}(432-3r^2)$$;$$\frac{\mathrm{d} V}{\mathrm{d} r}=0 \Rightarrow  432-3r^2=0$$;$$\Rightarrow r^2=43\frac{2}{3}=144$$;r = 12 (ANS);iii) Volume of cylinder, V ;=$$ \frac{\pi }{2}r(432-r^2)$$;=$$6\pi (432-144)$$;=$$1728\pi $$;$$\approx 5430 cm^3$$ (ANS);since $$\approx 5430 cm^3$$ > 0, it is a minimum value. (ANS)

a) $$16\sin x-8\sin ^2x=5\cos ^2x$$;  $$\Rightarrow 16\sin x-8\sin ^2x = 5-5\sin ^2x$$;$$\Rightarrow 3\sin ^2x-16\sin x+5=0$$;$$\Rightarrow (3\sin x-1)(\sin x-5)=0$$;$$\Rightarrow \sin x=\frac{1}{3} or \sin x=5$$ (Rejected);therefore $$x=\sin ^{-1}(\frac{1}{3}) or x=\pi -\sin ^{-1}(\frac{1}{3})$$;Hence x = $$19.5^{\circ} or ;x=180^{\circ}-19.5^{\circ}=160.5^{\circ}$$ (ANS);ii) $$4\sin y\cos y-3\cos ^2y=0$$;$$\Rightarrow \cos y(4\sin y-3\cos y)=0$$;$$\Rightarrow \cos y=0 or 4\sin y=3\cos y$$;$$\Rightarrow y=90^{\circ},270^{\circ} or \tan y=\frac{3}{4}$$;$$\Rightarrow y=90^{\circ},270^{\circ} or y=\tan ^{-1}(\frac{3}{4}),\pi +\tan ^{-1}(\frac{3}{4})$$;$$\Rightarrow y=90^{\circ},270^{\circ} or y=36.87^{\circ},216.87^{\circ}$$;Hence y = $$36.87^{\circ}, 90^{\circ}, 216.87^{\circ}, 270^{\circ}$$ (ANS); iii)$$sec(\frac{ (3z)}{2}-18^{\circ})+2=0$$;$$\Rightarrow secx=-2$$;$$\Rightarrow \cos x=\frac{1}{(secx)}=-\frac{1}{2}$$;$$\Rightarrow x=\cos ^{-1}(\frac{1}{(-2)}) or \pi -\cos ^{-1}(\frac{1}{(-2)})$$;$$\Rightarrow x=120^{\circ} or 240^{\circ}$$;Substituting x in terms of z to find values of z,;therefore;$$ \frac{ (3z)}{2}-18^{\circ}=120^{\circ} or 240^{\circ} or 480^{\circ}$$;$$\Rightarrow \frac{ (3z)}{2}=138^{\circ} or 258^{\circ} or 498^{\circ}$$;$$\Rightarrow z=\frac{2}{3}(138^{\circ}) or \frac{2}{3}(258^{\circ}) or \frac{2}{3}(498^{\circ})$$;i.e $$z=92^{\circ} or 172^{\circ} or 332^{\circ}$$ (ANS)

a) To find C, we apply;$$\vec{AB}=\vec{DC}$$;$$\Rightarrow \vec{OB}-\vec{OA}=\vec{OC}-\vec{OD}$$;$$\Rightarrow \vec{OC}=\vec{OB}-\vec{OA}+ \vec{OD}$$;therefore $$\vec{OC} = \binom{2}{7}-\binom{-1}{4}+\binom{1}{0}))=\binom{4}{3}$$;Hence, we have C(4, 3) (ANS);To find E, by ratio theorem,;$$\vec{OE}=\frac{1}{3}(2\vec{OB}+\vec{OC})$$;=$$\frac{1}{3}[2\binom{2}{7}+\binom{4}{3}]$$;=$$\frac{1}{3}\binom{8}{17}$$;=$$\binom{\frac{8}{3}}{\frac{17}{3}}$$;Therefore E$$(\frac{8}{3}, \frac{17}{3})$$ (ANS);b) Gradient of DC = $$\frac{ (3-0)}{(4-1)}=1$$therefore equation of line is (y - 0)=1(x - 1) using D(1, 0);i.e y = x - 1........equation of line DC (ANS);therefore x-c\infty rdinate of F = $$\frac{8}{3}$$When x = $$\frac{8}{3}$$,;y = $$\frac{8}{3} - 1 = \frac{5}{3}$$;$$y - c\infty rdinate of F$$;hence $$c\infty rdinate of F$$ is $$(\frac{8}{3},\frac{5}{3})$$ (ANS);  c) Now;$$N(-1,0)\Rightarrow \vec{AN}=\vec{ON}-\vec{OA}$$;=$$(\binom{-1}{0})-(\binom{-1}{4})$$;=$$(\binom{0}{-4})$$;And ;$$\vec{EF}=\vec{OF}-\vec{OE}$$;=$$\binom{\frac{8}{3}}{\frac{5}{3}}-\binom{\frac{8}{3}}{\frac{17}{3}}=(\binom{0}{\frac{-12}{3}})$$;=$$\binom{0}{-4}$$;$$\Rightarrow \vec{AN}=\vec{EF}$$;Therefore  AN and EF are of same length and AN is parallel to EF, hence AEFN is a parallelogram (shown).;$$AN=\sqrt{0^2+4^2}=4$$;perpendicular Distance between AN and EF,;d = $$\frac{8}{3}-(-1)=\frac{11}{3}$$; therefore area of AEFN = (AN)(d);= $$(4)\frac{11}{3}$$;=$$\frac{44}{3}units^2$$ (ANS)

$$\vec{OA}-=a, \vec{OB}-=b, \vec{OC}-=a+2b$$;img;If;$$\frac{AD}{AB}=p \Rightarrow  \frac{(AD)}{(DB)}= \frac{p}{(1-p)}$$ and ;$$ \frac{(OD)}{(OC)}=q \Rightarrow \frac{( OD)}{(DC)}= \frac{q}{(1-q)}$$;  By ratio theorem,;a) $$\vec{OD}=\frac{1}{(p+(1-p))}[p\vec{OB}+(1-p)\vec{OA}]$$;=$$p(b)+(1-p)(a)$$;=pb + (1 - p)a (ANS);b)   $$\vec{OD}=q\vec{OC}=q(a+2b)$$;= qa + 2qb (ANS);By equating the two expressions for $$\vec{OD}$$ we have,;$$\vec{OD}=(1-p)a+pb=qa+2qb$$;$$1-p=q$$ ?? (1);$$p=2q$$ ??..(2);(1) + (2) yields, 1 = 3q;therefore ;q= $$\frac{1}{3}$$;Substitute q = $$\frac{1}{3}$$ into (2), ;p= 2q ;= $$\frac{2}{3}$$; Hence p = $$\frac{2}{3}$$ and q = $$\frac{1}{3}$$ (ANS)

a) i) Remainder of $$x^3-ax+a^2$$;when x = 2 is ;$$f(2)=2^3-2a+a^2 = a^2-2a+8$$ ??(1);Similarly remainder of $$ax^3-x^2-17$$ is;$$g(2)=8a+4-17=8a-13$$ ??. (2);Now;f(2) = g(2);$$\Rightarrow a^2-2a+8=8a-13$$;$$\Rightarrow a^2-10a+21=0$$;$$(a-3)(a-7)=0$$;therefore a = 3 or a =7 (ANS);ii) When a = 3, remainder is given by;f(2) = g(2) =8(3) -13 = 11 (ANS);a = 7, remainder is given by;f(2) = g(2) =8(7) -13 = 43 (ANS);b) To find x-coordinate of each of the three point s of intersection, solve the simultaneous equations.;$$y=6x^2-5$$ ??? (1);$$y=17x-\frac{6}{x}$$ ??.. (2); (1) - (2) yields,;$$6x^2-5-17x+\frac{6}{x}=0$$;$$\Rightarrow 6x^2-17x^2-5x+6=0$$;let $$f(x)=6x^2-17x^2-5x+6$$;by trial and error, we find that;$$f(\frac{1}{2})=6(\frac{1}{2})^2-17(\frac{1}{2})^2-5(\frac{1}{2})+6=0$$;therefore $$(x-\frac{1}{2})$$ or $$(2x - 1)$$ is a factor of f(x).;img;therefore ;$$f(x)=6x^2-17x^2-5x+6$$;=$$(2x-1)(3x^2-7x-6)$$;=$$(3x+2)(x-3)(2x-1)$$;$$\Rightarrow 6x^2-17x^2-5x+6=(3x+2)(x-3)(2x-1)=0$$;and hence ;$$x=\frac{2}{3},\frac{1}{2} or 3$$ (ANS);c) To find k, we attempt to factorize $$x^3-5x^2+12$$ into a linear factor and a quadratic factor.;Let $$g(x)=x^3-5x^2+12$$;By trial and error,;$$g(2)=2^3-5(2)^2+12=8-20+12=0$$;therefore (x - 2) is a factor of g(x);img;Hence ;$$g(x)=x^3-5x^2+12$$;=$$(x-2)(x^2-3x-6)$$;If $$x^2-3x+k$$ is a factor of $$x^3-5x^2+12$$ then it must be $$x^2-3x-6$$;therefore k = - 6 (ANS)

a) Let a be the first term and d be the common difference of the A.P.;$$\Rightarrow T_10=10th term of the AP=a+9d=40$$;$$S_10=Sum of the first 10 terms of the AP=5(2a+9d)=265$$;Now;$$a+9d=40$$ ??..(1);$$2a+9d=53$$ ??(2); (2) - (1) yield a = 53 - 40 = 13;When a = 13,; $$d=\frac{ (40-a)}{9}=\frac{ (40-13)}{9}=\frac{27}{9}=3$$;therefore first term of A.P, a = 13;common difference of A.P, d = 3;Hence sum of the first 20 terms of the A.P is given by;$$S_20=\frac{20}{2}(2a+19d)=10(26+57)$$;= 830 (ANS);b) Let a be the first term and r be the common difference of the G.P.;$$\Rightarrow T_1=a=100$$;$$T_2=ar=120=\frac{120}{a}=\frac{120}{100}=1.20$$;To find k, we find the kth term of the G.P which is ;$$T_k=ar^{k-1}=100(1.2)^{k-1}$$;To find k such that; $$T_k<5000$$;$$100(1.2)^{k-1}<5000$$;$$\Rightarrow (1.2)^{k-1}<50$$;$$\Rightarrow (k-1)\log (1.2)<\log 50$$;$$\Rightarrow (k-1)(0.07918)<1.69897$$;$$\Rightarrow k<\frac{1.69897}{0.07918}+1$$;$$\Rightarrow k<22.46$$;therefore largest integer for k is k = 22 (ANS);Hence the sum of the first k(= 22) terms of the G.P is;$$S_22=a\frac{ (r^k-1)}{(r-1)}$$;=$$100(\frac{ ((1.2)^{(k-1)}}{(1.2-1)})$$;=$$100(\frac{54.2061}{0.2})$$;=27103.07;$$\approx  27103$$ (ANS);c) Let a and r be the first term and common ratio of t he initial G.P.;Now;$$\Rightarrow T_1=a=18$$;$$S_\infty =\frac{a}{(1-r)}=30$$;From which, we may write;a = 18;$$r=1-\frac{a}{30}=1-1\frac{8}{30}=1-\frac{3}{5}=\frac{2}{5}=0.4$$;EAch term of the initial G.P is squared to form a new geometrical progress. Now the new G.P has $$a^2$$ as the first term and $$r^2$$as the common ratio.;Hence the first term of the new G.P,;b = $$a^2=18^2=324$$;	common ratio of the new G.P, ;t = $$r^2=0.4^2=0.16$$  ;The sum to infinity of the new progression is thus;$$S_\infty =\frac{b}{(1-t)}= \frac{324}{(1-0.16)}= \frac{324}{0.84}=385.71$$; \approx 386 (ANS)

a) i) Compute the values of xy and $$x^3$$ for each corresponding value of x and plot the graph of  xy versus $$x^3$$;img; From the graph, gradient of the line = $$-\frac{Y}{Xz}=-\frac{79}{5z}=-15.8$$;$$\Rightarrow (xy-79)=-15.8(x^3-1)$$;$$\Rightarrow xy=-15.8x^3+94.8$$;i.e $$y=-15.8x^2+\frac{94.8}{x}$$ (ANS);ii) when  ; $$y=\frac{60}{x} \Rightarrow  xy=60$$;From the graph,;$$x^3=2.2\Rightarrow x=(2.2)^{\frac{1}{3}}$$;$$\approx 1.30$$ (ANS);b) Now the line equation of (xy - x) against y is given by;$$ \frac{ ((xy-x)-1)}{(y-2)}= \frac{ (2-1)}{(1.5-2)}=- \frac{1}{0.5}=-2$$;$$\Rightarrow xy-x-1=-2y+4$$;$$\Rightarrow xy+2y=x+5$$;$$\Rightarrow y(x+2)=x+5$$;therefore; $$y=\frac{ (x+5)}{(x+2)}$$;Hence c = 5 and d = 2 (ANS)

a) i) $$2\cos 2x=4\sin x+3$$;$$\Rightarrow 2(1-2\sin ^2x)=4\sin x+3$$;$$\Rightarrow 2-4\sin ^2x=4\sin x+3$$;$$\Rightarrow 4\sin ^2x+4\sin x+1=0$$;$$\Rightarrow (2\sin x+1)^2=0$$;$$\Rightarrow 2\sin x+1=0$$;$$\Rightarrow \sin x=-\frac{1}{2}$$;hence $$x=210^{\circ},330^{\circ}$$ (ANS);ii) $$\sin (y+30^{\circ})=3\cos y$$;$$\Rightarrow \sin y\cos 30^{\circ}+\cos y\sin 30^{\circ}=3\cos y$$;$$\Rightarrow \sqrt{\frac{3}{2}}\sin y+\frac{1}{2}\cos y=3\cos y$$;$$\Rightarrow \sqrt{\frac{3}{2}}\sin y=\frac{5}{2}\cos y$$;$$\Rightarrow \tan y=\frac{5}{\sqrt3}=2.8868$$;therefore $$y=70.9^{\circ},250.9^{\circ}$$ (ANS); b) Let ;$$3\cos x-4\sin x-=R\cos (x+\alpha )$$;$$\Rightarrow 3\cos x-4\sin x=R\cos \alpha \cos x-R\sin \alpha \sin x$$;$$R\cos \alpha =3$$ ??(1);$$R\sin \alpha =4$$ ??.(2);$$(1)^2+(2)^2$$ yield;$$R^2(\cos ^2\alpha +\sin ^2\alpha )=R^2=3^2+4^2=5^2$$;therefore R = 5;(2) + (1) yield;$$\tan \alpha =\frac{4}{3}\Rightarrow \alpha =\tan ^{-1}(\frac{4}{3})=0.927rad$$;therefore;$$3\cos x-4\sin x=5\cos (x+0.927)$$;i) The point  on the curve at which y = 1 is given by;$$3\cos x-4\sin x=1$$;$$\Rightarrow 5\cos (x+0.927)=1$$;$$\Rightarrow \cos (x+0.927)=\frac{1}{5}$$;$$\Rightarrow x+0.927=1.369$$;$$\Rightarrow x=0.422rad$$;There the coordinate of the point  is (0.422,1) (ANS);ii)$$y=3\cos x-4\sin x=5\cos (x+0.927)$$;$$\Rightarrow \frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x}=-5\sin (x+0.927)$$;therefore  \sin (x + 0.927) = 0 at stationary point  of the curve;$$\Rightarrow x+0.927=\pi $$;$$\Rightarrow x=\pi -0.927=2.215$$;when x = 2.215;$$y = 5\cos (x + 0.927) = 5\cos \pi  =- 5$$;therefore the coordinates of the stationary point  for $$0\leq x\leq \pi $$ is (2.215, - 5). (ANS)

a) Let z = \sin  x and $$z^2=\sin ^2x$$Now ;$$\frac{\mathrm{d} }{\mathrm{d} x}(z^2)=2z\frac{\mathrm{d}z}{\mathrm{d} x}; \frac{\mathrm{d}z}{\mathrm{d} x}=\cos x$$;therefore $$\frac{\mathrm{d} }{\mathrm{d} x}(\sin ^2x)=2\sin x\cos x=\sin 2x$$ (ANS);b) $$\frac{\mathrm{d} }{\mathrm{d} x}(\frac{ (2x-3)}{(x+5)})= \frac{ ((x+5)(2)-(2x-3)(1))}{(x+5)^2}$$;Therefore $$\frac{\mathrm{d} }{\mathrm{d} x}\frac{ ((2x-3)}{(x+5))}= \frac{ (2x+10-2x-3)}{(x+5)^2}=\frac{13}{(x+5)^2}=\frac{k}{(x+5)^2}$$;hence k = 13 (ANS);c) $$y^2=x^2+2xy+8$$when x = 2;$$y^2=4+4y+8$$;$$\Rightarrow y^2-4y-12=0$$;$$\Rightarrow (y-6)(y+2)=0$$;therefore y = +6 or y = - 2;Hence the two point s are A(2, - 2)and B(2, 6) ;Now by differentiating the equation, we have;$$2y\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x}=2x+2x\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x}+2y$$;$$\Rightarrow (y-x)\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x}=y+x$$;$$\Rightarrow \frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x}=\frac{ (y+x)}{(y-x)}$$;Thus for A(2, - 2) the gradient at A is ;$$\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x}=\frac{-2+2}{-2-2}=0$$ (ANS);Similarly for B(2, 6) the gradient at B is;$$\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x}=\frac{ (6+2)}{(6-2)}= \frac{8}{4}=2$$ (ANS);d)i) $$y=\frac{c}{(1+2x)^2}$$;$$\Rightarrow \frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x}=\frac{ (-2c)}{(1+2x)^3(2)}=- \frac{ (4c)}{(1+2x)^3}$$ (ANS);ii) When x increases from 1 to 1 + p,;$$gradx = (1+p)-1=p$$;$$\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x}$$ at x = 1 is given by $$\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x}=-\frac{ (4c)}{(3^3)}=- \frac{ (4c)}{27}$$;Thus by applying,; $$grad y\approx (\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x})grad x$$;for small increment in x, incremental change in y is given by;$$grad y\approx (-\frac{ (4c)}{27})p=\frac{ (-4cp)}{27}$$;Given;$$grad y=-\frac{ (8p)}{3}\Rightarrow -\frac{ (8p)}{3}=\frac{ (-4cp)}{27}$$;$$\Rightarrow c=(\frac{8}{3})(\frac{27}{4})=18$$ (ANS)

a) $$\int \sqrt{4x+5}dx=\frac{2}{3}(\frac{1}{4})(4x+5)^{(\frac{3}{2})}+c$$;=$$\frac{1}{6} (4x+5)^{(\frac{3}{2})}+c$$ (ANS);b) i)$$v=8\cos (\frac{t}{4} )$$;When at instantaneous rest, v = 0;$$\Rightarrow 8\cos (\frac{t}{4} )=0$$;$$\Rightarrow \cos (\frac{t}{4} )=0$$;$$\Rightarrow \frac{t}{4} =\frac{\pi }{2}$$;i.e $$t=2\pi =6.28sec$$ (ANS);ii) Distance travelled in the first 4 seconds,;$$s=\int _{t=0}^4vdt$$;=$$8\int _0^4\cos (\frac{t}{4} )dt$$;=$$8[4\sin (\frac{t}{4} )]_0^4$$;=$$32(\sin 1-\sin 0)$$;=$$32(0.8415-0)$$;$$\approx 27m$$ (ANS);img;c)i) Area under the curve $$y=\frac{12}{(x+3)}$$ from x = 1 to x = 3 is given by;$$A_1=\int _1^3ydx$$;=$$\int _1^3(\frac{12}{(x+3)})dx$$;=$$12[\ln (x+3)]_1^3$$;=$$12[\ln 6-\ln 4]$$;=$$12\ln (\frac{6}{4})$$;= 12\ln (1.5);=$$4.8656 units^2$$;Area of trapezium ocpq is ;$$A_2=\frac{1}{2}(op+cq)(3-1)=op+cq where$$;$$op=y(x=1)= \frac{12}{(1+3)}=\frac{12}{4}=3$$;$$cq=y(x=3)= \frac{12}{(3+3)}= \frac{12}{6}=2$$;Therefore  $$A_2=3+2=5units^2$$;Area of shaded region = 5 - 4.8656 = 0.1344 ;$$\approx 0.13 units^2$$ (ANS)

i) $$\frac{\mathrm{d}x }{\mathrm{d} t}=4t-\frac{9}{t^2} , \frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} t}=2$$;Therefore,;$$\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x}=\frac{\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} t}}{\frac{\mathrm{d} x}{\mathrm{d} t}}$$;=$$\frac{2}{(4t-\frac{9}{t^2})}$$;=$$ \frac{ (2t^2)}{(4t^2-9)}$$ (ANS);ii) To find equation of tangent at (13, - 3), need to know the gradient of the tangent at the point  ;Now y = 2t -  5 =- 3;t = 1;Therefore gradient of tangent at (13, - 3);=$$ \frac{ (y-(-3))}{(x-13)}=-\frac{2}{5}$$;$$\Rightarrow 5y+15=-2x+26$$;$$\Rightarrow 5y=-2x+11$$;When y = 0,;$$x=\frac{ (11-5y)}{2}=1\frac{1}{2}=5.5$$;Thus the tangent meets the x - axis (i.e y = 0) at point  (5.5, 0) (ANS);iii) Now $$\frac{\mathrm{d} x}{\mathrm{d} y}=\frac{1}{(\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x})} = \frac{ (4t^2-9)}{(2t^2)}$$;Thus ;$$\frac{\mathrm{d} x}{\mathrm{d} y}=0$$;$$\Rightarrow \frac{ (4t^2-9)}{(2t^2)}=0$$;$$\Rightarrow 4t^2-9=0$$;$$\Rightarrow t^2=\frac{9}{4}$$;$$\Rightarrow t= +-\frac{3}{2}$$;when $$t=-\frac{3}{2},$$;$$x=4(-\frac{3}{2})+\frac{9 }{ (-\frac{3}{2})}=-6-6=-12$$;$$y=2(-\frac{3}{2})-5=-3-5=-8$$;therefore (x, y) = (- 12, 8) at $$t=-\frac{3}{2}$$;$$t=\frac{3}{2}$$;$$x=4(\frac{3}{2})+\frac{9 }{ (\frac{3}{2})}=12$$;$$y=2(\frac{3}{2})-5=3-5=-2$$;therefore (x, y) = (12, - 2) at $$t=\frac{3}{2}$$;Hence the coordinates of each of the point s on the curve at which the tangent to the curve is parallel to the y-axis are (- 12, - 8) and (12, - 2) respectively. (ANS);iv) $$(4t+\frac{9}{t})+(2t-5)=16$$;$$\Rightarrow 6t-21+\frac{9}{t}=0$$;$$\Rightarrow 6t^2-21t+3=0$$;$$\Rightarrow 2t^2-7t+1=0$$;$$\Rightarrow (2t-1)(t-3)=0$$;therefore ;$$t=\frac{1}{2} or t=3$$ (ANS);v) Now;$$x=\frac{4t+9}{t}$$ ??(1);$$y=2t-5$$ ??...(2);From (2) we have ;$$ \frac{ (y+5)}{2}=t$$;By substituting $$\frac{ (y+5)}{2}=t$$ into(1) we have;$$x=4\frac{ ((y+5)}{2)+9}{(\frac{ (y+5)}{2})}$$;$$\Rightarrow x=\frac{ (2(y+5)^2+18)}{(y+5)}$$;$$\Rightarrow x=2\frac{ ((y+5)^2+9)}{(y+5)}$$;x =$$\frac{ (2y^2+20y+68)}{(y+5)}$$ (ANS)

From;$$pq^2=144$$;$$\Rightarrow p=\frac{144}{q^2}$$;therefore;$$\frac{\mathrm{d} p}{\mathrm{d} q}=144(\frac{(-2)}{(q^3)})=\frac{-288}{q^3}$$ (ANS);Now ;$$q=q_0=6, gradq=k$$;$$\frac{\mathrm{d} p}{\mathrm{d} q}=\frac{(-288)}{q^3}=\frac{(-288)}{6^3}=\frac{-4}{3}$$;therefore;$$gradp=\frac{(-4)}{3} \times  k = \frac{(-4)}{3}k$$ (ANS)

To find P, solve the equations;$$y=2x$$;$$y=4\sqrt x$$;$$\Rightarrow 2x=4\sqrt x$$;$$\Rightarrow 2(\sqrt x)(\sqrt {x-2})=0$$;$$\Rightarrow \sqrt x=0$$(rejected) or $$\sqrt x=2$$;x = 4;y = 2(4) = 8;therefore coordinates of P is (4, 8) (ANS);Volume generated;= $$\pi \int _0^4{(4\sqrt x)^2-(2x)^2}dx$$;=$$\pi \int _0^4{16x-4x^2}dx$$;=$$4\pi [2x^2-\frac{ (x^3)}{3}]_0^4$$;=$$4\pi [32-\frac{64}{3}]$$;=$$\frac{ (128\pi )}{3}units^3$$ (ANS)

a) To find  term in x in the expansion of $$(x-\frac{2}{x})^7$$, we solve for r so that $$T_r$$ is in x, i.e.,;$$7-2r=1 or r=\frac{ (7-1)}{2}=3$$;Thus coefficient of x is given by; $$^7C_3(-2)^3=-280$$; (ANS);b)Now;$$(1-\frac{x}{2})^8=1-8(\frac{x}{2})+28(\frac{x}{2})^2-56(\frac{x}{2})^3+...$$;=$$1-4x+7x^2-7x^3+...$$;Thus $$(2+5x)(1-\frac{x}{2})^8=(2+5x)(1-4x+7x^2-7x^3+...)$$;and terms in $$x^3$$ is given by;$$2(-7x^3)+5x(7x^2)=-14x^3+35x^3=21x^3$$;Hence the coefficient of $$x^3$$ in the expansion of $$(2+5x)(1-\frac{x}{2})^8$$ is 21. (ANS)

$$f(x)=2x^2-6x+7$$;=$$2(x^2-3x)+7$$;=$$2[(x-\frac{3}{2})^2-\frac{9}{4}]+7$$;Or;$$f(x)=2(x-\frac{3}{2})^2+\frac{5}{2}$$;Now when x = 0, f(0) = 7;x = 4, ;$$f(4)=2(\frac{5}{2})^2+\frac{5}{2}=15$$;But minimum value of f(x) occurs at $$x=\frac{3}{2}$$ whose value is given by;$$f(\frac{3}{2})=\frac{5}{2}$$;Therefore range of the function $$f:x \mapsto  2x^2-6x+7$$ for the domain $$0\leq x\leq 4$$ is $$2 \frac{1}{2}\leq f(x)\leq 15$$ (ANS)

a) $$y=(2x+1)(4-x^2)$$;$$\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x}=2(4-x^2)+(-2x)(2x+1)$$;=$$8-2x^2-4x^2-2x$$;=$$8-2x-6x^2$$ ;Stationary point  of curve y are obtained by setting ;$$\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x}=0$$;$$\Rightarrow 3x^2+x-4=0$$;$$\Rightarrow (3x+4)(x-1)=0$$;$$x=-\frac{4}{3} or x=1$$;when $$x=-\frac{4}{3}$$, ;$$y=(1-\frac{8}{3})(4-\frac{16}{9})=-\frac{100}{27}$$;when x = 1, y = (3)(3) = 9;Now;	$$\frac{\mathrm{d}^{2} y}{\mathrm{d} x^{2}}=-2-12x$$;when $$x=-\frac{4}{3}$$;$$\frac{\mathrm{d}^{2} y}{\mathrm{d} x^{2}}=-2-12(-\frac{4}{3})=-2+16=14>0$$;and hence $$(-\frac{4}{3},-\frac{100}{27})$$ is a minimum point  of the curve. (ANS);When x = 1,;$$ \frac{\mathrm{d}^{2} y}{\mathrm{d} x^{2}}=-2-12(1)=-14<0$$;and hence (1, 9) is a maximum point of the curve. (ANS);b)9x + 8y = 720 or 8y = 720 - 9x....(1);Area, A, in terms of x and y is given by;$$A=6xy=\frac{ (3x)}{4(8y)}= \frac{ (3x)}{4(720-9x)}$$;$$A=\frac{3}{4}(720-9x^2)$$ (SHOWN);To find x such that A is a maximum, we set;$$ \frac{\mathrm{d} A}{\mathrm{d} x} =0$$;$$\Rightarrow 720-18x=0$$;$$x=40 and y=\frac{1}{8}(720-360)=45$$;and check that;$$ \frac{\mathrm{d}^{2} y}{\mathrm{d} x^{2}}=-\frac{27}{2}<0$$;Thus when x = 40 m and y = 45 m, the area A is a maximum. a) $$\vec{OA}-=\binom{2}{3}, \vec{OB}-=\binom{5}{1}$$;$$\vec{OC}=\vec{OA}+\vec{OB}=\binom{2}{3}+\binom{5}{1}=\binom{7}{4}$$;Thus;$$\vec{AB}=\vec{OB}-\vec{OA}=\binom{5}{1}-\binom{2}{3}=\binom{3}{-2}$$;$$\vec{AC}=\vec{OB}-=\binom{5}{1}$$;$$\Rightarrow \vec{AB}\ast \vec{AC}=\binom{3}{-2}\ast \binom{5}{1}$$;       = 15 - 2 = 13 (ANS);But ;$$\Rightarrow \vec{AB}\ast \vec{AC}=(AB)(AC)\cos (CAB)$$;$$\Rightarrow 13=(\sqrt{3^2+2^2})(\sqrt{5^2+1^2})\cos (CAB)$$;$$\cos (CAB)= \frac{13}{(\sqrt{13}\sqrt{26})}= \frac{13}{(13\sqrt2)}= \frac{1}{\sqrt2}$$ (ANS);Therefore ;$$CAB = 45^{\circ} $$ (ANS);b)$$\vec{OP}=p$$;$$\vec{OQ}=q$$;$$\vec{OR}=4p$$;$$\vec{OM}=\frac{1}{2}(\vec{OP}+\vec{OQ})=\frac{1}{2}(p+q)$$;Therefore ;$$\vec{OS}=\frac{8}{5}(\vec{OM}=\frac{8}{5}\ast \frac{1}{2}(p+q)= \frac{4}{5}(p+q)$$ (ANS);and ;$$\vec{QR}=\vec{OR}-\vec{OQ}=4p-q$$ (ANS);Now;$$\vec{QS}=\vec{OS}-\vec{OQ}$$;=$$\frac{4}{5}(p+q)-q$$;=$$\frac{1}{5}(4p+4q-5q)$$;=$$ \frac{1}{5}(4p-q)$$;$$\vec{SR}=\vec{OR}-\vec{OS}$$;=$$4p-\frac{4}{5}(p+q)$$;=$$ \frac{4}{5}(5p-p-q)$$;=$$ \frac{4}{5}(4p-q)$$;Therefore ;$$\vec{QS}=\frac{1}{4}[\frac{4}{5}(4p-q)]= \frac{1}{4}\vec{SR}$$;since $$\frac{QS}{SR}$$ and S is a common point , QSR is thus a straight line and hence S lies on R (proved);Now;$$\vec{QS}=\frac{1}{4}\vec{SR}$$;$$\Rightarrow QS=\frac{1}{4}SR$$;i.e QS:SR = 1:4 (ANS)

$$y=\frac{x^2}{9}+\frac{x}{6}+k$$;Area of region A = $$\int _0^6ydx=23 units^2$$;$$\Rightarrow area A=\int _0^6\frac{ (x^2)}{9}+\frac{x}{6}+kdx$$;=$$[\frac{1}{27}x^3+\frac{1}{12}x^2+kx]_0^6$$;=$$8 + 3 + 6k$$;=$$11 + 6k$$;$$\Rightarrow 11+6k=23$$;	Therefore;$$k=\frac{ (23-11)}{6}$$;=$$\frac{12}{6}$$;= 2 (SHOWN); i) Now $$y=\frac{x^2}{9}+\frac{x}{6}+2$$;Coordinates of P is $$P -= (6, 7)$$ and;$$\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x}=\frac{2}{9x}+\frac{1}{6}$$;Gradient of tangent at P = $$\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x}=\frac{2}{9}(6)+ \frac{1}{6}=\frac{3}{2}$$;Gradient of normal at P = $$-\frac{1}{(\frac{3}{2})}=-\frac{2}{3}$$ ;Therefore equation of normal PQ is thus given by;$$y-7=-\frac{2}{3}(x-6)$$;$$\Rightarrow y=-\frac{2}{3}x+11$$ ? (line PQ);Coordinates of is thus $$Q -= (0, 11)$$ (ANS);img;ii) Area of trapezium QXPQ;= $$\frac{1}{2}(6)(OQ+PX)$$;=$$3(11+7)$$;=$$54units^2$$;Therefore area of B = area of trapezium QXPQ - area of A = 54 - 23 = $$31 units^2$$ (ANS)

a) Let $$f(x)=4x^4-9a^2x^2+2(a^2-7)x-18$$;since f(x) is divisible by (2x - 3a), by factor theorem,;$$f(\frac{3}{2}a)=0$$;$$\Rightarrow 4(\frac{3}{2}a)^4-9a^2(\frac{3}{2}a)^2+2(a^2-7)(\frac{3}{2}a)-18=0$$;$$\Rightarrow\frac{ (81a^4)}{4}-\frac{ (81a^4)}{4+3a(a^2-7)}-18=0$$;$$\Rightarrow a^3-7a-6=0$$ (shown);To find a, we solve for a from the equation;$$a^3-7a-6=0$$;Now when a = - 1,;$$a^3-7a-6=-1+7-6=0$$;Therefore (a + 1) is a factor of ;$$a^3-7a-6$$;$$\Rightarrow a^3-7a-6=(a+1)(a^2-a-6)$$;$$=(a+1)(a+2)(a-3)$$;therefore;$$a^3-7a-6=(a+1)(a+2)(a-3)=0$$;Hence a = -1, or a = 2 or a = 3 (ANS);b) Let;$$f(x)=2x^3+bx^2-cx+d$$;since f(x) has the same remainder when divided by x +1 or x - 2 or 2x - 1, then;$$f(-1)=f(2)=f(\frac{1}{2})$$;$$\Rightarrow -2+b+c+d=16+4b-2c+d$$;=$$\frac{1}{4}+\frac{1}{4}b-\frac{1}{2}c+d$$;$$\Rightarrow -2+b+c+d=16+4b-2c+d$$;$$\Rightarrow -2+b+c+d=\frac{1}{4}+\frac{1}{4}b-\frac{1}{2}c+d$$;$$\Rightarrow b-c=-6$$ ??.(1);$$\Rightarrow b+2c=3$$ ??(2);Solving the two equations, we have ;(2) - (1) ;3c = 3 + 6 = 9;c = 3 (ANS);and hence b = 3 - 2c = - 3 (ANS);Now;$$f(x)=2x^3-3x^2-3x+d$$;since f(x) is exactly divisible by ( x + 2), we have ;f(- 2) = 0;- 16 - 12 + 6 + d = 0;therefore d = 22 (ANS)

a) The length of sides of polygon are in A.P.;Thus a = first term of the A.P = length of the shortest side of polygon = 1.3 m.;b = last term of the A.P = length of the longest side of polygon = 5.7 m.;$$\Rightarrow 42=\frac{1}{2}n(1.3+5.7)\Rightarrow n=\frac{84}{7.0}=12$$;Thus the polygon has 12 sides. (ANS);b) $$T_1$$ = first term of G.P = 25 = a;$$S_1$$ = sum of the first three terms of G.P;= $$a\frac{ (1-r^3)}{(1-r)}$$;= $$25(\frac{ (1-r^3)}{(1-r)})$$  ;where r = common ratio of G.P.;$$\Rightarrow 25(\frac{ (1-r^3)}{(1-r)})=61\Rightarrow 25(r^2+r+1)=61$$;$$\Rightarrow 25r^2+25r-36=0\Rightarrow (5r+9)(5r-4)=0$$;$$r=-\frac{9}{5 }or r=\frac{4}{5}$$;since the G.P has a sum to infinity, then |r| < 1and hence ;$$r=\frac{4}{5}$$(ANS);Therefore;$$S_oo=\frac{a}{(1-r)}=\frac{25}{(1-\frac{4}{5})}=(25)(5)=125$$ (ANS);c)i) The distances walked by the man form a G.P.;Thus a = distance walked on first day dated 1st June = 35 km;r = common ratio of G.P = 95% = 0.95;Now on 10th June, he has already continued his journey for 10 days, thus distance walked is;$$d=S_10=a(\frac{ (1-r^10)}{(1-r)c})$$;=$$35(\frac{ (1-0.95^10)}{(1-0.95)})=700(1-0.5987)$$;=$$280.91$$;$$\approx 281km$$ (ANS);ii) To complete the walk, if n is the number of days he walks, then;$$S_n\geq 480$$;$$\Rightarrow 35(\frac{ (1-0.95^n)}{(1-0.95)})\geq 480$$;$$\Rightarrow 1-0.95^n\geq 0.6857$$;$$\Rightarrow 0.95^n\leq 0.3143$$;$$\Rightarrow n\geq \frac{(\log (0.3143))}{(\log 0.95)}since \log  0.95<0)$$;$$\Rightarrow n\geq \frac{ (-0.5027)}{(-0.02228)}$$;$$\Rightarrow n\geq 22.56$$;Thus n is 23. i.e he needs 23 days to complete the journey. Hence he will complete the walk on 23rd June. (ANS)

a) i)$$ \frac{\mathrm{d} }{\mathrm{d} x} \cos ^2x$$;=$$(2\cos x) \frac{\mathrm{d} }{\mathrm{d} x} (\cos x)$$;=$$(2\cos x)(-\sin x)$$;=$$-\sin 2x$$ (ANS);ii)   $$\frac{\mathrm{d} }{\mathrm{d} x} (e^{(3-2x)})$$;=$$e^{(3-2x)}\frac{\mathrm{d} }{\mathrm{d} x}(3-2x)$$;=$$-2e^{3-2x}$$ (ANS);b)$$y=\frac{ (3x)}{(2x-3)}$$;=$$\frac{3}{2}(\frac{ (2x)}{(2x-3)})$$;=$$\frac{3}{2}+\frac{9}{(2(2x-3))}$$;$$\Rightarrow \frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x}=\frac{9}{2}[-\frac{2}{(2x-3)^2}]$$ ;=$$- \frac{9}{(2x-3)^2}$$;$$\Rightarrow -\frac{9}{(2x-3)^2}=-\frac{9}{4}$$;$$\Rightarrow (2x-3)^2=4$$;$$\Rightarrow 2x-3= \pm 2$$;$$\Rightarrow x=\frac{5}{2} or x=\frac{1}{2}$$ (ANS);c) $$xy^2-y^3+4=0$$;$$y=2\Rightarrow 4x-8+4=0\Rightarrow x=1$$;Thus the point on the curve is $$P -= (1, 2)$$.;Now by differentiating the given curve equation,;$$2xy\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x}+y^2-3y^2\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x}=0$$;$$\Rightarrow (3y-2x)\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x}=y$$;$$\Rightarrow \frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x}=\frac{y}{(3y-2x)}$$;Thus at point $$P -= (1, 2)$$, gradient of curve is ;$$\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x}=\frac{2}{(6-2)}= \frac{2}{4}=\frac{1}{2}$$ (ANS)

i) The points of intersection of curve with 5y = x - 2 are given by;$$x=\frac{t+1}{t-1}, y=\frac{t-1}{t-1}  where  t\neq 0$$;$$5(\frac{t-1}{t-1})=(\frac{t+1}{t-1})-2$$;$$\Rightarrow 5t-\frac{5}{t}-5=t+\frac{1}{t}-3$$;$$\Rightarrow 4t-2-\frac{6}{t}=0$$;$$\Rightarrow 2t^2-t-3=0$$;$$\Rightarrow (2t-3)(t+1)=0$$;Thus t = - 1 or t = $$\frac{3}{2}$$ (ANS);ii) $$\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x}=1+\frac{1}{t^2}=\frac{ (1+t^2)}{t^2}$$;$$\frac{\mathrm{d} x}{\mathrm{d} t}=1-\frac{1}{t^2}=\frac{ (t^2-1)}{t^2}$$;Therefore;$$\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x}=\frac{\frac{\mathrm{d}y }{\mathrm{d} t}}{\frac{\mathrm{d}x }{\mathrm{d} t}}=\frac{\frac{ (1+t^2)}{(t^2)}}{( \frac{ (t^2-1)}{t^2})}$$;=$$\frac{ (t^2+1)}{(t^2-1)}$$ (ANS);iii) Now;$$\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x}=\frac{-5}{3}$$;$$\Rightarrow\frac{ (t^2+1)}{(t^2-1)}= \frac{ (-5)}{3}$$;$$\Rightarrow 5t^2-5=-3t^2-3$$;$$\Rightarrow 8t^2=2$$;$$\Rightarrow t^2=\frac{1}{4}$$;$$t=\pm \frac{1}{2}$$;When $$t=-\frac{1}{2}$$,;$$x=-\frac{1}{2}-2-1=-\frac{7}{2}$$;$$y=-\frac{1}{2}+2-1=\frac{1}{2}$$;When $$t=\frac{1}{2}$$,;$$x=\frac{1}{2}+2-1=\frac{3}{2}$$;$$y=\frac{1}{2}-2-1=-\frac{5}{2}$$;Thus $$P-=(\frac{ (-7)}{2},\frac{1}{2})$$;and $$Q-=(\frac{3}{2},-\frac{5}{2})$$;Hence mid-point of line;$$PQ-=[\frac{1}{2}(-\frac{7}{2}+\frac{3}{2}),\frac{1}{2}(\frac{1}{2}-\frac{5}{2})]-=(-1,-1)$$ (ANS);iv);img;img v) $$x=t+\frac{1}{t}-1\Rightarrow t+\frac{1}{t}=x+1\Rightarrow t=\frac{1}{2}[(x+1)+(y+1)]=\frac{1}{2}(x+y+2)$$;$$y=t-\frac{1}{t}-1\Rightarrow t-\frac{1}{t}=y+1\Rightarrow \frac{1}{t}=\frac{1}{2}[(x+1)-(y+1)]=\frac{1}{2}(x-y)$$;Now;$$t(\frac{1}{t})=1$$;$$\Rightarrow \frac{1}{4}(x+y+2)(x-y)=1$$;Hence (x - y)(x + y +2) = 4 is the cartesian equation of the curve. (ANS)

a) $$(\frac{x^2-3}{x})^5$$ has a general, $$T_r$$ term given as ;$$T_r=^5C_r(x)^r(\frac{-3}{x})^{(5-r)}$$;where r = 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5.;Thus to find the term of $$x^1$$, we have;2r - (5 - r) = 1;3r = 6;r = 2;Thus the term of interest is the T2 term where,;$$T_2=^5C_2(x)^2(\frac{-3}{x})^{(3)}$$;= (10)(-27)x;= -270x;therefore coefficient of x is - 270 (ANS);b)$$(1+p)^7=1+7p+^7C_2p^2+^7C_3p^3+...$$;=$$1+7p+21p^2+35p^3+...$$ (ANS);  By substituting $$p=x^2+2x^2$$;we have,;$$(1+x+2x^2)^7$$;=$$1+7(x+2x^2)+21(x+2x^2)^2+35(x+2x^2)^3+...$$;=$$1+(7x+14x^2)+21x^2(1+2x)^2+35x^3(1+2x)^3+...$$;The only two $$x^3$$ terms are in $$21x^2(1+2x)^2$$ and $$35x^3(1+2x)^3$$ which are given as,;$$21x^2(4x) and 35x^3$$ respectively. This can be combined as $$119x^3$$;Hence coefficient of $$x^3$$ in the expansion of $$(1+x+2x^2)^7$$ is 119. (ANS)

img;i) Radius of the base of the water at height x is given by;$$r=(\frac{20}{60})x=\frac{1}{3}x$$;Volume, v, of t he water in the container is thus,;$$v=\frac{1}{3}(\pi r^2)x$$;=$$\frac{1}{3}\pi (\frac{1}{3}x)^2x$$;=$$\frac{1}{3}\pi (\frac{1}{9}x^2)x$$;=$$\frac{ (\pi x^3)}{27}$$ (Shown);ii)Now;$$\frac{\mathrm{d} v}{\mathrm{d} t}=40cm^3s^{-1}$$ and ;$$ \frac{ (\pi x^2)}{9}=\frac{ (\pi (2)^2)}{9}=\frac{ (4\pi )}{9}$$ when x = 2;therefore ;$$40=(\frac{ (4\pi )}{9})(\frac{\mathrm{d} x}{\mathrm{d} t})$$;$$\Rightarrow \frac{\mathrm{d} x}{\mathrm{d} t}=40(\frac{9}{(4\pi )})= \frac{90}{\pi} $$;$$\approx 28.6cms^{-1}$$ (ANS)

i) $$v=t^2-4t-5, t\geq 0$$;$$\Rightarrow  acceleration,a=\frac{\mathrm{d} v}{\mathrm{d} t}=2t-4,t\geq 0$$ (ANS); ii)   The distance of P from B is given by,;$$S=\int vdt$$;=$$\int (t^2-4t-5)dt$$;=$$\frac{t^3}{3-2t^2-5t}+c$$;At t = 0, s =4;c = 4;Therefore distance of P from A is ;$$| \frac{t^3}{3-2t^2-5t+4}|$$ (ANS);iii) When P comes to instantaneously to rest,;$$v=0$$;$$\Rightarrow t^2-4t-5=0$$;$$\Rightarrow (t-5)(t+1)=0$$;$$\Rightarrow t=5$$;Therefore distance of P from A is;$$| \frac{5^3}{3}-2(5)^2-5(5)+4|= 29 \frac{1}{3}m$$ (ANS);iv)Between t = 0 to t = 5, distance travelled by P is $$\frac{100}{3}m$$ ;as computed in part (iii). Between t = 5 to t = 10, the distance travelled by P is;$$\int _5^10[t^2-4t-5]dt$$;=$$[\frac{1}{3}t^3-2t^2-5t]_5^10$$;=$$[\frac{1000}{3}-200-50]-[\frac{1}{3}(5)^3-2(5)^2-(5)(5)]$$;=$$ \frac{250}{3}-\frac{-100}{3}$$;=$$ \frac{350}{3}$$;Thus the total distance travelled by P from t = 0 to t = 10 is;$$ \frac{350}{3} + \frac{100}{3}$$ or 150m (ANS)

a) $$y=27+12x+3x^2-2x^3$$;$$\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x}=12+6x-6x^2=6(2+x-x^2)$$;$$ \frac{\mathrm{d} ^{2}y}{\mathrm{d} x^{2}}=6(1-2x)$$;To find stationary points, solve;$$\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x}=0$$;$$\Rightarrow 2+x-x^2=0$$;$$\Rightarrow (2-x)(1+x)=0$$;$$x=2 or x=-1$$;When x = -1, y = 27 - 12 + 3 + 2 = 20;when x = 2, y = 27 + 24 +12 - 6 = 47;Now when x = - 1,;$$ \frac{\mathrm{d} ^{2}y}{\mathrm{d} x^{2}}=18>0$$;Therefore (-1, 20) is a minimum point on the curve. (ANS);When x = 2,;$$ \frac{\mathrm{d} ^{2}y}{\mathrm{d} x^{2}}=-18<0$$;Therefore (2, 47) is a maximum point on the curve. (ANS);b) i) Let h be the height of the tan k, then area of the rectangular tan k;=$$2(2xh+2x^2+hx)$$;=$$2(3hx+2x^2)$$;$$\Rightarrow 2(3hx+2x^2)=48$$;$$\Rightarrow 3hx+2x^2=24$$;$$\Rightarrow 3hx=24-2x^2$$;$$\Rightarrow h=\frac{8}{x}-\frac{ (2x)}{3}$$ (ANS);ii) Let v be the volume of the \tan k, then volume = length x width x height;$$v=(2x)(x)(h)=2x^2(\frac{8}{x}-\frac{ (2x)}{3})$$;$$\Rightarrow v=16x-\frac{ (4x^3)}{3}$$ (ANS);Now;$$\frac{\mathrm{d} v}{\mathrm{d} t}=16-4x^2$$;$$\frac{\mathrm{d} v}{\mathrm{d} t}=0\Rightarrow 4x^2=16$$;$$\Rightarrow x^2=4$$;$$x\pm 2$$;x must be positive;When x = 2, ;$$h=\frac{8}{2}-\frac{4}{3}=\frac{8}{3 }and v=\frac{64}{3}cm^3$$;Therefore dimensions of the \tan k for which the volume is a maximum are given by length of 4 cm, width of 2 cm and height of $$\frac{8}{3}$$cm (ANS)
