a) $$\frac{x}{8} = \frac{50}{x}$$ ; $$x^2 = 400$$ ; x = 20 or -20;;b) $$\frac{t + q}{4} = \frac{q}{5}$$ ; 5t + 5p = 4q ; 5t = 4q - 5p ; $$t = \frac{4q - 5p}{5}$$;;c-i) $$y = a + \frac{600}{x}$$ ; $$17 = a + \frac{600}{50}$$ ; $$17 = a + 12$$ ; a = 5;;c-ii) $$y = 5 + \frac{600}{x}$$ ; When x = 100, y = 5 + $$\frac{600}{100}$$ = 11 ; The cost of each copy is $11.;;c-iii) When x = 300, $$y = 5 + \frac{600}{300} = 7$$ ; The total cost of printing 300 copies = $$300 \times 7$$ = $2100;;c-iv) $$y = 5 + \frac{600}{x}$$ ; When y = 5.2, 5.2 = 5 + $$\frac{600}{x}$$ ; $$0.2 = \frac{600}{x}$$ ; $$x = \frac{600}{0.2} = 300$$ ; The number of copies of the book that were printed amount to 3000.

a-i) The total amount that Alan will pay for the computer ; = $$\frac{1}{3} \times 1299 + 40.30 \times 24$$ ; = $1400.20;;a-ii) Required percentage ; = $$\frac{1400.20 - 1299}{1299} \times 100\%$$ = 7.79%;;b) The amount of interest that Betty will pay ; = $$1299 (1 + \frac{6}{100})^3 - 1299$$ ; $$\approx$$ $248.13;;c) The amount that the trader paid for the camera ; = $$\frac{100}{115} \times 759 = $660$$

a) Equation of the line is: y = $$\frac{4}{3} x$$ + C ; 4 = $$\frac{4}{3} (-5)$$ + C ; C = $$\frac{32}{3}$$ ; y = $$\frac{4}{3} x + \frac{32}{3}$$;;b) Sub. y =$$\frac{4}{3}x + \frac{32}{3}$$ into 2x + 9y = 68 ; $$2x + 9(\frac{4}{3} x + \frac{32}{3}) = 68$$ ; 2x + 12x + 96 = 68 ; 14x = -28 ; x = -2 ; Sub x = -2 into y = $$\frac{4}{3}x + \frac{32}{3}$$ ; $$y = \frac{4}{3}(-2) + \frac{32}{3} = 8$$ ; The coordinates of B = (-2, 8).;;c-i) |$$\vec{AE}$$| = $$\sqrt{6^2 + 1^2} = \sqrt{37}$$ ; $$\approx$$ 6.08 units;;c-ii) $$\vec{AE} = \vec{OE} - \vec{OA}$$ ; $$\begin{bmatrix}6\\1\end{bmatrix} = \vec{OE} - \begin{bmatrix}-5\\4\end{bmatrix}$$ ; $$\vec{OE} = \begin{bmatrix}6\\1\end{bmatrix} + \begin{bmatrix}-5\\4\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix}1\\5\end{bmatrix}$$ ; The coordinates of E = (1, 5).;;c-iii-a) $$\vec{DE} = \vec{OE} - \vec{OD}$$ ; $$\begin{bmatrix}1\\5\end{bmatrix} - \begin{bmatrix}4\\2\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix}-3\\3\end{bmatrix}$$;;c-iii-b) $$\vec{DB} = \vec{OB} - \vec{OD}$$ ; $$\begin{bmatrix}-2\\8\end{bmatrix} - \begin{bmatrix}4\\2\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix}-6\\6\end{bmatrix}$$;;c-iv) $$\vec{DE} = -3 \begin{bmatrix}1\\1\end{bmatrix}$$ ; $$\vec{DB} = -6\begin{bmatrix}1\\1\end{bmatrix} = 2\vec{DE}$$ ; $$\Rightarrow$$ The points D, E and B lie on the same line and DB = 2DE.

a-i) Sum of exterior angles = $$360^{\circ}$$ ; One exterior angle = $$360^{\circ} \div 15 = 24^{\circ}$$ ; $$\therefore  \angle $$XCD = $$24^{\circ}$$;;a-ii) $$\angle XDC = 24^{\circ}$$ ; In $$\Delta $$CXD = $$180^{\circ} - \angle XCD - \angle XDC$$ ; = $$180^{\circ} - 24^{\circ} - 24^{\circ} = 132^{\circ}$$;;b) XB = XE since XBE is isosceles triangle.;;c) $$\angle DEB = \angle XDC = 24^{\circ}$$ (corr. $$\angle $$s, CD $$\parallel$$ BE) ; one interior angle of regular polygon with 15 sides = $$180^{\circ} - 24^{\circ} = 156^{\circ}$$ ; $$\angle BEF = \angle DEF - \angle DEB$$ ; =$$156^{\circ} - 24^{\circ}$$ = $$132^{\circ}$$

a) In $$\Delta $$PQR ; $$PR^2 = PQ^2 + QR^2 - 2(QR)(PQ) \cos \angle PQR$$ ; =$$\frac{95^2 + 102^2 - 170^2}{2(95)(102)}$$ ; = $$-\frac{3157}{6460}$$ ; $$\angle PQR \approx 119.3^{\circ}$$;;b) tan $$\angle Q$$ = $$\frac{23}{95}$$ ; $$\angle Q \approx 13.6^{\circ}$$ ;The angle of depression of Q from B = $$\theta \approx 13.6^{\circ}$$;;c) Area of $$\Delta $$PRS = $$5200 m^2$$ ; $$\frac{1}{2} \times PR \times RS \times \sin \angle PRS = 5200$$ ; $$\frac{1}{2} \times 170 \times RS \times \sin 52^{\circ} = 5200$$ ; RS = $$\frac{5200}{85 \sin 52^{\circ}}$$ ; = 77.6 m;;d-i) Number of panels that need to be bought = $$\frac{RS}{3}$$ = $$\frac{77.634}{3} \approx 26$$;;d-ii) Total cost of the panels and posts ; = $$28.50 \times 26 + 14.95 \times 27$$ ; $1144.65

a-i) Let the reflex angle POQ be $$\theta$$ rad. ; Total perimeter of the major sector POQR ; = 44 m ; 8$$\theta$$ + 16 = 44 ; 8$$\theta$$ = 28 ; $$\theta = 3.5$$ ; The reflex angle POQ = 3.5 rad;;a-ii) Area of $$\Delta POQ = \frac{1}{2} \times 8 \times 8 \times \sin (2\pi - 3.5)$$ ; $$\approx 11.2 m^2$$;;a-iii) Total area of cross-section of the tunnel ; = Area of major sector POQR + Area of $$\Delta $$POQ ; $$= \frac{1}{2} \times 8^2 \times 3.5 + \frac{1}{2} \times 8 \times 8 \times \sin (2\pi - 3.5)$$ ; $$\approx 123 m^2$$;;b) Look at the picture provided;img;;b-i) Volume of the bollard ; = Vol. of the Pyramid + Vol. of the cuboid ; = $$\frac{1}{3} \times 10 \times 10 \times 12 + 10 \times 10 \times 30$$ ; $$= 3400 cm^3$$;;b-ii) In $$\Delta VNP$$ ; $$VP^2 = 12^2 + 5^2 = 169$$ ; VP = 13 cm ; Area of $$\Delta VBC = \frac{1}{2} \times BC \times VP$$ ; = $$\frac{1}{2} \times 10 \times 13$$ ; = $$65 cm^2$$ ; The surface area of the bollard = (Area of $$\Delta $$VBC) $$\times$$ 4 + (Area BCGF) $$\times$$ 4 ; = $$65 \times 4 + 300 \times 4 $$; = $$1460 cm^2$$

Trapezium rule:;$$Area\approx \frac{1}{2}h\left[ {{y}_{0}}+{{y}_{4}}+2\left( {{y}_{1}}+{{y}_{2}}+{{y}_{3}} \right) \right]$$;where $$h=\frac{\left( 3-1 \right)}{4}=0.5$$;and $$y_i$$ is the value of y at $$x=1+ih$$.;With $${{y}_{0}}=2,{{y}_{1}}=2.8,{{y}_{2}}=3.4,{{y}_{3}}=3.8,{{y}_{4}}3.6$$;$$\begin{align};  & \therefore Area\approx \frac{1}{2}\left( 0.5 \right)\left[ 2+3.6+2\left( 2.8+3.4+3.8 \right) \right] \\ ; & =6.4 \\ ;\end{align}$$;;The approximate value is less than the true area of the region because the curve is concave downwards and, so, the area of each trapezium is less than the true area of each strip.;img

For small x, $$\cos x\approx 1-\frac{1}{2}{{x}^{2}},\sin x\approx x$$;$$\begin{align};  & \cos x-4\sin x=6x \\ ; & \left( 1-\frac{1}{2}{{x}^{2}} \right)-4x=6 \\ ; & \frac{1}{2}{{x}^{2}}+10x-1=0 \\ ; & {{x}^{2}}+20x-2=0 \\ ;\end{align}$$;;$$\begin{align};  & {{x}^{2}}+20x-2=0 \\ ; & \Rightarrow x=\frac{-20\pm \sqrt{{{20}^{2}}-4\left( 1 \right)\left( -2 \right)}}{2} \\ ; & =-10\pm 10.099504\end{align}$$;$$ =0.099504$$ or $$-20.099504 $$;$$\therefore x =0.0995 $$(3sf), since x is small

$$\begin{align};  & 5\sin \theta +12\cos \theta  \\ ; & =R\sin \left( \theta +\alpha  \right) \\ ; & =R\sin \theta \cos \alpha +R\cos \theta \sin \alpha  \\ ;\end{align}$$;;Comparing coefficients:;$$\begin{align};  & \sin \theta :R\cos \alpha =5 \\ ; & \cos \theta :R\sin \alpha =12 \\ ; & \Rightarrow R=\sqrt{{{5}^{2}}+{{12}^{2}}}=13 \\ ; & \tan \alpha =\frac{12}{5} \Rightarrow \alpha ={{67.38}^{\circ}} \\ ; & \therefore 5\sin \theta +12\cos \theta =13\sin \left( \theta +{{67.4}^{\circ}} \right) \\ ;\end{align}$$;;$$\begin{align};  & 6\sec \theta -5\tan \theta =12 \\ ; & \frac{6}{\cos \theta }-\frac{5\sin \theta }{\cos \theta }=12 \\ ; & 6-5\sin \theta =12\cos \theta  \\ ; & 5\sin \theta +12\cos \theta =6 \\ ; & \equiv 13\sin \left( \theta +{{67.4}^{\circ}} \right)=6 \\ ; & \Rightarrow \sin \left( \theta +{{67.4}^{\circ}} \right)=\frac{6}{13} \\ ; & \theta +{{67.4}^{\circ}}=180{{n}^{\circ}}+{{\left( -1 \right)}^{n}}\left( {{27.48}^{\circ}} \right) \\ ; & \theta =189{{n}^{\circ}}+{{\left( -1 \right)}^{n}}\left( {{27.48}^{\circ}} \right)-{{67.4}^{\circ}} \\ ; &  \\ ; & {{0}^{\circ}}<\theta <{{360}^{\circ}} \\ ; & \Rightarrow \theta ={{85.13}^{\circ}},{{320.10}^{\circ}} \\ ; & ={{85.1}^{\circ}},{{320.1}^{\circ}} \\ ;\end{align}$$

(i) \begin{align};  & y=\ln \sec x \\ ; & \frac{dy}{dx}=\frac{d}{dx}\left[ \ln \sec x \right] \\ ; & =\frac{1}{\sec x}\left( \sec x\tan x \right)=\tan x \\ ; & \frac{{{d}^{2}}y}{d{{x}^{2}}}=\frac{d}{dx} \tan x ={{\sec }^{2}}x\end{align};(ii) Let $$y=f\left( x \right)=\ln \sec x$$;Maclaurin's series for $$y=f\left( x \right)$$ is;\begin{align};  & y=f\left( 0 \right)+f'\left( 0 \right)x+\frac{f''\left( 0 \right)}{2!}{{x}^{2}}+\frac{f'''\left( 0 \right)}{3!}{{x}^{3}}+... \\ ; & f\left( 0 \right)=\ln \left( \sec 0 \right)=0 \\ ; & f'\left( 0 \right)=\tan 0=0 \\ ; & f''\left( 0 \right)={{\sec }^{2}}0=1 \\ ; & f'''\left( x \right)=\frac{d}{dx}\left[ {{\sec }^{2}}x \right] \\ ; & =2\sec x\left( \sec x\tan x \right)=2{{\sec }^{2}}x\tan x \\ ; & \therefore f'''\left( 0 \right)=2{{\sec }^{2}}0\tan 0=0 \\ ; & {{f}^{\left( 4 \right)}}\left( x \right)=\frac{d}{dx}\left[ 2{{\sec }^{2}}x\tan x \right] \\ ; & =2{{\sec }^{2}}x\left( {{\sec }^{2}}x \right)+2\left( 2{{\sec }^{2}}x\tan x \right)\tan x \\ ; & =2{{\sec }^{4}}x+4{{\sec }^{2}}x{{\tan }^{2}}x \\ ; & \therefore {{f}^{\left( 4 \right)}}\left( 0 \right)=2{{\sec }^{4}}0+4{{\sec }^{2}}0{{\tan }^{2}}0=2 \\ ; & \therefore y=0+\left( 0 \right)x+\frac{1}{2!}{{x}^{2}}+\left( 0 \right){{x}^{3}}+\frac{2}{4!}{{x}^{4}}+... \\ ; & =\frac{1}{2}{{x}^{2}}+\frac{1}{12}{{x}^{4}}+... \\ ;\end{align};

a);Let r=radius of circle;;Circumference of circle;$$=2\pi r=x\Rightarrow r=\frac{1}{2\pi }x$$;;Area of circle;$$C=\pi {{r}^{2}}=\pi {{\left( \frac{1}{2\pi }x \right)}^{2}}=\frac{1}{4\pi }{{x}^{2}}$$;;Let a=length of side of square;;Perimeter of square;$$=4a=8-x\Rightarrow a=2-\frac{1}{4}x$$;;Area of square;$$S={{a}^{2}}={{\left( 2-\frac{1}{4}x \right)}^{2}}=4-x+\frac{1}{16}{{x}^{2}}$$;;Sum of the area;$$\begin{align};  & A=C+S=\left( \frac{1}{4\pi }{{x}^{2}} \right)+4-x+\frac{1}{16}{{x}^{2}} \\ ; & =\left( \frac{1}{4\pi }+\frac{1}{16} \right){{x}^{2}}-x+4 \\ ;\end{align}$$;;Coefficient of $${{x}^{2}}$$, $$\left( \frac{1}{4\pi }+\frac{1}{16} \right)>0$$;; $$\Rightarrow $$ A is a minimum function.;When A is minimum, $$\frac{dA}{dx}=0$$;$$\begin{align}; & \Rightarrow \frac{d}{dx}\left[ \left( \frac{1}{4\pi }+\frac{1}{16} \right){{x}^{2}}-x+4 \right]=0 \\ ; & 2\left( \frac{1}{4\pi }+\frac{1}{16} \right)x-1=0 \\ ; & \therefore \frac{4+\pi }{8\pi }x=1, \\ ; & x=\frac{8\pi }{4+\pi } \\ ; &  \\ ; & \therefore r=\frac{1}{2\pi }x=\frac{1}{2\pi }\frac{8\pi }{4+\pi }=\frac{4}{4+\pi } \\ ;\end{align}$$;;b);(i);Let r=radius of balloon;Let V=volume of balloon=$$\frac{4}{3}\pi {{r}^{2}}$$;\[\begin{align};  & \frac{dV}{dt}=\frac{d}{dt}\left[ \frac{4}{3}\pi r \right]=4\pi {{r}^{2}}\frac{dr}{dt} \\ ; & \frac{dV}{dt}=150,r=50 \\ ; & \Rightarrow 150=4\pi {{\left( 50 \right)}^{2}}\frac{dr}{dt} \\ ; & \therefore \frac{dr}{dt}=\frac{150}{10000\pi }=0.00477cm{{s}^{-1}} \\ ;\end{align}\];;(ii);Let A=surface area of balloon = $$4\pi {{r}^{2}}$$;\[\frac{dA}{dt}=\frac{d}{dt}\left[ 4\pi {{r}^{2}} \right]=8\pi r\frac{dr}{dt}\];At $$r=50$$,;$$\frac{dA}{dt}=8\pi \left( 50 \right)\frac{150}{10000\pi }=6c{{m}^{2}}{{s}^{-1}}$$

a);(i) At the end of 1 year, the account will have $$ \left | (x+0.05x )\right |$$= $$ \left |1.05x\right |$$;(ii) Let $$E_i$$=amount in the account at the end of the i th years.;Deduce that:;$$\begin{align};  & {{E}_{1}}=1.05x \\ ; & {{E}_{2}}=1.05\left( x+1.05x \right)=1.05+1.05{{x}^{2}} \\ ; & {{E}_{3}}=1.05\left( x+1.05+1.05{{x}^{2}} \right) \\ ; & =1.05x+{{1.05}^{2}}x+{{1.05}^{3}}x \\ ; & ... \\ ;\end{align}$$;Deduce that;$$E_n=\Sigma$$(1st n term of G.P. with 1st term a=1.05x, and common ration r=1.05);;$$\begin{align};  & \frac{a\left( {{r}^{n}}-1 \right)}{r-1}=\frac{1.05x\left( {{1.05}^{n}}-1 \right)}{1.05-1} \\ ; & =\$$21\left({{1.05}^{n}}-1\right)x\\\end{align}$$;(iii);$$\begin{align}; & {{E}_{n}}\ge 12x \\ ; & \Rightarrow 21\left( {{1.05}^{n}}-1 \right)x\ge 12x \\ ; & {{1.05}^{n}}-1\ge \frac{12}{21}=\frac{4}{7} \\ ; & {{1.05}^{n}}\ge 1+\frac{4}{7}=\frac{11}{7} \\ ; & n\ge \frac{\ln \frac{11}{7}}{\ln 1.05}=9.26 \\ ;\end{align}$$;;Required no. of years = 10;;b);Let $$A_i$$=amount in account in the ith year.;Let $$I_i$$ interest from the i th year.;Deduce that;$${{A}_{i}}=iy$$ and $${{I}_{i}}=0.05{{A}_{i}}=0.05iy$$;At the end of n years, total interest received;;$$\begin{align}; & =\sum{\begin{align}; &  \\ ; &  \\ ;\end{align}};;{{I}_{i}} \\ ; & = 0.05y+0.05\left( 2 \right)y+0.05\left( 3 \right)y+...+0.05\left( n \right)y \\ ; & = \frac{1}{2}n\left[ 2a+\left( n-1 \right)d \right] \\ ; & = \frac{1}{2}n\left[ 2\left( 0.05y \right)+\left( n-1 \right)\left( 0.05y \right) \right] \\ ; & = \frac{1}{2}n\left[ 0.05n+0.05 \right]y \\ ; & = \frac{1}{40}n\left(n+1\right)y\\\end{align}$$

a);Sketch region;img;;Area of enclosed region = Area under chord OA (area of triangle) ; Area under curve $$y=\tan x$$;\[\begin{align}; & =\frac{1}{2}\left( \frac{1}{4}\pi  \right)\left( 1 \right)-\int\limits_{0}^{\frac{1}{4}\pi }{\tan xdx} \\ ; & =\frac{1}{8}\pi -\int\limits_{0}^{\frac{1}{4}\pi }{\frac{\sin x}{\cos x}dx} \\ ; & =\frac{1}{8}\pi -\left[ -\ln \left( \cos x \right) \right]_{0}^{\frac{1}{4}\pi } \\ ; & =\frac{1}{8}\pi -\left[ -\ln \left( \cos \frac{1}{4}\pi  \right)+\ln \left( \cos 0 \right) \right] \\ ; & =\frac{1}{8}\pi -\left[ -\ln \left( \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \right) \right] \\ ; & =\frac{1}{8}\pi -\ln \sqrt{2}uni{{t}^{2}}\end{align}\];;b);img;;$$\begin{align}; & ay={{x}^{2}}\Rightarrow y=\frac{{{x}^{2}}}{a} \\ ; & x=r,y={{y}_{1}}=\frac{{{r}^{2}}}{a} \\ ; & x=3r,y={{y}_{2}}=\frac{{{\left( 3r \right)}^{2}}}{a}=\frac{9{{r}^{2}}}{a}\end{align}$$;;Depth of bowl;$$={{y}_{2}}-{{y}_{1}}=\frac{9{{r}^{2}}}{a}-\frac{{{r}^{2}}}{a}=\frac{8{{r}^{2}}}{a}unit$$;;Volume of bowl = volume generated by rotating $$ay={{x}^{2}}$$, for $${{y}_{1}} < y < {{y}_{2}}$$, about the y-axis,;;\[\begin{align};  & {{V}_{y}}=\int\limits_{{{y}_{1}}}^{{{y}_{2}}}{\pi {{x}^{2}}dy} \\ ; & =\pi \int\limits_{{{y}_{1}}}^{{{y}_{2}}}{aydy} \\ ; & =ay\left[ \frac{1}{2}{{y}^{2}} \right]_{{{y}_{1}}}^{{{y}_{2}}} \\ ; & =\frac{1}{2}a\pi \left[ {{y}_{2}}^{2}-{{y}_{1}}^{2} \right] \\ ; & =\frac{1}{2}a\pi \left[ {{\left( \frac{9{{r}^{2}}}{a} \right)}^{2}}-{{\left( \frac{{{r}^{2}}}{a} \right)}^{2}} \right] \\ ; & =\frac{40\pi {{r}^{4}}}{a}uni{{t}^{3}} \\ ;\end{align}\];;$$\begin{align}; & {{r}^{4}}=\frac{1}{400}{{a}^{4}},i.e.{{r}^{2}}=\frac{1}{20}{{a}^{2}} \end{align}$$;;Depth of bowl;$$\begin{align};  & =\frac{8{{r}^{2}}}{a}\\ ; &=\frac{8\left( \frac{1}{20}{{a}^{2}} \right)}{a} \\ ; & =\frac{2}{5}a \\ ;\end{align}$$

(i);Let $$\frac{3x+5}{\left( x+1 \right)\left( x+2 \right)\left( x+3 \right)}\equiv \frac{A}{x+1}+\frac{B}{x+2}+\frac{C}{x+3}$$;;Cover-up Rule:;;$$\begin{align};  & x=-1:A=\frac{3\left( -1 \right)+5}{\left( -1+2 \right)\left( -1+3 \right)}=1 \\ ; & x=-2:B=\frac{3\left( -2 \right)+5}{\left( -2+1 \right)\left( -2+3 \right)}=1 \\ ; & x=-3:C=\frac{3\left( -3 \right)+5}{\left( -3+1 \right)\left( -3+2 \right)}=-2 \\ ; & \therefore f\left( x \right)=\frac{1}{x+1}+\frac{1}{x+2}-\frac{2}{x+3} \\ ;\end{align}$$;;(ii);$$\begin{align};  & f\left( x \right)=\frac{1}{x+1}+\frac{1}{x+2}-\frac{2}{x+3} \\ ; & ={{\left( 1+x \right)}^{-1}}+\frac{1}{2}{{\left( 1+\frac{1}{2}x \right)}^{-1}}-\frac{2}{3}{{\left( 1+\frac{1}{3}x \right)}^{-1}} \\ ; & =\left( 1-x+{{x}^{2}}+... \right)+\frac{1}{2}\left( 1-\frac{1}{2}x+\frac{1}{4}{{x}^{2}}+... \right)-\frac{2}{3}\left( 1-\frac{1}{3}x+\frac{1}{9}{{x}^{2}}+... \right) \\ ; & =\frac{5}{6}-\frac{37}{36}x+\frac{227}{216}{{x}^{2}}+... \\ ; & \approx \frac{5}{6}-\frac{37}{36}x+\frac{227}{216}{{x}^{2}} \\ ;\end{align}$$;;(iii);;$$\begin{align};  & \int\limits_{0}^{0.1}{f\left( x \right)dx} \\ ; & \approx \int\limits_{0}^{0.1}{\left( \frac{5}{6}-\frac{37}{36}x+\frac{227}{216}{{x}^{2}} \right)dx} \\ ; & =\left[ \frac{5}{6}x-\frac{37}{72}{{x}^{2}}+\frac{227}{648}{{x}^{3}} \right]_{0}^{0.1} \\ ; & =\frac{5}{6}\left( 0.1 \right)-\frac{37}{72}{{\left( 0.1 \right)}^{2}}+\frac{227}{648}{{\left( 0.1 \right)}^{3}} \\ ; & =0.078545=0.0785 \\ ;\end{align}$$;;(iv);Let $$P_n$$ denotes;;$$\begin{align};  & \sum\limits_{r=1}^{n}{\frac{3r+5}{\left( r+1 \right)\left( r+2 \right)\left( r+3 \right)}}=\frac{7}{6}-\frac{3n+7}{\left( n+2 \right)\left( n+3 \right)} \\ ; & n=1, \\ ; & LHS=\sum\limits_{r=1}^{1}{\frac{3r+5}{\left( r+1 \right)\left( r+2 \right)\left( r+3 \right)}}=\frac{3+5}{\left( 1+1 \right)\left( 1+2 \right)\left( 1+3 \right)}=\frac{8}{24}=\frac{1}{3} \\ ; & RHS=\frac{7}{6}-\frac{3+7}{\left( 1+2 \right)\left( 1+3 \right)}=\frac{7}{6}-\frac{10}{12}=\frac{1}{3}=LHS \\ ;\end{align}$$;;$$\therefore P_1$$ is true.;Assume $$P_k$$ is true for $$k\in {{Z}^{+}}$$,;i.e. \[\sum\limits_{r=1}^{n}{\frac{3r+5}{\left( r+1 \right)\left( r+2 \right)\left( r+3 \right)}}=\frac{7}{6}-\frac{3k+7}{\left( k+2 \right)\left( k+3 \right)}\];;For n=k+1,;;\[\begin{align};  & RHS=\frac{7}{6}-\frac{3\left( k+1 \right)+7}{\left[ \left( k+1 \right)+2 \right]\left[ \left( k+1 \right)+3 \right]} \\ ; & LHS=\sum\limits_{r=1}^{k+1}{\frac{3r+5}{\left( r+1 \right)\left( r+2 \right)\left( r+3 \right)}} \\ ; & =\sum\limits_{r=1}^{k+1}{\frac{3r+5}{\left( r+1 \right)\left( r+2 \right)\left( r+3 \right)}}+\frac{3\left( k+1 \right)+5}{\left( k+1+1 \right)\left( k+1+2 \right)\left( k+1+3 \right)} \\ ; & =\frac{7}{6}-\frac{3k+7}{\left( k+2 \right)\left( k+3 \right)}+\frac{3\left( k+1 \right)+5}{\left( k+1+1 \right)\left( k+1+2 \right)\left( k+1+3 \right)} \\ ; & =\frac{7}{6}-\frac{3k+7}{\left( k+2 \right)\left( k+3 \right)}+\frac{3k+8}{\left( k+2 \right)\left( k+3 \right)\left( k+4 \right)} \\ ; & =\frac{7}{6}-\frac{\left( 3k+7 \right)\left( k+4 \right)-\left( 3k+8 \right)}{\left( k+2 \right)\left( k+3 \right)\left( k+4 \right)} \\ ; & =\frac{7}{6}-\frac{3{{k}^{2}}+16k+20}{\left( k+2 \right)\left( k+3 \right)\left( k+4 \right)} \\ ; & =\frac{7}{6}-\frac{\left( k+2 \right)\left( 3k+10 \right)}{\left( k+2 \right)\left( k+3 \right)\left( k+4 \right)}=\frac{7}{6}-\frac{3k+10}{\left( k+3 \right)\left( k+4 \right)} \\ ; & =\frac{7}{6}-\frac{3\left( k+1 \right)+7}{\left[ \left( k+1 \right)+2 \right]\left[ \left( k+1 \right)+3 \right]}=RHS \\ ;\end{align}\];;$$\therefore P_{k+1}$$ is true if $$P_k$$ is true.;Therefore, by mathematical induction, $$P_n$$ is true for all $$n\in {{Z}^{+}}$$.

a);$$\begin{align};& x^2 - 2xy + 2y^2 = 4 \\;& \frac{d}{dx}[x^2 - 2xy + 2y^2] = 0 \\;& 2x - 2x \frac{dy}{dx} - 2y + 4y\frac{dy}{dx} = 0 \\;& \frac{dy}{dx}(2y-x) = y-x \\;& \therefore \frac{dy}{dx} = \frac{y-x}{2y-x} \\;\end{align}$$;;For tangents parallel to the x-axis, ;$$\frac{dy}{dx} = 0 \Rightarrow \frac{y-x}{2y-x} = 0 \Rightarrow y=x$$;Subst into $$x^2 - 2xy + 2y^2 = 4$$;$$\begin{align};& \Rightarrow x^2 -2xy + 2y^2 = 4 \\;& x^2 = 4, i.e. x= \pm 2 \\;\end{align}$$;For $$x = \pm 2, y = \pm 2$$;$$\therefore$$ Required coordinates are (2,2) and (-2,2);;b);$$\begin{align};& x = t^2, y = t^3 \\;& \Rightarrow \frac{dy}{dx} = \frac{dy}{dt} / \frac{dx}{dt} = \frac{3 t^2}{2t} = \frac{3}{2} t \\;\end{align}$$;At $$P(p^2, p^3), i.e. t=p, \frac{dy}{dx} = \frac{3}{2}p$$;;Equation of the tangent is:;$$\begin{align};& y - p^3 = \frac{3}{2}p(x-p^2) \\;& 2y-2p^3 =  3px - 3p^3 \\;& 2y-3px + p^3 = 0 \\;\end{align}$$;;Tangent passes through (-3, -5);$$\begin{align};& \Rightarrow 2(-5) -3p(-3) + p^3 = 0 \\;& -10 + 9p +p^3 = 0 \\;& (p-1)(p^2 + p + 10) = 0 \\;\end{align}$$;;Discriminant of $$(p^2 + p + 10) = 1- 40 = -39 < 0$$;;$$\Rightarrow  p^2 +  p + 10$$ has no real solutions.;$$\therefore (p-1)(p^2 + p + 10) = 0$$ has only 1 solution p=1.;;Coordinate of this point = $$(p^2, p^3)  = (1^2, 1^3) = (1,1)$$;;

(i);No of ways to choose 2 of 36 people \[{{=}^{36}}{{C}_{2}}=630\];No of ways to choose 2 of 25 Lee $${{=}^{25}}{{C}_{2}}=300$$;P(they both have the name Lee);$$=\frac{300}{630}=\frac{10}{21}$$;;(ii);No of ways to choose a married couple = 8 (Lee) + 3 (Chan) =11;P(they are married to each other);$$=\frac{11}{630}$$;;(iii);No of ways to choose a married couple named Lee=8;P(they both have the name Lee | they are married to each other);$$=\frac{\frac{8}{630}}{\frac{11}{630}}=\frac{8}{11}$$;;(iv);No of ways to choose a man named Lee;= 4 (single) + 8 (married) = 12;;No of ways to choose a woman named Lee;= 5 (single) + 8 (married) = 13;;No of ways to choose a man and a woman both named Lee ;$$= 12\times 13=156$$;;No of ways to choose a man named Chan;= 2 (single) + 3 (married) = 5;;No of ways to choose a man and a woman both named Chan ;$$= 5\times 6=30$$;;P(they are a man and a woman with the same name);$$=\frac{156+30}{630}=\frac{186}{630}=\frac{31}{105}$$;;(v);P(they are married to each other | they are a man and a woman with the same name);$$=\frac{\frac{11}{630}}{\frac{186}{630}}=\frac{11}{186}$$

a) Let n=sample size=5;Let p=proportion of population having blood group A=0.35 and $$q=1-p=0.65$$;;$$\begin{align};  & X\tilde{\ }B\left( n,p \right) \\ ; & P\left( X\le 2 \right) \\ ; & =P\left( X=0 \right)+P\left( X=1 \right)+P\left( X=2 \right) \\ ; & ={{q}^{5}}{{+}^{n}}{{C}_{1}}.{{p}^{1}}.{{q}^{n-1}}{{+}^{n}}{{C}_{2}}.{{p}^{2}}.{{q}^{n-2}} \\ ; & ={{\left( 0.65 \right)}^{5}}{{+}^{5}}{{C}_{1}}{{\left( 0.35 \right)}^{1}}{{\left( .065 \right)}^{4}}{{+}^{5}}{{C}_{2}}{{\left( 0.35 \right)}^{2}}{{\left( 0.65 \right)}^{3}} \\ ; & =0.7648=0.765 \\ ;\end{align}$$;;b);(i);Let $${{q}_{2}}=P\left( X>2 \right)=1-P\left( X\le 2 \right)=0.235$$;;Let C = no. of samples out of 3 with X>2;$$P\left( C=3 \right)={{q}_{2}}^{3}={{\left( 0.235 \right)}^{3}}=0.01298=0.013$$;;(ii);Required results are X=1, X=2 and X>2;As there are 3! Possible permutations, required probability;;$$\begin{align};  & =3!\times P\left( X=1 \right)\times P\left( X=2 \right)\times P\left( X>2 \right) \\ ; & =3!{{\times }^{n}}{{C}_{1}}{{p}^{1}}{{q}^{n-1}}{{\times }^{n}}{{C}_{2}}{{p}^{2}}{{q}^{n-2}}\times 0.235 \\ ; & =6{{\times }^{5}}{{C}_{1}}{{\left( 0.35 \right)}^{1}}{{\left( 0.65 \right)}^{4}}\times 10{{\left( 0.35 \right)}^{2}}{{\left( 0.65 \right)}^{3}}\times 0.235 \\ ; & =0.1482=0.148 \\ ;\end{align}$$;;Let $$n_2$$=sample size = 100;Let $${{p}_{2}}=P\left( X\le 2 \right)=1-{{q}_{2}}=0.765$$;Let Y=no. samples out of n2 with $$X\le 2$$;$$Y~B(n_2,p_2)$$;Sine n2 (=100) is large,;$$n_2 q_2 = 23.5 > 5$$ and $$n_2 p_2 = 76.5 > 5$$,;$$Y~N(n_2 p_2, n_2 p_2 q_2)$$ approximately;;$$\begin{align};  & P\left( Y\ge 70 \right) \\ ; & \equiv P\left( Y>69.5 \right) \\ ; & \equiv P\left( Z>\frac{69.5-{{n}_{2}}{{p}_{2}}}{\sqrt{{{n}_{2}}{{p}_{2}}{{q}_{2}}}} \right) \\ ; & =P\left( Z>\frac{69.5-76.5}{\sqrt{100\left( 0.765 \right)\left( 0.235 \right)}} \right) \\ ; & =P\left( Z>-1.651 \right)\equiv \phi \left( 1.651 \right) \\ ; & =0.9506=0.951 \\ ;\end{align}$$

a);(i) Let K = No of 'Kubla' sets sold in a give week;Let $$\lambda =E\left( K \right)=1.8$$;;$$\begin{align};  & K\tilde{\ }{Po}\left( \lambda  \right) \\ ; & P\left( K=2 \right)=\frac{{{e}^{-\lambda }}{{\lambda }^{2}}}{2!}=\frac{{{e}^{-1.8}}{{1.8}^{2}}}{2!}=0.2677=0.268 \\ ;\end{align}$$;;(ii) Let K2 = No of  'Kubla' sets sold in a 2-week period;Let $${{\lambda }_{2}}=E\left( {{K}_{2}} \right)=2\lambda =3.6$$;;$$\begin{align};  & {{K}_{2}}\tilde{\ }{{P}_{0}}\left( {{\lambda }_{2}} \right) \\ ; & P\left( {{K}_{2}}=4 \right)=\frac{{{e}^{-{{\lambda }_{2}}}}{{\lambda }^{4}}}{4!}=\frac{{{e}^{-3.6}}{{3.6}^{4}}}{4!}=0.1912=0.191 \\ ;\end{align}$$;;(iii) Let X = no of 'Xanadu' sets sold in a given week;Let $$\mu =E\left( X \right)=2.7$$;;$$X\tilde{\ }{{P}_{0}}\left( \mu  \right)$$;Let $$Y=K+X$$;Let $$m=E\left( Y \right)=E\left( K+X \right)=E\left( K \right)+E\left( X \right)=1.8+2.7=4.5$$;;\[\begin{align};  & Y\tilde{\ }{{P}_{0}}\left( m \right) \\ ; & P\left( Y\ge 4 \right) \\ ; & =1-P\left( Y<4 \right) \\ ; & =1-\left[ P\left( Y=0 \right)+P\left( Y=1 \right)+P\left( Y=2 \right)+P\left( Y=3 \right) \right] \\ ; & =1-{{e}^{-m}}\left[ \frac{{{m}^{0}}}{0!}+\frac{{{m}^{1}}}{1!}+\frac{{{m}^{2}}}{2!}+\frac{{{m}^{3}}}{3!} \right] \\ ; & =1-{{e}^{-4.5}}\left[ 1+4.5+\frac{{{4.5}^{2}}}{2!}+\frac{{{4.5}^{3}}}{3!} \right] \\ ; & =0.6577=0.658 \\ ;\end{align}\];;b);$$\begin{align};  & X\tilde{\ }{{P}_{0}}\left( \lambda  \right) \\ ; & {{p}_{r+1}}=P\left( X=r+1 \right)=\frac{{{e}^{-\lambda }}{{\lambda }^{r+1}}}{\left( r+1 \right)!} \\ ; & {{p}_{r}}=P\left( X=r \right)=\frac{{{e}^{-r}}{{\lambda }^{r}}}{r!} \\ ; & \therefore \frac{{{p}_{r+1}}}{{{p}_{r}}}=\frac{{{e}^{-\lambda }}{{\lambda }^{r+1}}}{\left( r+1 \right)!}/\frac{{{e}^{-r}}{{\lambda }^{r}}}{r!}=\frac{\lambda }{r+1} \\ ;\end{align}$$;;$$\begin{align};  & r<\lambda -1\Rightarrow r+1<\lambda \Rightarrow 1<\frac{\lambda }{r+1} \\ ; & \Rightarrow \frac{{{p}_{r+1}}}{{{p}_{r}}}>1\Rightarrow {{p}_{r+1}}>{{p}_{r}} \\ ;\end{align}$$;;(i) For $$\lambda >12.3$$;$${{p}_{r+1}}>{{p}_{r}}={{p}_{r}}<{{p}_{r+1}}$$ when r<12.3-1=11.3;$$\Rightarrow ...{{p}_{10}}<{{p}_{11}}<{{p}_{12}}$$ and $${{p}_{12}}\ge {{p}_{13}}\ge {{p}_{14}}...\left[ r\ge 11.3 \right]$$;;$$p_r$$ is greatest when r = 12;;(ii) For $$\lambda =15$$;;pr<pr+1 when r < 15 - 1 = 14;;$$\Rightarrow ...{{p}_{12}}<{{p}_{13}}<{{p}_{14}},{{p}_{14}}\ge {{p}_{15}}\ge {{p}_{16}}...\left[ r\ge 14 \right]$$;;$$p_r$$ is greatest when r = 14;;For $$\lambda \in Z,{{p}_{\lambda }}={{p}_{\lambda -1}}$$, i.e. $$p_{15} = p_{14}$$;$$p_r$$ is greatest when r = 14 or 15

Deduce that f(0-x) = f(0+x);;F(x) is symmetrical about x=0;;$$\begin{align};  & \therefore E\left( X \right)=0 \\ ; & E\left( {{X}^{2}} \right)=\int_{-\infty }^{\infty }{{{x}^{2}}f\left( x \right)dx} \\ ; & =\int_{-2}^{2}{\left[ {{x}^{2}}\frac{3}{32}\left( 4-{{x}^{2}} \right) \right]dx} \\ ; & =\frac{3}{32}\int_{-2}^{2}{\left[ 4{{x}^{2}}-{{x}^{4}} \right]dx} \\ ; & =\frac{3}{32}\left[ \frac{4}{3}{{x}^{3}}-\frac{1}{5}{{x}^{5}} \right]_{-2}^{2} \\ ; & =\frac{3}{32}\left[ \frac{4}{3}{{\left( 2 \right)}^{3}}-\frac{1}{5}{{\left( 2 \right)}^{5}}-\frac{4}{3}{{\left( -2 \right)}^{3}}+\frac{1}{5}{{\left( -2 \right)}^{5}} \right] \\ ; & =\frac{4}{5} \\ ; & Var\left( X \right)=E\left( {{X}^{2}} \right)-{{\left[ E\left( X \right) \right]}^{2}}=\frac{4}{5}-{{0}^{2}}=\frac{4}{5} \\ ;\end{align}$$;;$$\begin{align};  & E\left( Y \right)=E\left( aX+b \right)=aE\left( X \right)+b=0+b=b \\ ; & \therefore E\left( Y \right)=50\Rightarrow b=50 \\ ; &  \\ ; & Var\left( Y \right)=Var\left( aX+b \right)={{a}^{2}}Var\left( X \right)=\frac{4}{5}{{a}^{2}} \\ ; & \therefore Var\left( Y \right)=80\Rightarrow \frac{4}{5}{{a}^{2}}=80\Rightarrow {{a}^{2}}=100 \\ ; & \Rightarrow a=10,(a>0) \\ ;\end{align}$$;;Let n=sample size=160;Let $$\mu =E\left( Y \right)=50$$;Let $${{\sigma }^{2}}=Var\left( Y \right)=80$$;Since n(=160) is large, Centre Limit Theorem;;$$\begin{align};  & \Rightarrow \overline{Y} \tilde{\ }N\left( \mu,\frac{{\sigma }^{2}}{n} \right) \\ ; & P\left( 49.0 < \overline{Y} < 50.5 \right) \\ ; & \equiv P\left( \frac{49.0 - \mu }{\frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}}} < Z < \frac{50.5 - \mu }{\frac{\sigma }{\sqrt{n}}} \right) \\ ; & =P\left( \frac{49.0-50}{\sqrt{\frac{80}{160}}} < Z<\frac{50.5-50}{\sqrt{\frac{80}{160}}} \right) \\ ; & =P\left( -1.4142 < Z < 0.7071 \right) \\ ; & =\phi \left( 0.707 \right)-\left[ 1 - \phi \left( 1.414 \right) \right] \\ ; & =0.7601-\left[ 1-0.9213 \right] \\ ; & =0.6814=0.681 \\ ;\end{align}$$

Let n = sample size = 80;Let p = proportion of seeds that germinate;;$$\begin{align};  & \widehat{p}=\frac{64}{80}=0.8 \\ ; & \widehat{q}=1-\widehat{p}=0.2 \\ ; & {{z}_{0.05}}\sqrt{\frac{\widehat{p}\widehat{q}}{n}}=1.645\sqrt{\frac{\left( 0.8 \right)\left( 0.2 \right)}{80}}=0.07357 \\ ;\end{align}$$;;The 90% confidence interval for p is;;\[\begin{align};  & \left[ \widehat{p}-{{z}_{0.05}}\sqrt{\frac{\widehat{p}\widehat{q}}{n}},\widehat{p}+{{z}_{0.05}}\sqrt{\frac{\widehat{p}\widehat{q}}{n}} \right] \\ ; & =\left[ 0.8-0.07357,0.8+0.07357 \right] \\ ; & =\left[ 0.726,0.873 \right] \\ ;\end{align}\];;Let n = sample size = 64;Let $$\mu $$ = population mean of x;Let $${{\sigma }^{2}}$$ = variance of x;;$$\begin{align};  & \widehat{\mu }=\overline{x}=\frac{\sum{x}}{n}=\frac{303.4}{64}=4.741=4.74 \\ ; &  \\ ; & {{\sigma }^{2}}=\frac{1}{n-1}\left[ {{\sum{{{x}^{2}}-\left( \frac{1}{n}\sum{x} \right)}}^{2}} \right] \\ ; & =\frac{1}{63}\left[ 1615.96-\frac{1}{64}{{\left( 303.4 \right)}^{2}} \right] \\ ; & =2.8199=2.82 \\ ;\end{align}$$;;Let $${{\mu }_{0}}$$ =  assumed mean = 50;Test H0: $$\mu ={{\mu }_{0}}$$ against H1: $$\mu <{{\mu }_{0}}$$ a 1-tailed test for less;The 10% critical value, z0.10=1.282;Reject H0 if z<-z0.10;Under H0, the test statistic is;$$z=\frac{\overline{x}-{{\mu }_{0}}}{\frac{\widehat{\sigma }}{\sqrt{n}}}=\frac{4.74-5}{\sqrt{\frac{2.82}{64}}}=-1.239$$;;Since z > -z0.10, do not reject H0 and conclude that, at the 10% level of significance, there is insufficient evidence that the mean crop weight is less than 5kg.;;H0 is rejected if z < -za,;;i.e. $$\begin{align};  & -1.239<-{{z}_{\alpha }}\equiv {{z}_{\alpha }}<1.239 \\ ; & \Rightarrow \alpha <1-\phi \left( 1.239 \right)=1-0.8924=0.1076 \\ ;\end{align}$$;;Largest significance level for rejection = 10.8%

a); img;;(i) Sketch $$y=\left| f\left( x \right) \right|$$;;$$y=f\left( x \right)\to y=\left| f\left( x \right) \right|$$;; img; ;(ii) Sketch $${{y}^{2}}=-f\left( x \right)$$;;$$\begin{align};  & y=f\left( x \right)\to y=-f\left( x \right) \\ ; & y=-f\left( x \right)\to {{y}^{2}}=-f\left( x \right) \\ ;\end{align}$$;; img;;b);;$$\begin{align};  & y=\frac{8}{\left( 3x-2 \right)\left( x+2 \right)} \\ ; & \frac{dy}{dx}=\frac{-8\left[ \left( 3x-2 \right)\left( 1 \right)+\left( 3 \right)\left( x+2 \right) \right]}{{{\left( 3x-2 \right)}^{2}}{{\left( x+2 \right)}^{2}}}=\frac{-16\left( 3x+2 \right)}{{{\left( 3x-2 \right)}^{2}}{{\left( x+2 \right)}^{2}}} \\ ;\end{align}$$;;At stationary points, $$\frac{dy}{dx}=0$$;;$$\begin{align};  & \Rightarrow \frac{-16\left( 3x+2 \right)}{{{\left( 3x-2 \right)}^{2}}{{\left( x+2 \right)}^{2}}}=0 \\ ; & \left( 3x+2 \right)=0\Rightarrow x=-\frac{2}{3} \\ ; & x=-\frac{2}{3}\Rightarrow y=\frac{8}{\left[ 3\left( -\frac{2}{3} \right)-2 \right]\left( -\frac{2}{3}+2 \right)}=-\frac{3}{2} \\ ;\end{align}$$;;Coordinates of stationary point is $$\left( -\frac{2}{3},-\frac{3}{2} \right)$$;;As $$x\to \frac{2}{3},y\to \infty ;x\to -2,y\to \infty $$;;$$\therefore x=\frac{2}{3}$$ and $$x=-2$$ are asymptotes;As $$x\to \infty ,y\to 0$$;$$\Rightarrow y=0$$ is an asymptote;;When x=0, y=-2;y>0 when $$x > \frac{2}{3}$$ or x < -2;y<0 when $$-2 < x < \frac{2}{3}$$;; img

Sketch $$y=\pi \sin x$$ and $$y=\pi -x$$;; img;;Since the graph of $$y=\pi \sin x$$ and $$y=\pi -x$$ intersect at 3 points, deduce that $$\pi \sin x=\pi -x$$ has 3 real roots;; img;;(i) Deduce from the graph that $$\alpha $$ and $$\beta $$ are equidistant from $$\pi $$;;$$\begin{align};  & \Rightarrow \beta -\pi =\pi -\alpha  \\ ; & \therefore \beta =2\pi -\alpha  \\ ;\end{align}$$;;(ii); $$\begin{align};  & \pi \sin x=\pi -x\equiv \pi \sin x-\pi +x=0 \\ ; & f\left( x \right)=\pi \sin x-\pi +x \\ ; & f\left( \frac{3}{2}\pi  \right)=\pi \sin \frac{3}{2}\pi -\pi +\frac{3}{2}\pi =-\frac{1}{2}\pi  \\ ; & f\left( 2\pi  \right)=\pi \sin 2\pi -\pi +2\pi =\pi  \\ ;\end{align}$$;;Linear interpolation on $$\left[ \frac{3}{2}\pi ,2\pi  \right]$$:;;$$\beta =\frac{\left( \frac{3}{2}\pi  \right)\left| f\left( 2\pi  \right) \right|+\left( 2\pi  \right)\left| f\left( \frac{3}{2}\pi  \right) \right|}{\left| f\left( 2\pi  \right) \right|+\left| f\left( \frac{3}{2}\pi  \right) \right|}=\frac{\left( \frac{3}{2}\pi  \right)\left| \pi  \right|+\left( 2\pi  \right)\left| -\frac{1}{2}\pi  \right|}{\left| \pi  \right|+\left| -\frac{1}{2}\pi  \right|}=\frac{5}{3}\pi $$;;(iii) $$f'\left( x \right)=\frac{d}{dx}\left[ \pi \sin x-\pi +x \right]=\pi \cos x+1$$;;Newton-Raphson method:;With $${{x}_{0}}=\frac{1}{4}\pi $$,;;$$\begin{align};  & f\left( {{x}_{0}} \right)=\pi \sin \frac{1}{4}\pi -\pi +\frac{1}{4}\pi =-0.1347 \\ ; & f'\left( {{x}_{0}} \right)=\pi \cos \frac{1}{4}\pi +1=3.2214 \\ ; & {{x}_{1}}={{x}_{0}}-\frac{f\left( {{x}_{0}} \right)}{f'\left( {{x}_{0}} \right)} \\ ; & =\frac{1}{4}\pi -\frac{\left( -0.1347 \right)}{3.2214} \\ ; & =0.8272=0.827 \\ ;\end{align}$$;;$$f''\left( x \right)=\frac{d}{dx}\left[ \pi \cos x+1 \right]=-\pi \sin x$$;; img;;For $$x\in \left[ 0,\frac{1}{2}\pi  \right],f'\left( x \right)>0$$ and $$f''\left( x \right)<0$$;$$\Rightarrow f(x)$$ is increasing and concave downwards;;$$\Rightarrow $$ The tangent from (x0, f(x0)) will intersect the x-axis at $${{x}_{1}}<\alpha $$;$$\therefore \alpha >0.827$$

(i);A cartesian equation for $$\prod$$ is:;$$ 2x+2y+z = 0 $$;;(ii);A vector equation of L is:;$$r=\left( 4i+8j+4k \right)+t\left( i+3j+2k \right),t\in R$$;;C is on L;;$$\begin{align};  & \Rightarrow c=\left( 4i+8j+4k \right)+t\left( i+3j+2k \right) \\ ; & =\left( 4+t \right)i+\left( 8+3t \right)j+\left( 4+2t \right)k,t\in R \\ ; & c.k=0\Rightarrow 4+2t=0,i.e.,t=-2 \\ ; & \therefore c=\left( 4-2t \right)i+\left( 8+3\left( -2 \right) \right)j+\left( 0 \right)k=2i+2j \\ ;\end{align}$$;;An alternative vector equation for L is:;$$L:r=\left( 2i+2j \right)+\lambda \left( i+3j+2k \right)$$;;An alternative Cartesian equation for L is:;;$$\frac{x-2}{1}=\frac{y-2}{3}=\frac{z}{2}$$;i.e. $$p=2, q=2,l=1, m=3, n=2$$;;(iii) Deduce that B(4,8,4) is a point on $$L\left( \lambda =0 \right)$$;;$$\begin{align};  & \overrightarrow{AB}=\overrightarrow{OB}-\overrightarrow{OA}=4i+8j+4k-\left( i+2j-3k \right)=3i+6j+7k \\ ; & \left| \overrightarrow{AB} \right|=\sqrt{{{3}^{2}}+{{6}^{2}}+{{7}^{2}}}=\sqrt{94} \\ ;\end{align}$$;;Let N = foot of perpendicular from A to L;\[\left| \overrightarrow{BN} \right|\]=projection of \[\overrightarrow{AB}\] on L;$$=\frac{\left( 3i+6j+7k \right)\left( i+3j+2k \right)}{\sqrt{{{1}^{2}}+{{3}^{2}}+{{2}^{2}}}}=\frac{3+18+14}{\sqrt{14}}=\frac{35}{\sqrt{14}}$$;;Length of perpendicular from A to L;;$$\left| \overrightarrow{AN} \right|=\sqrt{{{\left| \overrightarrow{AB} \right|}^{2}}+{{\left| \overrightarrow{BN} \right|}^{2}}}=\sqrt{94-{{\left( \frac{35}{\sqrt{14}} \right)}^{2}}}=\sqrt{\frac{91}{14}}=\sqrt{\frac{13}{2}}$$;;(iv) ;a) A vector normal to $$\prod$$ is $$2i+2j+k$$;\[\overrightarrow{AB}=\overrightarrow{OB}-\overrightarrow{OA}=\left( 3i+5j+2k \right)-\left( i+2j-3k \right)=2i+3j+5k\];;Length of projection of \[\overrightarrow{AB}\] onto $$\left( 2i+2j+ki \right)$$;$$d =\frac{\left( 2i+3j+5k \right)\left( 2i+2j+k \right)}{\left| 2i+2j+k \right|}$$;$$=\frac{4+6+5}{\sqrt{{{2}^{2}}+{{2}^{2}}+{{1}^{2}}}}=5$$ units;; img;;b) Length of projection of \[\overrightarrow{AB}\]  onto $$\prod$$,;$$\begin{align};& p = \sqrt{{|\overrightarrow{AB}|}^2 - d^2} \\;& = \sqrt{(2^2 + 3^2 + 5^2) - 5^2} \\;& = \sqrt{13} \space units \end{align}$$

Let $$\alpha ={{1}^{st}}$$ term of G.P. = 10;Let r = common ratio of G.P.;;Sum to infinity of G.P., $${{S}_{\infty }}=15$$;;$$\begin{align};  & \Rightarrow \frac{a}{1-r}=15 \\ ; & \frac{10}{1-r}=15 \\ ; & 1-r=\frac{10}{15}=\frac{2}{3} \\ ; & \therefore r=\frac{1}{3} \\ ;\end{align}$$;;The 3rd term, $${{T}_{3}}=a{{r}^{n-1}}=\left( 10 \right){{\left( \frac{1}{3} \right)}^{3-1}}=\frac{10}{9}$$

$$\begin{align};  & y={{e}^{x}}\cos x \\ ; & \frac{dy}{dx}=\frac{d}{dx}\left[ {{e}^{x}}\cos x \right]=-{{e}^{x}}\sin x+{{e}^{x}}\cos x={{e}^{x}}\left( \cos x-\sin x \right) \\ ; & \frac{{{d}^{2}}y}{d{{x}^{2}}}=\frac{d}{dx}\left[ {{e}^{x}}\left( \cos x-\sin x \right) \right] \\ ; & ={{e}^{x}}\left( -\sin x-\cos x \right)+{{e}^{x}}\left( \cos x-\sin x \right)=-2{{e}^{x}}\sin x \\ ;\end{align}$$;;$$\frac{{{d}^{3}}y}{d{{x}^{3}}}=\frac{d}{dx}\left[ -2{{e}^{x}}\sin x \right]=-2\left( {{e}^{x}}\cos x+{{e}^{x}}\sin x \right)=-2{{e}^{x}}\left( \cos x+\sin x \right)$$;;Let $$y=f\left( x \right)={{e}^{x}}\cos x$$;Maclaurin's series for y=f(x) is: ;;$$\begin{align};  & y=f\left( 0 \right)+f'\left( 0 \right)+\frac{f''\left( 0 \right)}{2!}{{x}^{2}}+\frac{f'''\left( 0 \right)}{3!}{{x}^{3}}+... \\ ; & f\left( 0 \right)={{e}^{0}}\cos 0=1 \\ ; & f'\left( 0 \right)={{e}^{0}}\left( \cos 0-\sin 0 \right)=1 \\ ; & f''\left( 0 \right)=-2{{e}^{0}}\sin 0=0 \\ ; & f'''\left( 0 \right)=-2{{e}^{0}}\left( \cos 0+\sin 0 \right)=-2 \\ ; & \therefore y=1+x+\left( 0 \right){{x}^{2}}+\left( \frac{-2}{3!} \right){{x}^{3}}+... \\ ; & =1+x-\frac{1}{3}{{x}^{3}} \\ ;\end{align}$$
The word SYLLABUS has 8 letters including 2 S's and 2 L's;;No. of ways to arrange 8 letters including 2 S's and 2 L's;$$=\frac{8!}{2!\times 2!}=10080$$;

(i) ;;$$\begin{align};  & A=4\pi {{r}^{2}} \\ ; & \Rightarrow \frac{dA}{dt}=\frac{d}{dt}\left[ 4\pi {{r}^{2}} \right]=8\pi r\frac{dr}{dt} \\ ; & r=3m\Rightarrow \frac{dA}{dt}=2\Rightarrow 2=8\pi \left( 3 \right)\frac{dr}{dt} \\ ; & \therefore \frac{dr}{dt}=\frac{1}{12\pi }m{{s}^{-1}} \\ ;\end{align}$$;;(ii) ;$$\begin{align};  & V=\frac{4}{3}\pi {{r}^{3}}\Rightarrow \frac{dV}{dt}=\frac{d}{dt}\left[ \frac{4}{3}\pi {{r}^{3}} \right]=4\pi {{r}^{2}}\frac{dr}{dt} \\ ; & r=3m\Rightarrow \frac{dr}{dt}=\frac{1}{12\pi }m{{s}^{-1}} \\ ; & \Rightarrow \frac{dV}{dt}=4\pi {{\left( 3 \right)}^{2}}\left( \frac{1}{12}\pi  \right)=3{{m}^{3}}{{s}^{-1}} \\ ;\end{align}$$

Let $$P_n$$ denotes $$\sum\limits_{r=1}^{1}{r\left( r+4 \right)}=1\left( 1+4 \right)=5$$;;For n=1,;;$$\begin{align};  & LHS=\sum\limits_{r=1}^{1}{r\left( r+4 \right)}=1\left( 1+4 \right)=5 \\ ; & RHS=\frac{1}{6}\left( 1 \right)\left( 1+1 \right)\left[ 2\left( 1 \right)+13 \right]=5=LHS \\ ;\end{align}$$;;$$P_1$$ is true;Assume $$P_k$$ is true for $$k\in {{Z}^{+}}$$,;;i.e. $$\sum\limits_{r=1}^{k}{r\left( r+4 \right)}=\frac{1}{6}k\left( k+1 \right)\left( 2k+13 \right)$$;For n=k+1;;$$\begin{align};  & RHS=\frac{1}{6}\left( k+1 \right)\left[ \left( k+1 \right)+1 \right]\left[ 2\left( k+1 \right)+13 \right] \\ ; & LHS=\sum\limits_{r=1}^{k+1}{r\left( r+4 \right)} \\ ; & =\sum\limits_{r=1}^{k}{r\left( r+4 \right)}+\left( k+1 \right)\left( k+1+4 \right) \\ ; & =\frac{1}{6}k\left( k+1 \right)\left( 2k+13 \right)+\left( k+1 \right)\left( k+1+4 \right) \\ ; & =\frac{1}{6}k\left( k+1 \right)\left( 2k+13 \right)+\left( k+1 \right)\left( k+5 \right) \\ ; & =\frac{1}{6}\left( k+1 \right)\left[ k\left( 2k+13 \right)+6\left( k+5 \right) \right] \\ ; & =\frac{1}{6}\left( k+1 \right)\left[ 2{{k}^{2}}+19k+30 \right] \\ ; & =\frac{1}{6}\left( k+1 \right)\left( k+2 \right)\left( 2k+15 \right) \\ ; & =\frac{1}{6}\left( k+1 \right)\left[ \left( k+1 \right)+1 \right]\left[ 2\left( k+1 \right)+13 \right]=RHS \\ ;\end{align}$$;;$$P_{k+1}$$ is true if $$P_k$$ is true.;Therefore, by mathematical induction, $$P_n$$ is true for all $$n\in {{Z}^{+}}$$

Let $$2\sin t+\left( 2\sqrt{3} \right)\cos t$$;;$$\equiv R\sin \left( t+\alpha  \right)=R\sin t\cos \alpha +R\cos t\sin \alpha $$;;Comparing coefficients;;$$\begin{align};  & \sin t:2=R\cos \alpha  \\ ; & \cos t:2\sqrt{3}=R\sin \alpha  \\ ; & \Rightarrow R=\sqrt{{{2}^{2}}+{{\left( 2\sqrt{3} \right)}^{2}}}=4 \\ ; & \tan \alpha =\frac{2\sqrt{3}}{2}\Rightarrow \alpha =\frac{1}{3}\pi  \\ ; & \therefore 2\sin t+\left( 2\sqrt{3} \right)\cos t\equiv 4\sin \left( t+\frac{1}{3}\pi  \right) \\ ; &  \\ ; & \frac{1}{10+2\sin t+\left( 2\sqrt{3} \right)\cos t}\equiv \frac{1}{10+4\sin \left( t+\frac{1}{3}\pi  \right)} \\ ;\end{align}$$;;is least when $$\sin \left( t+\frac{1}{3}\pi  \right)=1$$;;Least value = $$\frac{1}{10+4\left( 1 \right)}=\frac{1}{14}$$

$$\theta $$ is close to zero; $$\begin{align};  & \Rightarrow \cos \theta \approx 1-\frac{1}{2}{{\theta }^{2}} \\ ; & \cos \theta +\frac{31}{8}\theta =0 \\ ; & \equiv \left( 1-\frac{1}{2}{{\theta }^{2}} \right)+\frac{31}{8}\theta =0 \\ ; & 4{{\theta }^{2}}-31\theta -8=0 \\ ; & \left( \theta -8 \right)\left( 4\theta +1 \right)=0 \\ ; & \theta =8(NA) \\ ; & or \\ ; & \theta =-\frac{1}{4} \\ ;\end{align}$$

Let \[f\left( x \right)=\frac{7-3x-{{x}^{2}}}{{{\left( 1-x \right)}^{2}}\left( 2+x \right)}\equiv \frac{A}{1-x}+\frac{B}{{{\left( 1-x \right)}^{2}}}+\frac{C}{2+x}\];Clearing the fractions:;$$\begin{align};  & 7-3x-{{x}^{2}} \\ ; & \equiv A\left( 1-x \right)\left( 2+x \right)+B\left( 2+x \right)+C{{\left( 1-x \right)}^{2}} \\ ; & \equiv \left( -A+C \right){{x}^{2}}+\left( -A+B-2C \right)x+\left( 2A+2B+C \right) \\ ;\end{align}$$;;Cover-up rule:;$$x=-2:C=\frac{7-3\left( -2 \right)-{{\left( -2 \right)}^{2}}}{{{\left[ 1-\left( -2 \right) \right]}^{2}}}=1$$;Comparing coefficients:;\[\begin{align};  & {{x}^{2}}:-1=-A+C \\ ; & \Rightarrow -1=-A+\left( 1 \right)\Rightarrow A=2 \\ ; & {{x}^{0}}:7=2A+2B+C \\ ; & \Rightarrow 2\left( 2 \right)+2B+1\Rightarrow B=1 \\ ; & \therefore f\left( x \right)\equiv \frac{2}{1-x}+\frac{1}{{{\left( 1-x \right)}^{2}}}+\frac{1}{2+x} \\ ; &  \\ ; & f\left( x \right)=2{{\left( 1-x \right)}^{-1}}+{{\left( 1-x \right)}^{-2}}+{{\left( 2+x \right)}^{-1}} \\ ; & =2\left( 1+x+{{x}^{2}}+... \right)+\left( 1+2x+3{{x}^{2}}+... \right)+\frac{1}{2}{{\left( 1+\frac{1}{2}x \right)}^{-1}} \\ ; & =\left( 3+4x+5{{x}^{2}}+... \right)+\frac{1}{2}\left[ 1-\frac{1}{2}x+\frac{\left( -1 \right)\left( -2 \right)}{2!}{{\left( \frac{1}{2}x \right)}^{2}}+... \right] \\ ; & =\left( 3+4x+5{{x}^{2}} \right)+\left( \frac{1}{2}-\frac{1}{4}x+\frac{1}{8}{{x}^{2}} \right)+... \\ ; & \approx 3\frac{1}{2}+3\frac{3}{4}x+5\frac{1}{8}{{x}^{2}} \\ ; & =\frac{1}{8}\left( 28+30x+41{{x}^{2}} \right) \\ ;\end{align}\]

(i) ;$$\begin{align};  & \overrightarrow{AB}=b-a \\ ; & =\left( 5i-2j+3k \right)-\left( 2i+3j-k \right) \\ ; & =3i-5j+4k \\ ;\end{align}$$;;Length of AB;$$=\left| \overrightarrow{AB} \right|=\sqrt{{{3}^{2}}+{{5}^{2}}+{{4}^{2}}}=7.0711=7.07$$;;(ii);$$\begin{align};  & \overrightarrow{AC}=c-a \\ ; & =\left( 4i+j-2k \right)-\left( 2i+3j-k \right) \\ ; & =2i-2j-k \\ ; & \overrightarrow{AB}.\overrightarrow{AC}=\left| \overrightarrow{AB} \right|\left| \overrightarrow{AC} \right|\cos \angle BAC \\ ; & \left( 3i-5j+4k \right).\left( 2i-2j-k \right) \\ ; & =\left| 3i-5j+4k \right|\left| 2i-2j-k \right|\cos \angle BAC \\ ; & =\left( 7.071 \right)\sqrt{{{2}^{2}}+{{2}^{2}}+{{1}^{2}}}\cos \angle BAC \\ ; & \cos \angle BAC=0.5657 \\ ; & \therefore \angle BAC=55.55={{56}^{\circ}} \\ ;\end{align}$$;;(iii) Area of $$\vartriangle ABC$$;\[\begin{align};  & =\frac{1}{2}\left| \overrightarrow{AB} \right|\left| \overrightarrow{AC} \right|\sin \angle BAC \\ ; & =\frac{1}{2}\left( 7.071 \right)\left( 3 \right)\sin \left( {{55.55}^{0}} \right) \\ ; & =8.746=8.75uni{{t}^{2}} \\ ; &  \\ ; & p=\left( 2+3t \right)i+\left( 3-5t \right)j+\left( -1+4t \right)k \\ ; & =\left( 2i+3j-k \right)+t\left( 3i-5j+4k \right) \\ ; & \equiv a+t.\overrightarrow{AB} \\ ;\end{align}\];;$$\Rightarrow$$ p lies on the line through A and B;;OP is perpendicular to AB;$$\begin{align};  & \Rightarrow p.\overrightarrow{AB}=0 \\ ; & \left[ \left( 2+3t \right)i+\left( 3-5t \right)j+\left( -1+4t \right)k \right].\left( 3i-5j+4k \right)=0 \\ ; & 3\left( 2+3t \right)-5\left( 3-5t \right)+4\left( -1+4t \right)=0 \\ ; & 6+9t-15+25t-4+16t=0 \\ ; & 50t=13 \\ ; & i.e. \\ ; & t=\frac{13}{50} \\ ; & \therefore p=\left[ 2+3\left( \frac{13}{50} \right) \right]i+\left[ 3-5\left( \frac{13}{50} \right) \right]j+\left[ -1+4\left( \frac{13}{50} \right) \right]k \\ ; & =\frac{1}{50}\left( 139i+85j+2k \right) \\ ;\end{align}$$

a);Let B1, B2 = the 2 possible positions of B.;Sketch diagram:; img;;(i) Sine rule:;\[\begin{align};  & \frac{\sin \angle ABC}{AC}=\frac{\sin ACB}{AB} \\ ; & \Rightarrow \sin \angle ABC=\frac{\sin ACB}{AB}AC=\frac{\sin {{60}^{\circ}}}{9}\left( 10 \right) \\ ; & =\frac{10}{9}\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}=0.9623 \\ ; & \Rightarrow \angle A{{B}_{1}}C={{74.21}^{\circ}} \\ ; & and \\ ; & \angle A{{B}_{2}}C={{105.79}^{\circ}} \\ ; & \therefore \angle {{B}_{1}}AC={{180}^{\circ}}-{{60}^{\circ}}-{{74.21}^{\circ}}={{45.79}^{\circ}}={{46}^{\circ}} \\ ; & \therefore \angle {{B}_{2}}AC={{180}^{\circ}}-{{60}^{\circ}}-{{105.79}^{\circ}}={{14.21}^{\circ}}={{14}^{\circ}} \\ ;\end{align}\];;(ii) Sine rule:;$$\begin{align};  & \frac{BC}{\sin \angle BAC}=\frac{AB}{\sin \angle ACB} \\ ; & \Rightarrow BC=\frac{AB}{\sin \angle ACB}\sin \angle BAC \\ ; & \therefore {{B}_{1}}C=\frac{9}{\sin {{60}^{\circ}}}\sin \left( {{45.79}^{\circ}} \right)=7.449=7.45cm \\ ; & {{B}_{2}}C=\frac{9}{\sin {{60}^{\circ}}}\sin \left( {{14.21}^{\circ}} \right) \\ ; & =2.551=2.55cm \\ ;\end{align}$$;;b);$$\begin{align};  & 2\sin x\cos x+4{{\cos }^{2}}x=1 \\ ; & \equiv 2\tan x+4={{\sec }^{2}}x \\ ; & 2\tan x+4=1+{{\tan }^{2}}x \\ ; & \therefore {{\tan }^{2}}x-2\tan x-3=0 \\ ; &  \\ ; & {{\tan }^{2}}x-2\tan x-3=0 \\ ; & \left( \tan x+1 \right)\left( \tan x-3 \right)=0 \\ ; & \tan x=-1 \\ ; & or \\ ; & \tan x=3 \\ ; & x=180{{n}^{\circ}}-{{45}^{\circ}} \\ ; & or \\ ; & x=180{{n}^{\circ}}+{{71.57}^{\circ}},n\in Z \\ ;\end{align}$$;General solution for x is;$$\begin{align};  & x=180{{n}^{\circ}}-{{45}^{\circ}} \\ ; & or \\ ; & x=180{{n}^{\circ}}+{{72}^{\circ}} \\ ;\end{align}$$

$$\begin{align};  & x=2+t,y=1-{{t}^{2}} \\ ; & \frac{dy}{dx}=\frac{dy}{dt}/\frac{dx}{dt}=\frac{d}{dt}\left[ 1-{{t}^{2}} \right]/\frac{d}{dt}\left[ 2+t \right]=- \frac{2t}{1}=-2t \\ ;\end{align}$$;;Gradient of a normal = $$-1/\frac{dy}{dx}=\frac{1}{2t}$$;Equation of a normal is;$$\begin{align};  & y-\left( 1-{{t}^{2}} \right)=\frac{1}{2t}\left[ x-\left( 2+t \right) \right] \\ ; & 2ty-2t+2{{t}^{3}}=x-2-t \\ ; & \therefore x-2ty=2{{t}^{3}}-t+2 \\ ;\end{align}$$;At T, where t=2, equation of normal is;$$\begin{align};  & x-2\left( 2 \right)y=2{{\left( 2 \right)}^{3}}-\left( 2 \right)+2 \\ ; & x-4y=16---\left( 1 \right) \\ ;\end{align}$$;At P, where t=p,;x=2+p and y=1-p2,;P(2+p,1-p2) is on normal (1);$$\begin{align};  & \Rightarrow \left( 2+p \right)-4\left( 1-{{p}^{2}} \right)=16 \\ ; & \therefore 4{{p}^{2}}+p-18=0 \\ ; &  \\ ; & 4{{p}^{2}}+p-18=0 \\ ; & \equiv \left( p-2 \right)\left( 4p+9 \right)=0 \\ ; & \therefore p=2 \\ ; & or \\ ; & p=-\frac{9}{4} \\ ;\end{align}$$;;Coordinates of P;$$\begin{align};  & =\left[ 2+\left( -\frac{9}{4} \right),1-{{\left( -\frac{9}{4} \right)}^{2}} \right]=\left( -\frac{1}{4},-\frac{65}{16} \right) \\ ; &  \\ ; & x=2+t\equiv t=x-2 \\ ;\end{align}$$;Subt into $$y=1-t^2$$;$$Y=1-(x-2)^2$$;;Sketch $$y=1-(x-2)^2$$;a maximum curve with ymax=1 at x=2;At y=0, x=1 or x=3; at x=0, y=-3;; img

a);x+2=A(2x+2)+B for all x,;Comparing coefficients:;$$\begin{align};  & x:1=2A\Rightarrow A=\frac{1}{2} \\ ; & {{x}^{0}}:2=2A+B \\ ; & i.e. \\ ; & 2=2\left( \frac{1}{2} \right)+B\Rightarrow 1 \\ ; &  \\ ; & \int{\frac{x+2}{{{x}^{2}}+2x+5}dx} \\ ; & =\int{\frac{\frac{1}{2}\left( 2x+2 \right)+1}{{{x}^{2}}+2x+5}dx} \\ ; & =\frac{1}{2}\int{\frac{2x+2}{{{x}^{2}}+2x+5}dx}+\int{\frac{1}{{{x}^{2}}+2x+5}dx} \\ ; & =\frac{1}{2}\ln \left( {{x}^{2}}+2x+5 \right)+\frac{1}{2}\int{\frac{2}{{{\left( x+1 \right)}^{2}}+{{2}^{2}}}dx}+{{c}_{1}} \\ ; & =\frac{1}{2}\ln \left( {{x}^{2}}+2x+5 \right)+\frac{1}{2}{{\tan }^{-1}}\frac{x+1}{2}+c \\ ;\end{align}$$;;b);$$\begin{align};  & x=4{{\cos }^{2}}\theta +7{{\sin }^{2}}\theta  \\ ; & =4{{\cos }^{2}}\theta +7\left( 1-{{\cos }^{2}}\theta  \right)=7-3{{\cos }^{2}}\theta  \\ ; & \therefore 7-x=3{{\cos }^{2}}\theta  \\ ; &  \\ ; & x=4{{\cos }^{2}}\theta +7{{\sin }^{2}}\theta  \\ ; & =4\left( 1-{{\sin }^{2}}\theta  \right)+7{{\sin }^{2}}\theta =4+3{{\sin }^{2}}\theta  \\ ; & \therefore x-4=3{{\sin }^{2}}\theta  \\ ; &  \\ ; & x=4{{\cos }^{2}}\theta +7{{\sin }^{2}}\theta , \\ ; & 7-x=3{{\cos }^{2}}\theta  \\ ; & and \\ ; & x-4=3{{\sin }^{2}}\theta , \\ ; &  \\ ; & x-4=3{{\sin }^{2}}\theta \Rightarrow dx=6\sin \theta \cos \theta d\theta  \\ ; & x=4,3{{\sin }^{2}}\theta =0\Rightarrow \theta =0 \\ ; & x=7,3{{\cos }^{2}}\theta =0\Rightarrow \theta =\frac{1}{2}\pi  \\ ; & \therefore \int_{4}^{7}{\frac{1}{\sqrt{\left( x-4 \right)\left( 7-x \right)}}dx}\equiv \int_{0}^{\frac{1}{2}\pi }{\frac{6\sin \theta \cos \theta }{\sqrt{\left( 3{{\sin }^{2}}\theta  \right)\left( 3{{\cos }^{2}}\theta  \right)}}d\theta } \\ ; & =\int_{0}^{\frac{1}{2}\pi }{2d\theta }=\left[ 2\theta  \right]_{0}^{\frac{1}{2}\pi }=\pi  \\ ;\end{align}$$;

a) y=x + 3sinx;$$\frac{dy}{dx}=\frac{d}{dx}\left[ x+3\sin x \right]=1+3\cos x$$;At turning points, ;$$\begin{align};  & \frac{dy}{dx}=0 \\ ; & \Rightarrow 1+3\cos x=0 \\ ; & \cos x=-\frac{1}{3} \\ ; & 0\le x\le \pi ,x=1.9106 \\ ; & x=1.9106\Rightarrow y=1.9106+3\sin \left( 1.9106 \right)=4.7391 \\ ;\end{align}$$;;Coordinates of the turning point are (1.91, 4.74);Sketch y=x+3sinx for $$0\le x\le \pi $$;$$\begin{align};  & x=0,y=0 \\ ; & x=\pi ,y=\pi  \\ ;\end{align}$$;Deduce that the curve is equivalent to y=3sinx with its x-axis transformed onto y=x;; img;;b);$$\begin{align} (i);  & \int_{0}^{\pi }{{{\sin }^{2}}xdx} \\ ; & =\int_{0}^{\pi }{\frac{1}{2}\left( 1-\cos 2x \right)dx} \\ ; & =\frac{1}{2}\left[ x-\frac{1}{2}\sin 2x \right]_{0}^{\pi } \\ ; & =\frac{1}{2}\left[ \pi -0 \right]=\frac{1}{2}\pi  \\ ;\end{align}$$;;$$\begin{align} (ii); & \int_{0}^{\pi }{x\sin xdx} \\ ; & =\left[ -x\cos x \right]_{0}^{\pi }+\int_{0}^{\pi }{\cos xdx} \\ ; & =\left[ \pi -0 \right]+\left[ \sin x \right]_{0}^{\pi }=\pi  \\ ;\end{align}$$;;c) Volume generated about the x-axis, Vx;\[\begin{align};  & =\int_{0}^{\pi }{\pi {{y}^{2}}dx}=\pi \int_{0}^{\pi }{{{\left( x+3\sin x \right)}^{2}}dx} \\ ; & =\pi \int_{0}^{\pi }{\left( {{x}^{2}}+6x\sin x+9{{\sin }^{2}}x \right)dx} \\ ; & =\pi \left\{ \int_{0}^{\pi }{{{x}^{2}}dx}+6\int_{0}^{\pi }{x\sin xdx}+9\int_{0}^{\pi }{{{\sin }^{2}}xdx} \right\} \\ ; & =\pi \left\{ \left[ \frac{1}{3}{{x}^{3}} \right]_{0}^{\pi }+6\left( \pi  \right)+9\left( \frac{1}{2}\pi  \right) \right\} \\ ; & =\frac{1}{3}{{\pi }^{4}}+\frac{21}{2}{{\pi }^{2}} \\ ; & =\frac{1}{6}{{\pi }^{2}}\left( 2{{\pi }^{2}}+63 \right)uni{{t}^{3}} \\ ;\end{align}\]

(a);z = w + 3i + 2  $$\equiv$$ w = z - 3i - 2   ----(1);$${z}^2 - iw + 5 - 2 i = 0$$                      ----(2);;Subst (1) into (2):;$${z}^{2} - i\left( z - 3i - 2\right) + 5 - 2 i = 0$$;$${z}^{2} - i z - 3 + 2 i + 5 - 2 i = 0$$;$${z}^{2} - i z + 2 = 0$$;;$$\therefore z =\frac{ i \pm \sqrt{{i}^{2} - 4(1)(2)}}{2}$$;;$$=\frac{1}{2}\left(i \pm \sqrt{-9} \right) = \frac{1}{2}\left( i \pm 3 i\right) = -i\text{ or }2i$$;;w = z - 3 i - 2;= ( - i ) - 3 i - 2   or  ( 2 i ) - 3 i - 2;= - 4 i - 2           or   - i - 2;$$\therefore$$ (z, w) = ( - i, - 2 - 4 i )  or ( 2 i, - 2 - i );;(b)(i);$$q = \frac{e^{i\theta}}{1 - e^{i\theta}}$$ = $$\frac{e^{i\theta}}{1-e^{i\theta}}\times\frac{e^{-\frac{1}{2}i\theta}}{e^{-\frac{1}{2}i\theta}}$$;$$=\frac{e^{\frac{1}{2}i\theta}}{{e^{-\frac{1}{2}i\theta}}-{e^{\frac{1}{2}i\theta}}}$$;$$=\frac{\cos\frac{1}{2}\theta + i\sin\frac{1}{2}\theta}{\left(\cos\frac{1}{2}\theta - i\sin\frac{1}{2}\theta\right) - \left(\cos\frac{1}{2}\theta + i\sin\frac{1}{2}\theta\right)}$$;$$=\frac{\cos\frac{1}{2}\theta + i\sin\frac{1}{2}\theta}{-2i\sin\frac{1}{2}\theta}$$;$$=\frac{\cos\frac{1}{2}\theta}{-2i\sin\frac{1}{2}\theta} \times \frac{i}{i}\text{ }+\text{ }\frac{i\sin\frac{1}{2}\theta}{-2i\sin\frac{1}{2}\theta}$$;$$= i\frac{1}{2}\cot(\frac{1}{2}\theta) - \frac{1}{2}$$;;(b)(ii);$$\therefore$$ Re($$q$$) = -$$\frac{1}{2}$$; Im($$q$$) = $$\frac{1}{2}\cot(\frac{1}{2}\theta)$$

(i);Topic removed from syllabus.;;(ii);Topic removed from syllabus.;;(iii) Deduce that :;$$\overrightarrow{OF} = 10 k $$,;$$\overrightarrow{OG} = 4 i + 14 k $$;$$\overrightarrow{OH} = 8 j + 18 k $$;;Let D = mid-point of AF;Let E = foot of perpendicular from D to GH;;$$\Rightarrow \overrightarrow{OD} = \frac{1}{2}\overrightarrow{OA} + \frac{1}{2}\overrightarrow{OF}$$;$$=\frac{1}{2}( 4i ) + \frac{1}{2}( 10k ) = 2i + 5k$$;;$$\overrightarrow{GH} = \overrightarrow{OH} - \overrightarrow{OG}$$;$$=( 8i + 18k) - ( 4i + 14k)$$;$$= - 4i + 8j +4k$$;;E is on GH;;$$\Rightarrow \overrightarrow{OE} = \overrightarrow{OG} + t\overrightarrow{GH}$$ , for some $$t \in \mathbb{R}$$;$$= ( 4i + 14k ) + t ( - 4i + 8j + 4k)$$;$$= ( 4 - 4t )i + 8tj + ( 14 + 4t )k$$;;$$\overrightarrow{DE} = \overrightarrow{OE} - \overrightarrow{OD}$$;$$= ( 4 - 4t )i + 8tj + ( 14 + 4t )k - ( 2i + 5k )$$;$$= ( 2 - 4t )i + 8tj + ( 9 + 4t )k$$;;DE is perpendicular to GH;$$\Rightarrow \overrightarrow{DE} . \overrightarrow{GH} = 0$$;$$\left[( 2 - 4t )i + 8tj + ( 9 + 4t )k\right] . \left[- 4i + 8j +4k\right] = 0$$;$$-4( 2 - 4t )+ 8( 8t ) + 4( 9 + 4t ) = 0$$;$$28 + 96t = 0$$;$$t = -\frac{7}{24}$$;;$$\therefore \overrightarrow{DE} = ( 2 - 4t )i + 8tj + ( 9 + 4t )k$$;$$=\left[ 2 - 4(-\frac{7}{24})\right]i + \left[ 8(-\frac{7}{24})\right]j + \left[ 9 + 4(-\frac{7}{24})\right]k$$;$$=\frac{19}{6}i - \frac{7}{3}j + \frac{47}{6}k$$;;Perpendicular distance from D to GH;$$=| \overrightarrow{DE} | = \sqrt{{(\frac{19}{6}})^{2}+{(\frac{7}{3})}^{2}+{(\frac{47}{6})}^{2}}$$;$$=8.765 = 8.77$$ units (ans)
