\[\begin{align};  & \sum\limits_{n=1}^{N}{\left( {{2}^{n-2}}+3n \right)} \\ ; & =\sum\limits_{n=1}^{N}{{{2}^{n-2}}+3\sum\limits_{n=1}^{N}{n}} \\ ; & =\left[ {{2}^{-1}}+{{2}^{0}}+{{2}^{1}}+...+{{2}^{N-2}} \right]+3\left[ \frac{1}{2}N\left( N+1 \right) \right] \\ ; & =\frac{\left( \frac{1}{2} \right)\left( {{2}^{N}}-1 \right)}{2-1}+\frac{3}{2}N\left( N+1 \right) \\ ; & =\frac{1}{2}\left( {{2}^{N}}-1 \right)+\frac{3}{2}N\left( N+1 \right) \\ ;\end{align}\]

(i) $${{\left( x+iy \right)}^{2}}=i\Rightarrow {{x}^{2}}-{{y}^{2}}+2ixy=i$$;Equating Re parts: $${{x}^{2}}-{{y}^{2}}=0\Rightarrow {{x}^{2}}={{y}^{2}}$$;Equating Im parts: $$2xy=1\Rightarrow y=\frac{1}{2x}$$;Subst $$y=\frac{1}{2x}$$ into $${{x}^{2}}={{y}^{2}}$$:;\[\begin{align};  & {{x}^{2}}={{\left( \frac{1}{2x} \right)}^{2}} \\ ; & {{x}^{4}}=\frac{1}{4} \\ ; & x=\pm \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}},y=\pm \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \\ ;\end{align}\];Possible values of (x,y) are $$\left( \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}},\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \right)$$ and $$\left( -\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}},-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \right)$$;;(ii) Let $$w=a+ib$$;Deduce from (i) that $${{w}^{2}}={{\left( a+ib \right)}^{2}}=-i$$;$$\Rightarrow a=\pm \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}},b=\mp \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}$$;Possible values of w are;$$\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left( 1-i \right)$$ and $$\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left( -1+i \right)$$;

a) ABRACADABRA;No. of ways to arrange the 11 letters including 5 A's, 2 B's, 2 R's;$$=\frac{11!}{5!\times 2!\times 2!}=83160$$;;b) 5-digit even number consists of 2, 3, 4, 5, 6;Number is even $$\Rightarrow$$ last digit is 2, 4 or 6, i.e. 3 possibilities;No. of ways to arrange remaining 4 digits = 4! = 24;No. of possible numbers = 24 x 3 =72;No. of wrong numbers = 72 - 1 =71

$$\begin{align};  & \left( 1-{{x}^{2}} \right)\frac{dy}{dx}-xy=1,\left| x \right|<1 \\ ; & \equiv \frac{dy}{dx}-\frac{x}{1-{{x}^{2}}}y=\frac{1}{1-{{x}^{2}}} \\ ;\end{align}$$;Let $$h\left( x \right)=\int{\frac{-x}{1-{{x}^{2}}}dx}=\frac{1}{2}\ln \left( 1-{{x}^{2}} \right)=\ln \sqrt{1-{{x}^{2}}}$$;Integrating factor,;$$\begin{align};  & {{e}^{h\left( x \right)}}={{e}^{\ln \sqrt{1-{{x}^{2}}}}}=\sqrt{1-{{x}^{2}}} \\ ; & {{e}^{-h\left( x \right)}}={{e}^{-\ln \sqrt{1-{{x}^{2}}}}}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-{{x}^{2}}}} \\ ;\end{align}$$;General solution is;$$\begin{align};  & y={{e}^{-h\left( x \right)}}\left[ \int{{{e}^{h\left( x \right)}}\frac{1}{1-{{x}^{2}}}dx}+c \right] \\ ; & =\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-{{x}^{2}}}}\left[ \int{\sqrt{1-{{x}^{2}}}\frac{1}{1-{{x}^{2}}}dx}+c \right] \\ ; & =\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-{{x}^{2}}}}\left[ \int{\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-{{x}^{2}}}}dx}+c \right] \\ ; & =\frac{{{\sin }^{-1}}x+c}{\sqrt{1-{{x}^{2}}}} \\ ;\end{align}$$;

(i) Sketch $$\vartriangle ABC$$; img;;Sine rule:;$$\begin{align};  & \frac{\sin \theta }{1}=\frac{\sin \left( \theta +\alpha  \right)}{2} \\ ; & 2\sin \theta =\sin \left( \theta +\alpha  \right)=\sin \theta \cos \alpha +\cos \theta \sin \alpha  \\ ; & 2\sin \theta -\sin \theta \cos \alpha =\cos \theta \sin \alpha  \\ ; & \sin \theta \left( 2-\cos \alpha  \right)=\cos \theta \sin \alpha  \\ ; & \frac{\sin \theta }{\cos \theta }=\frac{\sin \alpha }{2-\cos \alpha } \\ ; & \therefore \tan \theta =\frac{\sin \alpha }{2-\cos \alpha } \\ ;\end{align}$$;;(ii) ;img;;Deduce from $$\angle B=\theta $$ and $$\angle C=\theta +\alpha $$ that $$\theta $$ is acute, i.e. $$\theta \le \frac{1}{2}\pi $$;$$\begin{align};  & 2\sin \theta =\sin \left( \theta +\alpha  \right)\le 1\Rightarrow \sin \theta \le \frac{1}{2} \\ ; & \Rightarrow \theta \le \frac{1}{6}\pi \Rightarrow {{\theta }_{l\arg est}}=\frac{1}{6}\pi  \\ ;\end{align}$$

;$$\begin{align};  & x={{t}^{2}},y={{t}^{3}} \\ ; & \Rightarrow \frac{dy}{dx}=\frac{dy}{dt}/\frac{dx}{dt}=\frac{d}{dt}\left[ {{t}^{3}} \right]/\frac{d}{dt}\left[ {{t}^{2}} \right] \\ ; & =\frac{3{{t}^{2}}}{2t}=\frac{3}{2}t \\ ;\end{align}$$;At the point with the parameter t, equation of a tangent is;$$\begin{align};  & y-\left( {{t}^{3}} \right)=\frac{3}{2}t\left[ x-\left( {{t}^{2}} \right) \right] \\ ; & 2y-2{{t}^{3}}=3tx-3{{t}^{3}} \\ ; & \therefore 2y-3tx+{{t}^{3}}=0 \\ ;\end{align}$$;;(i) Tangent passes through fixed point (X, Y);$$\Rightarrow 2Y-3tX+{{t}^{3}}=0$$, which is a cubic equation in the parameter t;$$\Rightarrow$$ there cannot be more than 3 real roots t;$$\Rightarrow$$ there cannot be more than 3 tangents passing through (X, Y);;(ii) At the point where t=2, equation of tangent is;$$\begin{align};  & 2y-3\left( 2 \right)x+{{2}^{3}}=0 \\ ; & y-3x+4=0 \\ ;\end{align}$$;The tangent meets curve at t=u, i.e. the point $$\left( {{u}^{2}},{{u}^{3}} \right)$$;$$\begin{align};  & \Rightarrow {{u}^{3}}-3{{u}^{2}}+4=0 \\ ; & \left( u+1 \right)\left( {{u}^{2}}-4u+4 \right)=0 \\ ; & \left( u+1 \right){{\left( u-2 \right)}^{2}}=0 \\ ;\end{align}$$;$$u=-1$$ or $$u=2$$ (the tangent);$$\therefore u=-1$$

$$f\left( x \right)=\frac{{{x}^{3}}+2}{{{x}^{2}}-1}\equiv x+\frac{x+2}{{{x}^{2}}-1}\equiv x=\frac{x+2}{\left( x+1 \right)\left( x-1 \right)}$$;Let $$\frac{x+2}{\left( x+1 \right)\left( x-1 \right)}=\frac{A}{x+1}+\frac{B}{x-1}$$;Clearing the fractions:;$$x+2=A\left( x-1 \right)+B\left( x+1 \right)$$;Cover-up rule:;$$\begin{align};  & x=-1:A=\frac{\left( -1 \right)+2}{\left( -1 \right)-1}=-\frac{1}{2} \\ ; & x=1:B=\frac{\left( 1 \right)+2}{\left( 1 \right)+1}=\frac{3}{2} \\ ; & \therefore f\left( x \right)\equiv x-\frac{1}{2\left( x+1 \right)}+\frac{3}{2\left( x-1 \right)} \\ ;\end{align}$$;;$$\begin{align};  & \int\limits_{-4}^{-2}{f\left( x \right)dx} \\ ; & \equiv \int\limits_{-4}^{-2}{\left[ x-\frac{1}{2\left( x+1 \right)}+\frac{3}{2\left( x-1 \right)} \right]dx} \\ ; & =\left[ \frac{1}{2}{{x}^{2}}-\frac{1}{2}\ln \left| x+1 \right|+\frac{3}{2}\ln \left| x-1 \right| \right]_{-4}^{-2} \\ ; & =\frac{1}{2}\left[ {{x}^{2}}-\ln \left| x+1 \right|+3\ln \left| x-1 \right| \right]_{-4}^{-2} \\ ; & =\frac{1}{2}\left[ {{\left( -2 \right)}^{2}}-\ln \left| -2+1 \right|+3\ln \left| -2-1 \right| \right]-\frac{1}{2}\left[ {{\left( -4 \right)}^{2}}-\ln \left| -4+1 \right|+3\ln \left| -4-1 \right| \right] \\ ; & =\frac{1}{2}\left[ 4-\ln 1+3\ln 3 \right]-\frac{1}{2}\left[ 16-\ln 3+3\ln 5 \right] \\ ; & =-6.2169=-6.22\left( 3sf \right) \\ ;\end{align}$$;

Let $$P_n$$ denotes;$$\begin{align};  & \sum\limits_{r=1}^{n}{\frac{1}{r\left( r+1 \right)\left( r+2 \right)}}=\frac{n\left( n+3 \right)}{4\left( n+1 \right)\left( n+2 \right)} \\ ; & n=1, \\ ; & LHS=\frac{1}{1\left( 1+1 \right)\left( 1+2 \right)}=\frac{1}{6} \\ ; & RHS=\frac{1\left( 1+3 \right)}{4\left( 1+1 \right)\left( 1+2 \right)}=\frac{1}{6}=LHS \\ ;\end{align}$$;$$\therefore P_1$$ is true;Assume $$P_k$$ is true for $$k\in {{Z}^{+}}$$,;i.e. $$\sum\limits_{r=1}^{n}{\frac{1}{r\left( r+1 \right)\left( r+2 \right)}}=\frac{k\left( k+3 \right)}{4\left( k+1 \right)\left( k+2 \right)}$$;For n=k+1,;$$\begin{align};  & RHS=\frac{\left( k+1 \right)\left[ \left( k+1 \right)+3 \right]}{4\left[ \left( k+1 \right)+1 \right]\left[ \left( k+1 \right)+2 \right]} \\ ; & LHS=\sum\limits_{r=1}^{k+1}{\frac{1}{r\left( r+1 \right)\left( r+2 \right)}} \\ ; & =\sum\limits_{r=1}^{k}{\frac{1}{r\left( r+1 \right)\left( r+2 \right)}}+\frac{1}{\left( k+1 \right)\left[ \left( k+1 \right)+1 \right]\left[ \left( k+1 \right)+2 \right]} \\ ; & =\frac{k\left( k+3 \right)}{4\left( k+1 \right)\left( k+2 \right)}+\frac{1}{\left( k+1 \right)\left( k+2 \right)\left( k+3 \right)} \\ ; & =\frac{k\left( k+3 \right)\left( k+3 \right)+4}{4\left( k+1 \right)\left( k+2 \right)\left( k+3 \right)} \\ ; & =\frac{{{k}^{3}}+6{{k}^{2}}+9k+4}{4\left( k+1 \right)\left( k+2 \right)\left( k+3 \right)} \\ ; & =\frac{\left( k+1 \right)\left( {{k}^{2}}+5k+4 \right)}{4\left( k+1 \right)\left( k+2 \right)\left( k+3 \right)} \\ ; & =\frac{{{k}^{2}}+5k+4}{4\left( k+2 \right)\left( k+3 \right)}=\frac{\left( k+1 \right)\left( k+4 \right)}{4\left( k+2 \right)\left( k+3 \right)} \\ ; & =\frac{\left( k+1 \right)\left[ \left( k+1 \right)+3 \right]}{4\left[ \left( k+1 \right)+1 \right]\left[ \left( k+1 \right)+2 \right]}=RHS \\ ;\end{align}$$;$$P_{k+1}$$ is true if $$P_k$$ is true.;Therefore, by mathematical induction, $$P_n$$ is true for all $$n\in {{Z}^{+}}$$;;For all $$n\in {{Z}^{+}}$$,;$$\begin{align};  & {{n}^{2}}+3n<{{n}^{2}}+3n+2 \\ ; & \equiv n\left( n+3 \right)<\left( n+1 \right)\left( n+2 \right) \\ ; & \Rightarrow \frac{n\left( n+3 \right)}{\left( n+1 \right)\left( n+2 \right)}<1 \\ ; & \therefore \frac{n\left( n+3 \right)}{4\left( n+1 \right)\left( n+2 \right)}<\frac{1}{4} \\ ;\end{align}$$;For all $$r\in {{Z}^{+}}$$,;$$\begin{align};  & 3r+1>2r \\ ; & {{r}^{3}}+3{{r}^{2}}+3r+1>{{r}^{3}}+3{{r}^{2}}+2r \\ ; & {{\left( r+1 \right)}^{3}}>r\left( r+1 \right)\left( r+2 \right) \\ ; & \Rightarrow \frac{1}{{{\left( r+1 \right)}^{3}}}<\frac{1}{r\left( r+1 \right)\left( r+2 \right)} \\ ; & \sum\limits_{r=1}^{n}{\frac{1}{{{\left( r+1 \right)}^{3}}}}<\sum\limits_{r=1}^{n}{\frac{1}{r\left( r+1 \right)\left( r+2 \right)}} \\ ; & \therefore \sum\limits_{r=1}^{n}{\frac{1}{{{\left( r+1 \right)}^{3}}}}<\frac{n\left( n+3 \right)}{4\left( n+1 \right)\left( n+2 \right)}<\frac{1}{4} \\ ;\end{align}$$

$$\begin{align};  & \cos 3\theta +\cos \theta =2\cos \frac{1}{2}\left( 3\theta +\theta  \right)\cos \frac{1}{2}\left( 3\theta -\theta  \right) \\ ; & =2\cos 2\theta \cos \theta  \\ ;\end{align}$$;;$$\begin{align};  & \cos 3\theta +\cos \theta =2\cos 2\theta \cos \theta  \\ ; & =2\left( 2{{\cos }^{2}}\theta -1 \right)\cos \theta  \\ ; & =4{{\cos }^{2}}\theta -2\cos \theta  \\ ; & \therefore \cos 3\theta =4{{\cos }^{2}}\theta -3\cos \theta  \\ ; & \equiv 4{{c}^{3}}-3c,\left( c=\cos \theta  \right) \\ ;\end{align}$$;;With $$\theta =\frac{4}{3}\pi $$;$$\begin{align};  & \cos 3\theta =\cos 3\left( \frac{4}{5}\pi  \right)=\cos \frac{12}{5}\pi  \\ ; & \equiv \cos \left( 2\pi -\frac{12}{5}\pi  \right)=\cos \frac{8}{5}\pi  \\ ; & =\cos 2\left( \frac{4}{5}\pi  \right)=\cos 2\theta  \\ ; & \therefore \theta =\frac{4}{5}\pi  \\ ;\end{align}$$;;Let $$c=\cos \theta =\cos \frac{4}{5}\pi $$;$$\begin{align};  & \Rightarrow \cos 3\theta =\cos 2\theta  \\ ; & \equiv 4{{c}^{3}}-3c=2{{c}^{2}}-1 \\ ; & \equiv 4{{c}^{3}}-3c-2{{c}^{2}}+1=0 \\ ;\end{align}$$;$$\therefore \cos \frac{4}{5}\pi $$ is a root of eqn (1);;$$\begin{align};  & 4{{c}^{3}}-2{{c}^{2}}-3c+1=0 \\ ; & \left( c-1 \right)\left( 4{{c}^{2}}+2c-1 \right)=0 \\ ;\end{align}$$;$$\therefore c=1$$ or $$c=-\frac{1}{4}\pm \frac{\sqrt{5}}{4}$$;$$\therefore c=1,-\frac{1}{4}+\frac{\sqrt{5}}{4},-\frac{1}{4}-\frac{\sqrt{5}}{4}$$;;$$\begin{align};  & \cos \frac{4}{5}\pi <0\Rightarrow \left\{ \begin{align};  & \cos \frac{4}{5}\pi ;e 1 \\ ; & \cos \frac{4}{5}\pi ;e -\frac{1}{4}+\frac{\sqrt{5}}{4} \\ ;\end{align} \right. \\ ; & \therefore \cos \frac{4}{5}\pi =-\frac{1}{4}-\frac{\sqrt{5}}{4} \\ ;\end{align}$$

& =3\cos 2x-4\sin 2x+7 \\ ; & i.e.a=3,b=-4,c=4 \\ ;\end{align}$$;Let \[3\cos 2x-4\sin 2x=R\cos \left( 2x+\alpha  \right)\];\[\begin{align};  & =R\cos 2x\cos \alpha -R\sin 2x\sin \alpha  \\ ; & \Rightarrow R=\sqrt{{{3}^{2}}+{{4}^{2}}}=5 \\ ;  & f{{\left( x \right)}_{greatest}}=5\left( 1 \right)+7=12 \\ ; & f{{\left( x \right)}_{least}}=5\left( -1 \right)+7=2 \\ ;\end{align}$$;; (i) $$f\left( x \right)=2$$;From earlier work,;$$\begin{align};  & f{{\left( x \right)}_{least}}=2\Rightarrow \cos \left( 2x+{{53.13}^{\circ}} \right)=-1 \\ ; & 2x+{{53.13}^{\circ}}=360n\pm {{180}^{\circ}},n\in Z \\ ; & \equiv \left( 2n+1 \right){{180}^{\circ}} \\ ; & 2x=\left( 2n+1 \right){{180}^{\circ}}-{{53.13}^{\circ}}=\left( 2n \right){{180}^{\circ}}+126.87 \\ ; & \therefore x=180{{n}^{\circ}}+{{63.4}^{\circ}}\left( 1dp \right) \\ ;\end{align}$$;;(ii) $$2\le f\left( x \right)\le \frac{9}{2}$$;Sketch $$y=f\left( x \right)=5\cos \left( 2x+{{53.13}^{\circ}} \right)+7$$;; img;;From earlier work,;$$f{{\left( x \right)}_{least}}=2\Rightarrow f\left( x \right)\ge 2,\forall x\in R$$;For $$f\left( x \right)=5\cos \left( 2x+{{53.13}^{\circ}} \right)+7=\frac{9}{2}$$;$$\begin{align};  & \cos \left( 2x+{{53.13}^{\circ}} \right)=-\frac{1}{2} \\ ; & 2x+{{53.13}^{\circ}}=360n\pm {{120}^{\circ}},n\in Z \\ ; & 2x=360n\pm {{120}^{\circ}}-{{53.13}^{\circ}} \\ ; & x=180n\pm {{60}^{\circ}}-{{26.57}^{\circ}} \\ ;\end{align}$$;For $${{0}^{\circ}}\le x\le {{180}^{\circ}}$$,;$$\begin{align};  & {{x}_{1}}=180\left( 0 \right)+60-26.57={{33.43}^{\circ}} \\ ; & {{x}_{2}}=180\left( 1 \right)-60-26.57={{93.43}^{\circ}} \\ ;\end{align}$$;For $$2\le f\left( x \right)\le \frac{9}{2},{{33.4}^{\circ}}\le x\le {{93.4}^{\circ}}\left( 1dp \right)$$;

(i) $$y = x^4  - 4x^3  + 27$$;$$\frac{dy}{dx} = \frac{d}{dx}[x^4  - 4x^3  + 27]$$;$$ = 4x^3 - 12x^2 = 4x^2 ( x - 3 )$$;At stationary points, $$\frac{dy}{dx} = 0 $$;$$\Rightarrow 4x^2 ( x - 3 ) = 0$$;$$x = 0$$ or $$x = 3$$;$$y = (0) - (0) + 27 = 27$$ or $$y = (3)^4 - 4(3)^3 + 27 = 0$$;$$\therefore $$ Coordinates of the stationary pts are:;$$( 0 , 27 ) $$ and $$ ( 3 , 0 )$$ (ans);;(ii) At $$x  = 0^{-}$$. $$\frac{dy}{dx} =  4x^2 ( x - 3 ) < 0 $$;At $$x  = 0^{+}$$. $$\frac{dy}{dx} =  4x^2 ( x - 3 ) > 0 $$;$$\therefore ( 0 , 27 )$$ is a point of inflexion. (ans);;$$\frac{d^y}{dx^2} = \frac{d}{dx}[4x^3 - 12x^2] = 12x^2 - 24x$$;At $$x = 3$$, $$\frac{d^y}{dx^2} = 12(3)^2 - 24(3) = 36 > 0$$;$$\therefore ( 3 , 0 )$$ is a minimum pt. (ans);;(iii) Sketch $$y = x^4  - 4x^3  + 27$$;img;;(ans)

(i) Assume that the lines intersect;$$\Rightarrow ( 5i + 2j + 4k ) + \lambda ( i + 3j + k ) = ( 3i + j + k ) + \mu ( 4i + 7j + 5k )$$ for some $$\lambda ,\mu \in \mathbb{R}$$;$$\Rightarrow 5 + \lambda = 3 + 4\mu$$  -----(1);$$ 2 + 3\lambda = 1 + 7\mu$$                   -----(2);$$ 4 + \lambda = 1 + 5\mu$$                     -----(3);;Eqn (1) - (3): $$1 = 2 - \mu$$   $$\Rightarrow \mu = 1$$;Eqn (1): $$ 5 + \lambda = 3 + 4(1)$$   $$\Rightarrow \lambda = 2$$;Subst into Eqn(2):;$$LHS = 2 + 3(2) = 8$$;$$RHS = 1 + 7(1) = 8 =  LHS$$;$$\therefore $$ the lines meet at $$\mu = 1 (\lambda = 2)$$,;i.e at $$( 3i + j + k ) + (1)( 4i + 7j + 5k )$$;$$ = 7i + 8j + 6k$$ (ans);;(ii) Let $$\theta = $$ acute angle between the lines;$$\Rightarrow \theta = \cos ^{-1}\frac{|( i + 3j + k ).|( 4i + 7j + 5k )|}{| i + 3j + k || 4i + 7j + 5k |}$$;$$ = \cos ^{-1}\frac{| 4 + 21 + 5|}{\sqrt{1^2 + 3^2 + 1^2}\sqrt{4^2 + 7^2 + 5^2}}$$;$$ = \cos ^{-1}(0.9535)$$;$$ = 17.56 = 17.6^{0}$$ (1 dp) (ans)

(i)$$f( x ) = x + \frac{1}{x}, x \ge 1$$;$$f^{'}( x ) = \frac{d}{dx}[x + \frac{1}{x}] = 1 - \frac{1}{x^2}$$;For all $$x \ge 1$$, $$1 - \frac{1}{x^2} \le 1$$;$$\Rightarrow f^{'}( x ) = 1 - \frac{1}{x^2} \ge 0$$;$$\Rightarrow f(x)$$ increases as $$x$$ increases. (ans);;(ii) Let $$y = f(x)$$, $$x \ge 1$$;Range of $$f$$ is $$y \ge 2$$ (ans);;(iii) Let $$y = f^{- 1}( x )$$;$$\Rightarrow f(y) = x$$;$$  y + \frac{1}{y} = x$$;$$ y^2 + 1  = xy$$;$$ y^2 - xy = -1 $$;$$ y^2 - xy + \frac{1}{4}x^2 = \frac{1}{4}x^2 - 1$$;$$ (y - \frac{1}{2}x)^2  =  \frac{1}{4}x^2 - 1$$;$$ y - \frac{1}{2}x = \sqrt{\frac{1}{4}x^2 - 1}$$;$$ y = \sqrt{\frac{1}{4}x^2 - 1} + \frac{1}{2}x$$;$$\therefore f^{- 1}: x \mapsto \sqrt{\frac{1}{4}x^2 - 1} + \frac{1}{2}x$$, $$x \ge 2$$ (ans)

No. of ways to take 3 of 6 balls = $${}^{6}{C}_{3}$$;No. of ways to take 2 of 2 green balls = $${}^{2}{C}_{2}$$;No. of ways to take 1 of 4 red balls = $${}^{4}{C}_{1}$$;;$$P ( G = 2 ) = \frac{{}^{2}{C}_{2} \times {}^{4}{C}_{1}}{{}^{6}{C}_{3}} = \frac{1}{5}$$ (ans);;No of ways to take 3 of 4 red calls = $${}^{4}{C}_{3}$$;$$P ( G = 0 ) = \frac{{}^{4}{C}_{3}}{{}^{6}{C}_{3}} = \frac{1}{5}$$;;No of ways to take 1 of 2 green balls = $${}^{2}{C}_{1}$$;No of ways to take 2 of 4 red balls = $${}^{4}{C}_{2}$$;$$P ( G = 1 ) = \frac{{}^{2}{C}_{1} \times {}^{4}{C}_{2}}{{}^{6}{C}_{3}} = \frac{3}{5}$$;;$$\therefore$$ Probability distribution of G is: ;img;(ans);;$$ E( G ) = \sum \limits_{all g} g . P( G = g ) = 0 \cdot \frac{1}{5} + 1 \cdot \frac{3}{5} + 2 \cdot \frac{1}{5} = 1$$ ;$$ E(G^2) = \sum \limits_{all g}g^2 \cdot P(G = g)$$ ;$$ = 0^2 \cdot \frac{1}{5} + 1^2 \cdot \frac{3}{5} + 2^2 \cdot \frac{1}{5} = \frac{7}{5}$$;$$Var(G) = E(G^2) - [ E(G) ]^2$$ ;$$ = \frac{7}{5} - 1^2 = \frac{2}{5}$$ (ans)

Let $$n$$ = sample size = 80;Let $$p$$ = proportion of Grade A eggs;Let $${p}_{0}$$ = assumed p = 60% = 0.6;      $${q}_{0} = 1- {p}_{0} = 0.4$$;Let $${p}_{s}$$ = sample p = 42/80 = 0.525;and $${q}_{s} = 1 - {p}_{s} = 0.475$$; ;Test $${H}_{0}: p = {p}_{0}$$ against $${H}_{1}: p < {p}_{0}$$ ;a 1- tailed test for less ;The 5 % critical value, $${z}_{0.05} = 1.645$$;Reject $${H}_{0}$$ if $$z < - {z}_{0.05}$$;Under $${H}_{0}$$, the test statistic is ;$$z = \frac{{p}_{s} - {p}_{0}}{\sqrt{{p}_{0}{q}_{0} / n}} = \frac{0.525 - 0.6}{\sqrt{( 0.6 ) ( 0.4 ) / 80}} = - 1.369$$;Since $$z > - {z}_{0.05}$$, do not reject $${H}_{0}$$ and conclude that, at the 5% significance level, there is insufficient evidence that the farm is failing to reach the target of at least 60% of eggs should be grade A.;The expression 'at the 5% significance level' refers to the probability that a correct null hypothesis, i.e. at least 60% of the eggs are Grade A, would be rejected by the test.

(a);(i) $$1^{st}$$ person can be born in any of 7 days;$$2^{nd}$$ person can be born in 6 of 7 days;$$3^{rd}$$ person can be born in 5 of 7 days;$$\therefore P = \frac{7}{7} \times \frac{6}{7} \times \frac{5}{7} = \frac{{}^7{P}_{3}}{7^3} = \frac{30}{49}$$ (ans);;(ii) $$4^{th}$$ person can be born in 4 of 7 days;$$\therefore P = \frac{7}{7} \times \frac{6}{7} \times \frac{5}{7} \times \frac{4}{7} = \frac{{}^7{P}_{4}}{7^4} = \frac{120}{343}$$ (ans);;(b) Let $$P$$ =  probability that $$n$$ people in the room were all born in different months;From the reasoning in (a), $$P = \frac{{}^{12}{P}_{n}}{12^n}$$;$$n = 2$$ , $$P = \frac{{}^{12}{P}_{2}}{12^2} = 0.9167$$;$$n = 3$$ , $$P = \frac{{}^{12}{P}_{3}}{12^3} = 0.7639$$;$$n = 4$$ , $$P = \frac{{}^{12}{P}_{4}}{12^4} = 0.5729$$;$$n = 5$$ , $$P = \frac{{}^{12}{P}_{5}}{12^5} = 0.3819$$;$$\therefore P < \frac{1}{2}$$, the smallest value of $$ n = 5$$ (ans);;(c) Let $$P$$ =  probability that $$n$$ people in the room were all born in different days;From the reasoning in (a), $$P = \frac{{}^{365}{P}_{n}}{365^n}$$; Let $$S$$ =  probability that at least 2 people in the room were born on the same day $$\equiv 1 - P$$;$$n = 21$$ , $$P = 0.55631$$ (given);$$n = 22$$ , $$P = \frac{{}^{365}{P}_{22}}{365^{22}} = 0.5243$$ , $$S = 0.4757$$;$$n = 23$$ , $$P = \frac{{}^{365}{P}_{23}}{365^{23}} = 0.4927$$ , $$S = 0.5073$$;$$\therefore S > \frac{1}{2}$$, the smallest value of $$ n = 23$$ (ans)

Sketch $$y={{e}^{x}}$$ and $$y={{e}^{-x}}$$;img;;Deduce from the graph that;$${{e}^{x}}-{{e}^{-x}}>0\equiv {{e}^{x}}>{{e}^{-x}}\Rightarrow x>0$$;;\[\begin{align};  & \int\limits_{-4}^{3}{\left| {{e}^{x}}-{{e}^{-x}} \right|dx} \\ ; & \equiv \int\limits_{-4}^{0}{\left( {{e}^{-x}}-{{e}^{x}} \right)dx}+\int\limits_{0}^{3}{\left( {{e}^{x}}-{{e}^{-x}} \right)dx} \\ ; & =\left[ -{{e}^{-x}}-{{e}^{x}} \right]_{-4}^{0}+\left[ {{e}^{x}}-{{e}^{-x}} \right]_{0}^{3} \\ ; & =52.62+18.14 \\ ; & =70.76=70.8\left( 3sf \right) \\ ;\end{align}\]

(i);$$\begin{align};  & \overrightarrow{AB}=\overrightarrow{OB}-\overrightarrow{OA} \\ ; & =\left( 7i+j+7k \right)-\left( 4i-11j+4k \right) \\ ; & =3i+12j+3k \\ ;\end{align}$$;A vector equation of the line l is;$$\begin{align};  & r=\overrightarrow{OA}+s\overrightarrow{AB},s\in R \\ ; & =\left( 4i-11j+4k \right)+s\left( 3i+12j+3k \right) \\ ; & \equiv \left( 4i-11j+4k \right)+t\left( i+4j+k \right),t\in R \\ ;\end{align}$$;;(ii) P is on l;$$\begin{align};  & \Rightarrow \overrightarrow{OP}=\left( ei-11j+4k \right)+\lambda \left( i+4j+k \right) \\ ; & =\left( 4+\lambda  \right)i-\left( 11-4\lambda  \right)j+\left( 4+\lambda  \right)k \\ ;\end{align}$$;OP is perpendicular to l;$$\begin{align};  & \Rightarrow \left[ \left( 4+\lambda  \right)i-\left( 11-4\lambda  \right)j+\left( 4+\lambda  \right)k \right]\left( i+4j+k \right)=0 \\ ; & \left( 4+\lambda  \right)\left( 1 \right)-\left( 11-4\lambda  \right)\left( 4 \right)+\left( 4+\lambda  \right)\left( 1 \right)=0 \\ ; & \lambda =2 \\ ; & \therefore \overrightarrow{OP}=\left( 4i-11j+4k \right)+\left( 2 \right)\left( i+4j+k \right) \\ ; & =6i-3j+6k \\ ;\end{align}$$

With $$x=\tan \theta $$, $$dx={{\sec }^{2}}\theta d\theta $$;At $$x=0$$, $$\theta =0$$; at $$x=1$$, $$\theta =\frac{1}{4}\pi $$;\[\begin{align};  & \int\limits_{0}^{1}{\frac{1-{{x}^{2}}}{{{\left( 1+{{x}^{2}} \right)}^{2}}}dx} \\ ; & \equiv \int\limits_{0}^{\frac{1}{4}\pi }{\frac{1-{{\tan }^{2}}\theta }{{{\left( 1+{{\tan }^{2}}\theta  \right)}^{2}}}{{\sec }^{2}}\theta d\theta } \\ ; & =\int\limits_{0}^{\frac{1}{4}\pi }{\frac{1-{{\tan }^{2}}\theta }{{{\left( {{\sec }^{2}}\theta  \right)}^{2}}}{{\sec }^{2}}\theta d\theta } \\ ; & =\int\limits_{0}^{\frac{1}{4}\pi }{{{\cos }^{2}}\theta \left( 1-{{\tan }^{2}}\theta  \right)} \\ ; & =\int\limits_{0}^{\frac{1}{4}\pi }{\left( {{\cos }^{2}}\theta -{{\sin }^{2}}\theta  \right)d\theta } \\ ; & =\int\limits_{0}^{\frac{1}{4}\pi }{\cos 2\theta d\theta } \\ ; & =\left[ \frac{1}{2}\sin 2\theta  \right]_{0}^{\frac{1}{4}\pi } \\ ; & =\left[ \frac{1}{2}\left( 1 \right)-0 \right]=\frac{1}{2} \\ ;\end{align}\];

Let R denotes $$\left| z-2i \right|\le 4$$;= circular region including circumference centred at (0, 2), radius 4;; img;;Let $$D=\left| z-3+4i \right|\equiv \left| z-\left( 3-4i \right) \right|$$;= distance of z from (3, -4);Deduce that greatest and least values of D are along diameter of R passing through (3, -4);; img;;Let M = distance between (3, -4) and centre (0, 2) of R;=$$\sqrt{{{\left( 3-0 \right)}^{2}}+{{\left( -4-2 \right)}^{2}}}=\sqrt{45}=6.708$$;;\[\begin{align};  & \therefore {{D}_{least}}=\sqrt{45}-4=6.708-4=2.708=2.7unit \\ ; & \therefore {{D}_{greatest}}=\sqrt{45}+4=6.708+4=10.708=10.7unit \\ ;\end{align}\]

(i);$$\begin{align};  & gf\left( x \right)=fg\left( x \right)+16 \\ ; & \equiv g\left( 2x-1 \right)=f\left( {{x}^{2}}+2 \right)+16 \\ ; & \equiv {{\left( 2x-1 \right)}^{2}}+2=\left[ 2\left( {{x}^{2}}+2 \right)-1 \right]+16 \\ ; & 4{{x}^{2}}-4x+3=2{{x}^{2}}+19 \\ ; & 2{{x}^{2}}-4x-16=0 \\ ; & {{x}^{2}}-2x-8=0 \\ ; & \left( x-4 \right)\left( x+2 \right)=0 \\ ;\end{align}$$;$$\therefore x=4$$ or $$x=-2$$;;(ii) Let $$y={{f}^{-1}}\left( x \right)$$;;$$\begin{align};  & \Rightarrow x=f\left( y \right)=2y-1 \\ ; & 2y=x+1 \\ ; & \therefore y=\frac{1}{2}\left( x+1 \right) \\ ; & \left| {f}^{-1} \left( x \right) \right| < 5\equiv \left| \frac{1}{2} \left( x+1 \right) \right| < 5 \\ ; & \Rightarrow -5 < \frac{1}{2}\left( x+1 \right) < 5 \\ ; & -10 < x+1 < 10 \\ ; & \therefore -11 < x < 9 \end{align}$$

$${{x}^{3}}+2{{x}^{2}}-2=0\equiv {{x}^{3}}=2-2{{x}^{2}}$$;Sketch $$y={{x}^{3}}$$ and $$y=2-2{{x}^{2}}$$;; img;;The graphs of $$y={{x}^{3}}$$ and $$y=2-2{{x}^{2}}$$ intersect at exactly one point where x is positive;$$\Rightarrow$$ the equation $${{x}^{3}}=2-2{{x}^{2}}\equiv {{x}^{3}}+2{{x}^{2}}-2=0$$ has exactly 1 positive root;;(i) ;$$\begin{align};  & {{x}^{3}}+2{{x}^{2}}-2=0 \\ ; & \equiv {{x}^{2}}\left( x+2 \right)=2\equiv x=\sqrt{\frac{2}{x+2}} \\ ;\end{align}$$;Hence $$\alpha $$ is a root of $$x=\sqrt{\frac{2}{x+2}}$$;;Let $$f\left( x \right)={{x}^{3}}+2{{x}^{2}}-2$$;Starting with x1=1,;$$\begin{align};  & {{x}_{2}}=\sqrt{\frac{2}{{{x}_{1}}+2}}=\sqrt{\frac{2}{\left( 1 \right)+2}}=0.816=0.82\left( 2sf \right) \\ ; & {{x}_{3}}=\sqrt{\frac{2}{{{x}_{2}}+2}}=\sqrt{\frac{2}{\left( 0.82 \right)+2}}=0.842=0.84\left( 2sf \right) \\ ; & {{x}_{4}}=\sqrt{\frac{2}{x3+2}}=\sqrt{\frac{2}{\left( 0.84 \right)+2}}=0.839=0.84\left( 2sf \right) \\ ; & f\left( 0.84+0.005 \right)=0.031>0 \\ ; & f\left( 0.84-0.005 \right)=-0.023<0 \\ ;\end{align}$$;Correct to 2 significant figures, $$\alpha =0.84$$;;(ii);$${{f}^{'}}\left( x \right)=\frac{d}{dx}\left[ {{x}^{3}}+2{{x}^{2}}-2 \right]=3{{x}^{2}}+4x$$;Newton-Raphson method with x1=1;$$\begin{align};  & {{x}_{2}}={{x}_{1}} - \frac{f\left( {{x}_{1}} \right)}{{{f}^{'}}\left( {{x}_{1}} \right)}=0.8571=0.857\left( 3sf \right) \\ ; & {{x}_{3}}={{x}_{2}} - \frac{f\left( {{x}_{2}} \right)}{{{f}^{'}}\left( {{x}_{2}} \right)}=0.8395=0.840\left( 3sf \right) \\ ; & {{x}_{4}}={{x}_{3}} - \frac{f\left( {{x}_{3}} \right)}{{{f}^{'}}\left( {{x}_{3}} \right)}=0.8393=0.839\left( 3sf \right) \\ ; & {{x}_{5}}={{x}_{4}} - \frac{f\left( {{x}_{4}} \right)}{{{f}^{'}}\left( {{x}_{4}} \right)}=0.8393=0.839\left( 3sf \right) \\ ; & f\left( 0.839+0.0005 \right)=0.0012>0 \\ ; & f\left( 0.839-0.0005 \right)=-0.0043<0 \\ ;\end{align}$$;Correct to 3 significant figures, $$\alpha =0.839$$

$$x = 3t \equiv t = \frac{1}{3}x$$;Subst into $$y = \frac{3}{t}  \Rightarrow  y = \frac{3}{(\frac{1}{3}x)} = \frac{9}{x}$$;Sketch $$y = \frac{9}{x}$$:;img;(ans);;At $$P, t = 2$$, $$x = 3(2) = 6$$, $$y = \frac{3}{2}$$;(i)$$\frac{dy}{dx} = \frac{dy}{dt}/\frac{dx}{dt} = \frac{d}{dt}[\frac{3}{t}]/\frac{d}{dt}[3t]$$;$$ = (-\frac{3}{t^2})/3 = -\frac{1}{t^2}$$;;Gradient of normal = $$- 1/\frac{dy}{dx} = t^2 = 2^2 = 4$$;Equation of normal at $$P$$ is;$$y - \frac{3}{2} = 4(x - 6)$$;$$2y - 3 = 8x - 48$$;$$\therefore 2y = 8x - 45$$ (ans);;(ii) At $$Q$$, let $$t = q  \Rightarrow x = 3q, y = \frac{3}{q}$$;$$Q$$ is on normal at $$P$$;$$\Rightarrow 2(\frac{3}{q}) = 8(3q) - 45$$;$$2 = 8q^2 - 15q$$;$$8q^2 - 15q - 2 = 0$$;$$(q - 2)(8q + 1) = 0$$;$$q = 2$$ (NA , pt $$P$$) or $$q = -\frac{1}{8}$$;$$\therefore$$ at $$Q, t = -\frac{1}{8}$$ (ans)

2\sin u)$$;$$ = (2u\sin u + u^2\cos u) + (2\cos u - 2u\sin u) - 2\cos u$$;$$ = u^2\cos u$$ (ans);;(iii)$$V = \pi \int_0^{\frac{1}{4}\pi}u^2 \cos udu$$;$$ = \pi [u^\sin u + 2u\cos u - 2\sin u]_0^{\frac{1}{4}\pi}$$;$$ = \pi [\frac{1}{16}\pi^2(\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}) + \frac{1}{2}\pi(\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}) - x + cx^2$$;At $$x = 1$$, $$y = 2$$, $$z = -\frac{1}{2(2)^2} = -\frac{1}{8}$$,;$$\Rightarrow -\frac{1}{8} = - (1) + c (1)^2  \Rightarrow  c = \frac{7}{8}$$;$$\therefore z = - x + \frac{7}{8}x^2$$;$$\equiv -\frac{1}{2y^2} = - x + \frac{7}{8}x^2$$;$$ - 4 = - 8xy^2 + 7x^2y^2 = 0$$;$$\therefore 7x^2y^2 - 8xy^2 + 4 = 0$$ (ans)

Let $$8\sin \theta  + 15\cos \theta$$;$$ = R\sin ( \theta  + \alpha  )$$;$$ = R\sin \theta\cos \alpha + R\cos \theta\sin \alpha$$;;Comparing coefficients:;$$\sin \theta: 8 = R\cos \alpha$$;$$\cos \theta: 15 = R\sin \alpha$$;$$\Rightarrow R = \sqrt{8^2 + {15}^2} = 17$$;$$\tan \alpha = \frac{15}{8} \Rightarrow \alpha = 61.92 = 61.9$$;;$$\therefore 8\sin \theta  + 15\cos \theta \equiv 17\sin (\theta + 61.9^{\circ})$$ (ans);;(i) $$8\sin \theta  + 15\cos \theta \equiv 17\sin (\theta + 61.9^0)$$ has greatest value when $$\sin (\theta + 61.9^0) = 1$$,;i.e its greatest value = $$17(1) = 17$$ (ans);;(ii)$$\frac{1}{20 + 8\sin \theta  + 15\cos \theta} \equiv \frac{1}{20 + 17\sin (\theta + 61.9^0)}$$ has greatest value when $$\sin (\theta + 61.9^0) = -1$$;i.e its greatest value $$ = \frac{1}{20 + 17(-1)} = \frac{1}{3}$$ (ans);;(iii)$$\frac{1}{20 + ( 8\sin \theta  + 15\cos \theta  )^2 } \equiv \frac{1}{20 + (17\sin (\theta + 61.9^0))^2 }$$ has greatest value when $$\sin (\theta + 61.9^0) = 0$$, i.e its greatest value;$$ = \frac{1}{20 + (17(0))^2 } = \frac{1}{20}$$ (ans)

Let $$n$$ = sample size = 5;$$X \sim B ( n , p )$$ ;$$ Var(X) = \frac{1}{4}E(X) = np(1 - p) = \frac{1}{4}np$$;$$ \Rightarrow 1 - p = \frac{1}{4} \Rightarrow p = \frac{3}{4}$$ ;;$$ Var(X) = E(X^2) - [ E(X) ]^2$$ ;$$ \Rightarrow E ( X^2 ) = Var ( X ) + [ E ( X ) ]^2$$ ;$$ = npq + [ np ]^2$$ ;$$ = ( 5 ) ( \frac{3}{4} ) ( \frac{1}{4} ) + [ ( 5 ) ( \frac{3}{4} ) ]^2 = 15$$ (ans)

Let $$n$$ = sample size = 960;Let $$p$$ = proportion of sample with cellphone;;$$\hat{p} = \frac{621}{960} = \frac{207}{320}$$ ;$$ \hat{q} = 1 - \hat{p} = \frac{113}{320}$$;$$ {z}_{0.05} \sqrt{\frac{\hat{p} \hat{q}}{n}} = 1.645\sqrt{\frac{( \frac{207}{320} ) ( \frac{113}{320} )}{960}}$$ ;$$ = 0.02537$$;;The 90% confidence interval for p is;$$\hat{p} - {z}_{0.05} \sqrt{\frac{\hat{p} \hat{q}}{n}} , \hat{p} + {z}_{0.05} \sqrt{\frac{\hat{p} \hat{q}}{n}} ]$$ ;$$ = [ \frac{207}{320}- 0.02537, \frac{207}{320}+ 0.02537 ] $$;$$  = [ 0.6215 , 0.6723 ] $$;$$ = [ 0.622, 0.672 ] $$;One way to reduce the interval width by half is to increase the sample size by 4 times. (ans)

(i) $$P ( A \cap B ) = P ( B \lvert A ) \cdot P ( A ) = \frac{1}{8} \cdot \frac{1}{5} = \frac{1}{40}$$;(ii) $$P ( B ) = P ( B \lvert A ) \cdot P ( A ) + P ( B \lvert A \prime ) \cdot P ( A \prime )$$;$$  = \frac{1}{40}+ \frac{1}{10}\cdot \frac{4}{5}= \frac{21}{200}$$;(iii) $$P ( A \cup B ) = P ( A ) + P ( B ) - P ( A \cap B )$$; $$  = \frac{1}{5}+ \frac{21}{200}- \frac{1}{40}= \frac{7}{25}$$;(iv) $$P ( A \lvert B ) = \frac{P ( A \cap B )}{P ( B )} = \frac{( \frac{1}{40} )}{( \frac{21}{200} )} = \frac{5}{21}$$

Answer:;Let $$\mu$$ = E(X) = 1;Let $$\sigma^2$$ = Var(X) = 20;$$X ~ N(\mu,\sigma^2)$$;;(i) $$P ( X < a ) = 2P ( X > a )$$ ;$$ P(X < a) = 2 [ 1 - P(X < a) ] $$;$$ 3P ( X < a ) = 2$$ ;$$ P(X < a) = \frac{2}{3}$$;$$ P ( z < \frac{a - \mu}{\sigma} ) = \frac{2}{3} \equiv \Phi ( \frac{a - \mu}{\sigma} ) = \frac{2}{3}$$ ;$$ \frac{a - \mu}{\sigma}= \Phi^{- 1}(\frac{2}{3}) = 0.431$$ ;$$ a = \mu + 0.431\sigma = ( 1 ) + 0.431\sqrt{20}$$ ;$$ = 2.927 = 2.93$$ (ans);;(ii) Let  $$\overline{x}$$ = sample mean of n observations;$$\overline{x} \sim N ( \mu , \sigma^2 / n )$$ ;$$ P(\overline{x} > 1.5) \leq 0.01$$ ;$$ \equiv P ( \overline{x} < 1.5 ) > 1 - 0.01 = 0.99$$ ;;$$ \Rightarrow P(z < \frac{1.5 - \mu}{\sigma/\sqrt{n}}) > 0.99 \equiv \Phi ( \frac{1.5 - \mu}{\sigma / \sqrt{n}} ) > 0.99$$ ;$$ \frac{1.5 - \mu}{\sigma/\sqrt{n}}> \Phi^{- 1}(0.99) = 2.326 $$;$$ \sqrt{n} = \frac{2.326\sigma}{1.5 - \mu} = \frac{2.326\sqrt{20}}{1.5 - 1} = 20.80 $$;$$ n >(20.80)^2 = 432.64$$;;$$\therefore P (\overline{x} > 1.5 ) \leq 0.01, n \geq 433$$ (ans)

Let $$X$$ = no. of sports cars served in 1 hr;$$X \sim Po(2)$$;Let Y = no. of motor-cycles served in 1 hr ;$$Y \sim Po(1)$$;Let $$Z$$ = no. of sports cars and motor-cycles served in a randomly chosen period of 2 hr ;$$     = {X}_{1} + {X}_{2} + {Y}_{1} + {Y}_{2}$$;where $${X}_{i}$$ = independent observations of X;     $${Y}_{i}$$ = independent observations of Y;Let $$\lambda = E(Z) = E({X}_{1} + {X}_{2} + {Y}_{1} + {Y}_{2})$$;$$      = 2E(X) + 2E(Y) = 2(2) + 2(1) = 6$$;;$$Z \sim P0(\lambda)$$;$$P ( Z \geq 4 )$$ ;$$ = 1 - P(Z \leq 3)$$ ;$$ = 1 - [ P ( Z = 0 ) + P ( Z = 1 ) + P ( Z = 2 ) + P ( Z = 3 ) ]$$ ;$$ = 1 - e^{- \lambda}[ \frac{\lambda^0}{0 !}+ \frac{\lambda^1}{1 !}+ \frac{\lambda^2}{2 !}+ \frac{\lambda^3}{3 !}] $$;$$ = 1 - e^{- 6} [ 1 + 6 + \frac{6^2}{2 !} + \frac{6^3}{3 !} ]$$;$$ = 0.8487 = 0.849$$ (ans);;Let $$C$$ = cost of petrol supplied to sport cars;$$C \sim U ( 10 , 100 )$$ ;$$ \Rightarrow E(C) = \frac{1}{2}(10 + 100) = 55 $$;$$ \Rightarrow Var ( C ) = \frac{1}{12} ( 100 - 10 )^2 = 675 $$;;Let $$D$$ = cost of petrol supplied to motor cycle;$$D \sim U ( 5 , 35 )$$ ;$$ \Rightarrow E(D) = \frac{1}{2}(5 + 35) = 20$$ ;$$ \Rightarrow Var ( D ) = \frac{1}{12} ( 35 - 5 )^2 = 75$$;Let $$T$$ = cost of petrol supplied to a random sample consisting of 4 cars and 2 motor cycles;$$ = {C}_{1} + {C}_{2} + {C}_{3} + {C}_{4} + {D}_{1} + {D}_{2}$$;where $${C}_{i}$$ = independent observations of C;     $${D}_{i}$$ = independent observations of D;;$$ E(T)  = E({C}_{1} + {C}_{2} + {C}_{3} + {C}_{4} + {D}_{1} + {D}_{2})$$ ;$$ = 4E ( C ) + 2E ( D )$$ ;$$ = 4(55) + 2(20) = 260$$ (ans); ;$$ Var ( T ) = Var ( {C}_{1} + {C}_{2} + {C}_{3} + {C}_{4} + {D}_{1} + {D}_{2} )$$ ;$$ = 4Var(C) + 2Var(D)$$ ;$$ = 4 ( 675 ) + 2 ( 75 ) = 2850$$ (ans)

Let $$n$$ = sample size = 80;Let $$\mu = E(x)$$;Let $$\sigma^2 = Var(x)$$;$$\hat{\mu} = \overline{x} = \frac{\sum x}{n} = \frac{79.53}{80} = 0.9941$$ ;$$ \hat{\sigma}^2 = \frac{1}{n - 1}[ \sum x^2 - \frac{1}{n}(\sum x)^2 ]$$ ;$$ = \frac{1}{79} [ 100.4621 - \frac{1}{80} ( 79.53 )^2 ] = 0.2709$$;;Let $$\mu_{0}$$ = required mean = 1.10kg;Test $${H}_{0}: \mu = \mu_{0}$$ against $${H}_{1} : \mu < \mu_{0}$$ a 1 tailed test for less;The 4% critical value, $${z}_{0.04} = 1.751$$ ;Reject $${H}_{0}$$, the test statistic is ;$$z = \frac{\overline{x} - \mu_{0}}{\hat{\sigma} / \sqrt{n}} = \frac{0.9941 - 1.10}{\sqrt{0.2709 / 80}} = - 1.819$$;Since $$z < - {z}_{0.04}$$, reject $${H}_{0}$$ and conclude that, at 4% level of significance, there is sufficient evidence that the mean mass of the contents is less than 1.10 kg.;;Alternative test is :;Test $${H}_{0}: \mu = \mu_{0}$$ against $${H}_{1} : \mu \neq \mu_{0}$$ a 2 tailed test for difference;At 4% significance level, critical value $${z}_{0.02} = 2.054$$;$${H}_{0}$$ is rejected if $$| z | > |{z}_{0.02}|$$;$$\lvert \frac{\overline{x} - \mu_0}{\hat{\sigma} / \sqrt{n}} \lvert > 2.054$$ ;$$ \lvert \overline{x} - \mu_0 \lvert > 2.054 \hat{\sigma}/\sqrt{n}$$;$$ \lvert 0.9941 - \mu_0 \lvert > 2.054\sqrt{0.2709 / 80} = 0.1195$$ ;$$ 0.9941 - \mu_0 < - 0.1195 $$ or $$ 0.9941 - \mu_0 > 0.1195$$ ;;$$ \mu_0 > 1.1136$$ or  $$\mu_0 < 0.8746$$ (ans)

For small x, $$\sin x\approx x$$ and $$\cos x\approx 1-\frac{1}{2}{{x}^{2}}$$;$$\begin{align};  & x\sin x+\cos x=1.015 \\ ; & \equiv x\left( x \right)+\left( 1-\frac{1}{2}{{x}^{2}} \right)=1.015 \\ ; & {{x}^{2}}+1-\frac{1}{2}{{x}^{2}}=1.015 \\ ; & \frac{1}{2}{{x}^{2}}\approx 0.015 \\ ; & {{x}^{2}}=0.03 \\ ; & \therefore x=\sqrt{0.03}\left( x>0 \right) \\ ; & =0.1732=0.173\left( 3sf \right) \\ ;\end{align}$$

;$$\begin{align};  & 6{{\cos }^{2}}x+7\sin x=1 \\ ; & 6\left( 1-{{\sin }^{2}}x \right)+7\sin x=1 \\ ; & 6{{\sin }^{2}}x-7\sin x-5=0 \\ ; & \left( 3\sin x-5 \right)\left( 2\sin x+1 \right)=0 \\ ;\end{align}$$;$$\sin x=\frac{5}{3}$$ (NA) or $$\sin x=-\frac{1}{2}$$;$$x=n\pi +{{\left( -1 \right)}^{n}}\left(- \frac{1}{6}\pi  \right),n\in Z$$

$$a-b=d-c\equiv \overrightarrow{BA}=\overrightarrow{CD}$$;i.e. BA is equal in length and parallel to CD.;Sketch ABCD:;img;;Deduce that AD must be parallel to BC;$$\Rightarrow$$ ABCD must be a parallelogram.;;$$\left| a-c \right|=\left| b-d \right|\equiv \left| \overrightarrow{CA} \right|=\left| \overrightarrow{DB} \right|$$;i.e. the diagonals are equal in length. Parallelogram with equal diagonals must be a rectangle.

With $$t=\sqrt{x+1}\equiv {{t}^{2}}-1=x\Rightarrow 2tdt=dx$$;At $$x=0,t=1$$; at $$x=3,t=2$$;$$\begin{align};  & \therefore \int\limits_{0}^{3}{x\sqrt{x+1}dx} \\ ; & =\int\limits_{1}^{2}{\left( {{t}^{2}}-1 \right)t2tdt} \\ ; & =2\int\limits_{1}^{2}{\left( {{t}^{4}}-{{t}^{2}} \right)dt} \\ ; & =2\left[ \frac{1}{5}{{t}^{5}}-\frac{1}{3}{{t}^{3}} \right]_{1}^{2} \\ ; & =2\left[ \frac{31}{5}-\frac{7}{3} \right]=7\frac{11}{15} \\ ;\end{align}$$;

$$4{{x}^{2}}+16xy+{{y}^{2}}+16x+14y+13=0$$;Taking x as a constant, rearrange equation as::;$${{y}^{2}}+\left( 16x+14 \right)y+\left( 4{{x}^{2}}+16x+13 \right)=0$$;Two distinct real values of y may be found ;$$\Rightarrow$$ Determinant >0;i.e.;$$\begin{align};  & {{\left( 16x+14 \right)}^{2}}-4\left( 1 \right)\left( 4{{x}^{2}}+16x+13 \right)> \\ ; & 256{{x}^{2}}+448x+196-16{{x}^{2}}-64x-52>0 \\ ; & 240{{x}^{2}}+384x+144>0 \\ ; & \therefore 5{{x}^{2}}+8x+3>0 \\ ;\end{align}$$;;$$\left( 5x+3 \right)\left( x+1 \right)>0$$;; img;;$$\Rightarrow x<-1$$ or $$x>-\frac{3}{5}$$

Let; $$\begin{align};  & f\left( x \right)={{x}^{3}}-9x-12 \\ ; & f\left( 3 \right)=-12<0 \\ ; & f\left( 4 \right)=24>0 \\ ; & \Rightarrow n=3 \\ ;\end{align}$$;;Let $$\alpha $$ = positive root of f(x), i.e. $$\alpha \in \left[ 3,4 \right]$$;Linear Interpolation on $$\left[ 3,4 \right]$$;$$\alpha \approx \frac{\left( 3 \right)\left| f\left( 4 \right) \right|+\left( 4 \right)\left| f\left( 3 \right) \right|}{\left| f\left( 4 \right) \right|+\left| f\left( 3 \right) \right|}=3.333=3.33\left( 3sf \right)$$

$$y={{x}^{3}}{{e}^{x}}$$;Let $$P_n$$ denotes;$$\frac{{{d}^{n}}y}{d{{x}^{n}}}={{e}^{x}}\left( {{x}^{3}}+3n{{x}^{2}}+3n\left( n-1 \right)x+n\left( n-1 \right)\left( n-2 \right) \right)$$;For n = 1,;$$\begin{align};  & LHS=\frac{dy}{dx}=\frac{d}{dx}\left[ {{x}^{3}}{{e}^{x}} \right]={{e}^{x}}\left( {{x}^{3}}+3{{x}^{2}} \right) \\ ; & RHS={{e}^{x}}\left( {{x}^{3}}+3{{x}^{2}} \right)=LHS \\ ;\end{align}$$;$$P_1$$ is true.;Assume $$P_k$$ is true for $$k\in {{Z}^{+}}$$;i.e. $$\frac{{{d}^{k}}y}{d{{x}^{k}}}={{e}^{x}}\left( {{x}^{3}}+3k{{x}^{2}}+3k\left( k-1 \right)x+k\left( k-1 \right)\left( k-2 \right) \right)$$;For n = k + 1,;$$\begin{align};  & RHS={{e}^{x}}\left( {{x}^{3}}+3\left( k+1 \right){{x}^{2}}+3\left( k+1 \right)\left( k+1-1 \right)x+\left( k+1 \right)\left( k+1-1 \right)\left( k+1-2 \right) \right) \\ ; & LHS=\frac{{{d}^{k+1}}y}{d{{x}^{k+1}}}=\frac{d}{dx}\left[ \frac{{{d}^{k}}y}{d{{x}^{k}}} \right] \\ ; & ={{e}^{x}}\left( {{x}^{3}}+3k{{x}^{2}}+3k\left( k-1 \right)x+k\left( k-1 \right)\left( k-2 \right) \right)+{{e}^{x}}\left( 3{{x}^{2}}+6kx+3k\left( k-1 \right) \right) \\ ; & ={{e}^{x}}\left( {{x}^{3}}+3\left( k+1 \right){{x}^{2}}+3k\left( k-1+2 \right)x+k\left( k-1 \right)\left( k-2+3 \right) \right) \\ ; & \equiv {{e}^{x}}\left( {{x}^{3}}+3\left( k+1 \right){{x}^{2}}+3\left( k+1 \right)\left( k+1-1 \right)x+\left( k+1 \right)\left( k+1-1 \right)\left( k+1-2 \right) \right) \\ ; & =RHS \\ ;\end{align}$$;;$$P_{k+1}$$ is true if $$P_k$$ is true.;Therefore, by mathematical induction, $$P_n$$ is true for all $$n\in {{Z}^{+}}$$.;Deduce that, for n = 8,;$$\begin{align};  & {{e}^{x}}\left( {{x}^{3}}+3n{{x}^{2}}+3n\left( n-1 \right)x+n\left( n-1 \right)\left( n-2 \right) \right) \\ ; & ={{e}^{x}}\left( {{x}^{3}}+24{{x}^{2}}+168x+336 \right) \\ ;\end{align}$$;i.e.;\[\begin{align};  & {{e}^{x}}\left( {{x}^{3}}+24{{x}^{2}}+168x+336 \right)\equiv \frac{{{d}^{8}}y}{d{{x}^{8}}} \\ ; & \therefore \int{{{e}^{x}}\left( {{x}^{3}}+24{{x}^{2}}+168x+336 \right)dx} \\ ; & \equiv \int{\frac{{{d}^{8}}y}{d{{x}^{8}}}dx}=\frac{{{d}^{7}}y}{d{{x}^{7}}} \\ ; & \equiv {{e}^{x}}\left( {{x}^{3}}+3\left( 7 \right){{x}^{2}}+3\left( 7 \right)\left( 7-1 \right)x+\left( 7 \right)\left( 7-1 \right)\left( 7-2 \right) \right) \\ ; & ={{e}^{x}}\left( {{x}^{3}}+21{{x}^{2}}+126x+210 \right) \\ ;\end{align}\]

Sketch diagram;img;;(i) ;Angle between line BH and plane BFGC is given by $$\angle HBG$$;$$\begin{align};  & \vartriangle BCG: \\ ; & B{{G}^{2}}=B{{C}^{2}}+C{{G}^{2}}=89 \\ ; & \vartriangle HBG: \\ ; & \tan \angle HBG=\frac{HG}{BG}=\frac{10}{\sqrt{89}}=1.060 \\ ; & \therefore \angle HBG=46.67={{46.7}^{\circ}}\left( 1dp \right) \\ ;\end{align}$$;;(ii);Angle between planes AEGC and DHGC is given by $$\angle ACD$$.;$$\begin{align};  & \tan \angle ACD=\frac{AD}{CD}=\frac{8}{10}=0.8 \\ ; & \therefore \angle ACD=38.66={{38.7}^{\circ}}\left( 1dp \right) \\ ;\end{align}$$;;(iii) ;Angle between skew lines BG and HC is given by $$\angle AHC$$.;(AH is parallel to BG and is in the same plane as HC);$$\begin{align};  & \vartriangle ABC: \\ ; & A{{C}^{2}}=A{{B}^{2}}+B{{C}^{2}}={{10}^{2}}+{{8}^{2}}=164 \\ ; & \vartriangle CDH: \\ ; & C{{H}^{2}}=C{{D}^{2}}+D{{H}^{2}}={{10}^{2}}+{{5}^{2}}=125 \\ ; & AH=BG=\sqrt{89} \\ ; & \vartriangle AHC: \\ ; & A{{C}^{2}}=A{{H}^{2}}+C{{H}^{2}}-2.AH.CH.\cos \angle AHC \\ ; & \Rightarrow \cos \angle AHC=1.3315 \\ ; & \therefore \angle AHC=76.29={{76.3}^{0}}\left( 1dp \right) \\ ;\end{align}$$

(i) ;Positive odd integers, less than 1000, could be represented by:;2n - 1, n = 1, 2, 3, ... ,  500;i.e. No. of such integers, $$N_{odd}$$ = 500;;(ii) ;Positive odd integers, less than 1000, which are divisible by 5, could be represented by: ;5(2n - 1), n = 1, 2, 3, ... , 100;;i.e. No. of such integers, $$N_{odd}$$, 5 = 100;No. of positive integers, less than 1000, which are odd numbers and not divisible by 5:;$$N_{odd}$$, not 5  = $$N_{odd} - N_{odd}$$, 5 = 500 - 100 = 400;;Sum of the odd numbers, less than 1000, which are not divisible by 5;$$\begin{align};  & =\sum\limits_{r=1}^{500}{\left( 2r-1 \right)}-\sum\limits_{r=1}^{100}{5\left( 2r-1 \right)} \\ ; & =2\left[ \frac{1}{2}\left( 500 \right)\left( 500+1 \right) \right]-500-10\left[ \frac{1}{2}\left( 100 \right)\left( 100+1 \right) \right]+5\left[ 100 \right] \\ ; & =200000 \\ ;\end{align}$$

$$f:x\mapsto \frac{6x}{x+3},x\ge 0$$;(i) Let y = f'(x);$$\begin{align};  & \Rightarrow f\left( y \right)=x \\ ; & \frac{6y}{y+3}=x \\ ; & 6y=x\left( y+3 \right) \\ ; & y\left( 6-x \right)=3x \\ ; & y=\frac{3x}{6-x} \\ ; & \therefore f'\left( x \right)=\frac{3x}{6-x} \\ ;\end{align}$$;;(ii) Range of f, $${{R}_{f}}=\left\{ x:0\le x\le 6 \right\}$$;;(iii) Sketch $$y=\frac{6x}{x+3},x\ge 0$$;At x = 0, y = 0;$$f\left( x \right)=\frac{6x}{x+3}\equiv 6-\frac{18}{x+3}$$;As $$x\to \infty ,f\left( x \right)\to 6-0=6$$;img;;Equation of its asymptote is y = 6;;(iv) Shade bounded region (above):;img;;Area of bounded region (shaded);$$\begin{align};  & =\int\limits_{0}^{6}{ydx}=\int\limits_{0}^{6}{\frac{6x}{x+3}dx} \\ ; & \equiv \int\limits_{0}^{3}{\left( 6-\frac{18}{x+3} \right)dx} \\ ; & =\left[ 6x \right]_{0}^{3}-18\left[ \ln \left( x+3 \right) \right]_{0}^{6} \\ ; & =36-18\ln 3 \\ ;\end{align}$$

a);$$\begin{align};  & {{\left( 3-i \right)}^{2}}={{3}^{2}}-6i+{{i}^{2}}=9-6i-1=8-6i \\ ; & {{\left( {{z}_{1}}+i \right)}^{2}}=-8+6i\equiv -1\left( 8-6i \right)\equiv {{i}^{2}}{{\left( 3-i \right)}^{2}} \\ ; & \Rightarrow {{z}_{1}}+i=i\left( 3-i \right)=3i-{{i}^{2}}=1+3i \\ ; & \therefore {{z}_{1}}=1+2i \\ ;\end{align}$$;;b);$${{z}_{1}}=2-3i,{{z}_{2}}=-2-i$$;(i) $$\left| {{z}_{1}}-{{z}_{2}} \right|=\left| \left( 2-3i \right)-\left( -2-i \right) \right|=\left| 4-2i \right|=\sqrt{{{4}^{2}}+{{2}^{2}}}=\sqrt{20}$$;;(ii) $$\arg \left( {{z}_{1}}+{{z}_{2}} \right)=\arg \left( \left( 2-3i \right)+\left( -2-i \right) \right)=\arg \left( -4i \right)=-\frac{1}{2}\pi $$

Let $$\frac{9{{x}^{2}}}{{{\left( x-1 \right)}^{2}}\left( x+2 \right)}\equiv \frac{A}{x-1}+\frac{B}{{{\left( x-1 \right)}^{2}}}+\frac{C}{x+2}$$;Clearing the fractions:;$$\begin{align};  & 9{{x}^{2}}\equiv A\left( x-1 \right)\left( x+2 \right)+B\left( x+2 \right)+C{{\left( x-1 \right)}^{2}} \\ ; & =\left( A+C \right){{x}^{2}}+\left( A+B-2C \right)x+\left( -2A+2B+C \right) \\ ;\end{align}$$;Cover-up rule:;$$\begin{align};  & x=-2:C=4 \\ ; & x=1:B=3 \\ ;\end{align}$$;Comparing coefficients:;$$\begin{align};  & {{x}^{2}}:9=A+C \\ ; & \Rightarrow A=5 \\ ;\end{align}$$;;$$\therefore \frac{9{{x}^{2}}}{{{\left( x-1 \right)}^{2}}\left( x+2 \right)}\equiv \frac{5}{x-1}+\frac{3}{{{\left( x-1 \right)}^{2}}}+\frac{4}{x+2}$$;;$$\begin{align};  & \therefore \int\limits_{2}^{3}{\frac{9{{x}^{2}}}{{{\left( x-1 \right)}^{2}}\left( x+2 \right)}dx}\equiv \int\limits_{2}^{3}{\left( \frac{5}{x-1}+\frac{3}{{{\left( x-1 \right)}^{2}}}+\frac{4}{x+2} \right)dx} \\ ; & =\left[ 5\ln \left( x-1 \right)-\frac{3}{x-1}+4\ln \left( x+2 \right) \right]_{2}^{3} \\ ; & =5\ln 2-\frac{3}{2}+4\ln 5-5\ln 1+3-4\ln 4 \\ ; & =\frac{3}{2}4\ln 5+5\ln 2-4\ln {{2}^{2}} \\ ; & =\frac{3}{2}4\ln 5-3\ln 2 \\ ;\end{align}$$;

$$\begin{align};  & y=\frac{{{x}^{3}}}{{{\left( x+1 \right)}^{2}}} \\ ; & \frac{dy}{dx}=\frac{d}{dx}\left[ \frac{{{x}^{3}}}{{{\left( x+1 \right)}^{2}}} \right]=\frac{{{\left( x+1 \right)}^{2}}\left( 2{{x}^{2}} \right)-\left( {{x}^{3}} \right)2\left( x+1 \right)}{{{\left( x+1 \right)}^{4}}} \\ ; & =\frac{2{{x}^{2}}\left( x+1 \right)\left( x+1-x \right)}{{{\left( x+1 \right)}^{4}}} \\ ; & =\frac{2{{x}^{2}}\left( x+1 \right)}{{{\left( x+1 \right)}^{4}}}=\frac{2{{x}^{2}}}{{{\left( x+1 \right)}^{3}}} \\ ;\end{align}$$;;At stationary pts, $$\frac{dy}{dx}=0$$;$$\begin{align};  & \Rightarrow \frac{2{{x}^{2}}}{{{\left( x+1 \right)}^{3}}}=0 \\ ; & \Rightarrow x=0 \\ ;\end{align}$$;$$\begin{align};  & x={{0}^{-}},\frac{dy}{dx}=\frac{2{{x}^{2}}}{{{\left( x+1 \right)}^{3}}}>0 \\ ; & x=0+,\frac{dy}{dx}=\frac{2{{x}^{2}}}{{{\left( x+1 \right)}^{3}}}>0 \\ ;\end{align}$$;At x = 0, the stationary pt is a point of inflexion.;

$$\begin{align};  & \frac{dy}{dx}+y=x{{y}^{3}}\equiv \frac{1}{{{y}^{3}}}\frac{dy}{dx}+\frac{1}{{{y}^{2}}=x} \\ ; & z=\frac{1}{{{y}^{2}}},\frac{dz}{dx}=\frac{d}{dx}\left[ \frac{1}{{{y}^{2}}} \right]=-\frac{2}{{{y}^{3}}}\frac{dy}{dx} \\ ;\end{align}$$;Subst $$\frac{1}{{{y}^{3}}}\frac{dy}{dx}$$ and $$\frac{1}{{{y}^{2}}}$$ into $$\frac{1}{{{y}^{3}}}\frac{dy}{dx}+\frac{1}{{{y}^{2}}}=x$$:;$$\begin{align};  & -\frac{1}{2}\frac{dz}{dx}+z=x \\ ; & \therefore \frac{dz}{dx}-2z=-2x\\ ;\end{align}$$;;With $$z=\frac{1}{{{y}^{2}}}$$,;$$\frac{dy}{dx}+y=x{{y}^{3}}\equiv \frac{dz}{dx}-2z=-2x$$;Let $$h\left( x \right)=\int{\left( -2 \right)dx}=-2x$$ ;$$\Rightarrow$$ integrating factor = $${{e}^{h\left( x \right)}}={{e}^{-2x}}$$ and $${{e}^{-h\left( x \right)}}={{e}^{2x}}$$;;General solution is:;$$\begin{align};  & z={{e}^{-h\left( x \right)}}\left[ \int{{{e}^{h\left( x \right)}}\left( -2x \right)dx}+c \right] \\ ; & ={{e}^{2x}}\left[ {{e}^{-2x}}x-\int{{{e}^{-2x}}dx}+c \right] \\ ; & ={{e}^{2x}}\left[ {{e}^{-2x}}x+\frac{1}{2}{{e}^{-2x}}+c \right] \\ ; & =x+\frac{1}{2}+c{{e}^{2x}} \\ ;\end{align}$$;;$$\begin{align};  & \equiv \frac{1}{{{y}^{2}}}=\frac{1}{2}+x+c{{e}^{2x}} \\ ; & i.e. \\ ; & \left( \frac{1}{2}+x+c{{e}^{2x}} \right){{y}^{2}}=1 \\ ;\end{align}$$;;At x = 0, $$y=\sqrt{2}$$;$$\begin{align};  & \Rightarrow \left( \frac{1}{2}+0+c{{e}^{0}} \right)\left( 2 \right)=1 \\ ; & \Rightarrow 1+2c=1\Rightarrow c=0 \\ ;\end{align}$$;Particular solution is ;$$\begin{align};  & \left( \frac{1}{2}+x \right){{y}^{2}}=1 \\ ; & \Rightarrow y=\sqrt{\frac{2}{1+2x}} \\ ;\end{align}$$

$$\begin{align};\overrightarrow{AB} = \overrightarrow{OB} - \overrightarrow{OA} = \begin{pmatrix};13\\ 9\\ \alpha \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 9\\ 3\\ 26 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 4\\ 6\\\alpha -26\end{pmatrix};\end{align}$$;;An equation of line M through A and B is M: $$r  = \overrightarrow{OA} + s \overrightarrow{AB}, s\in\mathbb{R}$$;$$\begin{align};=  \begin{pmatrix} 9\\ 3\\ 26 \end{pmatrix} + s \begin{pmatrix} 4\\ 6\\\alpha -26\end{pmatrix};\end{align}$$;;Lines L and M intersect at P;$$\begin{align} ;\Rightarrow \overrightarrow{OP} =  \begin{pmatrix} 9\\ 3\\ 26 \end{pmatrix} + s \begin{pmatrix} 4\\ 6\\\alpha -26\end{pmatrix} = + s \begin{pmatrix} 1\\ 3\\ 7 \end{pmatrix} + t \begin{pmatrix} 2\\ -1\\5\end{pmatrix};\end{align}$$ ;for some s, $$t \in\mathbb{R}$$;;Equating components:;$$\begin{align};& 9 + 4s = 1 + 2t &----(1)\\;& 3 + 6s = 3 - t &----(2)\\;& 26 + (\alpha-26)s = 7 + 5t & ----(3)\\;\end{align}$$;;Eqn(1) + 2 x (2):;$$15 +16s =7 \Rightarrow s = -\frac{1}{2}$$;Subst $$s = -\frac{1}{2}$$ into Eqn(2):;$$3+6(-\frac{1}{2}) = 3 - t \Rightarrow t=3 $$;Subst $$s = -\frac{1}{2}$$ and t=3 into Eqn(3):;$$26 +(\alpha - 26)(-\frac{1}{2})=7 + 5(3)$$;$$\Rightarrow \alpha = 34$$;;$$\overrightarrow{AB} = \begin{pmatrix} 4\\ 6\\ 34-26 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 4\\ 6\\ 8 \end{pmatrix}$$;;Let $$\theta$$ = acute angle between lines L and AB;$$\begin{align};& \Rightarrow \left| \begin{pmatrix} 2\\ -1\\ 5 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 4\\ 6\\ 8 \end{pmatrix}\right| = \left| \begin{pmatrix} 2\\ -1\\ 5 \end{pmatrix} \right| - \left| \begin{pmatrix} 4\\ 6\\ 8 \end{pmatrix} \right| \cos{\theta} \\;&\Rightarrow |(2)(4) + (-1)(6) + (5)(8)| = \sqrt{2^{2} + (-1)^{2} + 5^{2}} \sqrt{4^{2} + 6^{2} + 8^{2}}\cos{\theta}\\;&\cos{\theta} = 0.7120\\;& \therefore \theta = \cos^{-1}(0.7120) = 44.60 = 44.6^{\circ} (1dp);\end{align}$$;;Q is on L;$$\begin{align};& \Rightarrow \overrightarrow{OQ} = \begin{pmatrix} 1\\ 3\\ 7 \end{pmatrix} + \begin{pmatrix} 2\\ -1\\ 5 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1+2t \\ 3-t\\ t+5t \end{pmatrix} for some t \in \mathbb{R}\\;& \overrightarrow{CQ} = \overrightarrow{OQ} - \overrightarrow{OC} = \begin{pmatrix} 1+2t \\ 3-t\\ t+5t \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 2\\ 5\\ 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -1+2t\\ -2-t\\ 6+5t \end{pmatrix};\end{align}$$;$$\overrightarrow{CQ}$$ is perpendicular to  L;$$\begin{align};\Rightarrow \begin{pmatrix} -1+2t\\ -2-t\\ 6+5t \end{pmatrix} . \begin{pmatrix} 2\\ -1\\ 5 \end{pmatrix} = 0 \\;\end{align}$$;img

Let $$\angle$$PXQ = $$\theta$$;Sine rule on $$\Delta$$PQX:;$$\frac{x}{\sin{\alpha}} = \frac{\lambda}{\sin{\theta}} \Rightarrow x = \frac{\lambda \sin{\alpha}}{\sin{\theta}}$$;Sine rule on $$\Delta$$PXR:;$$\frac{y}{\sin{\alpha}} = \frac{\mu}{\sin{(\pi-\theta)}} \equiv \frac{\mu}{\sin{\theta}}\Rightarrow y = \frac{\mu\sin{\alpha}}{\sin{\theta}}$$;$$\therefore \frac{\left(\frac{\lambda \sin{\alpha}}{\sin{\theta}}\right)}{\left(\frac{\mu\sin{\alpha}}{\sin{\theta}}\right)} = \frac{a}{b} = \frac{\lambda}{\mu}$$

Let a = $$1^{st}$$ term of G.P.;Let r = common ratio of G.P.;Let $$T_i$$ = $$i^{th}$$ term of G.P. (= $$ar^{i-1}$$);;Population at end of 1995 ($$T_1$$) = 46650;$$\Rightarrow a = 46650$$;;Population at end of 2000 ($$T_6$$) = 54200;$$\Rightarrow ar^{5}$$ = 54200;;$$\begin{align};i.e. \\;&(46650)r^{5} = 54200 \\;& r^{5} = 1.1618 \\;&\therefore r = 1.030;\end{align}$$;;(i) Population at end of 2006,;$$T_{12} = ar^{11} = (46650)(1.030)^{11} = 64574 = 64570(4 sf)$$;;(ii) Let n = year in which the population reaches 100000;$$\begin{align};& T_n = ar^{n-1} > 100000 \\;& \Rightarrow (46650)(1.030)^{n-1} > 100000\\;& (1.030)^{n-1} > 2.143\\;& n-1 > \frac{\ln{2.143}}{\ln{1.030}} = 25.78\\;& n > 26.78\\;&\therefore n=27 ;\end{align}$$

No. of ways to place 10 canisters on 10 bases;= ^{10}\textrm{P}_{10} = 10! = 3 628 800;;(i) No. of ways to place 2 particular canisters on remaining 6 bases (not A, E, F or J);= ^{6}\textrm{P}_{2} = \frac{6!}{(6-2)!} = 30;No. of ways to place remaining 8 canisters on remaining 8 bases;= ^{8}\textrm{P}_{8} = 8! = 40 320;$$\therefore$$ No. of ways to place the canisters ;= 30 x 40 320 = 1 209 600;;(ii) ;Case 1:;1st particular canisters is placed in one of 4 corner bases (A, E, F or J),;2nd particular canisters can be placed in any of 8 bases (not next to the 1st on the same side);No. of ways to place remaining 8 canisters on remaining 8 bases = 40 320;$$\therefore$$ No. of ways to place the canisters; = 4 x 8 x 40 320 = 1 290 240;;Case 2:;1st particular canisters is placed in one of 6 non-corner bases (not A, E, F or J),;2nd particular canisters can be placed in any of 7 bases (not next to the 1st on the same side);No. of ways to place remaining 8 canisters on remaining 8 bases = 40 320;$$\therefore$$ No. of ways to place the canisters; = 6 x 7 x 40 320 = 1 693 440;;$$\therefore$$ Total no. of ways to place the canisters; = 1 290 240 + 1 693 440; = 2 983 680

a) $$f(\theta) = \sin^{2}{\theta} - 6 \sin{\theta} + 4 \equiv (\sin{\theta} - 3)^{2} - 5$$;Deduce that $$f(\theta)$$ is greatest when $$ \sin{\theta = -1} \equiv (\sin{\theta} -3) = -4$$;i.e. $$f(\theta)_{greatest} = (-4)^{2} -5 = 11$$;Deduce that $$f(\theta)$$ is least when $$\sin{\theta} = 1 \equiv (\sin{\theta} -3) = -2$$;i.e. $$f(\theta)_{least} = (-2)^{2} -5 = -1$$;;b) ;$$\begin{align} &\sin{(A+B)} = 2 \cos{(A-B)}\\;& \Rightarrow \sin{A} \cos{B} + \cos{A}\sin{B} = 2(\cos{A}\cos{B} + \sin{A}\sin{B}) \\;&\equiv \frac{\sin{A} \cos{B}}{\cos{A}\cos{B} } + \frac{\cos{A}\sin{B} }{\cos{A}\cos{B} } = 2\left(1+\frac{ \sin{A}\sin{B}}{\cos{A}\cos{B}}\right)\\;& \tan{A} + \tan{B} = 2 + 2 \tan{A}\tan{B}\\;& \frac{1}{3} + \tan{B} = 2 + \frac{2}{3} \tan{B}\\;& \left(1-\frac{2}{3}\right)\tan{B} = 2 - \frac{1}{3}\\;&\therefore \tan{B} = 5;\end{align}$$

Given $$P(A \cup B)$$ = 0.9, $$P(A \cap B)$$ = 0.2, and P(A|B) = 0.8.;;$$\begin{align};& P(A \cap B) = P(A | B).P(B) \\;& i.e. 0.2 = 0.8 P(B) \\;& \Rightarrow P(B) = 0.25 \\;& P ( A \cup B ) = P ( A ) + P ( B ) - P ( A \cap B ) \\;& i.e. 0.9 = P(A) + 0.25 - 0.2 \\;& \therefore P ( A ) = 0.85 \\;& P(B \prime) = 1 - P(B) = 1 - 0.25 = 0.75\\;\end{align}$$

Let X = mass of an apple of variety A;Let Y = mass of an apple of variety B;X ~ N(0.125,0.022), Y ~ N(0.100,0.032);Let C = $$(X_{1}+ X_{2}+ X_{3}) + (Y_{1}+ Y_{2}+ Y_{3}+ Y_{4})$$;where $$X_{1}, X_{2}, X_{3}$$ are masses of 3 randomly chosen apples of variety A, and $$Y_{1}, Y_{2}, Y_{3}, Y_{4}$$ are masses of 4 randomly chosen apples of variety B.;$$\begin{align};&Let \mu_c = E (C) \\ ;&= E((X_1 + X_2 + X_3) -(Y_1 + Y_2 + Y_3 + Y_4)) \\ ;&= 3E ( X ) - 4E ( Y ) \\ ;&= 3(0.125) - 4(0.100) = - 0.025 \\ ;\end{align}$$;;$$\begin{align};&Let \sigma_c^2 = Var ( C ) \\ ;&= Var((X_1 + X_2 + X_3) -(Y_1 + Y_2 + Y_3 + Y_4)) \\ ;&= 3Var ( X ) + 4Var ( Y ) \\ ;&= 3({0.02}^2) + 4({0.03}^2) = 0.0048 \\;\end{align}$$;;$$\begin{align};&C \sim N ( \mu_c , \sigma_c^2 ) \\ ;&P((X_1 + X_2 + X_3) >(Y_1 + Y_2 + Y_3 + Y_4)) \\ ;&\equiv P ( ( X_1 + X_2 + X_3 ) - ( Y_1 + Y_2 + Y_3 + Y_4 ) > 0 ) \\ ;&\equiv P(C > 0) \\ ;&\equiv P ( Z > \frac{0 - \mu_c}{\sigma_c} ) = P ( Z > \frac{0 - ( - 0.025 )}{\sqrt{0.0048}} ) \\ ;&= P(Z > 0.3608) \equiv 1 - \Phi(0.3608) \\ ;&= 1 - 0.6410 = 0.3590 = 0.359 (3sf);\end{align}$$

Let $$p_{9} = 9^{th}$$ percentile of X;$$\begin{align};& F( p_9 ) = 0.09 \\;& \frac{1}{81}(p_9)^2 = 0.09 \\;& \therefore p_9 = 2.7 ;\end{align}$$;;$$\begin{align};& f(x) = \frac{d}{dx} F(x) \\;& =  \frac{d}{dx}[\frac{1}{81} x^2 ] \\;&= \frac{2}{81}x, for 0 \leq x \leq 9 \\;\end{align}$$;;$$\begin{align};& E (\sqrt{X}) = \int^\infty_{-\infty} \sqrt{x}f (x)dx \\;& =   \int^9_0 \sqrt{x} \left( \frac{2}{81}x \right)dx, for 0 \leq x \leq 9 \\;& =   \int^9_0 \frac{2}{81} x^{3 / 2}dx \\;& = {\left[ \frac{4}{405} x^{5 / 2}\right]}^9_0   = \frac{12}{5}\\;\end{align}$$;;$$\begin{align};& E ( X ) = \int^\infty_{- \infty}x.f(x) dx \\;& = \int^9_0 x(\frac{2}{81}x) dx \\;& = \int^9_0 \frac{2}{81}x^2 dx \\;& = {[ \frac{2}{243} x^3 ]}^9_0 = 6 \\;\end{align}$$;$$\begin{align};& Var(\sqrt{X}) = E(X) - [ E(\sqrt{X}) ]^2 \\;& = 6 - ( \frac{12}{5} )^2 = 0.24 \\;\end{align}$$

A suitable model for the distribution of Y is uniform (or rectangular) distribution.;;Let M = total mass of batch = $$\sum \left(x_{i} + \frac{y_{i}}{1000}\right)$$;$$\begin{align};& E(M) = E\left[\sum \left(x_{i} + \frac{y_{i}}{1000}\right)\right] \\;& =\left(\sum x_{i}\right) + \frac{E(\sum y_{i})}{1000} \\;& =\left(\sum x_{i}\right) + \frac{60E(Y)}{1000} \\;\end{align}$$;;$$\begin{align};& Y \sim U (0,1000) \\;& \Rightarrow E(Y) = \frac{1}{2}(0, 1000) = 500 \\;& \therefore E(M) = (\sum x_{i} ) + \frac{60(500)}{1000} = (\sum x_{i} ) + 30;\end{align}$$;;Given Var(Y) = $$\frac{10^{6}}{12}$$;$$P(\left(\sum x_{i}\right)+30$$ within $$\pm$$ 5kg of $$\sum \left(x_{i} + \frac{y_{i}}{1000}\right))$$;$$\equiv$$ P(30 within $$\pm$$ 5kg of $$\frac{\sum y_{i}}{1000}$$);$$\equiv P\left(25 < \frac{\sum y_{i}}{1000} < 35\right)$$;;$$\begin{align};& Let S = \frac{\sum y_{i}}{1000} \\;& E(S) = E\left(\frac{\sum y_{i}}{1000}\right) \\;& = \frac{60E(Y)}{1000} \\;& = \frac{60(500)}{1000} = 30 \\;& Var(S) = Var\left(\frac{\sum y_{i}}{1000}\right) \\;& = \frac{60 Var(Y)}{{1000}^2} \\;& = \frac{60\left(\frac{{10}^6}{12}\right)}{{10}^6}= 5 \\;\end{align}$$;;Since batch size (=60) is large, S ~ N(30,5) approximately. ;$$\begin{align};& P ( 25 < \frac{\sum y_{i}}{1000} < 35 ) \\;& \equiv P(25 < S < 35) \\;& \equiv P\left(\frac{25 - 30}{\sqrt{5}} < Z < \frac{35 - 30}{\sqrt{5}}\right) \\;& = P(- \sqrt{5}< Z < \sqrt{5}) \equiv 2 \Phi(\sqrt{5}) - 1 \\;& = 2\Phi ( 2.236 ) - 1 = 2 ( 0.9873 ) - 1 \\;& = 0.9746 = 0.975 (3sf)\\;\end{align}$$

A condition is that the moths are caught at randomly scattered intervals.;;Let M = no. of moths caught in an evening ;Let $$\lambda$$=E(M)=3.5;M ~ Po($$\lambda$$);P(5 or more moths caught in an evening);P ( M $$\geq$$ 5 ) ;$$\equiv$$ 1 - P(M $$\leq$$ 4) ;= 1 - [P(M=0) + P(M=1) + P(M=2) + P(M = 3) + P(M = 4)] ;= 1 - $$e^{- \lambda} \left[ \frac{\lambda^0}{0 !} + \frac{\lambda^1}{1 !} + \frac{\lambda^2}{2 !} + \frac{\lambda^3}{3 !} + \frac{\lambda^4}{4 !}\right]$$ ;= 1 - $$e^{- 3.5} \left[ 1 + 3.5 + \frac{(3.5)^2}{2}+ \frac{(3.5)^3}{6}+ \frac{(3.5)^4}{24} \right]$$ ;= 0.2746 = 0.275 (3sf);;Let B = $$M_1+M_2+M_3+M_4$$ where $$M_1, M_2, M_3, M_4$$ are no. of moths caught in 4 randomly chosen evenings. ;Let $$\mu$$=E(B)=E($$M_1+M_2+M_3+M_4$$) = 4E(M) = 4(3.5) = 14.0;B ~ Po($$\mu$$);Since $$\mu$$(=14) $$\geq$$ 10;B ~ N($$\mu$$,$$\mu$$) approximately;P( 18 or more caught in 4 evenings) ;P ( B $$\geq$$ 18 ) ;$$\equiv$$ P(B > 17.5) ;$$\equiv$$ P$$\left(Z > \frac{17.5 - \lambda}{\sqrt{\lambda}}\right)$$;= P$$\left(Z > \frac{17.5 - 14}{\sqrt{14}}\right)$$;= P$$(Z > 0.9354) \equiv 1 - \Phi (0.935)$$;= 1 - 0.8251 = 0.175 (3sf)

a) The procedure does not gives a random sample because the children do not have equal chances of being selected.;;b) ;Let n = sample size = 50;Let $$p_0$$ = assume p = 0.8 and $$q_0$$ = 1 - $$p_0$$ = 0.2;Let $$p_s$$ = sample p = $$\frac{34}{50}$$ = 0.68 and $$q_s$$ = 1- $$p_s$$ = 0.32;;Test $$H_0: p = p_0$$ against $$H_1: p < p_0$$ a 1 tailed test for less;The 5% critical value, $$z_{0.05}$$ = 1.645 ;Reject $$H_0$$ if $$z < -z_{0.05}$$;Under $$H_0$$, the test statistic is ;$$z = \frac{p_s - p_0}{\sqrt{p_0 q_0 / n}} = \frac{0.68 - 0.8}{\sqrt{( 0.8 ) ( 0.2 ) / 50}} = - 2.12$$;Since $$z < -z_{0.05}$$, reject $$H_0$$ and conclude that at the 5% level of significance, there is sufficient evidence that the proportion of children at the school with access to a computer at home is less than 0.8.;;$$z_{0.025} \sqrt{\frac{p_s q_s}{n}} = 1.960\sqrt{\frac{( 0.68 ) ( 0.32 )}{50}} = 0.1293$$;A symmetric 95% confidence interval;$$p_s - z_{0.025} \sqrt{\frac{p_s q_s}{n}} , p_s + z_{0.025} \sqrt{\frac{p_s q_s}{n}}$$  ;= [ 0.68 - 0.1293, 0.68 + 0.1293 ] ;= [ 0.5507 , 0.8093 ] ;= [ 0.551, 0.809 ] (3sf)

(i) Tabulate all possible products:;img;Tabulate frequency / probability distribution:;img;;$$E(X) = \sum_{all x_{i}} x_{i}.P(X = x) $$;$$= (1)\left(\frac{6}{36}\right) + (2)\left(\frac{12}{36}\right) + (3)\left(\frac{6}{36}\right) + (4)\left(\frac{6}{36}\right) + (6)\left(\frac{6}{36}\right) $$;$$= 3$$;;$$E(X^{2}) = \sum_{all x_{i}} {x_{i}}^{2}.P(X = x) $$;$$= (1)^{2}\left(\frac{6}{36}\right) + (2)^{2}\left(\frac{12}{36}\right) + (3)^{2}\left(\frac{6}{36}\right) + (4)^{2}\left(\frac{6}{36}\right) + (6)^{2}\left(\frac{6}{36}\right)$$;$$= \frac{35}{3}$$;;$$\therefore Var(X) = E(X^{2}) - [E(X)]^{2}$$;$$ = \left(\frac{35}{3}\right) - (3)^{2} = \frac{8}{3}$$;;(ii) ;Let n = sample size = 100;Let p = P(X = 2) = $$\frac{12}{36}$$ = $$\frac{1}{3}$$ and q = 1 - p = $$\frac{2}{3}$$;T ~ B(n,p);Since n(= 100) is large and np$$\left(= \frac{100}{3}\right)$$ > 5 and nq$$\left(= \frac{200}{3}\right)$$ > 5;X ~ N(np, npq) = N $$\left(\frac{100}{3}, \frac{200}{9}\right)$$ approximately ;P(T $$\geq$$ 40);$$\equiv$$ P(T > 39.5) $$\leftarrow$$ continuity correction;$$\equiv$$ P$$\left(Z > \frac{39.5 - np}{\sqrt{npq}}\right)$$ = P $$\left(Z > \frac{39.5-\frac{100}{3}}{\sqrt{\frac{200}{9}}} \right)$$;= P(Z > 1.3081) = 1 - $$\Phi$$(1.308);= 1 - 0.9045 = 0.0955(3sf)

(i) ;Let n = sample size = 50;Let $$\mu_{0}$$ = assume $$\mu$$ = 9.5;Let $$\sigma^{2}$$ = Var(X) = 15;;$$\hat{\mu} = \overline{x} = \frac{\sum x}{n} = \frac{527.1}{50} = 10.542$$;Test $$H_{0}: \mu = \mu_{0}$$ against $$H_{1}: \mu \neq \mu_{0}$$ a 2-tailed test for difference;At 5% significance level, critical value $$z_{0.025}$$ = 1.960;Reject $$H_{0}$$ if $$\left| z \right| > \left| z_{0.025} \right|$$;Under $$H_{0}$$, the test statistic is ;$$z = \left( \frac{\overline{x} - \mu_{0}}{\sigma / \sqrt{n}} \right) = \frac{10.542 - 9.5}{\sqrt{15/50}} = 1.902$$;;Since $$\left| z \right| < \left| z_{0.025} \right|$$, do not reject $$H_{0}$$ and conclude that, at the 5% significance level, there is insufficient evidence that $$\mu \neq 9.5$$;;(ii);Let $$\mu_{1}$$ = alternative assume $$\mu = 11.5$$;With $$\hat{\mu}(= 10.542) < \mu_{1}(= 11.5)$$, in a 1-tailed test with $$H_{0}: \mu < \mu_{1}$$;$$\hat{\sigma}^{2} = \frac{1}{n-1}\left[\sum x^{2} - \frac{1}{n}\left(\sum x\right)^{2}\right]$$;= $$\frac{1}{49}\left[6172.31 - \frac{1}{50}\left(527.1\right)^{2}\right]$$ = 12.56;For a 1-tailed test, the $$\alpha$$% critical value is $$z_{\alpha}$$;Under $$H_{0}$$, the test statistic is ;$$z = \left( \frac{\overline{x} - \mu_{1}}{\sigma / \sqrt{n}} \right) = \frac{10.542 - 11.5}{\sqrt{12.56/50}} = -1.911$$;$$H_{0}$$ is accepted if $$z > - z_{\alpha}$$;;i.e. -1.911 > -$$z_{\alpha}$$;$$z_{\alpha}$$ > 1.911;$$\equiv \Phi(z_{\alpha}) > \Phi(1.911)$$ ;$$\equiv 1 - \alpha > 0.9720$$;$$\therefore \alpha < 0.028$$;$$\equiv$$ Significance level of test < 2.8%

$$\theta = 30^{\circ}$$ is a root of $$2 - \cos ^{2}\theta = \lambda \cos 2\theta$$;$$\Rightarrow 2 - \cos^{2}30^{\circ} = \lambda \cos 2(30^{\circ})$$;$$2 - \left(\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\right)^{2}  = \frac{1}{2} \lambda$$;$$\Rightarrow \lambda = \frac{5}{2}$$;$$\therefore$$ Equation is:;$$2 - \cos^{2}\theta = \frac{5}{2} \cos 2 \theta $$;$$4 - 2 \cos^{2}\theta = \frac{5}{2} ( 2 \cos^{2} \theta - 1)$$;$$2 \ cos^{2} \theta = 9$$;$$\cos^{2}\theta = \frac{3}{4}$$;$$\cos\theta = \pm \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}$$;$$\theta = 360 n^{\circ} \pm 30^{\circ}$$ or $$360 n^{\circ} \pm 150^{\circ}$$;For $$0^{\circ} \leq \theta \leq 360^{\circ}$$, besides $$\theta = 30^{\circ}, \theta= 150^{\circ} ,210^{\circ}$$ or $$330^{\circ}$$

$$1 + \left | 2x -3  \right | = 3x \Rightarrow \left | 2x -3  \right | = 3x -1$$;;For $$2x - 3 > 0 \Rightarrow x > \frac{3}{2}$$;$$\left | 2x -3  \right | = 3x -1$$;$$\equiv 2x -3 = 3x -1$$;$$\Rightarrow x = -2$$ (NA, since $$x >\frac{3}{2}$$);;For $$2x - 3 < 0 \Rightarrow x < \frac{3}{2}$$,;$$\left | 2x -3  \right | = 3x -1$$;$$\equiv -(2x -3) = 3x -1$$;$$\Rightarrow x = \frac{4}{5}$$
