img;The region is bounded by the positive x-axis, the positive y-axis and the curve: ;$$Y = \frac{1}{(x^2 + 1)^{\frac{1}{3}}}$$;i)Using the trapezium rule, with 4 intervals of equal width of 0.25 unit, to estimate the shaded area of region R,;Trapezium rule:;$$\int_{a}^{b} y dx \approx \frac{1}{2} h \left[y_0 + y_n + 2 \left[ y_1 + ...+ y_n - 1 \right] \right]$$;Where  h = width of each trapezium, and $$y_i$$ is the value of y at $$x = a + ih$$;With $$b = 1$$, $$a = 0$$ and $$n = 4$$,; $$H =  \frac{b-a}{n} = \frac{1-0}{4} = 0.25$$;Area of region R;= $$\int_{0}^{1}\frac{1}{\left ( x^{2}+ 1 \right )^{\frac{1}{3}}}dx$$;= $$\frac{1}{2} 0.25 \left [ 1 + 0.79370 + 2\left ( 0.97999 + 0.92832 + 0.86177 \right )  \right ]$$;= $$0.917(3dp)$$;(ii)Expanding $$(x^{2} + 1) ^{-\frac{1}{3}}$$ in ascending powers of x up to, and including, the term in $$x^{4}$$,;$$\equiv \left ( 1 + x^{2} \right )^{-\frac{1}{3}};= 1 - \frac{1}{3}x^{2} + \frac{\left ( -\frac{1}{3} \right )\left ( -\frac{4}{3} \right )}{2!}\left ( x^{2} \right )^{2};\approx 1 - \frac{1}{3}x^{2} + \frac{2}{9}x^{4}$$;Using this expansion, to get a second estimate of the area of R;= $$\left [ x - \frac{1}{9}x^{3} + \frac{2}{45}x^{5} \right ]10 ;= 0.933(3dp)$$

At the points of intersection between ;y = x - 3 and $$y^{2} + y = 2x^{2} - x + 1$$;$$\begin{align};& \left ( x - 3 \right )^2 + \left ( x -3 \right ) = 2x^{2}- x + 1\\;& \Rightarrow x^{2} - 6x + 9 + x - 3 - 2x^{2} - x +1\\;& x^{2} + 4x - 5  = 0\\;\end{align}$$;$$\therefore x = -5$$ or $$x = 1$$;$$\Rightarrow y = x - 3 = -2$$ or $$-8$$;$$\therefore$$ There are 2 points of intersection: (1,-2) and (-5,-8);$$\begin{align};& y^{2} + y = 2x^{2} - x +1\\;& \Rightarrow \frac{d}{dx}[y^2 + y] = \frac{d}{dx}[2x^{2} - x +1]\\;& 2y\frac{dy}{dx} + \frac{dy}{dx} = 4x -1\\;& (2y+1)\frac{dy}{dx} = 4x -1\\;& \frac{dy}{dx} = \frac{4x-1}{2y+1}\\;\end{align}$$;;Gradient $$m_1$$ of line y = (1)x - 3 is 1.;Gradient $$m_2$$ of curve is given by $$\frac{dy}{dx}$$;At (1, -2), $$m_2 = \frac{dy}{dx} = \frac{4(1)-1}{2(-2)+1} = -1$$;Since $$m_2 = \frac{1}{m_1}$$, line y = x - 3 is normal to the curve at this point.;At (-5,-8), $$m_2 = \frac{dy}{dx} = \frac{4(-5)-1}{2(-8)+1} = 1.4$$;Since $$m_2 \neq \frac{1}{m_1}$$, line y = x - 3 is not normal to the curve at this point.;;$$\therefore$$ The line is normal to the cruve at exactly one (1,-2) of the two points of intersection

The differential equation;$$x\frac{d}{dx} + y = x y^{3}------(1)$$;Using the substitution; $$y^{2} = \frac{1}{z}------(2)$$;Reducing (1):;(2) $$= y = \frac{1}{\sqrt{z}};\frac{d}{dx} = - \frac{1}{2} \frac{1}{z^{\frac{3}{2}}}\frac{d}{dx}------(3)$$;Substitute (3) into (1);$$X(-\frac{1}{2}\frac{1}{z^{\frac{3}{2}}}\frac{d}{dx} + \frac{1}{\sqrt{z}} = x \frac{1}{z^{\frac[3}{2}}$$;The differential equation is reduced to;$$\frac{d}{dx} - \frac{2z}{x} = -2$$;Solving (1):;Let $$h(x) = \int \frac{-2}{x}dc = -2 \ln x = \ln x^{-2}$$;Integrating factor:;$$\exp h(x) = \exp(l x ^{-2}) = x^{-2} = \frac{1}{x^{2}}$$;General solution:; $$Z = \exp(-h(x)) \left [ \int \exp (h(x))(-2)dx \right ];= x^\left(2\right)\left [ -2\int \frac{1}{x^{2}}dx \right ];=x^{2}\left [ 2\frac{1}{x}+ c \right ]$$ where c is a constant;$$= 2x + cx^{2}$$;Substitute into (2);Gerneral solution of differential equation; $$Y^{2} = \frac{1}{2x+cx^{2}}$$ where c is a constant

(i);$$\begin{align};&ff(\lambda) =  f[(\lambda)^{2} - 6\lambda(\lambda)] \\;&= f(-5\lambda^{2})\\;&=(-5\lambda^{2})^{2} - 6\lambda(-5\lambda^{2})\\;&=25\lambda^{4} + 30\lambda^{3}\\;\end{align}$$;;(ii);img;$$f(x) = x^{2} - 6\lambda x = ( x - 3 \lambda)^2 - 9\lambda^{2}$$ ;Since $$(x - 3\lambda)^{2} \geq 0, f(x) = (x-3\lambda)^{2} - 9\lambda^{2} \geq -9\lambda^{2}$$;i.e. $$D_f$$ is $$f(x) \geq -9\lambda^{2}$$;Function f does not have an inverse beacuse it is not a one-one function.;$$f(x) \equiv (x-3\lambda)^{2} - 9\lambda^2$$;$$\Rightarrow f(3\lambda + x) = f(3\lambda -x)$$;i.e. $$f(x)$$ is symmetrical about $$x = 3\lambda$$;$$\Rightarrow f(x)$$ could be a one-one function if its domain is restricted to one side of $$x = 3\lambda$$;$$\therefore k = 3\lambda$$;;Let $$y = f^{-1}(x)$$;$$\Rightarrow f(y) = x$$;i.e. ;$$\begin{align} &y^{2} - 6\lambda y = x\\;&y^{2} - 6\lambda y - x = 0\\;&\therefore y = \frac{-(-6\lambda) \pm \sqrt{(-6\lambda)^{2} - 4(1)(-x)}}{2(1)}\\;&= 3\lambda \pm \sqrt{9\lambda^{2} + x};\end{align}$$;$$\therefore$$ For $$x \geq 3\lambda$$,;$$f^{-1}(x) = 3\lambda + \sqrt{9\lambda^{2} +x} $$;For $$x \leq 3\lambda$$,;$$f^{-1}(x) = 3\lambda - \sqrt{9\lambda^{2} +x} $$

(i) Let M = the mid-point of AB, and N = the foot of perpendicular from V to the base of ABCDEF;;Sketch diagram:;img;Angle between the planes VAB and ABCDEF is given by $$\angle$$VMN;Deduce the AN = BN = AB = 2a and AM = $$\frac{1}{2}$$AB = $$\frac{1}{2}$$(2a) = a;;$$\Delta$$ AMN:;$$MN^{2} =  AN^{2} - AM^{2} = (2a)^{2} - a^{2} = 3 a^2$$;$$\therefore$$ MN = $$\sqrt{3}a$$;;$$\Delta$$AMV :;$$MV^{2} = AV^{2} - AM^{2} = (4a)^{2} - (a)^{2} = 15 a^{2}$$;$$\therefore$$ MV =$$\sqrt{15}a$$;;$$\cos {\angle VMN} = \frac{MN}{MV} = \frac{\sqrt{3}a}{sqrt{15}a} = 0.4472$$;$$\therefore \angle VMN = \cos^{-1}{0.4472} = 63.4 = 63^{\circ}(nearest ^{\circ})$$;;(ii) Let P = foot of the perpendicular from A onto VB;Sketch diagram:;img;Angle between planes VAB and VBC is given by $$\angle$$CPA;;Area of $$\Delta$$VAB;$$= \frac{1}{2}AP VB = \frac{1}{2} VM AB$$;i.e.$$\frac{1}{2}AP. (4a) = \frac{1}{2}(\sqrt{15}a).(2a)$$;$$\therefore$$ AP = $$\frac{\sqrt{15}}{2} a$$;;$$\Delta$$ VAB an $$\Delta$$ VAC are identical isosceles triangle.;$$\Rightarrow$$ P is also the foot of the perpendicular from C onto VB, and.;CP = AP = $$\frac{\sqrt{15}}{2} a$$;;$$\Delta$$ ABC:;$$AC^{2} = AB^{2} + BC^{2}  - 2 AB.BC.\cos{\angle ABC}$$;$$ = (2a)^{2} + (2a)^{2} - 2(2a)(2a) \cos 120^{\circ} = 12 a ^{2}$$;;$$\Delta$$ APC:;$$AC^{2} = AP^{2} + CP^{2} - 2 AP. CP.\cos{\angle CPA}$$;i.e. $$12a^{2} = \left( \frac{\sqrt{15}}{2} a\right)^{2} + \left( \frac{\sqrt{15}}{2} a\right)^{2} - 2\left( \frac{\sqrt{15}}{2} a\right)\left( \frac{\sqrt{15}}{2} a\right)\cos{\angle CPA}$$;$$\cos \angle{CPA} = -0.6$$;$$\therefore \angle{CPA} = 126.9 = 127^{\circ}(nearest ^{\circ})$$

;$$\begin{align}I = \int\frac{P(x)}{x^{3} + 1} dx \end{align}$$;;(i) For $$P(x) = x^{2}$$,;$$\begin{align} ;& I = \int \frac{x^{2}}{x^{3} + 1} dx \equiv \frac{1}{3} \int \frac{3x^{2}}{x^{3} + 1} dx \\;& =\frac{1}{3} \ln|x^{3} + 1 | + c \\;\end{align}$$;;(ii) Let $$x^{3} + 1 \equiv (x + 1) ( x^{2} + Ax + B) = x^{3} + (A+1)x^{2}(A+B)x+B$$;Comparing coefficients of x:;$$\begin{align};& x^{2}: 0 = A + 1 \Rightarrow A = - 1\\;& x^{0}: B = 1\\;& \therefore x^{3} + 1 \equiv (x+1)(x^{2}-x+1)\\;\end{align}$$;(a) For $$P(x) = x^{2} - x + 1$$;$$\begin{align};&l = \int \frac{x^{2} - x + 1}{x^{3}+1}dx\\;& \equiv \int \frac{x^{2} - x + 1}{(x+1)(x^{2} - x + 1)}dx\\;& =\int\frac{1}{x+1}\\;& =\ln|x+1| + c\\;\end{align}$$ ;;(b) For $$P(x) = x + 1$$;$$\begin{align};& l = \int\frac{x+ 1}{x^{3} + 1} dx \\;& \equiv \int\frac{x + 1}{(x+1)(x^2 - x +1} dx \\;& = \int\frac{1}{x^2 - x +1} dx \\ ;&= \int\frac{1}{(x-\frac{1}{2})^2 + \frac{3}{4}} dx \\ ;& = \int\frac{1}{(x-\frac{1}{2})^2 + \left(\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\right)} dx \\ ;& = \frac{2}{\sqrt{3}} \tan^{-1} \left[\frac{x - \frac{1}{2}}{ \left(\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\right) } \right] + c\\ ;&= \frac{2}{\sqrt{3}} \tan^{-1} \left(\frac{2x-1}{\sqrt{-3}}\right) + c\\;\end{align}$$;;(iii) For $$P(x) = 1$$, deduce that;$$\begin{align};& 1 = \frac{1}{2} [(x^2 - x +1) = (x^2) + (x+1)]\\;& \Rightarrow I = \int \frac{1}{x^{3} + 1} dx \\;& = \frac{1}{2}[\int\frac{x^2-x+1}{x^3+1}dx - \int\frac{x^2}{x^3+1}dx + \int\frac{x+1}{x^3+1}dx]\\;& = \frac{1}{2}\left[\ln |x+1| - \frac{1}{3}\ln |x^3+1| + \frac{2}{\sqrt{3}} \tan^{-1}{\left(\frac{2x-1}{\sqrt{3}}\right)} + c\right]\\;& = \frac{1}{2} \ln{|x+1| - \frac{1}{6}\ln{|x^3+1|}} + \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}\tan^{-1}{\frac{2x-1}{\sqrt{3}}} + c\\;\end{align}$$

$$l_1 : r = \begin{pmatrix}0\\ 1\\ 2 \end{pmatrix} + s\begin{pmatrix}1\\ 0\\ ;3 \end{pmatrix}$$, $$l_2 : r = \begin{pmatrix}-2\\ 3\\ 1\end{pmatrix} + t\begin{pmatrix}2\\ b\\ 0\end{pmatrix}$$ where s, t $$\in \mathbb{R}$$;;(i) $$l_1$$ and $$l_2$$ intersect,;$$\Rightarrow \begin{pmatrix} 0\\ 1\\ 2 \end{pmatrix} +s\begin{pmatrix} 1\\ 0\\ 3 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -2\\ 3\\ 1 \end{pmatrix} + t\begin{pmatrix} 2\\ b\\ 0 \end{pmatrix}$$ for some s, t $$\in \mathbb{R}$$;$$\begin{align};& \Rightarrow 0 + s = -2 + 2t &----(1)\\;& 1 = 3+ bt &----(2) \\;& 2 + 3s = 1 &----(3)\\;\end{align}$$;;$$\begin{align};&Eqn(3) &\Rightarrow s = -\frac{1}{3}\\;&Eqn(1): 0 + \left(-\frac{1}{3}\right) = -2 + 2t &\Rightarrow t = \frac{5}{6}\\;&Eqn(2): 1 = 3 + b \left(\frac{5}{6}\right) &\Rightarrow b = -\frac{12}{5}\\;\end{align}$$;;Let $$\theta$$ = acute angle btween $$l_1$$ and $$l_2$$;$$\begin{align};&\Rightarrow \left|\begin{pmatrix} 1\\ 0\\ 3 \end{pmatrix}.\begin{pmatrix} 2\\ -\frac{12}{5}\\ 0 \end{pmatrix}\right| = \left|\begin{pmatrix} 1\\ 0\\ 3 \end{pmatrix}\right|\left|\begin{pmatrix} 2\\ -\frac{12}{5}\\ 0 \end{pmatrix}\right| \cos{\theta}\\;& \left| (1)(2) + (0)\left(-\frac{12}{5}\right) + (3)(0)\right|\\;& = \sqrt{1^2+0+3^2} \sqrt{2+\left(-\frac{12}{5}\right)^2 + 0} \cos{\theta}\\;& \cos{\theta} = 0.2024 \\;& \therefore \theta = \cos^{-1}{0.2024} = 78.32^{\circ} = 78.3^{\circ}\\; \end{align}$$;;(ii) For b = 1, P is on $$l_1$$;$$\begin{align};& \Rightarrow \overrightarrow{OP} = \begin{pmatrix} 0\\ 1\\ 2 \end{pmatrix} + s\begin{pmatrix} 1\\ 0\\ 3 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} s\\ 1\\ 2+3s \end{pmatrix}\\ \end{align}$$;for some s $$\in \mathbb{R}$$;Q is on $$l_2$$;$$\begin{align};& \Rightarrow \overrightarrow{OQ} = \begin{pmatrix} -2\\ 3\\ 1 \end{pmatrix} + t\begin{pmatrix} 2\\ 1\\ 0 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -2+2t\\ 3+t\\ 1 \end{pmatrix}\\ \end{align}$$;;O, P and Q are collinear;$$\Rightarrow \overrightarrow{OP} = \lambda\overrightarrow{OQ}$$, for some $$\lambda\in\mathbb{R}$$;i.e. $$\begin{pmatrix} s\\ 1\\ 2+3s \end{pmatrix} = \lambda\begin{pmatrix} -2+2t\\ 3+t\\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$$;;$$\begin{align};& \Rightarrow s = -2\lambda + 2\lambda t &----(1)\\ ;& 1 = 3\lambda + \lambda t &----(2)\\ ;& 2 + 3s = \lambda &----(3) \\ ;& Eqn(2) x 2 - (1) : 2 - s = 8\lambda &----(4) \\ \end{align}$$;Subst $$\lambda = 2+3s$$ [eqn(3)] into eqn(4):;2 - s = 8(2 + 3s);25s = -14;$$\begin{align}& \Rightarrow s = -\frac{14}{25} \\ \end{align}$$;Subst $$\lambda=\frac{8}{25}$$ into eqn(2):;$$ 1 = 3 \left(\frac{8}{25}\right) + \left(\frac{8}{25}\right)t $$;$$ \Rightarrow t = \frac{1}{8}$$;$$\begin{align}& \therefore \overrightarrow{OP} = \begin{pmatrix} \left(-\frac{14}{25}\right)\\ 1\\ 2 + 3\left(-\frac{14}{25}\right)\ \end{pmatrix} = \frac{1}{25}\begin{pmatrix} -14\\ 25\\ 8 \end{pmatrix}\\;& \therefore \overrightarrow{OQ} = \begin{pmatrix} -2+2\left(\frac{1}{8}\right)\\ 3+\left(\frac{1}{8}\right)\\ 1 \end{pmatrix} = \frac{1}{8}\begin{pmatrix} -14\\ 25\\ 8 \end{pmatrix}\\ \end{align}$$

Subst $$ z = i $$ into eqn:;LHS = $$ i^4 - 2i^3 + 6i^2 = 2i + 5 = 1 + 2i - 6 -2i + 5 = 0$$ = RHS;$$ \Rightarrow z = i $$ is a root of the eqn.;Since all coefficients of the eqn are real, $$ z=i $$ is a root $$ \Rightarrow z = -i $$ is a root;i.e. $$ (z-1)(z+1) = z^2 + 1 $$ is a factor;By observation (or long division),;$$\begin{align} ;& z^4 - 2z^3 + 6z^2 - 2z = 5 =0\\;& \equiv (z^2+1)(z^2 -2z +5) = 0\\ ;& \Rightarrow z = \frac{-(-2) \pm\sqrt{(-2)^2 -4(1)(5)}}{2(1)}\\;& 1 \pm 2i\\  \end{align}$$;$$\therefore$$ Other roots are $$-i, 1\pm2i$$

(i) Area A = $$ 4\pi r^2 $$;$$\begin{align} ;& \Rightarrow \frac{d}{dt} [A] = \frac{d}{dr} [4\pi r^2] x \frac{dr}{dt}\\  ;& \frac{dA}{dt} = 8\pi r\frac{dr}{dt}\\ ;& i.e. -0.4 = 8\pi (0.25)\frac{dr}{dt}\\ ;& \therefore \frac{dr}{dt} = -\frac{1}{5\pi} ms^{-1}\\ \end{align}$$;;(ii) Volume  V = $$ \frac{4}{3}\pi r^3 $$;$$\begin{align}  ;& \Rightarrow \frac{d}{dt}[V] = \frac{d}{dr} \left[\frac{4}{3}\pi r^3\right]x\frac{dr}{dt}\\;& \frac{dV}{dt} = 4\pi r^2 \frac{dr}{dt}\\ ;& = 4\pi(0.25)^2\left(-\frac{1}{5\pi}\right)\\;& = -0.050m^3s^-1\\  \end{align}$$;$$ \therefore $$ During a short time $$ \delta t $$. small change in volume, ;$$ \delta V \approx \frac{dV}{dt} \delta t = -0.050\delta t$$

Let $$ 3\sin{2x} + 2\cos{2x} $$;$$ \equiv R\sin{(2x + \alpha)}$$;$$ = R\sin{2x}\cos{\alpha} + R\cos{2x}\sin{\alpha}$$;Comparing coefficients:;$$ \sin{2x}: 3 = R \cos{\alpha}$$;$$ \cos{2x}: 2 = R \sin{\alpha}$$;$$\begin{align}& \Rightarrow R = \sqrt{3^2 + 2^2} = \sqrt{13}\\;& \alpha = \tan^{-1}{\left(\frac{2}{3}\right)} = 0.5880\\ ;& \therefore f(x) \equiv \sqrt{\sin{(2x + 0.588)}}\\ \end{align}$$;;(i) $$ |k| > \sqrt{13} $$;(ii) ;$$\begin{align}& f(x) = \sqrt{13}\sin{(2x+0.588)} = 1\\;& \Rightarrow \sin{(2x + 0.5888)} = \frac{1}{\sqrt{13}}\\;& 2x + 0.588 = n\pi +(-1)^n(0.28103)\\ ;& \therefore x = n\pi + (-1)^n(0.1405) - 0.294\\ ;& = n\pi + (-1)^n(0.141) - 0.294(3sf)\\ \end{align}$$

(i) ;a, b, c are $$ 1^{st} $$ 3 terms of a G.P. $$  \Rightarrow $$common ratio;$$\begin{align} r = \frac{b}{a} = \frac{c}{b} \Rightarrow b^2 = ac \end{align}$$;;a, c, b are $$ 1^{st} $$ 3 terms of a A.P. $$  \Rightarrow $$common difference;$$\begin{align} d = c-a =b-c \Rightarrow c = \frac{a+b}{2} \end{align}$$;;(ii);Subst $$ c = \frac{a+b}{2} $$ into $$ b^2 = ac $$;$$\begin{align}  ;& b^2 = a \frac{a+b}{2}\\ ;& \Rightarrow 2b^2 = a^2 + ab\\ ;& 2b^2 - ab-a^2 =0\\ ;& \therefore 2\left(\frac{b}{a}\right)^2 - \left(\frac{b}{a}\right)-1 = 0\\ \end{align}$$;;(iii);Subst $$ r = \frac{b}{a} $$ into eqn from (ii):;$$2r^2 - r -1 = 0$$;$$\Rightarrow (2r+1)(r-1) = 0$$;$$r=-\frac{1}{2}$$ or $$r=1$$ (NA since S to exist);$$\begin{align} \therefore S = \frac{a}{1-r} = \frac{a}{1-\left(-\frac{1}{2}\right)} = \frac{2}{3}a \end{align}$$

(i) Deduce that f(x) is symmetrical about x =1 $$\Rightarrow$$Mode = 1;;(ii) f(x)$$\geq$$0 for 0$$\leq$$x$$\leq$$2 - by definition $$\Rightarrow$$ f(0)$$\geq$$0;$$\begin{align}  ;i.e. & a - b ( 0 - 1 )^2 \geq 0 \\;&a - b \geq 0 \\;&\therefore a \geq b\\;\end{align}$$;;(iii) ;$$\begin{align} ;& \int^\infty_{- \infty} f ( x ) dx = 1 \\;& \Rightarrow \int^2_0 [ a - b(x - 1)^2 ] dx = 1 \\;& {[ ax - \frac{1}{3}b ( x - 1 )^3 ]}^2_0 = 1 \\;& 2a - \frac{2}{3}b = 1 \\;& 3a - b = \frac{3}{2}\\;\end{align}$$;;(iv) $$ b = \frac{3}{8} \Rightarrow 3a - \frac{3}{8} = \frac{3}{2} \Rightarrow a = \frac{5}{8}$$;If q is upper quartile of X, $$ \int^q_{- \infty} f ( x )d x = \frac{3}{4}$$;$$\begin{align}  ;\\ \int^{\sqrt{2}}_0 f(x)dx;\\ \int^{\sqrt{2}}_0 \left[ \frac{5}{8}- \frac{3}{8}(x-1)^2 \right] dx ;\\ = {\left[ \frac{5}{8}- \frac{1}{8}(x-1)^3 \right]}^{\sqrt{2}}_0 ;\\ = \left[ \frac{5}{8}(\sqrt{2})- \frac{1}{8}(\sqrt{2}-1)^3 \right]-\left[ 0- \frac{1}{8}(-1)^3 \right] ;\\ = \frac{1}{8}\left[ 5 \sqrt{2}-(2 \sqrt{2}-6 + 3 \sqrt{2}-1)-(1) \right] ;\\ = \frac{6}{8}= \frac{3}{4};\end{align}$$;$$\Rightarrow \sqrt(2)$$ is upper quartile of X.

Let X = no. of flaws in 200m of ribbon;Let $$\lambda = E(X) = 2$$;$$\begin{align} ;X \sim P_0 ( \lambda ) ;\\ P(X \geq 3) ;\\ \equiv 1 - P ( X = 0 ) - P ( X = 1 ) - P ( X = 2 ) ;\\ = 1 - e^{- \lambda}[ 1 + \lambda + \frac{\lambda^2}{2 !}] ;\\ = 1 - e^{- 2} [ 1 + 2 + \frac{2^2}{2 !} ] ;\\ = 0.3233 = 0.323(3dp);\end{align}$$;;Let L = required length of ribbon;Let Y = no. of flaws in length L of ribbon;Deduce that E(Y) = L / 100 and $$Y ~ P_o(L / 100)$$;$$\begin{align}  ;i.e. & P(Y=0) = 0.001\\;& \Rightarrow e^{- L / 100} = 0.001 \\;& - L/100 = \ln  (0.001) = - 6.908 \\;& \therefore L = 690.8 = 691m(3sf) \\;\end{align}$$;;Let R = no. of flaws in 2000 m of ribbon;Let $$\mu=E(R)=20$$;$$R \sim P_o(\mu)$$;Since $$\mu(=20) > 10$$,;$$R ~ N(\mu,\mu)$$ approximately;P ( R < 12 ) ;$$ \equiv P(R < 11.5) \leftarrow$$  continuity correction;$$ \equiv P \left( Z < \frac{11.5 - \mu}{\sqrt{\mu}} \right) = P ( Z < \frac{11.5 - 20}{\sqrt{20}} ) $$;$$ = P(Z < - 1.9007) \equiv 1 - \Phi(1.901) $$;$$ = 1 - 0.9714 = 0.0286 = 0.029(3dp)$$

For a uniform (rectangular) distribution with $$ l - 0.03 \leq x \leq l + 0.03$$,;$$\begin{align} ;&f(x) &= 1/0.06, &l - 0.03 \leq x \leq l+0.03\\;& &=0, & otherwise\\; \end{align}$$;;Let $$\mu$$=E(X);Let $$\sigma^2$$=Var(X);Deduce that f(x) is symmetrical about $$x = l$$ ;$$\mu = E ( X ) = l $$;$$\begin{align}  ;{\sigma^2 = \int}^\infty_{- \infty}(x- \mu)^2. f(x)dx ;\\ {\equiv \int}^{l + 0.03}_{l-0.03}(x-l)^2.(1/0.06) dx ;\\ = {\left[ \frac{1}{3}(x-l)^3(1/0.06) \right]}^{l + 0.03}_{l-0.03};\\ = ( 1 / 0.18 ) [ ( 0.03 )^3 - ( - 0.03 )^3 ] ;\\ = 0.0003;\end{align}$$;;$$T = \sum^{50}_{r = 1} X$$;$$E ( T ) = E ( \sum^{50}_{r = 1} X ) = 50E ( X ) = 50l $$;$$Var ( T ) = Var ( \sum^{50}_{r = 1} X ) = 50Var ( X )$$;$$= 50 ( 0.0003 ) = 0.015$$;Since sample size (=50) is large, Central Limit Theorem;T ~ N(50l,0.015) approximately;;Deduce that 5 observations of T is equal to (5 x 50 =) 250 observations of X;Let n = sample size = 250;$$\begin{align} \hat{l} \equiv \hat{\mu} = \overline{x} = \frac{\Sigma t}{n} = \frac{499.53}{250} = 1.99812\end{align}$$;Let $$l_0$$ = assumed $$l$$ (or $$\mu$$) =2;Test $$H_0: l = l_0$$ against $$H_1: l < l_0$$ a 1-tailed test for less;The 1% critical value, $$z_{0.01} = 2.326$$;Reject $$H_0$$ if $$z < -z_{0.01}$$;Under $$H_0$$, the test statistic is ;$$\begin{align} z = \frac{\overline{x} - l_0}{\sigma / \sqrt{n}} = \frac{1.99812 - 2}{\sqrt{0.0003 / 250}} = - 1.7162 \end{align}$$;Since $$z > -z_{0.01}$$, do not reject $$H_0$$ and conclude that, at the 1% level of significance, there is insufficient evidence that $$l$$<2.

Let D =  red ball taken;Let H = white ball taken;$$\begin{align}  ;P(R=0) = P(HHH);\\ = \left(\frac{n}{n+3}\right)\left(\frac{n-1}{n+2}\right)\left(\frac{n-2}{n+1}\right);\\ = \frac{n(n-1)(n-2)}{(n+3)(n+2)(n+1)};\end{align}$$;;$$\begin{align}  ;P(R=1) = P(DHH) + P(HDH) + P(HHD);\\ = \left(\frac{3}{n+3}\right)\left(\frac{n}{n+2}\right)\left(\frac{n-1}{n+1}\right) + \left(\frac{n}{n+2}\right)\left(\frac{3}{n+3}\right)\left(\frac{n-1}{n+1}\right) + \left(\frac{n}{n+2}\right)\left(\frac{n-1}{n+1}\right)\left(\frac{3}{n+3}\right);\\ = \frac{9n(n-1)}{(n+3)(n+2)(n+1)};\end{align}$$;;$$\begin{align}  ;P(R=2) = P(DDH) + P(DHD) + P(HDD);\\ = \left(\frac{3}{n+3}\right)\left(\frac{2}{n+2}\right)\left(\frac{n}{n+1}\right) + \left(\frac{3}{n+3}\right)\left(\frac{n}{n+1}\right)\left(\frac{2}{n+2}\right) + \left(\frac{n}{n+1}\right)\left(\frac{3}{n+3}\right)\left(\frac{2}{n+2}\right);\\ = \frac{18n(n-1)}{(n+3)(n+2)(n+1)};\end{align}$$;;$$\begin{align}  ;P(R=3) = P(DDD);\\ = \left(\frac{3}{n+3}\right)\left(\frac{2}{n+2}\right)\left(\frac{1}{n+1}\right);\\ = \frac{6(n-1)(n-2)}{(n+3)(n+2)(n+1)};\end{align}$$;;$$\therefore$$ The p.d.f. of R is:;img ;;$$\begin{align}  ;E(R) = \sum r . P(R=r) ;\\ = (0) + (1)\frac{9n(n-1)}{(n+3)(n+2)(n+1)} + (2)\frac{18n(n-1)}{(n+3)(n+2)(n+1)} + (3)\frac{6(n-1)(n-2)}{(n+3)(n+2)(n+1)}  ;\\ = \frac{(9n^2-9n)+(36n)+(18)}{(n+3)(n+2)(n+1)} ;\\ = \frac{9(n^2 +3n + 2)}{(n+3)(n+2)(n+1)} ;\\ = \frac{9(n+2)(n+1)}{(n+3)(n+2)(n+1)} ;\\ = \frac{9}{(n+3)} \end{align}$$;;$$\begin{align}  ;E(R^2) = \sum r^2 . P(R=r) ;\\ = (0) + (1^2)\frac{9n(n-1)}{(n+3)(n+2)(n+1)} + (2^2)\frac{18n(n-1)}{(n+3)(n+2)(n+1)} + (3^2)\frac{6(n-1)(n-2)}{(n+3)(n+2)(n+1)}  ;\\ = \frac{(9n^2-9n)+(72n)+(54)}{(n+3)(n+2)(n+1)} ;\\ = \frac{9(n^2 +7n + 6)}{(n+3)(n+2)(n+1)} ;\\ = \frac{9(n+6)(n+1)}{(n+3)(n+2)(n+1)} ;\\ = \frac{9(n+6)}{(n+3)(n+2)} \end{align}$$;;$$\begin{align}  ;Var(R) = E(R^2) - E(R)^2;\\ = \frac{9(n+6)}{(n+3)(n+2)} - \frac{9^2}{(n+3)^2};\\ = 9 \frac{(n+6)(n+3) - 9(n+2)}{(n+3)^2(n+2)};\\ = 9 \frac{n^2+9n+18-9n-18}{(n+3)^2(n+2)};\\ = \frac{9n^2}{(n+3)^2(n+2)} \end{align}$$;;$$\begin{align}  ;E(W) = E(3-R) \equiv 3 - E(R) ;\\ = 3 - \frac{9}{n+3} ;\\ = \frac{3(n+3) -9}{n+3};\\ = \frac{3n}{n+3} \end{align}$$;;$$\begin{align}  ;Var(W) = Var(3-R) \equiv Var(R) ;\\ = \frac{9n^2}{(n+3)^2(n+2)} \end{align}$$

A symmetric 90% cofidence interval is o.6567 < p < 0.8100;$$ \Rightarrow p_s$$ = (0.6567 + 0.8100)/2 = 0.73335 and $$q_s$$ = 1 - $$p_s$$ = 0.26665;$$\begin{align} \Rightarrow p_s + z_{0.05} \sqrt{\frac{p_s q_s}{n}} = 0.8100 \end{align}$$;$$\begin{align}  ;i.e. 0.73335 + 1.645\sqrt{\frac{(0.73335)(0.26665)}{n}} = 0.8100;\\ \therefore n = \frac{(1.645)^2(0.73335)(0.26665)}{(0.8100-0.73335)^2} = 90.07 = 90;\end{align}$$;;Let $$p_0$$ = assumed value of $$p=\frac{2}{3}$$;Test $$ H_0 p=p_0 $$ against $$p > p_0$$ a 1-tailed test for greater value;The 10% critical value, $$z_{0.10} = 1.282$$;Reject $$ H_0 $$if $$ z > z_{0.10}$$;Under $$H_0$$, the test statistic is ;$$\begin{align} z = \frac{p_s-p_0}{\sqrt{p_0 q_0/n}} = \frac{0.73335 - 0.66667}{\sqrt{(0.73335)(0.26665)/90}} = 1.342 \end{align}$$;Since $$z > z_{0.10}$$, reject $$H_0$$ and conclude that, at the 10% level of significance, there is sufficient evidence that the probability p of a dropped drawing pin landing 'point-up' is greater than $$\frac{2}{3}$$;;To take p = 0.7( and q = 1- p = 0.3);No. of 'point-ups' obtained in $$1^{st}$$ trial = $$n p_s$$ = (90)(0.73335) = 66;Let X = no. of 'point-ups' obtained in $$2^{nd}$$ trial ;$$X\sim B(n,p)$$;Since n(=90) is larege, ;$$X \sim N(np, npq)$$approximately;$$ P(X = 66)$$;$$ = P(65.5 < X < 66.5) \leftarrow$$ continuity correction;$$\begin{align} ;\equiv P\left(\frac{65.5 - np}{\sqrt{npq}} < Z < \frac{66.5 - (90)(0.7)}{\sqrt{(70)(0.7)(0.3)}}\right);\\ = P(0.57505 < Z < 0.80508);\\ \equiv \Phi (0.805) - \Phi(0.575);\\ = 0.7896 - 0.7174;\\ = 0.0722 = 0.072 (3dp); \end{align}$$

Let $$ a = 1^{st} $$ term of G.P.;Let $$ r = $$ common ratio of G.P.;;$$\begin{align}  ;S_n = 6 - \frac{2}{3^{n-1}};\\ \Rightarrow \frac{a(1-r^n)}{1-r} = 6 - \frac{2}{3^{n-1}};\\ = 6\left[1- \left(\frac{1}{3}\right)^n\right];\\ = \frac{4\left[1- \left(\frac{1}{3}\right)^n\right]}{1-\frac{1}{3}};\end{align}$$;;$$ \therefore a=4 $$ and $$ r = \frac{1}{3} $$

Let $$a$$ = length of sides of a ABCD;Let P = foot of perpendicular from M to (horizontal surface of table;;Sketch diagram:;img;;Inclination of AM to the horizontal is given by $$ \angle $$ MAP;$$ \Delta $$ ABM:;AM$$^2$$ = AB$$^2$$ + BM$$^2$$ = $$a^2 + (\frac{1}{2}a)^2 = \frac{5}{4}a^2$$;$$ \Rightarrow  $$AM = $$ \frac{\sqrt{5}}{2} a$$;$$ \Delta $$BMP:;MP = BM $$ \sin{\angle} $$MBP = $$ \frac{1}{2}a\sin{52^{\circ}} = 0.394a$$;;$$ \Delta $$AMP:;$$ \angle $$MAP = $$ \sin^{-1}{} $$(MP/AM);$$ =  \sin^{-1}{\left[(0.394a)/\left(\frac{\sqrt{5}}{2}a\right)\right]}$$;= 20.63 = 20.6$$^{\circ}(1dp)$$

$$\begin{align}  ;& f: x \mapsto 5x + 3, & x >0\\;& g: x \mapsto \frac{3}{x}, & x>0.;\end{align}$$;;$$\begin{align} ;fg(x) = f\left(\frac{3}{x}\right) + 5\left(\frac{3}{x}\right) + 3= \frac{15}{x}+3;\\ \therefore fg: x\mapsto\frac{15}{x} + 3, x > 0;\end{align}$$;;$$\begin{align} ;g^2(x) = g\left(\frac{3}{x}\right) = \frac{3}{(3/x)} = x;\\ \therefore g^2: x \mapsto x, x>0;\end{align}$$;;$$\begin{align} g^3(x) = g(g^2(x)) = g(x) = \frac{3}{x} \end{align}$$;Deduce that $$ g^{2n+1}(x) \equiv g(x).$$ for $$ n \in \mathbb{Z} $$;$$\begin{align}  ;\therefore g^{35}(x) \equiv g(x) = \frac{3}{x};\\ \therefore g^{35}: x \mapsto \frac{3}{x};\end{align}$$;;$$ 25x + 18 = 5(5x + 3) + 3 = f(5x+3) = ff(x) $$;$$ \therefore h = f^2 $$

Possible combinations are:;Case 1: None of 3 identical balls selected ;No. of ways to choose 2 of 5 balls = $$ ^{5}\textrm{C}_{3} $$ = 10;;Case 2: 1 of 3 identical balls selected;No. of ways to select remaining 2 of 5 balls = $$ ^{5}\textrm{C}_{2} $$ = 10;;Case 3: 2 of 3 identical balls selected;No. of ways to select remaining 1 of 5 balls = $$ ^{5}\textrm{C}_{1} $$ = 5;;Case 4: All 3 identical balls selected;No. of ways = 1;;$$ \therefore $$ Total no. of different ways to selcet 3 of 8 balls, with 3 balls identical; = 10 + 10 + 5 + 1 = 26

(i) ;Let L denotes $$ |z + 4 - 4i| = 3 \equiv |z-(-4+4i)| = 3 $$;$$ \equiv $$ circle centred at C(-4,4), radius 3;img;;(ii);$$ |z-i| \equiv $$ distance of $$ z $$ from D(0,1);Deduce that least possible value of $$ |z-i|$$ is on the line extended from radius of L to D.;Least possible value of $$ |z-i|$$;= CD - (radius of L);= $$ \sqrt{3^2+4^2} - 3 = 2$$ units

Assume that $$ z^4 - 2z^3 + 6z^2 - 8z + 8 = 0 $$ has a root of the form $$ ki $$;$$\begin{align}  ;\Rightarrow (ki)^4 - 2(ki)^3 + 6(ki)^2 - 8(ki) + 8 = 0;\\ (ki)^4 - 2k^3i + 6k^2 - 8ki + 8 = 0;\\ (k^4 - 6k^2 + 8) + (2k^2-8)ki = 0;\end{align}$$;;Equating Im parts:;$$ (2k^2 -8)k = 0 \Rightarrow k =0 (NA) or K = \pm 2$$ ;Equating Re parts:;$$ k^4 - 6k^2 + 8 = 0 $$;Subst $$ k = \pm 2$$ into eqn:;LHS = $$(\pm 2)^4 - 6(\pm 2)^2 + 8 = 0$$ = LHS;$$ \therefore z^4-2z^3+6z^2-8z+8=0 $$ has roots $$\pm2i$$;;$$\pm2i$$ are roots;$$ \Rightarrow (z-2i)(z+2i) = (z^2 + 4) $$ is a factor;By long division:;$$ z^4 - 2z^3 + 6z^2 - 8z + 8 = 0$$;$$ \equiv (z^2+4)(z^2 - 2z + 2) =0 $$;$$  z^2 -2z +2 =0$$;$$ \Rightarrow z = \frac{-(-2)\pm\sqrt{(-2)^2-4(1)(2)}}{2(1)} = 1\pm i$$;$$ \therefore z^4-2z^3+6z^2-8z + 8 =0 $$;$$ \Rightarrow$$ z = i, -i, 1+i or 1-i

Let h = depth of liquid;Let r = radius of liquid surface;Let V = volume of liquid;;$$ \frac{dV}{dt} = 2 cm^3s^-1$$;r = h $$ \tan^{-1}{45^{\circ}} $$ = h;;$$\begin{align}  ;\Rightarrow V = \frac{1}{3}\pi r^2 h = \frac{1}{3}\pi h^3 \Rightarrow h = \left(\frac{3V}{\pi}\right)^{\frac{1}{3}};\\ \Rightarrow \frac{dh}{dt} = \frac{d}{dV} \left(\frac{3V}{\pi}\right)^{\frac{1}{3}} x \frac{dV}{dt} = \frac{1}{\pi}\left(\frac{3V}{\pi}\right)^{-\frac{2}{3}}\frac{dV}{dt};\end{align}$$;;After 3 minutes, volume of remaining liquid, V = (initial volume) - (3min x run out rate) = 390 - 3 x 60 x 2 = 30 $$cm^3$$;$$ \therefore $$ Rate at which depth is decreasing,;$$\begin{align}  ;\frac{dh}{dt} = \frac{1}{\pi}\left(\frac{3V}{\pi}\right)^{-\frac{2}{3}}\frac{dV}{dt} = \frac{1}{\pi}\left(\frac{3(30)}{\pi}\right)^{-\frac{2}{3}}(2);\\ = 0.067996 = 0.0680 cms^{-1} (3sf) \end{align}$$

$$\begin{align}  ;3x^2 + xy + y^2 = 33;\\ \Rightarrow \frac{d}{dx} [3x^2 + xy + y^2\ = \frac{d}{dx}[33];\\ 6x + y + x \frac{dy}{dx} + 2y\frac{dy}{dx} = 0;\\ \frac{dy}{dx}(x+2y) = -(6x+y);\\ \therefore \frac{dy}{dx} = -\frac{6x + y}{x+2y} \end{align}$$;;At points where tangent is parallel to x-axis,;$$\begin{align} \frac{dy}{dx} = 0 \end{align}$$, i.e. $$\begin{align} -\frac{6x+y}{x+2y} = 0 \Rightarrow y = -6x \end{align}$$;At $$ y =-6x $$,;$$\begin{align} 3x^2 + x(-6x) +(-6x)^2 = 33 ;\\ 3x^2 - 6x^2 + 36x^2 = 33 ;\\ x^2 = 1;\Rightarrow x \pm 1 \Rightarrow y=-6(\pm1) = \mp 6\end{align}$$;$$ \therefore $$ Coordinates of the points are (1, -6) and (-1,6).

(i);$$\begin{align}  ;\frac{d}{d\theta}[\sec\theta] ;\\ \equiv \frac{d}{d\theta}\left[\frac{1}{\cos\theta}\right] ;\\ = \frac{-(-\sin\theta)}{\cos^{2}{\theta}};\\ = \frac{1}{\cos{\theta}}\frac{\sin\theta}{\cos\theta} ;\\ \equiv \sec\theta \tan\theta \end{align}$$;;(ii) With $$ x = \sec\theta -1, $$ dx = $$ \sec\theta \tan\theta d\theta$$;At $$ x = \sqrt{2} - 1, \theta = \frac{1}{4} \pi; $$ at $$ x = 1, \theta = \frac{1}{3}\pi $$;$$\begin{align} (x+1)\sqrt{x^2 + 2x} ;\\ \equiv (\sec\theta -1 +1)\sqrt{(\sec\theta-1)^2 + 2(\sec\theta-1)};\\ = \sec\theta \sqrt{\sec^{2}\theta - 2\sec\theta +1 +2\sec\theta - 2};\\ = \sec\theta \sqrt{\sec^{2}\theta - 1} ;\\ = \sec\theta \sqrt{\tan^2\theta} ;\\ \therefore \int^{1}_{\sqrt{2}-1} \frac{1}{(x+1)\sqrt{x^2+2x}}dx;\\ = \int^{\frac{1}{3}\pi}_{\frac{1}{4}\pi} \frac{1}{\sec\theta\tan\theta}\sec\theta\tan\theta d\theta;\\ = \int^{\frac{1}{3}\pi}_{\frac{1}{4}\pi} d\theta;\\ = [\theta]^{\frac{1}{3}\pi}_{\frac{1}{4}\pi};\\ = \frac{1}{3}\pi - \frac{1}{4}\pi = \frac{1}{12}\pi \end{align}$$

$$\begin{align} \sin {3\theta} = \sin{(2\theta+\theta)};\\ = \sin{2\theta}\cos{\theta} + \cos{2\theta}\sin{\theta} ;\\ = (2\sin{\theta}\cos{\theta})\cos{\theta} + (1-2\sin^{2}{\theta})\sin{\theta};\\ = 2\sin{\theta}\cos^{2}{\theta} + (1-2\sin^{2}{\theta})\sin{\theta};\\ = 2\sin{\theta}(1-\sin^{2}{\theta})+\sin{\theta}-2\sin^{3}{\theta};\\ = 2\sin{\theta} - 2\sin^{3}{\theta} + \sin{\theta} - 2\sin^{3}{\theta};\\ = 3\sin{\theta} - 4 \sin^{3}{\theta} \end{align}$$;;(i);$$\begin{align} 8\sin^{3}{\theta} - 6\sin{\theta} = 1.5;\\ \equiv -2(3\sin{\theta}-4\sin^{3}{\theta}) = 1.5;\\ \equiv -2 \sin{3\theta} = 1.5 ;\\ \sin{3\theta} = -\frac{3}{4};\\ 3\theta = n\pi + (-1)^n (-0.8481), n \in \mathbb{Z};\\ \therefore \theta = \frac{1}{3}n\pi + (-1)^n (-0.2827);\\ = \frac{1}{3}n\pi + (-1)^n (-0.283) rad (3sf)\end{align}$$;;(ii);$$\begin{align} \sin{3\theta} = 3\sin{\theta} - 4\sin^{3}{\theta};\\ \Rightarrow \sin^{3}{\theta} = \frac{3}{4}\sin{\theta}-\frac{1}{4}\sin{3\theta};\\ \therefore \int^{\frac{1}{3}\pi}_{0} \sin^{3}{\theta} d\theta;\\ \equiv \int^{\frac{1}{3}\pi}_{0} \left(\frac{3}{4}\sin{\theta} - \frac{1}{4}\sin{3\theta}\right) d\theta;\\ = \left[-\frac{3}{4}\cos{\theta} + \frac{1}{12} \cos{3\theta}\right]^{\frac{1}{3}\pi}_{0};\\ = \left[-\frac{3}{4}\cos{\frac{1}{3}\pi} + \frac{1}{12} \cos{\pi}\right]-\left[-\frac{3}{4}\cos{0} + \frac{1}{12} \cos{0}\right];\\ = -\frac{3}{4}\left(\frac{1}{2}\right) + \frac{1}{12}(-1) + \frac{3}{4}(1) - \frac{1}{12}(1);\\ = \frac{3}{8} - \frac{2}{12} = \frac{5}{24} \end{align}$$

Let $$\begin{align} f(x) = \frac{1+x-2x^2}{(2-x)(1+x^2)} \equiv \frac{A}{2-x} + \frac{Bx+C}{1+x^2} \end{align}$$;;Clearing the fractions:;$$\begin{align} 1+x-2x^2;\\ \equiv A(1+x^2) + (Bx + c)(2-x);\\= (A - B)x^2 +(2B-C)x + (A + 2C) \end{align}$$;;Cover-up rule:;$$\begin{align} x = 2: A = \frac{1+(2)-2(2)^2}{1+(2)^2} = -1 \end{align}$$;;Comparing coefficients:;$$\begin{align} x^2: -2 = A-B;\\ \Rightarrow -2 =(-1)-B \Rightarrow B = 1;\\ x^1: 1 = 2B-C ;\\ \Rightarrow 1 = 2(1) -C \Rightarrow C = 1 ;\\ \therefore f(x) = -\frac{1}{2-x} + \frac{x+1}{1+x^2} \end{align}$$;;$$\begin{align}  f(x) \equiv -\frac{1}{2} \left(1-\frac{1}{2}x\right)^{-1} + (1+x)(1+x^2)^{-1};\\ = -\frac{1}{2} \left[1+(-1)\left(-\frac{1}{2}x\right) + \frac{(-1)(-2)}{2!}\left(-\frac{1}{2}x\right)^2 +...\right]+(1+x)\left[1+(-1)(x^2)+...\right];\\ = \left[-\frac{1}{2} - \frac{1}{4}x -\frac{1}{8}x^2+...\right] + (1+x)[1-x^2+...];\\ = \left[-\frac{1}{2} - \frac{1}{4}x -\frac{1}{8}x^2+...\right] + [1+x-x^2+...];\\ = \frac{1}{2} + \frac{3}{4}x - \frac{9}{8}x^2\end{align}$$;;The expansion is valid for;$$ \left| \frac{1}{2}x \right| < 1$$ and $$ \left| x^2 \right| < 1 $$;$$ \equiv$$ | x | < 1 or -1< x <1

(i);$$\begin{align} (1-x)\frac{dy}{dx} - xy - 1 = 0, |x| < 1 ;\\ = \frac{dy}{dx} - \frac{x}{1-x^2}y = \frac{1}{1-x^2}\end{align}$$;;Let $$ h(x) = \int\frac{-x}{1-x^2}dx$$;$$= \frac{1}{2} \ln {|1-x^2|}$$;$$= \ln{\sqrt{1-x^2}}  $$ (for | x | <  1);$$ \Rightarrow $$ integrating factor,;$$ e^{h(x)} = e^{\ln{\sqrt{1-x^2}}} = \sqrt{1=x^2}$$ and;$$ e^{-h(x)} =  e^{-\ln{\sqrt{1-x^2}}} = \frac{1}{\sqrt{1=x^2}}$$;$$ \therefore $$ General Solution is;$$\begin{align} y = e^{-h(x)}\left[\int e^{h(x)} \frac{1}{1-x^2} dx\right] ;\\ = \frac{1}{\sqrt{1-x^2}}\left[\int\sqrt{1-x^2}\frac{1}{1-x^2} dx \right] ;\\ = \frac{1}{\sqrt{1-x^2}}\left[\int\sqrt{1-x^2}dx \right] ;\\ = \frac{\sin^{-1}{x} + c}{\sqrt{1-x^2}} \end{align}$$;;(ii) $$ y = \frac{1}{2}\pi $$ when x = 0;$$\begin{align} \Rightarrow \frac{1}{2}\pi = \frac{\sin^{-1}{0}+c}{\sqrt{1-(0)^2}} \Rightarrow c = \frac{1}{2}\pi \end{align}$$;When $$ x = \frac{1}{2} $$;$$\begin{align} y = \frac{\sin^{-1}{\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)} + \frac{1}{2}\pi}{\sqrt{1-\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^2}};\\= \frac{\frac{1}{6}\pi+ \frac{1}{2}\pi}{\sqrt{1-\frac{1}{4}}} ;\\ = \frac{4}{3\sqrt{3}}\pi\end{align}$$;;(iii) For | x | > 1,;$$\begin{align} h(x) = \frac{1}{2}\ln{|1 - x^2| \equiv \sqrt{x^2-1}};\\ \Rightarrow y = e^{-h(x)} \left[\int e^{h(x)} \frac{1}{1-x^2} dx \right] ;\\ = \frac{1}{\sqrt{x^2-1}}\left[\int \sqrt{x^2-1}\frac{1}{1-x^2} dx\right];\\ = \frac{1}{\sqrt{x^2-1}}\left[- \int \sqrt{x^2-1}\frac{1}{x^2-1} dx\right] ;\\ \therefore y\sqrt{x^2-1} = - \int \frac{1}{\sqrt{x^2-1}} dx \end{align}$$

(i) ;Gradient of QR, ;$$\begin{align}  m_{QR} = \frac{y_R - y_Q}{x_R - X_Q} = \frac{\frac{c}{r} - \frac{c}{q}}{cr-cq};\\ = \frac{q-r}{qr(r-q)};\\ = -\frac{1}{qr} \end{align}$$;;(ii) Deduce from part(i) that  gradient of PV, $$ m_{PV} = - \frac{1}{pv}$$;PV is perpendicular to QR $$ \Rightarrow m_{PV} = - \frac{1}{m_{QR}} = qr $$;i.e. $$\begin{align} -\frac{1}{pv} = qr \Rightarrow v = -\frac{1}{prq} \end{align}$$;;(iii);$$\begin{align} \frac{dy}{dx} = \frac{dy}{dt} / \frac{dx}{dt} ;\\ = \frac{d}{dt}\left[\frac{c}{t}\right] / \frac{d}{dt}[ct];\\ = - \frac{c}{t^2}/c = -\frac{1}{t^2}\end{align}$$;Gradient of normal, $$ m' = -1/\frac{dy}{dx} = t^2$$;Gradient of normal at $$ P(t=p), m_P' = p^2$$;;(iv) ;Normal at P meets curve at $$ S(t=s) \Rightarrow $$ gradient of PS, $$ m_{PS} = m_{P}' = p^2$$;Deduce from part(i) that $$ m_{PS} = - \frac{1}{ps}$$;i.e. $$\begin{align} - \frac{1}{ps} = p^2 \Rightarrow s = -\frac{1}{p^3} \end{align}$$;;(v) $$ \angle$$QPR is 90$$^{\circ}$$;i.e. PQ is perpendicular to PR ;$$\Rightarrow$$ gradient of PQ, $$ m_{PQ} = -1/(m_{PR}) = -1/(-\frac{1}{pr}) = pr $$;Deduce from par (i) that $$ m_{PQ} = - \frac{1}{pq}$$;i.e. $$\begin{align} -\frac{1}{pq} = pr \Rightarrow -\frac{1}{qr} = p^2 \equiv m_{QR} = m_P'\end{align}$$;i.e. gradient of QR = gradient of normal at P.;$$\therefore$$ QR is parallel to the normal at P.

AP: PB = $$ \lambda : 1 - \lambda$$;$$\begin{align} ;\Rightarrow \overrightarrow{OP} = (1-\lambda)\overrightarrow{OA} + \lambda\overrightarrow{OB} ;\\ = (1-\lambda)(i -2j + 5k) + \lambda(i+3j);\\ = i -\lambda i - 2j + 2\lambda j + 5(1-\lambda)k +\lambda i +3\lambda j ;\\ = i+(5\lambda -2)j+5(1-\lambda)k \end{align}$$;;CQ: QD = $$ \mu : 1 - \mu$$;$$\begin{align} ;\Rightarrow \overrightarrow{OQ} = (1-\mu)\overrightarrow{OC} + \mu \overrightarrow{OD} ;\\ = (1-\mu)(10i + j + 2k) + \mu(-2i+4j+5k);\\ = 10i - 10\mu i + j - \mu j +2k - 2\mu k -2\mu i +4 \mu j + 5\mu k;\\ = (10-12\mu)i+(1+3\mu)j+(2+3\mu)k \end{align}$$;;(i) ;$$ \overrightarrow{AB} = \overrightarrow{OB} - \overrightarrow{OA} $$;$$ = (i+3j) - (i-2j+5k) $$;$$ = 5j-5k $$;;$$ \overrightarrow{CD} = \overrightarrow{OD} - \overrightarrow{OC} $$;$$ = (-2i +4j +5k) - (10i +j +2k) $$;$$ = -12i + 3j + 3k $$;;$$ \overrightarrow{PQ} = \overrightarrow{OQ} - \overrightarrow{OP} $$;$$ = (10-12\mu)i + (1+3\mu)j + (2+3\mu)k - [i+(5\lambda -2)j +5(1-\lambda)k] $$;$$ = (9-12\mu)i+(3+3\mu-5\lambda)j +(3\mu+5\lambda-3)k $$;;PQ is perpendicular to AB;$$ \Rightarrow \overrightarrow{PQ} . \overrightarrow{AB} = 0 $$;i.e. $$ (9-12\mu)i+(3+3\mu-5\lambda)j +(3\mu+5\lambda-3)k . (5j-5k)=0 $$;$$ (9-12\mu)(0)+(3+3\mu-5\lambda)(5) +(3\mu+5\lambda-3)(-5) =0 $$;$$ \Rightarrow \lambda = \frac{3}{5} $$;$$ \therefore \overrightarrow{PQ} = (9-12\mu)i+(3+3\mu-5(\frac{3}{5})j +(3\mu+5(\frac{3}{5})-3)k$$;$$ = (9-12\mu)i + 3\mu j + 3\mu k $$;PQ is perpendicular to CD;$$ \Rightarrow  \overrightarrow{PQ} . \overrightarrow{CD} = 0  $$;i.e. $$ [(9-12\mu)i + 3\mu j + 3\mu k].(-12i+3j+3k) = 0 $$;$$(9-12\mu)(-12) + 3\mu(3) + 3\mu(3) = 0  $$;$$ \Rightarrow \mu = \frac{2}{3} $$;$$ \therefore \overrightarrow{PQ} = (9-12(\frac{2}{3}))i + 3(\frac{2}{3} )j + 3(\frac{2}{3} )k $$;$$= i+2j+2k $$;;(ii) PQ is perpendicular to AB;img;$$ \Rightarrow $$ area of $$ \Delta $$ ABQ;$$\begin{align} = \frac{1}{2} |\overrightarrow{AB}| |\overrightarrow{PQ}| ;\\ = \frac{1}{2} |5j-5k| |i+2j+2k|;\\ = \frac{1}{2} \sqrt{5^2+(-5)^2}\sqrt{1^2+2^2+2^2};\\ = \frac{15}{\sqrt{2}} units^2\end{align}$$

$$\begin{align}  \frac{x-9}{x^2-9} \leq 1;\\ \Rightarrow \frac{x-9}{x^2-9} -1 \leq 0;\\ \frac{(x-9)-(x^2-9)}{x^2-9} \leq 0;\\ \frac{x-x^2}{x^2-9} \leq 0;\\ \frac{x(1-x)}{(x-3)(x+3)} \leq 0, [x\neq\pm3]] \end{align}$$;;Critical values are -3, 0, 1, 3;Let $$ f(x) = \frac{x(1-x)}{(x-3)(x+3)} $$;;$$\begin{align}  ;& Range & Test Value & Sign of f(x) \\;& x < -3 & -4 & - \\;& -3 < x \leq 0 & -1 & + \\;& 0 \leq x \leq 1 & \frac{1}{2} & - \\ ;& 1\leq x \leq 3 & 2 & + \\;& x > 3 & 4 & - \\ ;\end{align}$$;;$$ \therefore $$ Solution is x < -3, 0 $$ \leq $$ x $$ \leq $$1, x > 3

Let x = $$ log_b a $$;$$\begin{align}  \Rightarrow b^x = a;\\ log_a b^x = log_a a = 1;\\ x.log_a b = 1 ;\\ \therefore x(=log_b a) = \frac{1}{log_a b}\end{align}$$;;$$\begin{align}  2log_9 x + 1 = 2log_x 3 = log_x 3^2 = log_x 9 = \frac{1}{log_9 x};\\ \Rightarrow 2(log_9x)^2 + (log_9 x) - 1 = 0;\\ \Rightarrow (log_9 x) = \frac{-(1)\pm\sqrt{(1)^2-4(2)(-1)}}{2(2)};\\ = \frac{1}{2} or -1(NA);\\ \therefore x = 9^\frac{1}{2} = 3 \end{align}$$

(i) Using the cosine formula, ;$$\begin{align} \Delta ABC: \cos{\angle ABC} = \frac{a^2+b^2-x^2}{2ab};\\ \Delta ADC: \cos{\angle ADC} = \frac{c^2+d^2-x^2}{2cd} ;\\ \angle ABC + \angle adc = 180^{\circ};\\ \Rightarrow \cos{\angle ABC} = \cos{(180^{\circ} - \angle ADC)};\\ = - cos{\angle ADC};\\ \frac{a^2+b^2-x^2}{2ab} = - \frac{c^2+d^2-x^2}{2cd} ;\\ a^2cd+b^2cd-cdx^2 = -abc^2-abd^2+abx^2;\\ \therefore (ab+cd)x^2 = a^2cd+abc^2+abd^2+b^2cd;\\ = ac(ad+bc) + bd(ad+bc);\\ = (ac+bd)(ad+bc) \end{align}$$;;(ii) BD = y:;img;$$\begin{align} \Delta ABD: \cos{\angle BAD} = \frac{a^2+d^2-y^2}{2ad} ;\\ \Delta BCD: \cos{\angle BCD} = \frac{b^2+c^2-y^2}{2bc} ;\\ \angle ABC + \angle ADC = 180^{\circ};\\ \Rightarrow \cos{\angle BAD} + \cos{\angle BCD} = 180^{\circ};\\ \Rightarrow \cos{\angle BAD} = \cos{(180^{\circ} - \angle BCD)} ;\\ = -\cos{\angle BCD};\\ \Rightarrow \frac{a^2+d^2-y^2}{2ad} = -\frac{b^2+c^2-y^2}{2bc} ;\\ (a^2+d^2-y^2)(bc) = - (b^2+c^2-y^2)(ad);\\ a^2bc -bcd^2-bcy^2 = -ab^2d -ac^2d + ady^2;\\ \therefore (ad+bc)y^2 = a^2bc + ab^2d+ac^2d+bcd^2 ;\\ = ab(ac+bd) + cd(ac+bd);\\ = (ab+cd)(ac+bd) ;\\ \Rightarrow y^2 = \frac{(ab+cd)(ac+bd)}{(ad+bc)}\end{align}$$;From part(i), $$\begin{align} x^2 = \frac{(ac+bd)(ad+bc)}{(ab+cd)} \end{align}$$;i.e.;$$\begin{align} x^2y^2 = \frac{(ac+bd)(ad+bc)}{(ab+cd)} \frac{(ab+cd)(ac+bd)}{(ad+bc)};\\ = (ac+bd)^2 \end{align}$$;$$ \therefore xy = ac+bd  $$

Let n = no. of electors in sample = 800;Let p = percentage of electorate that support George Berry as Presidential candidate;;$$\begin{align}  ;\hat{p} = \frac{417}{800} ;\\ \hat{q} = 1 - \hat{p} = \frac{383}{800};\\ z_{0.005} \sqrt{\frac{\hat{p} \hat{q}}{n}} = 2.576\sqrt{\frac{\left( \frac{417}{800} \right) \left( \frac{383}{800} \right)}{800}} = 0.045497;\end{align}$$;;The 99% confidence interval for p is;$$\begin{align}  ;[ \hat{p} - z_{0.005} \sqrt{\frac{\hat{p} \hat{q}}{n}} , \hat{p} + z_{0.005} \sqrt{\frac{{}\hat{p} \hat{q}}{n}} ] ;\\ = \left[ \frac{417}{800}- 0.045497, \frac{417}{800} + 0.045497 \right] ;\\ = [ 0.47575 , 0.56675 ] ;\\ = [ 0.476, 0.567 ] (3dp);\end{align}$$;;An assumption that need to be made is that the electors were randomly selected.

Tabulate all possible sums:;  ;img;;Score on the red die is divisible by 3;$$\Rightarrow$$ score on the red die is 3 or 6 (underlined);i.e. $$P(A) = \frac{2}{6} =\frac{1}{3}$$;;4 of 36 sums are equal to 9 (in brackets);i.e. $$P(B) = \frac{4}{36} = \frac{1}{9}$$;;$$P(A)P(B) = \left(\frac{1}{3}\right) \left(\frac{1}{9}\right)=\frac{1}{27}$$;;2 of 36 scores have sums equal to 9 and the score on the red die divisible by 3 (underlined and in brackets);i.e. $$P(A \cap B) = \frac{2}{36} = \frac{1}{18} \ne P(A)P(B)$$;$$\Rightarrow$$ A and B are not independent.;;14 of 36 scores have sums equal to 9 or the score on the red die is divisible by 3 (underlined or in brackets);i.e. $$P(A \cup B) = \frac{14}{36} = \frac{7}{18}$$

Let $$G_i = i^{th}$$ pupil in sample is a girl;Let $$B_i = i^{th}$$ pupil in sample is a boy;;$$\begin{align}  ;P ( X = - 3 ) = P ( B_1 , B_2 , B_3 );\\ = \frac{4}{10}\cdot \frac{3}{9}\cdot \frac{2}{8}= \frac{1}{30};\end{align}$$;;$$\begin{align}  ;\\ P(X = - 1) = P(G_1, B_2, B_3) +P(B_1, G_2, B_3) +(B_1, B_2, G_3) ;\\ = \frac{6}{10} \cdot \frac{4}{9} \cdot \frac{3}{8} +\frac{4}{10} \cdot \frac{6}{9} \cdot \frac{3}{8} +\frac{4}{10} \cdot \frac{3}{9} \cdot \frac{6}{8} ;\\ = \frac{9}{30}= \frac{3}{10};\end{align}$$ ;$$\begin{align}  ;\\ P(X = 1) = P(G_1, G_2, B_3) +P(G_1, B_2, G_3) +(B_1, G_2, G_3) ;\\ = \frac{6}{10} \cdot \frac{5}{9} \cdot \frac{4}{8} +\frac{6}{10} \cdot \frac{4}{9} \cdot \frac{5}{8} +\frac{4}{10} \cdot \frac{6}{9} \cdot \frac{5}{8} ;\\= \frac{15}{30}= \frac{1}{2};\end{align}$$;;$$\begin{align}  ;\\ P(X = 3) = P(G_1, G_2, G_3) ;\\ = \frac{6}{10}\cdot \frac{5}{9}\cdot \frac{4}{8};\\ = \frac{5}{30} = \frac{1}{6};\end{align}$$;;$$ \therefore $$Probability distribution of X is:;   img;;$$\begin{align}  ;E ( \lvert X \lvert ) ;\\ = \sum_{all  x} \lvert x \lvert P ( X = x ) ;\\ = 1 \cdot(\frac{9}{30}+\frac{15}{30}) +3 \cdot(\frac{1}{30}+\frac{5}{30}) ;\\ = 1.4 ;\end{align}$$;;$$\begin{align}  ;\\ E(\lvert X \lvert^2) ;\\ = {\sum_{all  x}\lvert x \lvert}^2 P(X = x) ;\\ = 1^2 \cdot ( \frac{9}{30} +\frac{15}{30} ) +3^2 \cdot ( \frac{1}{30} +\frac{5}{30} ) ;\\ = 2.6 ;\end{align}$$;;$$\begin{align}  ;\\ Var ( \lvert X \lvert ) ;\\ = E ( \lvert X \lvert^2 ) - [ E ( \lvert X \lvert ) ]^2 ;\\ = 2.6 -(1.4)^2 ;\\ = 0.64;\end{align}$$

Let n = no. of bags in sample = 80;Let $$\mu=E(x)$$;Let $$\sigma^2=Var(x)$$;;$$\begin{align}  ;\hat{\mu} = \overline{x} = \frac{\Sigma ( x - c )}{n} +c = \frac{- 2510}{80} +10000 ;\\ = 9968.625 ;\end{align}$$;$$\begin{align} ;\\ \hat{\sigma}^2 = \frac{1}{n - 1}\left[ \Sigma(x - c)^2 - \frac{(\Sigma(x - c))^2}{n}\right] ;\\ = \frac{1}{79} \left( 2010203 - \frac{( - 2510 )^2}{80} \right) ;\\ = 24448.76 (2dp); \end{align}$$;;Let $$\mu_0$$ = required mean = 10 kg = 10000 g;Test $$H_0 : \mu=\mu_0$$ against $$H_1: \mu<\mu_0$$a 1-tailed test for less ;The 5% critical value, $$ z_{0.05} = 1.645 $$;Reject $$H_0$$ if $$ z < -z_{0.05}$$;Under $$H_0$$, the test statistic is ;$$\begin{align}  z = \frac{\overline{x} - \mu_0}{\hat{\sigma} / \sqrt{n}} = \frac{9968.625 - 100000}{\sqrt{24448.76 / 80}} = - 1.794 \end{align}$$;Since $$z < -z_{0.05}$$, reject $$H_0$$ and conclude that, at the 5% level of significance, there is sufficient evidence that the mean mass of the contents of a bag is less than 10 kg.;;The '5%significance level' refers to the probability that, by chance alone, the null hypothesis is rejected incorrectly, i.e. the null hypothesis is rejected although the sample is taken from a population in which the mean mass of the contents of a bag is 10 kg.

Let $$X_i =$$ no. of severe floods in the ith 100 years;Let $$\mu=E(X_i) = 2$$;$$\begin{align}  ;X_i \sim P_0 ( \mu ) ;\\ P(X_1 = 1, X_2 = 1) ;\\ = P ( X_1 = 1 ) \cdot P ( X_2 = 1 ) ;\\ =(e^{- \mu}) \cdot(e^{- \mu}) =(e^{- 2})(e^{- 2}) ;\\ = 0.018316 = 0.0183 (3sf);\end{align}$$;;Let Y = no. of severe floods in 1000 years $$\sum_{r=1}^{10} X_r$$;Let $$\lambda=E(Y) \equiv 10E(X)=10(2)=20$$;$$Y\sim P_o(\lambda)$$;Since $$\lambda(=20)>10$$,;$$Y \sim N(\lambda,\lambda)=N(20,20)$$ approximately;P ( Y > 25 );$$ \equiv P(Y > 25.5) \leftarrow$$ continuity correction;$$ \equiv P ( Z > \frac{25.5 - \lambda}{\sqrt{\lambda}} ) = P ( Z > \frac{25.5 - 20}{\sqrt{20}} ) $$;$$ = P(Z > 1.2298) \equiv 1 - \Phi(1.230) $$;$$ = 1 - 0.8907 $$;$$= 0.1093 = 0.109 (3sf)$$

X~U(0,1) or R(0,1);i.e. X has the density function ;$$\begin{align}  ;& f(x) &= 1 &0 < x < 1  ;\\&  &= 0 &otherwise. ;\end{align}$$;;Let $$\mu = E ( X ) = \frac{1}{2} ( 0 + 1 ) = \frac{1}{2} $$;$$\begin{align} ;Var(X) =   \int^{\infty}_{- \infty}(x- \mu)^2 \cdot f(x) dx ;\\ =   \int^1_0(x- \frac{1}{2})^2 \cdot(1) dx ;\\ = {\left[ \frac{1}{3}\left(x- \frac{1}{2}\right)^3 \right]}^1_0 ;\\ = \frac{1}{3} \left[ \left( \frac{1}{2} \right)^3 - \left( - \frac{1}{2} \right)^3 \right] = \frac{1}{12}; \end{align}$$;;$$Y\sim U(-1,2)$$ and $$Y \equiv 3X - 1$$;$$\begin{align}  \;E ( Y ) \equiv E ( 3X - 1 ) ;\\ = 3E(X) - 1 ;\\ = 3 \left( \frac{1}{2} \right) - 1 = \frac{1}{2} ;\end{align}$$;$$\begin{align};\\ Var ( Y ) \equiv Var ( 3X - 1 ) ;\\ = 3^2 Var(X) +0 ;\\ = 9 \left( \frac{1}{12} \right) = \frac{3}{4};\end{align}$$;;;$$ T = \lambda X + ( 1 - \lambda ) Y $$;$$\begin{align}  ;\\ \Rightarrow E(T) = E [ \lambda X +(1 - \lambda) Y ] ;\\ = \lambda E ( X ) +( 1 - \lambda ) E ( Y ) ;\\ = \lambda\left(\frac{1}{2}\right) + (1 - \lambda)\left(\frac{1}{2}\right) ;\end{align}$$;$$  = \frac{1}{2} \leftarrow$$ independent of $$\lambda$$;;$$\begin{align}  ;Var ( T ) = Var [ \lambda X +( 1 - \lambda ) Y ] ;\\ = \lambda^2 Var  (X) +(1 - \lambda)^2 Var(Y) ;\\ = \frac{1}{12} \lambda^2 +\frac{3}{4} ( 1 - \lambda )^2 ;\\ = \frac{1}{12}[ \lambda^2 +9(1 - 2 \lambda +\lambda^2)]  ;\\ = \frac{1}{12} [ 10 \lambda^2 - 18\lambda +9 ] ;\\ = \frac{10}{12}\left[ \lambda^2 - \frac{18}{10}\lambda +\frac{9}{10}\right] ;\\ = \frac{5}{6} \left[ \left( \lambda - \frac{9}{10} \right)^2 - \left( \frac{9}{10} \right)^2 +\frac{9}{10} \right];\end{align}$$;;Deduce that Var(T) is smallest when ;$$\begin{align} \lambda-\frac{9}{10} = 0,\end{align}$$  $$\begin{align}i.e. \lambda = \frac{9}{10} \end{align}$$

Let X= speed of a car;Let $$\mu=E(X)$$;Let $$\sigma^2=Var(X)$$;;$$\begin{align};X \sim N ( \mu , \sigma^2 ) ;\\ P(X > 125) = 1/80 = 0.0125 ;\\ \equiv P ( Z > \frac{125 - \mu}{\sigma} ) = 0.0125 ;\\ \equiv P\left(Z < \frac{125 - \mu}{\sigma}\right) = 1 - 0.0125 = 0.9875 ;\\ \Phi ( \frac{125 - \mu}{\sigma} ) = 0.9875 ;\\ \frac{125 - \mu}{\sigma}= \Phi^{- 1}(0.9875) = 2.240 ;\\ \mu +2.240\sigma = 125 ----(1); \end{align}$$;;$$\begin{align} ;P ( X < 40 ) = 1 / 10 = 0.1 ;\\ \equiv P(Z < \frac{40 - \mu}{\sigma}) = 0.1 ;\\ \equiv P ( Z < \frac{\mu - 40}{\sigma} ) = 1 - 0.1 = 0.9 ;\\ \Phi(\frac{\mu - 40}{\sigma}) = 0.9 ;\\ \frac{\mu - 40}{\sigma} = \Phi^{- 1} ( 0.9 ) = 1.282 ;\\ \mu - 1.282 \sigma = 40 ----(2); \end{align}$$;;Eqn(1) - (2):;$$ 3.522\sigma = 85$$;$$ \Rightarrow \sigma =24.134 = 24.1 km h^{-1} (3sf)$$;Subst $$\sigma = 24.134$$ into eqn(2):;$$ \mu - 1.282(24.134) = 40 $$;$$ \Rightarrow \mu =70.94 = 70.9 km h^{-1}$$;;(i) Let n = no. of cars in sample = 10;Let p = P(X<40) = 0.1 and q = 1- p = 0.9;Let Y = no. of cars out of n with X < 40;;Y ~ B(n,p);P(at least 7 cars with X > 40);$$\equiv$$ P(at most 3 cars with X < 40);$$=P ( Y \leq 3 ) $$;$$= P(Y = 0) +P(Y = 1) +P(Y = 2) +P(Y = 3) $$;$$= q^n +^n{C_1} p^1 q^{n - 1} +^n{C_2} p^2 q^{n - 2} +^n{C_3} p^3 q^{n - 3} $$;$$=(0.9)^{10}+ ^{10}{C_1}{(0.1)}^1 {(0.9)}^9 + ^{10}{C_2} {( 0.1 )}^2 {( 0.9 )}^8 + ^{10}{C_3} {( 0.1 )}^3 {( 0.9 )}^7 $$;$$ = 0.9872 = 0.987(3sf)$$;;(ii) Let m = no. of cars in $$2^{nd}$$ sample = 100;Let S= no. of cars out of m with X < 40;;S ~ B(m, p);Since m(=100) is large, mp = (100)(0.1) = 10 >5 and mq = (100)(0.9) = 90 >5,;S~N(mp,npq) approximately;P(at most 8 cars with X < 40);= P(S $$\leq$$8);$$\equiv$$ P(S<8.5)$$\leftarrow$$ continuity correction;$$\begin{align} \equiv P\left(Z < \frac{8.5-mp}{\sqrt{mpq}}\right);\\ = P\left(Z < \frac{8.5-100(0.1)}{\sqrt{100(0.1)(0.9)}}\right);\\ = P(Z < -0.5000);\\ = 1 - \Phi(0.5000);\\ = 1 - 0.6915 ;\\ = 0.3085 = 0.309(3sf)\end{align}$$

It meant that there is a 95% confidence level that the interval (3.52, 414) encloses the true value of $$\mu$$.;It is not necessary to make any assumptions because the Central Limit Theorem suggests that the sample mean of a large sample is approximately normally distributed.;;Let X = time per week a teenager spend playing computer games;Let $$\sigma^{2}$$ = Var(X);(3.52,4.14) is a 95% confidence interval;$$\begin{align}  \Rightarrow (3.52, 4.14) = \left[\overline{x} - z_{0.025} \frac{\hat{\sigma}}{\sqrt{n}}, \overline{x} + z_{0.025} \frac{\hat{\sigma}}{\sqrt{n}}\right];\\ \Rightarrow \overline{x} = \frac{1}{2} (3.52+4.14) = 3.83;\\ z_{0.025} \frac{\hat{\sigma}}{\sqrt{n}} = \frac{1}{2}(4.14-3.52) = 0.31;\\ \therefore  \frac{\hat{\sigma}}{\sqrt{n}} = 0.31/z_{0.025} = 0.31/1.960 = 0.15816;\\ z_{0.025} \frac{\hat{\sigma}}{\sqrt{n}} = (2.576)(0.15816) = 0.4074\end{align}$$;A symmetric 99% confidence interval for $$\mu$$;$$\begin{align}  = \left[\overline{x} - z_{0.005} \frac{\hat{\sigma}}{\sqrt{n}}, \overline{x} + z_{0.005} \frac{\hat{\sigma}}{\sqrt{n}}\right];\\ = [3.83-0.407, 3.83+0.407];\\ = [3.423, 4.237] = [3.42,4.24](3sf)\end{align}$$;;(i) Since $${I_1}^'$$ encloses $$I_1$$,;P(both $$I_1$$ and $${I_1}^'$$ to contain $$\mu$$);= P($$I_1$$ contains $$\mu$$) = 95%;;(ii) Since $${I_1}^'$$ encloses $$I_1$$,;P(exactly one of $$I_1$$ and $${I_1}^'$$ to contain $$\mu$$);= P($${I_1}^'$$ contains $$\mu$$) - P($$I_1$$ contains $$\mu$$);=0.99 - 0.95 = 0.04 $$\equiv$$ 4%;;(iii) P(both $$I_1$$ and $$I_2$$ to contain $$\mu$$);= P($$I_1$$ contains $$\mu$$) $$\cdot$$ P($$I_2$$ contains $$\mu$$);=(0.95)(0.95) = 0.9025 $$\equiv$$ 90.25%;;(iv) P(exactly one of $$I_1$$ and $$I_2$$ to contain $$\mu$$);= P($$I_1$$ contains $$\mu$$) $$\cdot$$ P($$I_2$$ doesn't contains $$\mu$$) + P($$I_1$$ doesn't contains $$\mu$$) $$\cdot$$ P($$I_2$$ contains $$\mu$$);= (0.95)(1-0.95)+(1-0.95)(0.95);= 0.095 $$\equiv$$ 9.5%

$$\begin{align} X = 0.4U + 0.6V;\\ \Rightarrow P(x < X < x+\delta x) ;\\ = \int^{x+\delta x}_{x} \{0.4g(t) + 0.6h(t)\} dt;\\ = \{0.4g(x) +0.6h(x)\} \delta x for small \delta x\end{align}$$;;$$\begin{align} f(x) &= \lim_{\delta x \to \infty} \frac{P(x < X < x+\delta x) }{\delta x}&\\ ;&=  \lim_{\delta x \to \infty} \frac{\{0.4g(x) +0.6h(x)\} \delta x }{\delta x}&\\;&= 0.4g(x) + 0.6h(x) &\\;&= \frac{4}{10}\left[\frac{1}{6}(2x+1)\right] + \frac{6}{10}\left[\frac{1}{2}(2-x)\right] &for 0< x < 2 \\ ;&= \frac{2}{15}x + \frac{1}{15} + \frac{3}{5} - \frac{3}{10}x &\\;&=\frac{2}{3} - \frac{1}{6} x = \frac{1}{6}(4-x)\end{align}$$;;Distribution function of X, ;$$\begin{align} F(x) &= \int^{x}_{-\infty} f(t)dt &\\;&= \int^{x}_{0} (4-t)dt & for 0< x < 2\\ ;&= \frac{1}{6}\left[4t - \frac{1}{2}t^2\right]^{x}_{0}&\\;&=\frac{1}{6}\left[4x-\frac{1}{2}x^2\right] = \frac{1}{12}x(8-x)\end{align}$$;;$$\begin{align} \therefore F(X) = &0 & x < 0 \\;&\frac{1}{12}x(8-x) & 0\leq x\leq 2 \\;&1 &x > 2\end{align}$$;;$$\begin{align} E(X^2) &= \int^{\infty}_{-\infty} x^2 \cdot f(x) dx &\\;&= \int^{2}_{0} x^2 \cdot \frac{1}{6}(4-x) dx & for 0 < x < 2\\;&= \frac{1}{6} \int^{2}_{0}(4x^2-x^3)dx&\\;&= \frac{1}{6} \left[\frac{4}{3}x^3 - \frac{1}{4}x^4\right]^2_0&\\;&=\frac{1}{6}\left[\frac{4}{3}(2)^3 - \frac{1}{4}(2)^4 \right]=\frac{10}{9}&\\ \end{align}$$;;$$\begin{align} E(X^4) &= \int^{\infty}_{-\infty} x^4 \cdot f(x) dx &\\;&= \int^{2}_{0} x^4 \cdot \frac{1}{6}(4-x) dx & for 0 < x < 2\\;&= \frac{1}{6} \int^{2}_{0}(4x^4-x^5)dx&\\;&= \frac{1}{6} \left[\frac{4}{5}x^5 - \frac{1}{6}x^6\right]^2_0&\\;&=\frac{1}{6}\left[\frac{4}{5}(2)^5 - \frac{1}{6}(2)^6 \right]=\frac{112}{45}&\\ \end{align}$$;;$$\begin{align} Var(X^2) &= E(X^4) - [E(X^2)]^2\\;&=\frac{112}{45} - \left[\frac{10}{9}\right]^2 \\;&= 1.254 = 1.25(3sf)\end{align}$$

Given an equation such that ;$$\begin{align} ;\\ \frac{2x^2-\ x-19}{x^2+\ 3x+2}-\ 1 = \frac{\left(2x^2-\ x-19\right)-\ (\ x^2+\ 3x+2)}{x^2+\ 3x+2}  & ---- (1); \end{align}$$;;$$\therefore$$ To prove the relation:;$$\begin{align}  ;LHS of (1)  &= \frac{2x^2 - x - 19 -(x^2+3x+2)}{x^2+3x+2};\\ &= \frac{2x^2 - x - 19 -x^2-3x-2}{x^2+3x+2};\\ &= \frac{x^2-\ 4x-21}{x^2+\ 3x+2} ;\\ &= RHS of (1) ;\end{align}$$;;Hence, without using calculator,;$$\therefore$$ Solving the inequality:;$$\begin{align} ;\\ \frac{2x^2-\ x-19}{x^2+\ 3x+2}\ >1 ;\\ \frac{2x^2-\ x-19}{x^2+\ 3x+2}\ -1 >0 & ----(2);  \end{align}$$;;Substitute (1) into (2):;$$\begin{align};\\ \frac{x^2-\ 4x-21}{x^2+\ 3x+2}\ >0 \Rightarrow \frac{\left(\ x-7\right)(x+3)}{\left(x+1\right)(x+2)}\ >0 ;\\ \Rightarrow \left(x-7\right)\left(x+3\right)\left(x+1\right)(x+2) >\ 0; \end{align}$$;;Critical values are -3, -2 and -1 and 7;img;$$\therefore$$ Solution set of the inequality:;x<-3 or -2 < x < -1 or x > 7

a); The locus of $$\left\|z+2-3i\right\|\ =\ \sqrt{13}\ $$ is a circle centre at ( -2,3) and radius $$\surd 13$$;; img;;b);Another complex number w is such that ;$$ ww* + 2w = 3 + 4i ----(1)$$;where w* is the complex conjugate of w;$$\therefore$$ To find w in the form a +ib:;Let$$ w = a+ib ----(2)$$;;Subsitute (2) into (1):;$$\begin{align} |w|^2 + 2w = 3+4i;\\ \Rightarrow a^2 + b^2 + 2(a+ib) = 3+4i;\\ \Rightarrow a^2 + b^2 + 2a + 2ib = 3+4i \end{align}$$;;Comparing the real term:;$$a^2+b^2+2a = 3 ----(3)$$;;Comparing the imaginary term:;$$2ib = 4i \Rightarrow b=2$$;;Subsitute b = 2 into equation (3):;$$\begin{align} a^2 + 2^2 + 2a = 3 \Rightarrow a^2 + 2a +1 = 0;\\ \Rightarrow (a+1)^2 = 0 \Rightarrow a = -1 \end{align}$$;;The complex number W, in the form of $$a\ +\ ib$$, where a and b are real ; $$=\ -1\ +\ 2i$$

$$\begin{align} 4\frac{dI}{dt}=2-3I  &----(1)\end{align}$$;Given that $$l = 2$$ when $$t  = 0, ---- (2)$$;$$\therefore$$ Finding $$l$$ in terms of t, ;$$\begin{align} (1): \frac{1}{2-3l} dl = \frac{1}{4} dt &----(3)\end{align}$$;;Integrating (3):;$$\begin{align}  ;& \int{\frac{1}{2-3I}}\ dI=\ \int{\frac{1}{4}\ dt} \\;& -\ \frac{1}{3}\ \int{\frac{-3}{2-3I}dI=}\ \int{\frac{1}{4}\ dt} \\;& \Rightarrow -\frac{1}{3}ln(2-3l)+A = \frac{1}{4}t \\;& \Rightarrow ln(2-3i) = -\frac{3}{4}t + 8 \\;& \Rightarrow 2-3l = e^{-\frac{3}{4}t + 8} \\;& \Rightarrow 3l = 2 - e^{-\frac{3}{4}t + 8};\end{align}$$;$$\Rightarrow l = \frac{2}{3} - \frac{1}{3}ke^{-\frac{3}{4}t}$$, where A and B are constants of integration $$----(4) $$;;Recall (2):;(4): $$\begin{align} 2 = \frac{2}{3}-\frac{1}{3}ke^0 \Rightarrow \frac{1}{3}k = -\frac{4}{3} \Rightarrow k = -4 \end{align}$$;$$\therefore l$$ in terms of $$t$$;$$\begin{align} = \frac{2}{3} - \frac{1}{3}(-4)e^{-\frac{3}{4}t} = \frac{2}{3} + \frac{4}{3}e^{-\frac{3}{4}t} ;\\ = \frac{2}{3}\left(1+2e^{-\frac{3}{4}t}\right)\end{align}$$;;For large values of t, i.e. $$(t \rightarrow \infty$$, the current of this circuit $$(l)$$ becomes:;$$\begin{align}  e^{-\frac{3}{4}t} \rightarrow 0 \frac{2}{3}\left(1+2e^{-\frac{3}{4}t}\right) \rightarrow \frac{2}{3} \Rightarrow \end{align}$$;$$\Rightarrow$$ tends to the values $$\frac{2}{3}$$

to the y-axis of the graph of $$y^{(1)} = \frac{1}{x+2}$$ by a factor of 3;;Step 3: Add $$y^{(2)} by 2$$;$$\begin{align} y^{(2)} = 3\left(\frac{1}{x+2}\right) \rightarrow y^{(3)} = 3\left(\frac{1}{x+2}\right) + 2 \equiv 3 . f(x+2) +2;\\ \Rightarrow y^{(3)} = y^{(2)} + 2\end{align}$$;Transformation: A translation of the graph of $$y = \frac{3}{x+2}$$ by 2 units in the positive (i);$$\therefore$$ Considering the scalar product between $$\overrightarrow{OA}$$ and $$\overrightarrow{OB}$$;$$\begin{align}  \overrightarrow{OA} . \overrightarrow{OB} = \begin{pmatrix}1\\-1\\2\end{pmatrix}.\begin{pmatrix}2\\4\\1\end{pmatrix}=2-4+2=0\end{align}$$;;$$\therefore$$ $$\overrightarrow{OA}$$ and $$\overrightarrow{OB}$$ are perpendicular.;;(ii);Given that there is a point M on the line segment AB such that;AM:MB = 1:2;$$\therefore$$ Let the position vector of M be $$\overrightarrow{OM}.$$;By ratio theorem, ;$$\begin{align}  \overrightarrow{OM} = \frac{2\overrightarrow{OA}+\overrightarrow{OB}}{2+1};\\ = \frac{2\begin{pmatrix}1\\-1\\2\end{pmatrix}+\begin{pmatrix}2\\4\\1\end{pmatrix}}{3} = \frac{\begin{pmatrix}2\\-2\\4\end{pmatrix}+\begin{pmatrix}2\\4\\1\end{pmatrix}}{3};\\ = \frac{1}{3}\begin{pmatrix}4\\2\\5\end{pmatrix}\end{align}$$;$$\therefore$$ The position vector of the point M is $$\frac{1}{3}(4i+2j+5k).$$;;(iii);Another point C has a position vector -4i+2j+2k.;$$\therefore$$ Using a vector product, the exact area of triangle OAC;$$\begin{align} = \frac{1}{2}|\overrightarrow{OA} \times \overrightarrow{OC}| = \frac{1}{2}\left|\begin{pmatrix}1\\-1\\2\end{pmatrix} \times \begin{pmatrix}-4\\2\\2\end{pmatrix}\right|;\\ = \frac{1}{2}\left| \begin{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix}-1&2\\2&2\end{pmatrix}\\ -\begin{pmatrix}1&-4\\2&2\end{pmatrix}\\ \begin{pmatrix}1&-4\\-1&2\end{pmatrix}\end{pmatrix}\right| = \frac{1}{2}\left|\begin{pmatrix}6\\-10\\-2\end{pmatrix}\right|;\\ = \frac{1}{2}\sqrt{36+100+4};\\ = \sqrt{35}units^2\end{align}$$

Given that the polynomial $$P(z)$$has real coefficients. $$----(1)$$;When the equation $$P(z)=0$$, it has a root in $$re^{i\theta}$$, where r > 0 and 0 < $$\theta$$ < $$\pi$$.;;(i);$$\therefore$$ To find a second root of in terms of r and $$\theta$$:;Since the polynomial equation has only real coefficients,;$$\therefore$$ The second root of the polynomial equation is tits conjugate pair, $$re^{-i\theta}$$;;Hence, ;$$\therefore$$ To find the quadratic factor,;since $$re^{i\theta}$$ and $$re^{-i\theta}$$ are roots of the equation (1),;$$\begin{align}  \Rightarrow P(re^{i\theta}) = 0\space and \space P(re^{-i\theta}) = 0;\\ \Rightarrow (z-re^{i\theta})(z-re^{-i\theta}) = 0;\\ z^2 -zre^{-i\theta}-zre^{i\theta}+r^2 = 0 ;\\ z^2 -rz(e^{-i\theta} + e^{i\theta}) +r^2 = 0  ;\\ z^2 - rz(\cos{\theta} - \sin{\theta} + \cos{\theta} + \sin{\theta}) + r^2 = 0 ;\\ z^2 -2rz\cos{\theta} +r^2 = 0\end{align}$$;;$$\therefore$$ A quadratic factor of P(z) is $$z^2 - 2rz\cos{\theta}+r^2$$;;(ii);$$\therefore$$ A complex function is defined by $$z^6 = -64 ----(2)$$;The solutions are in the form $$re^{i\theta}$$, where r > 0 and $$-\pi < \theta \leq \pi$$;$$\therefore$$ Solving (2):;$$\begin{align} z^6 = 64e^{i(\pi+2k\pi)} ;\\ z = 64^{\frac{1}{6}}e^{i\pi(\frac{1+2k}{6})}\end{align}$$; where k = -2, -1, 0, 1, 2, 3;;$$\begin{align} When \space k = -2, \space z = 64^{\frac{1}{6}}e^{i\pi\left(\frac{1+2(-2)}{6}\right)} = 2e^{-i\frac{\pi}{2}};\\ When \space k = -1, \space z = 64^{\frac{1}{6}}e^{i\pi\left(\frac{1+2(-1)}{6}\right)} = 2e^{-i\frac{\pi}{6}};\\ When \space k = 0, \space z = 64^{\frac{1}{6}}e^{i\pi\left(\frac{1+2(0)}{6}\right)} = 2e^{i\frac{\pi}{6}};\\ When \space k = 1, \space z = 64^{\frac{1}{6}}e^{i\pi\left(\frac{1+2(1)}{6}\right)} = 2e^{i\frac{\pi}{2}};\\ When \space k = 2, \space z = 64^{\frac{1}{6}}e^{i\pi\left(\frac{1+2(2)}{6}\right)} = 2e^{i\frac{5\pi}{6}};\\ When \space k = 3, \space z = 64^{\frac{1}{6}}e^{i\pi\left(\frac{1+2(3)}{6}\right)} = 2e^{i\frac{7\pi}{6}}\end{align}$$;;$$\therefore$$ Solution of $$z^6 = -64$$ are $$2e^{\pm i\frac{\pi}{2}}, 2e^{\pm i\frac{\pi}{6}}, 2e^{\pm i\frac{5\pi}{6}}$$ ;;(iii);Hence or otherwise,;$$\therefore$$ Expressing $$z^6 - 64$$ as a product of three quadratic factors with real coefficients:;$$\begin{align} z^6 - 64 ;\\ = \left(z-2e^{i\frac{\pi}{2}}\right)\left(z-2e^{-i\frac{\pi}{2}}\right) \left(z-2e^{i\frac{5\pi}{6}}\right) \times \left(z-2e^{-i\frac{5\pi}{6}}\right)\left(z-2e^{i\frac{\pi}{6}}\right)\left(z-2e^{-i\frac{\pi}{6}}\right);\\ = \left[z^2 - 2(2)z\cos{\frac{\pi}{2}} +(2)^2\right] \times \left[z^2 - 2(2)z\cos{\frac{\pi}{6}} +(2)^2\right] \times \left[z^2 - 2(2)z\cos{\frac{5\pi}{6}} +(2)^2\right];\\ = (z+4)(z^2-2\sqrt{3z} + 4)(z^2+2\sqrt{3z}+4)\end{align}$$

(i);Using the GC; img;; $$\alpha =0.619\ $$ and $$\beta =1.512$$;;(ii); X$${}_{n+1}$$ = $$\frac{1}{3}e^{x\_n}$$ for $$n \geq 1 ----(2)$$ ;$$\therefore$$ If the sequence converges, $$x_n \rightarrow x$$ then $$x_{n+1} \rightarrow x$$;;From (2):;$$\begin{align} x_{n+1} = \frac{1}{2}e^{x} \Rightarrow x=\frac{1}{3}e^{x} \Rightarrow 3x = e^x \Rightarrow e^{x} -3x = 0 \end{align}$$;$$\therefore$$ Algebraically, the sequence must converge to the roots of equation, $$\alpha$$ and $$\beta$$;;(iii); Using the GC; img;;$$\therefore$$ The behavior of the sequence when ;$$\begin{align} x_1=0 \space and \space 1, \space x_\infty \rightarrow 0.619\Rightarrow Sequence \space converges \space to  \space \alpha;\\ x_1=2, \space x_\infty \rightarrow \infty \Rightarrow Sequence \space diverges \end{align}$$;;(iv);By considering $$x_{n+1} - x_n, ----(3)$$;$$\therefore$$ Substitute (2) into (3):;$$\begin{align} x_{n+1} - x_n = \frac{1}{3}e^x - x_n = \frac{1}{3}(e^x - 3x_n) \end{align}$$;;$$\therefore $$ if $$\alpha < x_n < \beta$$, ;$$\begin{align} e^x - 3x_n < 0;\\ x_{n+1} -x_n < 0;\\ \Rightarrow x_{n+1} < x_n \end{align}$$;;$$\therefore $$ if $$x_n < \alpha$$ or $$x_n > \beta$$, ;$$\begin{align} e^x - 3x_n > 0;\\ x_{n+1} -x_n > 0;\\ \Rightarrow x_{n+1} > x_n \end{align}$$;;(v);$$\therefore$$ The results in part (iv) relate to the behaviours determined in part(iii) as briefed below:;;When $$x_1 = 0$$ , $$0 < \alpha $$ and $$x_{n+1}> x_n$$;$$\Rightarrow$$ sequence increases;$$\therefore$$ Sequence converges to $$\alpha$$;img;;When $$x_1 = 1$$ , $$\alpha <  x_1 < \beta$$ and $$x_{n+1} < x_n$$;$$\Rightarrow$$ sequence decreases;$$\therefore$$ Sequence converges to $$\alpha$$;img;;When $$x_1 = 2 >\beta$$, x_{n+1}> x_n$$;$$\Rightarrow$$ sequence increases;$$\therefore$$ Sequence diverges;img

(i) $$\therefore$$ To show that $$3r^2 - 5r +2 = 0 ----(1)$$;$$1^{st}$$ term of geometric series = first term of the arithmetic series  = $$a$$;$$2^{nd}$$ term of geometric series = $$4^{th}$$ term of arithmetic series;;$$\begin{align} \Rightarrow ar = a + 3d \Rightarrow ar - a = 3d;\\ \Rightarrow a(r-1) = 3d \Rightarrow a = \frac{3d}{r-1} ----(2) \end{align}$$;;$$3^{rd}$$ term fo geometric series  = $$6^{th}$$ term of the arithmetic series;$$\Rightarrow ar^2 = a + 5d ----(3)$$;;Substitute (2) into (3):;$$\begin{align} \left( \frac{3d}{r-1}\right)(r^2) = \frac{3d}{r-1}+5d ;\\ (d)\left(\frac{3r^2}{r-1}\right) = (d)\left(\frac{3}{r-1}+5\right);\\ \frac{3r^2}{r-1} = \frac{3+5(r-1)}{r-1};\\ 3r^2 = 3+5r-5 \Rightarrow 3r^2 = 5r -2\end{align}$$;;$$\therefore$$ The relation is $$3r^2-5r +2 = 0$$;;(ii) ;$$\therefore$$ To show that geometric series is convergent:;Solving (1):;$$ (3r-2)(r-1)=0 $$;$$ r = \frac{2}{3} ----(4)$$  or $$r=1$$ (Rejected, since r is a ratio of a geometric series. therefore $$r\neq)1$$;$$\therefore$$ Since $$r=\frac{2}{3} < 1$$, the geometric series is convergent.;$$\therefore$$ Sum to infinity, in term of $$\alpha$$,;$$\begin{align} S_{\infty} = \frac{a}{1-r} = \frac{a}{1-\left(\frac{2}{3}\right)} = 3a \end{align}$$;;(iii);Given that S denotes the sum of the first n terms of the arithmetic series where the first term, a > 0.;For S to exceed 4a,;$$\therefore$$ Let {Z} be the set of possible values of n.;Substitute (4) into (2):;$$\begin{align} a = \frac{3d}{\left(\frac{2}{3}\right)-1} \Rightarrow 3d = \frac{2}{3}a -a \Rightarrow 3d =-\frac{1}{3}a;\\ \Rightarrow d=-\frac{1}{9}a ----(5)\end{align}$$;;Sum of the first n terms of the arithmetic series,;$$\begin{align} S = \left(\frac{n}{2}\right)[2a+(n-1)d] \end{align}$$;;Deduce, ;$$\begin{align} \{Z\} \equiv \left(\frac{n}{2}\right)[2a+(n-1)d] > 4a ;\\ \left(\frac{n}{2}\right)\left[2a+(n-1)\left(-\frac{1}{9}a\right)\right] > 4a;\\ \left(\frac{n}{2}\right)(a)\left[2+(n-1)\left(-\frac{1}{9}\right)\right] > 4a \end{align}$$;;Since $$\alpha > 0$$, therefore, ;$$\begin{align} \Rightarrow \left(\frac{n}{2}\right)\left[2+(n-1)\left(-\frac{1}{9}\right)\right] > 4;\\ \Rightarrow \left(\frac{n}{2}\right)\left(2-\frac{1}{9}n+\frac{1}{9}\right) > 4 ;\\ \Rightarrow \left(\frac{n}{2}\right)\left(2\frac{1}{9}-\frac{1}{9}n\right) - 4 > 0 ;\\ \Rightarrow \frac{19n}{18} - \frac{n^2}{18} - 4 > 0\end{align}$$;;From GC, roots of the equation:;The critical values are n = 5.227 or n =13.77;Since n is an integer,;$$\therefore$$ The set of possible values for n for which S exeeds 4a is $$\{n \in \mathbb{Z}^{+}, 6 \leq n \leq 13\}$$

For $$0 \leq t \leq \frac{1}{2}\pi$$, a curve is defined by a pair of parametric equations:;$$ x = \cos^{2}{t} ----(1)$$;$$ y = \sin^{3}{t} ----(2)$$;(i);Sketch;img;;(ii);With respect to the origin O, the trangent to the curve at $$(cos^{2}{\theta}, \sin^{2}{\theta}) $$ meets the x- and y-axes at Q and R respectively. It is given that $$0 < \theta < \frac{1}{2}\pi$$;;$$\therefore$$ To deduce the area of triangle OQR:;Differentiating (1) wrt x, ;$$\begin{align} \frac{dx}{dt} = 2(\cos{t})(-\sin{t}) = -2\sin{t}\cos{t} \end{align}$$;Differentiating (2) wrt x,;$$\begin{align} \frac{dy}{dt} = 3(\sin^{2}{t})(\cos{t}) = 3\sin^{2}{t}\cos{t} \end{align}$$;;$$\begin{align} \frac{dy}{dx} = \frac{dy}{dt} / \frac{dx}{dt} = \frac{3\sin^{2}{t}\cos{t}}{-2\sin{t}\cos{t}} = -\frac{3}{2}\sin{t}\end{align}$$;;At the point $$(\cos^{2}{\theta}, \sin^{3}{\theta})$$, t  = $$\theta \Rightarrow \frac{dy}{dx} = -\frac{3}{2}\sin{\theta}$$;;Equation of the tangent at $$(\cos^{2}{\theta}, \sin^{3}{\theta})$$:;$$\begin{align} y_1-y_2 = m(x_1-x_2);\\ y-\sin^{3}{\theta} = - \frac{3}{2}\sin{\theta}(x-\cos^{2}{\theta});\\ y=-\frac{3}{2}\sin{\theta}(x-\cos^{2}\theta)+\sin^{3}{\theta}\end{align}$$;;At x = 0, $$\begin{align} y = \frac{3}{2}\sin{\theta}\cos^{2}{\theta} +\sin^{3}{\theta} \end{align}$$;At y = 0, $$\begin{align} -\frac{3}{2}\sin{\theta}(x-\cos^{2}\theta)+\sin^{3}{\theta} = 0 \end{align}$$;;$$\begin{align} -\frac{3}{2} x \sin{\theta} + \frac{3}{2}\sin{\theta}\cos^{2}{\theta} + \sin^{3}{\theta} = 0;\\ \frac{3}{2}x\sin{\theta} = \frac{3}{2}\sin{\theta}\cos^{2}{\theta}+\sin^{3}{\theta} ;\\ x = \cos^{2}{\theta} + \frac{2}{3}\sin^{2}{\theta}\end{align}$$;;$$\therefore$$ The area of triangle OQR:;$$\begin{align} = \frac{1}{2}\left(\cos^{2}{\theta} + \frac{2}{3}\sin^2{\theta}\right)\left(\frac{3}{2}\sin{\theta}\cos^{2}{\theta}+\sin^{3}{\theta}\right) ;\\ = \frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{3}{2}\sin{\theta}\cos^{4}{\theta} + \cos^{2}{\theta}\sin^{3}\theta+\cos^{2}{\theta}\sin^{3}{\theta}+\frac{2}{3}\sin^{5}{\theta}\right);\\ = \frac{3}{4}\sin{\theta}\cos^{4}{\theta} + \cos^{2}{\theta}\sin^{3}{\theta}+\frac{1}{3}\sin^{5}{\theta};\\ = \frac{1}{12}\sin{\theta}(9\cos^{4}{\theta} + 12\cos^{2}{\theta}\sin^{2}{\theta}+4\sin^{4}{\theta});\\ = \frac{1}{12}\sin{\theta}(3\cos^{2}{\theta} + 2\sin^{2}{\theta})^2\end{align}$$;;(iii);For $$0 \leq t \leq \frac{1}{2}\pi$$,;$$\therefore$$ To show that the area under the curve is $$2\int^{\frac{1}{2}\pi}_{0} \cos{t}\sin^{4}{t} \space dt$$;;Considering (1):;When x = 0, $$\cos{t} = 0 \Rightarrow t = \frac{\pi}{2}$$;When x = 1, $$\cos{t} = 1 \Rightarrow t = 0$$;;Differentiating (1) wrt t:;$$\begin{align} \frac{dx}{dt} = 2\cos{t}(-\sin{t});\\ \Rightarrow dx = 2\cos{t}(-\sin{t}) \space dt  ----(3)\end{align}$$;;Area under curve  = $$\int^{1}_{0} y \space dx ----(4)$$;Substitute (3) into (4):;$$\therefore$$ The area under curve;$$\begin{align} = \int^{0}_{-\frac{\pi}{2}} (\sin^{3}{t}[2\cos{t}(-\sin{t}) \space dt] ;\\ = 2 \int^{\frac{1}{2}\pi}_{0} \cos{t}\sin^{4}{t} \space dt ----(5)\end{align}$$;$$\therefore$$ Using the substitution $$\sin{t} = u ----(6)$$;;Differentiating (5) wrt u:;$$\begin{align} \cos{t}\frac{dt}{du} = 1 \Rightarrow dt = \frac{du}{\cos{t}} ----(7) \end{align}$$;;At $$t = 0, u = \sin{(0)} = 0$$;At $$t=\frac{1}{2}\pi, u = \sin{(\frac{1}{2}\pi)} = 1 $$;;Substitute (7) into (5):;$$\therefore$$ Area under curve;$$\begin{align} = 2\int^{\frac{\pi}{2}}_{0} \cos{t}\sin^{4}{t} \space dt;\\ = 2 \int^{1}_{0} (\cos{t})(u^4)\left(\frac{du}{\cos{t}}\right) ;\\ = 2 \int^{1}_{0} u^4 \space du ;\\ = 2\left[\frac{u^5}{5}\right]^{1}_{0};\\ = 2\left(\frac{1}{5}\right) - 0 ;\\ = \frac{2}{5} \space units^{2}\end{align}$$

$$\therefore$$ Let $$T_L$$ be the total amount paid by Lee Lian. ;Let P, M and L represent price per kilogram of pineapples, mangoes and lychees respectively;;1.15P + 0.60M + 0.55L = 8.28;1.20P + 0.45M + 0.30L = 6.84;2015P + 0.90M  + 0.65L = 13.05;;$$\begin{align} \begin{pmatrix}1.15&0.60&0.55\\1.20&0.45&0.30\\2.15&0.90&0.65\end{pmatrix}\begin{pmatrix}P\\M\\L\end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix}8.28\\6.84\\13.05\end{pmatrix} ;\\ \begin{pmatrix}P\\M\\L\end{pmatrix}  = \begin{pmatrix}1.15&0.60&0.55\\1.20&0.45&0.30\\2.15&0.90&0.65\end{pmatrix}^{-1}\begin{pmatrix}8.28\\6.84\\13.05\end{pmatrix} ;\\ = \begin{pmatrix}3.50\\2.60\\4.90\end{pmatrix} \space (From \space GC) \end{align}$$;;$$\therefore$$ The total amount that person Lee Lian paid for the fruits, ;$$T_L$$ ;= 1.30P + 0.25M + 0.50L;= 1.30(3.50) + 0.25(2.60) + 0.50(4.90);= $7.65

(i) ;Let $$P_n$$ be $$u_n = \frac{1}{n^2}$$ where $$ n \in \mathbb{Z}^{+}$$;When n = 1, ;$$P_1 = U_1$$;LHS of $$P_1 = 1$$;RHS OF $$P_1 = \frac{1}{1^2} = 1 =$$ LHS of $$P_1$$;$$\therefore P_1$$ is true.;;Assume $$P_k$$ is true for some $$k \in \mathbb{Z}^{+}, k \leq n$$: $$u_k=\frac{1}{k^2}$$;When n=k+1,;RHS of $$\begin{align} P_{k+1} = \frac{1}{(k+1)^2}  \end{align}$$;LHS of $$\begin{align} u_{k+1} = u_{k} - \frac{2k+1}{k^2(k+1)^2} \end{align}$$;$$\begin{align} =\frac{1}{k^2} - \frac{2k+1}{k^2(k+1)^2} = \frac{(k+1)^2 - (2k+1)}{k^2(k+1)^2} ;\\ = \frac{k^2 + 2k +1 -2k -1}{k^2(k+1)^2} = \frac{k^2}{k^2(k+1)^2};\\ = \frac{1}{(k+1)^2} = RHS \space of \space P_{k+1}\end{align}$$;;$$\therefore P_{k+1}$$ is true when $$P_k$$ is true.;$$\therefore$$ By mathematical induction, $$P_n$$ is true for all $$ n\in \mathbb{Z}^{+}$$;;(ii) ;$$\begin{align} \sum^{N}_{n=1} \frac{2n+1}{n^2(n+1)^2};\\ = \sum^{N}_{n=1} (u_n - u_{n+1});\\  = u_1 - u_2 + u_2 - u_3 +...+u_{N-1} - u_N + u_N - U_{N+1};\\ = u_1-u_{N+1} \space (Method \space of \space differences) ;\\ = 1- \frac{1}{(N+1)^2}\end{align}$$;;(iii);$$\therefore$$ The reason that the series in [art(ii) is convergent is as ;$$\begin{align} N \rightarrow +\infty, \frac{1}{(N+1)^2} \rightarrow 0;\\ \Rightarrow \sum^{\infty}_{n=1} \frac{2n+1}{n^2(n+1)^2} = 1 - \frac{1}{(\infty+1)^2} = 1 - 0 = 1 \end{align}$$;$$\therefore$$ The series is convergent;$$\therefore$$ The sum to infinity is 1.;;(iv) Using the answer from part (ii);$$\begin{align} \sum^{N}_{n=1} \frac{2n+1}{n^2(n+1)^2} ;\\ = \sum^{N-1}_{n=1} \frac{2(n+1)+1}{(n+1)^2(n+1+1)^2} \space (replace \space n \space with \space n+1);\\ = \sum^{N-1}_{n=1} \frac{2n+1}{n^2(n+1)^2};\\ = 1-\frac{1}{N^2}\end{align}$$

(i);The function is defined by $$y = (1+x)^n ----(1)$$;$$\therefore$$ To find its Maclaurin's series, (1) is differentiated successively wrt x:;$$\begin{align} \frac{dy}{dx} = n(1+x)^{n=1};\\ \frac{d^{2}y}{dx^{2}} = n(n-1)(1+x)^{n-2};\\ \frac{d^{3}y}{dx^{3}} = n(n-1)(n-2)(1+x)^{n-3}\end{align}$$;;When x = 0,;$$\begin{align} y = 1;\\ \frac{dy}{dx} = n;\\ \frac{d^{2}y}{dx^{2}} = n(n-1);\\ \frac{d^{3}y}{dx^{3}} = n(n-1)(n-2)\end{align}$$;;$$ \therefore $$ The Maclaurin's series for (1+x)^n, up to and including x^3:;$$\begin{align} y\approx 1+ nx + \frac{n(n-1)}{2!}x^2+\frac{n(n-1)(n-2)}{3!}x^3 \end{align}$$;;(ii);$$ \therefore $$ Expansion of $$ (4-x)^{\frac{3}{2}(1+2x^2)^{\frac{3}{2}} }$$ up to and including $$x^3$$;$$\begin{align} = 4^{\frac{3}{2}}\left(1-\frac{x}{4}\right)^{\frac{3}{2}}(1+2x^2)^{\frac{3}{2}};\\ \approx 8\left[1+\left(\frac{3}{2}\left(-\frac{x}{4}\right)\right)+\frac{\left(\frac{3}{2}\right)\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)}{2!}\left(-\frac{x}{4}\right)^2+\frac{\left(\frac{3}{2}\right)\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)\left(-\frac{1}{2}\right)}{3!}\left(-\frac{x}{4}^3\right)\right]\left[1+3x^2\right];\\ = 3\left(1-\frac{3x}{8}+\frac{3x^2}{128}+\frac{x^3}{1024}\right)\left(1+3x^2\right);\\ = \left(8-3x+\frac{3x^2}{16}+\frac{x^3}{128}\right)\left(1+3x^2\right);\\ \approx 8 - 3x +\left(\frac{3}{16}+24\right)x^2 + \left(\frac{1}{128}-9\right)x^3;\\ = 8 - 3x + \frac{387}{16}x^2-\frac{1153}{128}x^3\end{align}$$;;(iii);$$\therefore$$ For expansion in part (ii) to be valid, $$\left|\frac{x}{4}\right| < 1$$ and $$\left|2x^2\right| < 1$$.;$$\begin{align} \left|\frac{x}{4}\right| < 1 \Rightarrow -4 < x <4;\\;\\ \left|2x^2\right| < 1 \Rightarrow 2x^2 - 1 < 0;\\ x^2-\frac{1}{2} < 0 \Rightarrow \left(x-\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}\right)\left(x+\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}\right)<0;\\ \Rightarrow -\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2} < x < \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}\end{align}$$;;$$\therefore$$ The set of values of $$x = \left\{x \in \mathbb{R}: -\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2} < x < \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}\right\}$$

(i) ;$$\therefore$$ The exact value of $$\int^{\frac{2}{3}\pi}_{0} \sin^{2}{x} \space dx$$;$$\begin{align} = \int^{\frac{2}{3}\pi}_{0} \frac{1-\cos{2x}}{2} \space dx \space (Use \space \cos{2x} = 1-2\sin^{2} x);\\ = \left[\frac{x}{2} - \frac{\sin{2x}}{4}\right]^{\frac{2}{3}\pi}_{0};\\ = \frac{5\pi}{6} - \frac{\sin{\frac{10\pi}{3}}}{4};\\ = \frac{5}{6}\pi + \frac{\sqrt{3}}{8}\end{align}$$;;$$\therefore$$ The exact value of $$\int^{\frac{5}{3}\pi}_{0} \cos^{2}{x} \space dx$$;$$\begin{align} = \int^{\frac{5}{3}\pi}_{0} (1-\sin^{2}{x}) \space dx;\\ = \left[x\right]^{\frac{5}{3}\pi}_{0} - \frac{5\pi}{6} - \frac{\sqrt{3}}{8};\\ = \frac{5\pi}{3} - \frac{5\pi}{6} - \frac{\sqrt{3}}{8};\\ = \frac{5}{6}\pi - \frac{\sqrt{3}}{8}\end{align}$$;;(ii);The shaded region R is bounded by the curve $$y=x^2\sin{x}$$, the line $$x=\frac{1}{2}\pi$$ and the part of the x-axis between 0  and $$\frac{1}{2}\pi$$ as shown.;img;;a);$$\therefore$$ The exact area of R;$$\begin{align} = \int^{\frac{1}{2}\pi}_{0} x^2\sin{x} \space dx;\\ = \left[(-\cos{x})x^2\right]^{\frac{1}{2}\pi}_{0} - \int^{\frac{1}{2}\pi}_{0}(-\cos{x})(2x) \space dx;\\ = 0 + \left[(\sin{x})(2x)\right]^{\frac{1}{2}\pi}_{0} - \int^{\frac{1}{2}\pi}_{0} 2\sin{x}\space dx;\\ = \pi + \left[2\cos{x}\right]^{\frac{1}{2}\pi}_{0} ;\\ = \pi + (0-2) ;\\ = \pi - 2 \space units^2\end{align}$$;;b) ;The bounded region R is made to rotate completely about the x-axis;$$\therefore$$ The numerical value of volume of revolution;$$\begin{align} = \int^{\frac{\pi}{2}}_{0} \pi y^2 \space dx = \int^{\frac{\pi}{2}}_{0} \pi (x^4\sin^{2}{x}) \space dx;\\ = 5.391 \space units^3 \space (from \space GC) (3dp)\end{align}$$

(i);$$\therefore$$ Real life example of a situation in which quota sampling could be used:;Quota sampling could be used by a market researcher to conduct a survey about how frequently shoppers at a particular mall visit the mall. A sample of 100 shoppers, subdivided according to age group or gender.;;Quota sampling is appropriate in this situation because it is quick and convenient to carry out, since the tasks of listing the whole population, randomly selecting the sample and following-up on non-respondents can be omitted from the process.;;Disadvantages of quota sampling:;Quota sampling is a non-random sampling method selection that is biased as those selected will be those who are most willing to cooperate.;The issue of the sample not representative of the general population leading to faulty conclusions remains a difficult problem;;(ii);$$\therefore$$ Based on the situation described in part(i), stratified sampling cannot be used because the sampling frame is not accessible

Let X represent the number of people who have gene A out of a random sample of 10 $$\Rightarrow$$ X ~ B(10,0.24);;$$\therefore$$ The probability that our of 10, at most 4 have gene A;$$\begin{align} = P(X \leq 4);\\ = P(X=0) + P(X=1) + P(X=2) + P(X=3) + P(X=4);\\ = \begin{pmatrix}10\\0\end{pmatrix}(0.24)^0(0.76)^{10} + \begin{pmatrix}10\\1\end{pmatrix}(0.24)^1(0.76)^{9} + \begin{pmatrix}10\\2\end{pmatrix}(0.24)^2(0.76)^{8} + \begin{pmatrix}10\\3\end{pmatrix}(0.24)^3(0.76)^{7} + \begin{pmatrix}10\\4\end{pmatrix}(0.24)^4(0.76)^{6};\\ = 0.06428 + 0.20301 + 0.28849 + 0.24294 + 0.13425;\\ = 0.93297;\\ = 0.933 (3dp)(or \space straight \space from \space GC)\end{align}$$;;Another random sample of 1000 from the population is taken.;Using the appropriate approximations,;(i);Let Y represent the no. of people who have gene A out of a random sample of 1000 $$\Rightarrow$$ Y ~ B(1000,0.24);Since n = 1000 is large, np = 240 > 5 and n(1-p) = 760 > 5, Y ~ N(240,182.4) approximately;$$\therefore$$ The probability that between 230 and 260, inclusive have gene A;$$\begin{align} = P(230 leq Y leq 260);\\ = P(229.5 leq Y \leq 260.5) \space (continuity \space correction);\\ = P\left(\frac{229.5-240}{\sqrt{182.4}} \leq Z \leq \frac{260.5-240}{\sqrt{182.4}}\right);\\ = P(-0.7775 \leq Z \leq 1.15179);\\ = \Phi(1.518)-[1-\Phi(0.778)];\\ = 0.9355-[1-0.7817];\\ = 0.7172 = 0.717(3dp)\end{align}$$;;(ii) ;Let u represent the number of people who have gene B out of a random sample of 1000 $$\Rightarrow$$ U ~ B(1000,.003);Since n=1000 is large and np = 3<10, U ~ Po(3) approximately;$$\therefore$$ The probability that at least 2 but fewer than 5 have gene B;$$\begin{align} = P(2 \leq U < 5);\\ = P(U=2) + P(U=3) + P(U=4);\\ = e^{-3}\left[\frac{(3)^2}{2!}+\frac{(3)^3}{3!} + \frac{(3)^4}{4!}\right];\\ = 0.616(3dp)\end{align}$$

Let X represent the time in hours taken by a student to complete a project, with population mean $$\mu$$.;$$\therefore$$ Unbiased estimate of mean, $$\mu$$;$$\begin{align} = \overline{x} = \frac{\sum x}{n} = \frac{4626}{150} = 30.84\end{align}$$;;$$\therefore$$ Unbiased estimate of population variance, $$s^2$$;$$\begin{align} =\frac{1}{150-1}\left[147691-\frac{4626^2}{150}\right];\\ = \frac{5025.16}{149} = 33.7(3sf) \end{align}$$;;$$\therefore$$ To test if the population mean time for a student to complete the project exceeds 30 hours at 5% significance level,;Test $$H_0: \mu = 30$$ against $$H_1:\mu>30$$;One-tail test at 5% significance level, $$\alpha = 0.05$$;Under $$H_0$$, since $$n=150$$ is large, by Central Limit Theorem, $$\overline{X} ~ N(30, \frac{33.7}{150})$$ approximately, where $$\overline{X}$$ is the sample means.;Perform Z-test with: $$\mu_0 = 30, s = \sqrt{33.7259}, \overline{x} = 30.84$$ and $$n=150$$.;From GC, p-value = 0.0382;Since p-value = 0.0382 < 0.05, we reject $$H_0$$ and conclude that there is sufficient evidence at the 5% significance level that the mean time for a student to complete the project exceeds 30hours.;;$$\therefore$$ No assumption is needed in order for the test to be valid because since sample size is large, by Central Limit Theorem, the sample mean is approximately normally distributed.

(i) ;Let C and T represent mass of a randomly chosen chicken and turkey respectively, in kg $$\Rightarrow \space C \sim N(2.2,0.5^2), T\sim N(10.5,2.1^2)$$;;$$\therefore$$ The probability that a randomly chosen chicken costs more than $7;$$\begin{align} = P(3C > 7);\\ = P\left(C > \frac{7}{3}\right) ;\\ = P\left(Z > \frac{\frac{7}{3} - 2.2}{0.5}\right) ;\\ = P(Z > 0.2667);\\ = 1- \Phi(0.267);\\ = 0.3947 = 0.395(3dp)\end{align}$$;;(ii) ;The probability that a randomly chosen turkey costs more than $55 ;$$\begin{align} = P(5T > 55);\\ = P\left(T > \frac{55}{5}\right) ;\\ = P\left(Z > \frac{11-10.5}{2.1}\right);\\ = P(Z > 0.2381);\\ = 1-\Phi(0.238);\\ = 0.4059\end{align}$$;;$$\therefore$$ Probability that both a random chicken costs more than $7 and random turkey costs more than $55;$$\begin{align} =  P(C > \frac{7}{3}) \times P(T > 11);\\ = 0.347 \times 0.4059;\\ = 0.1602 = 0.160 (2dp)\end{align}$$;;(iii);Let Y be the cost of 3 chickens and 5 turkeys;Y = 3C + 5T;Y~N$$\left(3(2.2) + 5(10.5), 3^2(0.5^2)+5^2(2.1^2) \right)$$;$$\Rightarrow$$ Y~N(59.1,112.5);;$$\therefore$$ The probability that the total selling price of a randomly chosen chicken and a randomly chosen turkey is more than $62;$$\begin{align} = P(Y > 62);\\ = P\left(Z > \frac{62-59.1}{\sqrt{112.5}}\right) ;\\ = P(Z > 0.2734);\\ = 1 - \Phi(0.273);\\ = 0.3924 = 0.392(2dp)\end{align}$$;;(iv) ;The reason why the answer to part (iii) is greater than the answer to part(ii) is because the condition for the total selling price of chicken and turkey exceeds $62[part(iii)] is less restrictive than the condition for the selling price of chicken is greater than $7 and at the same time, the selling price of turkey is greater than $55[part(ii)]
